PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam War from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987-88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned.
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 30 citizens) and Peter Baume (from 57 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash PBS payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McGauran) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to re-establish an end of war list for Australian service personnel.
Motion (by Senator McGauran) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Private Member's Bill before the Senate relates to an unfinished chapter in Australian history; that is the Vietnam War.
The chapter relates to the failure of the Whitlam Government to establish an End of War List on the return home of the Australian troops from Vietnam.
After every war which Australians have served in an End of War List has been drawn-up.
The Vietnam War stands as the exception.

End of War Lists are established for the purpose of recognizing individual acts of valour that were overlooked in the disruption of the war. The list itself consists of a quota of awards ranging, from a `Mention-in-Dispatches' to the highest honour of a Victoria Cross.
The purpose of the Bill is to create an End of War List for the Australian Defence Forces personnel who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973.

The Bill has the full support of the National Executive of the Returned Services League and the Vietnam Veterans Association. The RSL has written to all its branches in Australia requesting its members to sign a petition of support.
These petitions are being presented on a daily basis to the Senate.

The establishment of an End of War List has much to do with maintaining a certain spirit of Australia, a spirit born out of the Gallipoli campaign. That spirit of pride and appreciation Australians have towards service men and women in times of war.

Regardless of the horror and evil of war, Australians have always had an appreciation of, and respect for, those who fought and died wearing the Australian uniform. That is what each ANZAC Day parade symbolises.
Not to recognize individual acts of valour in the Vietnam War would be to destroy that spirit passed on through time.
Unless the decision not to establish an End of War List is reversed, the Vietnam veterans can never be on a par with veterans from past campaigns.

Nobody should doubt that, because of the decision not to establish an End of War List, there are now many unsung heroes of the Vietnam war. Two cases of young Australians who died in heroic service have been brought to my attention.
Documents released following a Freedom of Information Act request show that the three Defence Departments-the Army, Navy and Air-made two requests for the establishment of an End of War List.

The first request was made in 1972 to the Minister for Defence in the McMahon Government, Mr David Fairbairn and was rejected upon the grounds that hostilities were continuing in Vietnam and Australian troops were still in South East Asia.
It should be noted that the future establishment of such a list was not ruled out by Mr Fairbairn.
The second request was made some nine months later when all of the Australian troops were home.
However, the Whitlam Government's Minister for Defence, Mr Lance Barnard, rejected the request on the grounds that it would be seen to be celebrating the war.
That decision distinctly lacked an understanding of the Australian people and their history.

Nobody at the time of Gallipoli or since could claim the campaign to be an event to celebrate. Indeed, Gallipoli was both a wartime and political disaster. Yet, what we do recognize and remember from that time are the individual acts of valour and those Australians who did not come home.

The real hang-over and shame of the lost Vietnam War comes from the fact that Parliament has been unwilling to accept this age-old tradition, for the single reason of fearing the revitalisation of the war debate. We have had to live with that mistake ever since, as we have had to live with defeat in the Vietnam War.

I am reminded of one story told to me by a veteran. He said that, while his attitude was against Australians being called up to fight, he believed that once in the battle zone, every soldier was duty bound to fight with every ounce of strength for those fellow Australians alongside him. If there was one weak link in the fighting chain, all his mates would be in danger.
That was the atmosphere and reality of the war zone in Vietnam regardless of the opinions and demonstrations at home.
It is to that spirit which those who served in Vietnam were so true.

It was not until the 1987 Coming Home Parade, organized by the Vietnam veterans themselves some 14 years after the soldiers left the battlefields of South East Asia, that the first step towards breaching the gap between the veterans and the Australian society was taken.

It was a very moving event for those who watched the thousands of Australian men and women march. The marchers had been given no victory, no glory and not even any pride in having done their duty until that day.

One could not help but believe Australia, on that day, had begun to heal the bitter divisions of the war, that the spirit of all that had made the Australian character so unique in the world had returned-that unique spirit of unconquerable determination of Australians against adversity.
Certainly, that spirit of mateship was present that day, when stories of bravery and loss were told.
If the Coming Home Parade was the first step taken, the second step must be the approval of an End of War List.

Many will say that time has passed and it is best to let such a controversial war be forgotten. `Besides', they will ask, `how could any investigation after so long reveal adequately the events of that war?'

To that I would reply that, in this Senate just before last Christmas, the War Crimes Amendment Bill was passed. That Bill sought justice some 50 years after World War II. The justice that was sought there was to seek out war criminals. The justice I seek is to seek our war heroes.
In my speech on the Bill I said:

As we fast approach a new century, the year 2001, we are being asked to look back to a time that for many was a time in history books, old film footage and, indeed, museums, and I am one such person who was not even born when the atrocities occurred in the Second World War. So it is significant for me to add that my generation has never been asked to go to war. We have been privileged with an era that has not challenged our beliefs to a point where we must take up arms and defend them in war. I rise to speak for that very reason. What my generation owes to past generations is due to the will and suffering of past generations of Australians and Europeans. My generation can say that they live in a free Australia. I believe that the past era should not be forgotten. A time should not be placed on justice, nor should there be a time to forget the dead. That is what every Shrine of Remembrance in this country asks of us-`Lest We Forget' the fallen soldier and civilian.
I hold the same belief in seeking the establishment of an End of War List.
I will now turn to individual aspects of the Bill.
The Bill would establish an End of War List Tribunal.
The Tribunal is to consist of 3 members from each of the three arms of the Australian Defence Force: the Navy; Army and Air Force.
The three members would be appointed by the Minister for Defence.

The function of the Tribunal is to prepare a list of Australian service personnel who served in the Vietnam War, being persons who did not receive awards for valour in respect of the relevant military conflict but who should, in the opinion of the Tribunal, receive awards.
The Tribunal is also to recommend to the Minister the level of the awards that the Tribunal believes should be granted.

In keeping with the spirit of the original request by the defence force a quota of 30 awards can be recommended, although the Bill empowers the Minister to expand the list beyond the initial total of 30 awards.
The Tribunal, in making its recommendations, is not to have regard to whether or not the rigid monthly quota of awards used by the defence forces during war time was filled.

The Bill also establishes the principle that such a tribunal would be established for future military conflicts. This aspect of the Bill would ensure that political considerations could never again prevent the creation of End of War Lists.

In conclusion, at a time that we are commemorating World War II 50 years since it began and are preparing to commemorate Gallipoli 75 years since, let now be the time to put aside the arguments for and against the Vietnam war.
Let now be the time to turn to the question of finally bringing our troops home.
The answer will finally depend upon this Parliament. I seek the support of the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT ACT 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, pursuant to section 2 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act 1989, the Senate approves proposed new sections 3f, 3g, and 3h of the Health Insurance Act 1973 as contained in section 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act 1989.

The motion before the Senate will allow for the proclamation of section 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act 1989, which provides for the vocational registration of general practitioners and related measures. When this matter was last before the Senate for debate, it was decided by the Senate that the legislation would be passed but that proclamation of it would be deferred until such time as the issues were considered by a Senate select committee. A Senate committee has now met. It has taken evidence, heard witnesses, considered the issues, and reported. The Government has responded to that report. It is noteworthy that the Government's response was tabled in this chamber last Thursday. The Senate committee is to be commended in that the members who served on it-the Chairperson, Senator Rosemary Crowley from South Australia, Senator Peter Baume from New South Wales, Senator John Coulter from South Australia, Senator John Faulkner from New South Wales, Senator Robert McMullan from the Australian Capital Territory and Senator Glenister Sheil from Queensland-brought down a unanimous report.

I do not propose today to go back over the entire history of this legislation, which has been the subject of substantial debate within both the Parliament and the medical profession. It has also been the subject of some misunderstandings, misinformation and, it can be said, malevolent intent by those who are opposed to it. Honourable senators will recall that section 10 of the legislation gives effect to an historic agreement between the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP). The agreement, which has now been endorsed by the unanimous findings of the Senate Select Committee, provides the basis for an improvement in both the quality and the cost effectiveness of primary medical care in Australia.

The package agreed with the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners involves the establishment of a vocational register for general practitioners (GPs) who have appropriate training or experience and who agree to take part in quality assurance and continual medical education programs accredited by the college. Those who enrol on the register will be entitled to use a new set of content-based descriptors which will have higher Medicare fees and benefits. The standard time tiering items for GP consultations will remain in the schedule so that no-one will be disadvantaged or worse off.

The Government has responded in detail to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee, as I have said. That response was tabled last week and has been available for scrutiny by all interested parties. I will refer later to a number of issues in relation to the Government's response which have been raised by representations to us and by representations from across the chamber. Before I do that I would like to make some general comments about the Select Committee and its recommendations. First, I would like to congratulate the Committee on the way it went about its task and on the comprehensive nature of its inquiries. Given the relatively short time in which it had to report, the complex and contentious subject matter it had to investigate and the large number of submissions it had to consider, it is a credit to the Committee that it was able to produce a unanimous report which has gained widespread support outside the Parliament. It is a reflection of the skill and dedication all members of the Committee brought to their task and they have every reason to be satisfied with the outcome of their efforts and to be congratulated on that by this chamber. It is a shining example of the strength of the committee system in the Senate. Therefore the Senate is bound to take due consideration of the report.

The Committee consulted widely and heard evidence from a range of individuals and organisations. Some supported the proposals and some were opposed to them. In the end the Committee reached the agreement that I have referred to, endorsed the essential elements of the package and produced a unanimous report which should provide a basis for cross-party support in this chamber. The Government has responded quickly and positively to all of the recommendations of the Select Committee. The Government's detailed response accepts all the Committee's recommendations and sets out the draft regu-lations required to establish the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee and the Vocational Registration Appeals Committee in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners also endorsed the Select Committee's report and agreed with its recommendations. Both the Government and the college have written to the Australian Medical Association (AMA), formally inviting the Association to participate in the implementation process and to accept full membership on the Standing Review Group on General Practice as recommended by the Committee. The AMA has responded positively to that, recognising the need for involvement as recommended by the Committee. A meeting between the college, the AMA and the Department of Community Services and Health has already been held and another meeting is scheduled to take place in Sydney tomorrow.

Given that there is now widespread support within the medical profession for the Committee recommendations, there is no reason for the Senate to further delay the proclamation of this legislation. The President of the Australian Medical Association, Dr Bryce Phillips, has advised the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) that he has spoken to the Opposition spokesman on health and to the Australian Democrats' representative on the Select Committee. I am informed that he has advised them that, subject to minor amendments to the draft regulations, to which I will refer later, the AMA does not oppose the legislation and believes that it should receive the endorsement of the Senate today.

With the major medical associations, in the form of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the Australian Medical Association, both supporting the legislation, it is somewhat disappointing that the Opposition has chosen to continue its negative, stalling campaign, to seek further delay and to frustrate this legislation. While it might be disappointing, I should observe that it is hardly surprising. The Opposition has, for many years, been out of step with mainstream thinking on health policy, and its continued opposition to an important initiative which will improve the quality and cost effectiveness of primary health care services is testimony of its irrelevance to the broader health debate in this country.

One could perhaps understand the Opposition's attitude to the legislation if the findings of the Senate Select Committee had not been unanimous, if its recommendations had not been acceptable to the medical profession or if the Government had not agreed to implement the recommendations in full; but none of these things happened. The findings were unanimous, the recommendations were accepted by the profession and the Government has not only agreed to implement the recommendations but also already commenced the process by drafting the necessary regulations and inviting the AMA to join the Standing Review Group on General Practice.

What, then, is the basis of the stand taken by the Opposition on this issue? Its continued rejection of a unanimous Senate Select Committee report can have little to do with the merits of the issue or the logic of the arguments. This issue has been rigorously examined by the Select Committee and overwhelmingly endorsed. It would seem that the logical position would be to accept what has been recommended and allow the doctors and patients of Australia to share the benefits of the new arrangements.

If there is one thing that can be said about the Opposition's attitude to health policy, it is that logic has no place in it. After 61/2 years on the Opposition benches, five different health spokesmen and at least as many attempts to formulate a coherent health poli-cy, the Opposition is still without anything constructive to contribute to the health debate in this country. The Opposition fails to understand that 70 per cent of Australians support Medicare-that is, seven out of 10 Australians now support our national health insurance arrangements. Yet, despite that overwhelming level of endorsement, the Opposition wants to dismantle Medicare. Exactly what it will replace it with is still unclear, as the latest version of the Opposition's health policy is still to appear.

We well remember the last disastrous attempt to cobble together a health policy just before the election in 1987. Even the usual allies of the Opposition could find few redeeming features in that effort and both the policy and the spokesman-I think it was Senator Michael Baume-have been consigned to obscurity since. I have no doubt that when it does appear, the Opposition's health policy will pander to the usual vested interests like private hospitals and health funds and promote an American-type market system which will inevitably lead to higher overall costs and a lower coverage of services.

TALK.START.PARA: —As they do in America.
—The honourable senator is right, as they do in America-a marketplace where the costs for ordinary health services are astronomical and beyond the reach of a large section of the American community.

SPEECH.PARA: With that background, it is hardly surprising that the Opposition, out of blind ideology, continues its attempt to obfuscate and delay this legislation. Without anything positive to contribute, it continues to rely on being negative and obstructionist. In most cases that does not really matter because most informed people regard the Opposition as completely irrelevant in the context of health policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —And most others.

—I said `most informed people', and that includes most others. In this case the Opposition is denying greater financial rewards to general practitioners and, more importantly, higher quality care to patients. The more sensible approach-that adopted by both the Australian Democrats and the Australian Medical Association-is to negotiate with the Government on the issues which are still regarded as unsatisfactory. The fact that the Opposition has chosen not to adopt this approach is a clear indication that it has reduced this issue to nothing more than a cynical political exercise. The fact that it has rejected the unanimous findings of the Senate Select Committee, which included representatives of both the Liberal and National parties, can only be interpreted as complete indifference to both the financial well-being of general practitioners and the physical well-being of their patients.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to note that Senator Coulter, who has now joined us in the chamber, has adopted a constructive approach to the Government's response by seeking clarification and further commitments on those issues which still cause him some concern. He has raised three issues to which I would now like to refer. The Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, has already written to Senator Coulter about these matters but I raise them formally today to advise other honourable senators of the commitments and to ensure that they are properly on the public record.

The first point relates to those doctors providing high quality primary care services but who are not general practitioners. It is the Government's intention to put into place mechanisms which will raise the standard of all primary care services. Recognition of the attainment and maintenance of agreed indications of this standard will be by way of registration. It must be recognised that the specialist primary care groups do not wish to be identified as GPs, nor do they want the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners to represent their interests or set their standards. In its report the Committee acknowledged that a small group of medical practitioners-those in special areas of general practice clearly outside the definition of general practice, for whom no parallel arrangement is made and those who are not involved in recognised vocational training-would not be eligible for the vocational register. Therefore, the Select Committee recommended in paragraph 3.14 that discussions be initiated between the Department, the Royal Australian College and those bodies representing primary care practitioners whose special interests excluded them from the definition of general practice.

The Committee suggested that parallel arrangements for these groups be implemented to ensure that they satisfied adequate standards of vocational training, quality assurance and continued medical education. This process has already commenced with discussions between the Department and people representing family planning, sports medicine and muscular skeletal medicine. Negotiation with each of these groups is continuing. Provided they can meet adequate standards of vocational training, continuing medical education and quality assurance, they will be given equal treatment in relation to the Medicare benefits schedule; that is, they will be recognised in their special area of expertise and they will be eligible for fees and benefits equal to those available to vocationally registered GPs. I make it quite clear to honourable senators that this Government has no wish to exclude any group from a system which provides financial incentives to obtain appropriate vocational qualifications and to maintain high quality of services through involvement in quality assurance and continuing medical education programs.

The second point raised by Senator Coulter relates to evaluation. As a scientific man, Senator Coulter is rightly concerned that proper mechanisms be put in place to evaluate the outcome of the new arrangements. I confirm that sufficient funding will be made available to ensure that adequate evaluation programs are put into place. Honourable senators who followed the Senate Select Committee hearings will be aware that Dr J. Dickinson, from the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Newcastle, gave evidence relating to the evaluation of health services. It is proposed that the Government will seek advice from Dr Dickinson on how to set up an evaluation program. This will involve the establishment of a pilot program as soon as practicable to determine how the evaluation can best be carried out.

Senator Coulter's final concern, and one which was raised by a number of people, is the availability of funding for the family medicine program. The issue of vocational training is central to the whole package. I confirm that the Government is committed to providing, and has available sufficient funding to ensure, places for all those who seek vocational training. While the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners is responsible for the accreditation of training courses, it does not necessarily mean that the family medicine program should be the only form of vocational training available. Approaches have already been made by two State governments for funding of vocational training courses for GPs. Should either of these receive accreditation from the college, the Government would need to consider the question of financial support.

Clearly, if doctors were to choose these options in preference to family medicine training, the financial requirements of the family medicine program would be reduced accordingly. It is hoped that over time other forms of vocational training for general practitioners would become available and would be accredited by the college. This will provide some level of choice for those doctors who for a variety of reasons do not wish to use the family medicine program as a vehicle for vocational training.

The President of the Australian Medical Association has also raised with the Government two matters which relate to the draft regulations. The first issue relates to the membership of the proposed vocational registration eligibility and appeals committees. The AMA's preferred position is that the membership consist of two nominees of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, two nominees of the AMA and one person appointed by the Minister. As currently drafted, the regulations give effect to the recommended membership of the committees as expressed in paragraph 2.16 of the Select Committee's report. The Government has no difficulty in accepting the revised membership if that is the wish of the Senate. I understand that the AMA has discussed this issue with the Democrats and the Opposition and that no concerns have been raised. The Government believes that it is important to ensure that the AMA's concerns are properly taken into account and in the absence of any objections the regulations will be redrafted to reflect the revised membership for the eligibility and appeals committees.

The only other issue raised by the AMA is the ability of the eligibility committees to make decisions independent of the criteria issued by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. Regulation 7 requires that eligibility committees must have regard to the criteria published by the RACGP relating to the eligibility for registration. This requirement is necessary for two reasons. First, as noted by the Senate Select Committee on page 11 of its report, the proper role for the RACGP as the professional body responsible is the development and maintenance of appropriate standards for general practice. In the same way as any other specialist colleges set standards for their disciplines, so too should the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners set standards for general practice.

Second, there must be some consistency in the different routes to vocational registration. However, regulation 19 allows an eligibility committee to inform itself on any matters in the manner it chooses. This allows the eligibility committees to take advice and to seek opinions in addition to the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners criteria. This supplementary advice would form part of the information on which a committee makes its decision so that it is not bound absolutely by the college criteria.

The AMA has requested that these two regulations be brought together to make it clearer that the eligibility committees would have some discretion to make independent decisions. It is therefore proposed to reword regulation 7 to give effect to the AMA's requirements. The exact wording will be a matter for the Attorney-General's Department but the drafting instructions will ask that the regulation allow for each case to be judged on its merits having regard to the RACGP's eligibility criteria and such other information as the committee believes is relevant.

With these two minor changes the AMA has agreed to support the legislation and has made this known to both the Democrats and the Opposition health spokesmen. As I said earlier, there is now no reason to delay further the proclamation of this legislation. The Senate has been given a report by a Select Committee which has won a great deal of praise in the medical profession. It would be quite improper in view of that for the Senate now to reject the unanimous report. The editorial of the 1 September issue of the Medical Observer magazine states:

The committee has handled a complete and politically sensitive task with great skill. The report succinctly summarises the issues under question and gives direct and readily achievable solutions to some of the more contentious issues. While pointing out that some of the opposition to the proposals stemmed from misleading and mischievous information supplied by opponents the committee generally refrained from direct attacks on any particular groups. It is encouraging to see that there are still some corners of our parliamentary system which can address themselves to the issue at hand without getting side-tracked by the political mileage they can gain.

That is the editorial of 1 September in the Medical Observer. I, too, congratulate the Senate Select Committee and, in particular, Senator Peter Baume and Senator Sheil, for not getting sidetracked by the political mileage they can gain, as the editorial says. It is unfortunate, albeit predictable, that the Opposition does not have a majority of like minds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence this debate by saying how unhelpful it is to the Senate's discussion of complex legislation in this place for the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) to make a major statement which amounts, in effect, to a revised second reading speech dealing with very complicated matters arising from recommendations, from proposed changes to regulations, and from proposals which the Government will now advance, without extending to the Opposition the courtesy of having the opportunity to look at the details of the Minister's statement in advance. When the Minister comes in here and says that the Government proposes to make certain changes to regulations and certain alterations in Government recommendations, the very least that can be expected is the elementary courtesy that the Opposition would have been given the details which the Minister has now announced in advance of this debate commencing. I simply put on record that I believe that is typical of the way in which the Government believes that, once it has made some arrangement with the Australian Democrats, it is not necessary for similar courtesy to be extended to the Opposition or to other senators in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: That having been said by way of introduction, I want to go now to the question of why the Opposition does not find itself in a position to support the Minister's motion, which, as he rightly says, will cause clause 10 of the legislation to be brought into effect. The first thing that I want to say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, relates to the characterisation of the nature of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance. The terms of reference of the Senate Select Committee were, as honourable senators will recall, to do two things: first, to examine in the particular questions arising from clause 10 of the legislation and, secondly, to deal with questions of medical insurance, which it will be doing on an ongoing basis. The full terms of reference for part one of the Committee's inquiry were:
(a) the meaning of clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 . . .
(b) the implications of clause 10 of the Bill for the medical profession in general, general practitioners in particular, and various categories of patients;
(c) whether the Senate should approve of clause 10 of the Bill, or whether the clause should be amended, and if so, in what respects it should be amended . . .

What the Senate Committee did not do, nor was required to, was conduct a comprehensive inquiry into the question of whether or not there should be a vocational register. That seems to me to be a question which has largely escaped the Minister and which has not been addressed substantially in the debates which have taken place so far. I propose to come back at a later stage in my address to the question of the vocational register per se.

The second thing that the Minister said in his statement this morning was that this represents what he described as an historic agreement between the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP). We are used to seeing these series of historic agreements from this Labor Government. This Government is a great one for entering into so-called historic arrangements between itself and various organisations and institutions. But what it does not do, and what is never comprehended in these historic agreements, is a fundamental analysis of what is in the best interests of the health care consumer or any other consumer at the end of the day. It is always a matter of what is the cosy relationship between the Government, the regulatory authority and some professional organisation, body, instrumentality, or institution. What is never addressed in these historic agreements is what is to the ultimate benefit of the health care consumer or indeed of the consumer in terms of any of these historic agreements.

The third matter that the Minister raises this morning is that the President of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) has said to various people, `Really, subject to minor amendments we are perfectly prepared to endorse this deal'. It is after all the philosophy of force majeure that, when it is explained to an organisation of people as intelligent as the AMA that the Government and the Australian Democrats have the numbers and they are asked whether they want to be part of the deal or want to be excluded from it, they are smart enough to say, `We understand the doctrine of force majeure and under those circumstances if we are going to be lumbered with this wretched thing, which we still oppose as a matter of principle, we would rather be in it than out of it'. That is perfectly understandable.

The next question which comes easily to the Minister's lips is the old hoary chestnut that the coalition parties propose to dismantle Medicare. On this matter, in relation to what our policy will be as far as Medicare is concerned, all I can say is that the Minister's proximity to the truth is roughly equivalent to his proximity to the truth on sandmining on Fraser Island. Ministers are supposed to be wedded to the truth, but every now and again they decide that the easiest thing is occasionally to live apart. On this particular occasion the Minister has decided once again, rather than to maintain the connubial arrangements, to live apart. He lives apart from the truth on this matter, as he lives apart from the truth on a number of others.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I object to that inference being slogged across the chamber that the Minister is a liar. I do not mind at all the humour about connubial bliss, et cetera, but the deliberate implication that our Minister is anything but honourable and honest ought to be withdrawn.
—I have been listening carefully to Senator Puplick and I really do not think that his words extended as far as that.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. We come next to the question of what are the arrangements which allegedly have been entered into with Senator Coulter arising from certain agreements, presumably made between Senator Coulter and the Minister, as far as potential changes to regulations are concerned. We are told in the first instance that there will be some new arrangements entered into based upon the recommendations in paragraph 3.14 of the Senate Committee report to provide for some allegedly alternative stream of vocational registration or of accreditation. I will come back to that point in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: On the questions of evaluation and of funding I say simply this: it is significant that, when Senator Patterson asked the Minister across the chamber for some specific guarantee in terms of funding for the family medicine program, no effective guarantees were forthcoming. We are entitled to take that at face value. We welcome the assurance that has been given that the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee (VREC) mechanism will be changed so as to eliminate some of the closed shop attitude which was apparent in the original draft recommendations and that the Committee's proposal in paragraph 2.16 has been revised so that the VREC operation will encompass two members of the AMA, two members of the college and one ministerial nominee. We also welcome the assurance from the Minister that changes will be made to draft regulation 7, which will broaden the eligibility criteria beyond those established by the College, for the eligibility questions to be addressed without being narrowly confined to the definition put by only one of the relevant or interested parties.

I therefore make a final comment about the overall approach that the Minister has established this morning-namely, that as soon as the Government, the college and the AMA get together, everybody else should bow out of it. In essence, that is what the Minister is saying. He is saying that health policy is fundamentally a matter to be determined between the Government, the vested interests and the established institutions within the health care delivery service. In effect, he is saying that, once we have done the deal, once we have made the arrangements with the bodies which we have picked out to be the appropriate and favoured bodies, the Parliament, as the representative of the public interest, should simply stand back and leave it to the experts to settle this matter.

I have to tell the Minister that democrats the world over have not fought, bled and died to overthrow the divine right of kings simply in order to replace it with a divine right of experts. What actually happens in this Parliament is that from time to time we are asked to exercise our independent judgment on behalf of the people whom we represent. I do not represent the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners; I do not represent the Australian Medical Association; nor indeed do any senators on this side see themselves in that role. We see ourselves as representing the people who are consumers of health care and, if we are not satisfied that their interests are being properly accommodated, frankly, I do not give a continental what the Government or any other established institution thinks ought to be done.

I come now to the substance of a number of matters which relate to this overall debate. First, if the Government had really decided that it wanted to make significant improvements in the way in which health care services are delivered, it would not be necessary to pursue this particular road of formal amendment and new institutional structures. If it had been capable of being persuaded on the basis of evidence, as distinct from its set ideological prejudices, that it should move away from the provision of medical rebates and financing on a time-tiered basis and towards a system in which fee structures were based upon a content-based delivery of services, it would be doing much better and it would be able to do it without legislative interference and without further control of the profession.

Secondly, we are expected to take on spec the Minister's assurances about what will be in the next series of regulations. I say to the Minister that the Government got the first draft regulations wrong. The regulations as provided in draft form in the document which was tabled on 30 August did not accord entirely with the recommendations made by the Senate Committee, no matter what the Government may say in that regard. We are entitled to say, `If you are going to amend these regulations further, we are entitled to withhold our judgment until we see those draft regulations on the second occasion. Let us see whether you get them right on this occasion because you manifestly did not get them right on the first occasion'.

I remind the Senate that, when Senator Tate was in charge of the debate in this chamber on the copyright legislation, which Senator Hill and I were handling, we deferred clauses and the Minister produced changes to legislation as the debate was under way so that we could judge those not on the basis of some vague assurance given by a Minister who now is no longer in the chamber. I draw attention to the fact that there is no Minister in this chamber at the moment. That is the seriousness that the Government places on maintaining its responsibility in the Senate. Not a single Minister of the Crown is here in the Senate chamber today to take any responsibility on behalf of the Government for the conduct of this debate. That is the way in which the Senate is treated by the Government once it thinks it has the Australian Democrats locked into this matter.

The third point that I make is that the majority of general practitioners are clearly still opposed to this proposal which the Government is putting forward. If one analyses the submissions that were made to the Senate Committee, one will find that 77 per cent of the submissions made to that Committee were opposed to the establishment of the vocational register. I draw attention in particular to a letter sent to the Committee Chairman, Senator Crowley, by the deans of the medical schools of the Universities of Adelaide, Melbourne, New South Wales, Sydney and Tasmania, Monash University and Flinders University in South Australia, which says that the Senate should not approve of clause 10. That letter says in part:

There is no evidence that those who graduate from current medical courses in Australia are less competent to function effectively, efficiently and safely as general practitioners following pre-registration training than medical practitioners who would qualify immediately for vocational registration under the proposed arrangements.
The deans make a second point:

There is no doubt that women graduates who wish to work part-time will be disadvantaged by the proposed registration arrangements, if not significantly in the period up to 1995 then certainly affecting those current and future medical students who will complete internship after 1995.
They go on to say that, while they support the principle of continuing medical education:

. . . it is our firm view that the vocational registration process proposed in the above Bill, linked with different scales of remuneration and creating two classes of general practitioners on grounds that are open to objection, is an inappropriate means of achieving these ends.
I believe that is a matter that needs to be drawn to attention.

I come next to the question of the discrimination which I believe this proposal continues to imply against particular classes of medical practitioners, and female general practitioners in particular. Those key regulations, which are not to be changed, fail to give an adequate definition of the word `predominantly'. In draft regulation 5 (1), it is provided that:
A medical practitioner is eligible for registration where an Eligibility Committee certifies:
(a) that the practitioners' medical practice is predominantly general practice . . .
Draft regulation 6 provides:
The name of a medical practitioner must be removed from the Register if the Appeals Committee, having dismissed the practitioner's appeal, gives the General Manager written notice that:
(a) the committee is satisfied that the medical practitioner's medical practice is no longer predominantly general practice . . .

The RACGP has said that doctors working predominantly in private practice means that more than 50 per cent of the practitioner's time or services as claimed against Medicare is spent in practice. Thus a general practitioner doing only two sessions a week in general practice would qualify. A doctor doing three sessions a week on a salary in a family planning clinic plus two sessions in an RACGP defined general practice would qualify. A doctor doing three sessions a week in a private sports medicine or breast cancer clinic plus two sessions in an RACGP defined practice would not qualify. A doctor of many years practice going into partial retirement and doing only one session a week in general practice would not qualify.

There are numerous similar anomalies. For instance, a member of the Royal Australian College of Physicians can choose to practise simply diabetic medicine, and there is no problem as far as that college is concerned, but a member of the College of General Practitioners cannot specialise in sports medicine, children's ailments or breast cancer and qualify in the same fashion. The discrimination which is practised against women who wish to leave the practice of medicine and to re-enter it at some later stage will be manifest. A large number of people have drawn this matter to the attention of the Committee and to the attention of honourable senators. The Opposition sees this as part and parcel of the general approach which this Government takes to the provision and control of health care services in Australia-its desires at the end of the day.

One thing we can say about Dr Blewett is that he remains one of the most forthright socialists in a socialist party. He has never concealed his belief in a socialist approach to the practice and control of the medical profession. I commend Dr Blewett because he has a degree of honesty about his ideological position which is manifestly lacking in a large number of his colleagues, most of whom are making gurgling noises in the chamber at the moment. In exactly the same way as Mr Staples is now in the process of threatening the pharmacists that if they do not fall in with his line he will make sure the supermarkets take over their work, the medical profession is now being told that either it will fall into line with what the Government has as its overall desire to bring about an essentially salaried and government controlled profession or it will find itself financially excluded. It is quite clear, for example, that while the Doherty report made very cogent criticisms about the quality and nature of medical education in this country it was at pains to say that additional vocational training should not be made mandatory. Indeed, it is not made technically mandatory under this scheme; it is simply that the financial inducements are put there which have the effect of making it almost mandatory. Clearly, that is the Government's intention in this matter. Recommendation 8 (v) of the Doherty Committee states:
Mandatory vocational training and special registration of general practitioners not be introduced at the present time.
In the arguments that it uses to support that conclusion it says, in part:

The Committee sees the mandatory concept as potentially inflexible for several groups of practitioners, including specialists reverting to general practice, graduates switching from other specialist training programs and for those returning to the workforce after career interruption.
That comes back to the role of female general practitioners in particular, which I have already mentioned. The Doherty Committee continues:

It also believes that the mandatory concept would present difficulties for many graduates, for example, in hospital positions, wishing to undertake part-time general practice such as locum tenens appointments.

This does not enforce a mandatory system. It is, however, a method of getting to a mandatory system through the back door. One of the things that I think will also happen as a consequence of this is that if the vocational register is introduced the RACGP and the family medicine program will set training requirements for RMOs. This is likely to mean that certain jobs, or terms, in hospitals will be accredited as providing experience necessary for GP training, and hence vocational registration, and some hospital terms will be considered as not contributing to such training. This, in turn, could lead to some hospital terms or jobs being unstaffed, for example, in nuclear medicine, oncology or radiotherapy, as young doctors choose GP-relevant terms rather than waste their time, as they see it, on those which do not contribute to their accreditation and potential future vocational registration. This has enormous implications for hospital staffing and work force management, particularly in the light of the Doherty report, which suggests that RMOs should also rotate to community based jobs and also recommends, as I said, against compulsory vocational registration.

Add to this the possibility and threat that RMOs may leave hospitals which cannot provide good general practice-accredited terms to get relevant community based experience and the problems of staffing mount further. This is particularly important in my State of New South Wales, where the New South Wales and Sydney universities are each reverting to a six-year course from a current five-year course. This will lead to fewer resident medical officers being available to the system over the next three years.

The issue of continuing medical education would be better addressed if it were addressed in the medical schools and in a way which would allow it to work its way through the system rather than changing the rules which are currently understood by recent graduates or people who are about to graduate, who would find that the rules had been changed on them.

I have a letter which was sent to me on 5 September from the President of the Australian Medical Students Association in which the medical students make the point that they regard this as a quite unfair imposition. They deny that there is widespread support for the recommendations and for section 10 of the Act. They say that they have withheld support for the recommendations of the report because their full implications have yet to be evaluated in open discussion as the draft regulations in their final form, which is now to be amended, are not available for scrutiny; that groups affected by these regulations have not been consulted and their subsequent problems addressed; and that the RACGP specific eligibility criteria to be established have not been released for wide scrutiny by affected groups-and that now goes to the alternatives which may be introduced as a result of the Minister's announcement today. They say that until all of these matters have been addressed there should be a deferral of the final consideration of this matter.

I want to conclude, therefore, by simply reiterating the fundamental points, as I see them, of this debate. First, we do not believe that the overall outcome of the passage of section 10 will improve the quality of health care and health service deliveries for consumers. That is our fundamental point, our fundamental concern. It has nothing to do with whether a cosy deal has been struck between the college, the AMA, the Minister for Community Services and Health and the Australian Democrats; it is whether the health care consumers of Australia benefit. We believe that if that question were properly addressed we would be moving away from the time-tiered operation to an essentially content based nature of rebates for medical services.

Secondly, we have been told by the Minister that he admits that the regulations need to be changed. We say to the Minister that we believe we are entitled to see his final proposals before we give them an endorsement. Thirdly, we believe that the long term nature of the Australian medical system is being undermined by the Government in a series of control mechanisms of which this is yet another. Fourthly, the legitimate questions raised by RMOs and medical graduates and undergraduates at the moment are not being properly addressed by the Government. We say that the question of continuing medical education needs to be addressed at a different level. It needs to be addressed fundamentally, in the first instance, at the training and medical school level.

We also say that the clear indication in the Doherty report that mandatory vocational registers should not be introduced, although it is not being pursued in those terms as a result of this legislation, is being pursued by the covert method of financial inducement. That will skew the medical system and the medical educational system in a way which we find to be unacceptable and undesirable. Finally, the issues addressed by the deans of the various medical schools and covered in the Senate Committee report have not been properly addressed either in the draft regulations or in the Minister's comments this morning.

It is for those reasons, and fundamentally for the reason that the enactment of section 10 in its present form will not be to the advantage of the consumers of health care in Australia, that the Opposition will not be supporting the motion which the Minister moved this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a sense, I normally enjoy Senator Puplick's speeches. Senator Puplick is undoubtedly intelligent and eloquent. But this was not one of his good performances. He has not used his intelligence in any way because what he said was not well informed. It was illogical and contained a number of arguments which, quite frankly, are irrelevant to what we are debating this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard as quite irrelevant the claim that in some sense the Australian Democrats have done a deal with the Government. I remind Senator Puplick that this afternoon we will be debating one of his private member's Bills. No deal has been struck with the Opposition in respect of his private member's Bill relating to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, which we will support. I hope that a Government senator will not stand up and say that some sort of deal has been done between the Democrats and the Opposition, because that would be equally ridiculous. The Democrats judge these things on their merits. As the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, pointed out, I was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance. I believe that I am well informed on this issue and that, on its merits, clause 10 should be allowed to pass. I will pick up several of Senator Puplick's points later in the course of my remarks.

I remind the Senate that when this proposal for a general practitioners register and the various elements that were associated with that was first announced, undoubtedly there was a great deal of division within the ranks of the medical profession. Indeed, I received and responded to 860 letters sent to me by doctors from both sides of this debate, a slight preponderance being in favour of what was being proposed. The doctors were aware that the Senate Select Committee was being set up, so a very large number of letters that were sent in a very short time came in.

The Senate Select Committee's report was made available and the Government has responded to it. I have received 14 letters relating to the Government's response. It seems to me to be quite clear that the majority of doctors are now happy with what is happening. Of the 14 letters I received, seven were for the proposal and seven were against it. The seven against have been against it all the time. They have some concerns which I believe have all been adequately answered. I will deal with those concerns in the course of my remarks. I will read some of the remarks from the seven in favour of the proposal. Dr Brian Hassett writes:
I believe the recommendations of the Committee are a reasonable compromise and address all the major issues.
These doctors are all quite unknown to me. Dr Ian Tulloch writes:
. . . the committee should be congratulated on the thorough job it did in examining so closely the arguments on both sides.
Dr Winterton states:
I feel the Committee deserves the highest praise for the effort it put into reaching their findings.
Dr Rowe writes:
Thank you for following up your work on the Senate Select Committee on the General Practice Registration proposal by sending a report to me.
My partners and I are very impressed with the work of your committee and consider your final recommendations highly appropriate.
Dr Downs writes:

Thank you for your letter and the attachments thereto. I have read the full report of your Senate Select Committee and would like to congratulate you on the quality and sagacity of its contents. As you say, it should meet nearly all the concerns expressed.
Dr Peter Schattner comments:
I am writing now to say how satisfied I am with the committee's findings . . .

Similarly, I have received a small number of telephone calls in respect of which the level of support was also roughly evenly divided. I ask the Senate to consider the size of that response compared with the vast amount of correspondence which was received when this proposal was first announced. It is fair on the statistical evidence to say that most doctors, even those who were expressing considerable concern, are now happy with what the Committee has recommended and the Government's response to that.

When I first saw the Government's response, I was not happy with two aspects, in particular, of it. Senator Cook, in his opening remarks, mentioned those two things. There seemed to be legitimate concern in the area of an alternative pathway to registration for those doctors who were outside the strictly and narrowly defined limits of general practice but who, nonetheless, were able to satisfy equivalent standards with respect to vocational training, continuing medical education, quality assurance and evaluation. It seemed to me that while the Committee had expressed a concern that the alternative pathway be put in place, the Government's response initially was inadequate in that respect.
Dr Blewett, in responding to my letter to him expressing concern about this, said:

The first point you raise relates to those doctors providing high quality primary care services but who are not general practitioners. You are quite correct in your understanding that the Government's intention is to raise the standard of all primary care services and that recognition of the attainment and maintenance of agreed indications of this standard will be by way of registration.

That is the key: to establish that the intention of this legislation is to guarantee a higher quality of delivery of primary care, most of which is in general practice but a small amount of which falls into other areas. That is clearly recognised by the Government. I accept its assurance that that is the intention and that the vocational registration eligibility committees, the VRECs, which were described in our Committee report, will be allowed to take on board consideration of qualifications which may be different in kind but equivalent in standards to those which deal specifically with general practice as narrowly defined. Senator Puplick totally missed, or perhaps totally misunderstood, the point that these VRECs will assess alternative qualifications held by people who want to get registration.

It may be that as this process develops different item numbers will be necessary in the schedule. That is something which clearly will evolve over time, as will the precision with which the VRECs will work. It is unrealistic to expect one to describe beforehand precisely how those bodies will operate and what the standards will be. But the Government has accepted that that recognition of the delivery of what is a professional service should be left with the profession. The VRECs will be composed, as I understand it, principally of members of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and members of the Australian Medical Association. As professional people they will be fully competent to make that assessment. It seems to me that, in the additional undertakings that the Government has given, that point is adequately addressed.

The other point I raised with the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, was in relation to evaluation. I was not happy with the initial response of the Government in this area. It was one of those matters that I pursued at some length with the Committee. I was surprised and disappointed to find that there was very little evidence of any sort in relation to the assessment of the quality of delivery of medical services. We on the Committee had the experience that one paper, by Dr Borgiel in Canada, was cited by both sides in the debate as support for and against the process of registration and accreditation of general practitioners. I have some experience in medical research and have the ability to assess such papers. I found it not particularly convincing, yet it was the best that could be produced by either side.

Senator Puplick said in his speech that there was no evidence of evaluation and that that had been drawn to attention by the deans of the medical schools. It reflects rather poorly on the medical schools in this country that they have been in a position for years to assess the quality of the graduates they turn out and of the services that those graduates provide to their patients but have ignored that responsibility. It is appropriate then that there should be a clear initiative from the Government to say, `Look, we are spending literally billions of dollars in this medical area; it is appropriate that evaluation be carried out and we will initiate studies to ensure that proper evaluation is carried out'.

It was most distressing that we had no clear indication as to whether the quality of provision of primary medical care in Australia is better or worse than in other countries, whether it is improving or getting worse, or whether this or that program will lead to improvement. At least out of the process of evaluation which I believe will now be put in place will come an ability to assess this proposal and other proposals. Five or so years down the track we will be in a better position to know whether this was the right course, whether some other course would have been more appropriate, or what modifications may be desirable. In the Minister's reply to me he said:

I agree with your comment that there is a need to properly evaluate the outcome of the new arrangements and the government will ensure that sufficient funding is available to ensure adequate evaluation programs are put in place. It is intended that initially the Government will approach Dr J A Dickinson-
who gave evidence before the Committee-
from the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Newcastle for advice about how to set up an evaluation program.

The letter goes on to describe a two-tier process in which initially a pilot evaluation scheme would be put in place from which a major study could be undertaken. That is absolutely appropriate because, as I think all honourable senators will recognise, it is extremely difficult to carry out robust and reliable research in this area. We are trying to assess things which are somewhat difficult to define. I believe that that aspect has also been adequately addressed by the Government. I also expressed a concern about the funding for the family medicine program. Again, Dr Blewett gives a clear undertaking when he says:

The issue of vocational training is essential to the whole package and I can confirm that the Government has sufficient funding and is committed to providing the funds necessary to ensure places for all those who seek vocational training.

The present draft regulations and the other draft document from the college look towards the first part, as it were, of the package-the establishment of the register of those who fall strictly within general practice, as narrowly defined. It is not appropriate, as Senator Puplick seems to be arguing, to look at this stage at other groups who fall outside that but who nonetheless may be able to establish appropriate standards of quality delivery of primary care. That process will be taken on through the VRECs. The relevant part of the regulations is the establishment of appropriate VRECs and an intention by Government that, through that process, the mechanism will be broadened and able to take on board those groups, which are not large in number but which are significant in terms of justice to the people in them.

Four doctors who are still opposed to the scheme have written me a letter expressing specific concerns. I would like to pick up each of those concerns in turn and indicate how I believe they are answered in the scheme. First, they say:
Our major concerns are:
1. The two tier system of rebates will create two classes of general practitioners, and doctors not eligible for the register will have problems with employment or viable practice.

It is perfectly true that some doctors will be registered and some will not. If that is regarded as two classes, there will be two classes. However, doctors are free to determine whether or not they register. Those on the register will, in a sense, have exposed themselves to further vocational training, quality assurance programs involving continuing medical education, and so on, and it is appropriate that that be recognised. That is what the scheme is about. If other doctors choose not to do that, that is their right and the item numbers which they use will remain within the system. Senator Puplick has characterised that as using a carrot. It is a carrot but it is an appropriate carrot under the circumstances. It seems to me that that point does not carry a great deal of weight. It is a matter of how one interprets what is happening-whether one sees it as something sinister or as something desirable. I see it as desirable and it is central to the whole thrust of this legislation. The next point in the letter is as follows:

2. The legislation will discriminate against women by the unnecessary length of training and the requirement of eligibility for the register of having to be predominantly in general practice as defined by the R.A.C.G.P.

In terms of the first part of the package, it is true that the training for those who go into what is narrowly and strictly defined as general practice will have to be predominantly in general practice but, as I have already indicated, I believe that in relation to the alternative courses, qualifications and areas in which people may choose to work-specifically, family planning, sexually transmitted diseases, sports medicine and a number of others which were mentioned to the Committee-the VREC process will be able adequately to take on board consideration of the equivalence of qualification for those people, who can then be led on to registration.

That also picks up the point about the adequacy or otherwise of the length of training in particular areas. Over time, I believe, VRECs will be able very clearly to say, `Yes, this is in; this is out'. There will be evolution towards that sort of process. I reiterate that we are looking at the first part here. We may be dealing with 90 or 95 per cent of those in the delivery of primary health care, but the mechanisms which will be put in place will pick up those other doctors. Another objection is as follows:

4. Doctors working exclusively, and many of those working predominantly, in the Special Interest areas of general practice such as Family Planning, Breast Clinics, Menopause Clinics, etc. will be excluded from this register.

That will certainly be true in the first instance where we are again dealing with general practice narrowly defined. The college draft document mentions several areas which have been quite specifically excluded. Again I reiterate that through the mechanism of the VREC, the ability of VRECs to take on an investigation and the establishment of equivalence of quality of vocational training, continuing medical education and so on, those things can and will be picked up. The letter continues:

5. The legislation is restrictive. It virtually gives the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners a monopoly. The R.A.C.G.P. has to set all eligibility criteria, accredit all training and continuing medical education for general practice.

Again, for what is specifically general practice, as narrowly defined, and for those who choose to achieve registration through the college process, that is absolutely true. However, through the VRECs these alternative mechanisms are in place and will evolve to take that on board. The letter continues:

There is no guarantee in the legislation that there will be sufficient training positions available for all doctors who need them, and if training is not available, the R.A.C.G.P. will also control manpower into viable general practice.

Again, it seems to me that it is not appropriate to pick up that point by way of legislation, but clearly we will be looking closely at the implementation of this and holding the Government to the undertakings that it has given. It is a question of whether we accept what the Government has done by way of giving an undertaking in this respect. I do accept what the Government is saying in that there are adequate amounts of money available for the expansion of that program and that it will be done as it is central to the process. Accepting that, I think the argument which has been put forward by these doctors has no force. Finally, they say:
As the people who will be most disadvantaged by this legislation will be young people and women, we request the Democrats, our traditional allies, to defend us and oppose this legislation.

The Australian Democrats have certainly traditionally defended young people and women but, in response to the concerns which this letter expresses-specifically with respect to those who are now medical students, those thinking of going into medical training and women who are in that position or who have already graduated-I believe those concerns have been picked up by the Committee and addressed. In time they will come to see that their concerns do not have a great deal of weight.

There was one point that was not picked up in this letter which has been mentioned to me several times on the telephone-and it particularly relates to women doctors. Will those who have already graduated, who get onto the register now because they have been predominantly in general practice but who then drop off the register-to have a family, or for some other reason-be required to do a lengthy period of training when they seek to go back on to the register post-1995? It seems to me that, in the context of this overall package, the situation of those people with respect to registration post-1995 has been adequately addressed through the establishment of the VRECs. It will be appropriate for the VRECs to look at the background of those people and the sort of training they have already undergone and make an assessment by comparing their training with the training required for registration de novo. They will be able to say whether the training is adequate.

While Senator Puplick was disparaging in talking about the divine right of experts, I should point out that the Committee-I believe, quite rightly-expressed the view that this is appropriately a professional job. It is not a job for government. It is appropriate for the VRECs to carry out that task. The VRECs will be composed of professional people. They will be composed of the peers of those people seeking registration. Again, I believe that the concerns expressed by these women do not have a great deal of weight. I do not think that their professional peers serving on these VRECs will be discriminatory when dealing with their applications. For those reasons we believe that the points-I was going to say `arguments', but that is elevating what was said to an unnecessary high level-which Senator Puplick made are without substantial foundation. His arguments did not take on board the breadth of this proposal and take into consideration an integration of all aspects of it. It is for those reasons that the Democrats are supporting the Government, and not because we have done a deal with the Government. We have independently assessed this report and we believe it is in the best interests of the delivery of high quality primary health care in Australia-and general practice. It will take on those broader aspects about which concern has been expressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the report prepared by the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance on the vocational registration of general practitioners. I would like to join with other senators in thanking the Committee secretariat for all its efforts, particularly in the preparation of the Committee's report. Derek Abbott, the Committee secretary, Barry Jenkins, Laurie Swift and Christine McDonald have all done a tremendous job in very difficult circumstances, and they deserve great credit for their work.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first Senate select committee that I have served on and the first parliamentary committee report, of any description, with which I have been associated. I say, as the newest senator, that working with the other Committee members was an enjoyable and worthwhile experience, and the unanimous report of the Committee is a significant achievement. The Committee inquired extensively into the meaning and implications of clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989.
