Clause 10 of that Bill contains a package of proposals which will provide a better level of health care and improved health outcomes for all Australians by the creation of a vocational register for general practitioners (GPs). Such a register will mean there will be a better quality and standard of health care delivered by better-trained doctors.

The Select Committee recommended broadening the process by which a medical practitioner can obtain vocational registration through the establishment of a Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee (VREC). The Committee has also recommended the establishment of a Vocational Registration Appeals Committee (VRAC), which will hear appeals from medical practitioners who have been refused certification and other practitioners whose names have been removed from the register under the provisions of proposed new section 3g in the Bill. The establishment of VREC and VRAC is a genuine attempt to come to grips with a major problem area that was identified not only by the medical community but also by the Opposition. Enrolment on the register is voluntary. The register will be nothing more than an annotation on the existing register of medical practitioners which will indicate the eligibility of general practitioners to use new item numbers of the medical benefits schedule which are available only to vocationally registered GPs.

The Senate now faces an absurd and regrettable situation. This Select Committee was established as a result of a motion moved by Senator Puplick on behalf of the Opposition. The Committee has heard evidence from 29 individuals and organisations, and examined 225 written submissions. The Committee comprised members from the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats. Through this process it has produced a unanimous report, but what is the Opposition's response? It is its usual negative, carping and destructive approach. It will now oppose this Committee's report, I believe, only from sheer bloody-mindedness. I suppose that is not an unusual response from the Opposition. After all, it changes its industrial relations policy on a daily basis. It even changes its leadership fairly regularly. But one would think that, with a report like this-which is responsive to issues that have been raised, and issues that the Opposition itself identified as being problem areas-the Opposition would follow the leadership provided by Senator Peter Baume and Senator Sheil.

After all, it was Senator Peter Baume and Senator Sheil who sat through and participated in the work of the Committee. It was those two senators who read all the submissions, heard all the evidence and participated in drawing up the report and its recommendations. I for one place on record my appreciation of their constructive approach. Unfortunately, we have seen some sort of backroom `get square' from some members of the Opposition, which will see all that good and productive work done by Senator Baume and Senator Sheil on behalf of the Opposition go down the drain. It is very disappointing that Senator Baume and Senator Sheil have been dudded by their colleagues in this way.

The Opposition finds itself very isolated with its about-face on the issue of vocational registration for GPs. We have the remarkable situation where the Government, the college, the Australian Medical Association (AMA) and health consumers are all in agreement and support the Committee's report. Only the Opposition and a few extremist resident medical officers and medical students find themselves caught between a rock and a hard place in opposition to the Committee's unanimous report. Dr Graeme Miller, the Honorary Secretary of the RACGP, said on behalf of the college in a press release after the publication of the Committee's report:
The Committee's unanimous recommendations, with the support of all political parties-
I interpolate here: at that stage he was not aware of the backsliding of the Opposition-
will put general practice back on the road to recovery.

The Committee has acted as an expert referee and the College would be delighted if the AMA would now join with it as a partner in further improving the quality of patient care and the standards and status of general practice.
The College welcomes the Committee's recommendation that the AMA should return to the negotiating table on fees and rebates.

The AMA, whose role I criticised in the debate on the Bill previously, has also responded constructively to the Select Committee's report. Dr Bryce Phillips, the Federal President of the AMA, issued a press release on 16 August under the heading `AMA will respond positively to Senate inquiry into GP fees'. What a refreshing headline from the AMA! In that press release Dr Phillips stated that the Committee's inquiry provided the opportunity for concerned groups within the medical profession to put their views to the Government. Dr Phillips said:

The Select Committee has addressed most of these concerns in a well balanced way . . . The AMA will therefore adopt a constructive attitude to the recommendations of the Select Committee and will respond positively to proposals for its further involvement in implementing the general thrust of the report.
As I said, this is a very refreshing approach from the AMA and one that stands in stark contrast to the one we heard from the Opposition and Senator Puplick today.

The Consumers Health Forum has also welcomed the Committee's report and has publicly encouraged the college and the AMA to respond constructively to the report's recommendations. It is in this very positive atmosphere that we have the Opposition's absolutely pathetic attempt to make political capital out of this report. It really is a very cynical exercise by the Opposition. Of course, Senator Peter Baume, who is sitting over there, knows that the Opposition's approach is wrong. Senator Puplick, who is sitting in front of him, also knows that the Opposition's approach is wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is hanging his head in shame.
—Senator Reynolds is right. I suppose it is a bit embarrassing for him. All Opposition members know that they are wrong on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to those main areas of the Bill which the Opposition and some significant sections of the medical community identified as the reason for establishing the Select Committee. In each case not only have these criticisms been dealt with properly-this is not only my opinion; it is the unanimous view of the whole Committee-but also satisfactory solutions have been found to them. Concerns were expressed that only the college would be able to determine eligibility for enrolment on the vocational register of any general practitioner. In most cases, the college will still determine eligibility, but with the establishment of the VREC, primary care medical practitioners who either do not apply for registration through the college or are referred by the college to VREC will have another avenue available to obtain registration.

The Committee has also addressed the need for an appeals mechanism for those who have been refused certification or whose removal from the register is sought by the college under 3g of clause 10 by the establishment of VRAC. The Committee has properly provided an appeals mechanism for any general practitioner affected by proposed new section 3g. The AMA and the college, as well as the Australian Medical Council and the National Specialists Qualifications Advisory Committee, will be represented on the VREC and the VRAC. This is exactly what the Opposition wanted and it is exactly what the Opposition got.

I turn to another problem area-the question of the definition of general practice raised again today by Senator Puplick. Proposed new sections 3f and 3g refer to the terms `predominantly in general practice' and `general practice'. The words `predominantly in general practice' have resulted in a great deal of confusion within the profession. The Committee heard evidence that on occasions conflicting advice on the meaning of `predominantly in general practice' had been given to GPs by the college. This has now been clarified by the college, which has defined `predominantly in general practice' as meaning that `more than 50 per cent of the practitioner's time or services, as claimed against Medicare, is spent in general practice'. This has cleared the air. Again, it is what the Opposition wanted; again, it is what the Opposition got. Questions were raised about subspecialities of general practice such as women's health, sport medicine, family planning and so forth. The college indicated in its supplementary submission to the Committee that Aboriginal health clinics, women's health clinics and student health clinics, amongst others, would fall within the definition. The college said:
Practices which limit their services to a narrow range of disease states or treatment modalities would generally not meet the definition.

Specific non-recognised specialities such as sports medicine, sexual counselling, acupuncture, hypnotherapy, etc, where these constitute the predominant form of practice may not qualify. However each practice would be considered on its merits.

The Committee's three recommendations contained in paragraph 3.56 will allay any remaining fears regarding the special interest areas of general practice. Again, this was demanded by the Opposition, and it has been addressed and resolved-the Opposition got what it wanted.

Organisations representing women doctors and individual women doctors have been particularly vocal about clause 10 of the legislation. Their principal concerns are that if women doctors wish to work part time or to stop work altogether for a period to allow them to have a family, they will be disadvantaged by vocational registration. There is certainly some validity in those claims. The Committee has gone as far as it can to meet the needs of such doctors. The attitude of the Committee was that while some disadvantage will inevitably be suffered by these doctors, this should be minimised by making sure that training schemes are equally accessible to both part time workers and women returning to the medical work force after a temporary absence.

In addition, the standard set by the college for vocational registration in the transitional period prior to 1995 is not onerous. The college has accepted two sessions per week for five years as the acceptable minimum level for registrations. In setting the five-year period, it is saying that a continuity of experience gained over a longer period is more valuable than a shorter more concentrated amount of experience. For this reason it will not accept more sessions for fewer years.

I have a great deal of admiration for women who manage to combine a career with a family. I have had first-hand experience of the pressures and the expenses that this causes. However, it needs to be said that the dilemmas faced by women doctors-that is, family claims versus career claims-are no greater or smaller than those faced by other professional women or, indeed, by any working woman. Equally, whilst arguments put to the Committee about such issues as costs and availability of child-care are in my view legitimate, they are problems faced by working women with young children. They are not specifically matters for this Committee to make recommendations on in the context of vocational registration. I also say-I know Senator Crowley will approve-that I hold out the hope that men are concerned with these important issues as well.

The Committee has also considered a number of submissions put to it about problems facing rural doctors; however whilst recommending the legitimacy of a number of issues raised, the Committee felt that such matters as after hours fees and the differential between fees paid to GPs and specialists performing similar services did not fall within the terms of reference of the Committee. It recommended that these concerns be addressed urgently by the Australian Health Ministers Conference. As to the question of vocational registration the Committee came to the conclusion that rural doctors would not face any special discrimination under the proposed scheme.

More than any other aspect of this whole debate, the proposed Independent Peer Review Organisation (IPRO) has received a great deal of criticism. It is worth reinforcing the point that the IPRO draft proposal was no more than that-a draft. The independence of the proposed IPRO was never accepted by the profession. It was perceived, as the Committee heard and read on countless occasions, to be little more than a mechanism for the college or the Government-depending on who was the biggest bogy person-just to spy on general practitioners. The draft operating principles of IPRO said in paragraph 5:
The IPRO will be a statutory body, independent of government and the RACGP.
Somehow by the time we got to paragraph 26 in the IPRO draft proposal, the independence from the Government and the college seemed to have got a little lost. Paragraph 26 said:

Draft composition of the board of management will ensure that the IPRO . . . will be composed of three members nominated by the RACGP, a nominee from a separate, appropriate medical organisation chosen by the Minister in consultation with the RACGP, a nominee of the Department of Community Services and Health and a nominee of the Health Insurance Commission.

Whilst there was some cause for concern about the issue of independence-there was obviously genuine concern about the operation of random professional audits-a great deal of hysteria over the IPRO draft proposal was whipped up unnecessarily. The Committee's response was very constructive. IPRO will sink without trace although there will be a descriptor utilisation review committee, the DURC, which I think is an awful acronym. Even Senator Puplick agrees with me on that point. I knew that eventually in the Senate I would find something with which Senator Puplick and I agreed on. The DURC will be established to review the new descriptors. Senator Puplick thinks that DURCs do other things, I am sure.

The college, the Department and the AMA will all be involved in the process of finalising the proposal for descriptor utilisation review. The scuttling of IPRO and the recommendations contained in paragraph 3.105 represent, again, a positive response to the evidence provided to the Select Committee. This is precisely what the Opposition wanted; it is precisely what the Opposition got. All witnesses before the Committee accepted that the college was the appropriate body to set professional standards for general practice. The Committee was keen to see the college remove itself from the fee negotiation arena and concentrate solely on professional matters. While the AMA has previously withdrawn from the role of negotiating with the Government, the Committee identified clearly that this was the appropriate function for the AMA to undertake. The Federal President of the AMA, Dr Phillips, has accepted that the Committee proposed a major role for the AMA in dealing with all of the issues raised by the legislation and this report.

The college was also roundly criticised for inadequately consulting with the profession over the original proposals and the college accepted, to be fair, that some of those criticisms were justified. It is important to realise that the college and the Minister wrote to all GPs about the proposal but they received little feedback. Unfortunately, the atmosphere of the debate was such that little constructive discussion took place on the proposals at all. This action was carried out in good faith. The Committee accepted that consultation with the profession was inadequate and that this contributed to the raising of emotions over the question of vocational registration. This is another area where this Select Committee responded favourably to the concerns of the Opposition.

In conclusion I would like to say that the Opposition really ought to examine its conscience-if it has one-on this whole issue. We find a unanimous Select Committee report dealing positively with a whole range of criticisms made by the Opposition being rejected by the Opposition without any rational basis at all. What a monumental waste of time, resources and taxpayers' money the whole exercise has been! The Opposition ought to reflect on the reason for setting up this Select Committee and as to whether there is any point in the Select Committee, which the Opposition wanted established and which it participated in, continuing its work. Senator Peter Baume and Senator Sheil deserve a great deal better than they are receiving from the Opposition on this issue. The Parliament deserves better than the Opposition's rejection of a unanimous report of a select committee. The people of Australia deserve better. I commend the Select Committee's report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to look at the history of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. If we look at the debate that ensued when this legislation came before the Senate we will find that the Opposition was very concerned about the sloppy legislation that the Government brought to this place. I can remember the debate when we were saying, `What about an appeals mechanism? There is no appeals mechanism in the legislation before us'. If a general practitioner wanted to appeal, because he had not been put on the register, that person had no formal method of doing so. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) assured us at that time that there was no need for an appeals mechanism in the legislation and that at a later stage one would be brought up by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. Therefore, the college would have its own appeals mechanism. I think Senator Puplick said at the time that that would be like adopting the Caesar unto Caesar principle.
—It was I, actually.

—I am sorry, it was Senator Peter Baume. I knew that it was one of our better debaters in this place. Perhaps I have won just one little point with Senator Peter Baume today. The legislation suggests that two streams should be available to general practitioners who want to be put on the vocational register. One way was to go through the college-we all know what that entails-and the second was to go through an alternative stream, the guidelines of which would be given to us at a later stage through the regulations. We on this side of the House were not prepared to accept legislation whereby registration could be done through the college or through an alternative stream, which we had not seen because we had not seen the regulations that were to apply to the legislation. We had not seen the proposed guidelines; we just knew that there would be an alternative stream. We were not prepared to accept such sloppy legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: More importantly, if honourable senators look at proposed new section 3h of the Health Insurance Act, as contained in section 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Act, they will find that the Minister can do away entirely with the college and set up a preferred provider scheme. In other words, the Minister, through just making an announcement in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, could say, `I am going to set up an entirely different body, perhaps a body of bureaucrats, and it will select the doctors who will become practitioners and be entitled to a higher schedule fee than those lesser mortals that we do not like the look of'. That is what proposed new section 3h is all about. Because the Opposition and the Australian Democrats were not prepared to accept this sloppy legislation, we insisted that the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance be set up to inquire into all the problems that we had brought forward. I congratulate the Senate Select Committee on dealing very speedily with the problems. It reported to the Senate right on the dot, which is most unusual for committees in this place.

The Committee's recommendations dealt with the majority of my concerns. The Committee considered appeals and in the Government's draft regulations there is an appeals mechanism. I am not altogether happy with that because I think that appeals ought to be dealt with in the legislation. Although regulations are not the correct mechanism with which to deal with appeals, at least they are in the regulations. The Government claims that it would take too long to amend the legislation to put the appeals mechanism in the correct place, so it was accepted that the appeals mechanism would be in the regulations. Under the draft regulations, a general practitioner can appeal if he is not accepted for registration on the vocational register. He can also appeal if he is crossed off the register and does not believe that he should be.

The Committee was very keen to see an alternative stream. This is where the draft regulations have not abided by the Committee's recommendation. The Committee made it very clear that it wanted two streams: one through the college, and one through a committee. The draft regulations leave us with two streams each doing the same thing. They state that the committee must take the college's guidelines into consideration, and that is my concern. It is no use having two lots of people dancing to the same tune. I believe that is an area where the draft guidelines have let the Committee down considerably.

The Committee believes that proposed new section 3h represents a first step in the preferred provider scheme and gives the Minister far more power than he should have. It believes that this new section should be amended or taken out of the legislation as soon as possible. The Committee has said that if the Government promises publicly to take the proposed new section out of the legislation it would be willing to have the legislation proclaimed. I do not trust the Government as much as the Committee does. I believe that if the will is there, and if the Government is really prepared to take proposed new section 3h out of the legislation at the earliest opportunity, it could be done today.

I have been a member of this place for some time now and I have seen a government which has the will to do something amend legislation and get it through both Houses of the Parliament in one afternoon. Yet we are told that would be just too hard and too tricky. The Government believes that as long as it makes a public promise to amend the legislation at the earliest opportunity, we will accept it. I am not terribly keen on the legislation being proclaimed and the Government promising to amend it as soon as possible. I do not think that the regulations accommodate an alternative stream. We do not know about the negotiated position on the minor amendments that the Minister is talking about. We have nothing before us which indicates that these regulations, which are presently draft regulations, will have minor amendments made to them. We on this side have seen nothing which indicates what those minor amendments will be; yet we are asked to proclaim the legislation.

I have spoken to members of the Royal College and they agree that the regulations need amending. They have said that they will negotiate with the Government to have the regulations amended so that they will more accurately fit in with the recommendations of the Committee. It has to be realised that we are now being asked to condone those regulations because we said that unless the regulations came up to scratch we would not be seeking proclamation of the legislation.

We are not satisfied with the regulations. The Government tells us that it will have to make minor amendments and the college tells us that it is negotiating to have amendments made. That is just not good enough for the Opposition. As I said, this matter could have been brought before the chamber in a sensible, rational manner. If the Government had had the will to do so the regulations could have been amended; indeed, regulations could have been brought down that did not need amending. We could amend the legislation to delete proposed new section 3h.

Let us look at what the College wants from the students before they become, if you like, proper doctors, general practitioners. I give the example of 18-year-old students who have just left school. They face six years as a student-sometimes five years, depending on the State-two years in a hospital, two years of the family medicine program, and one year in which they do other general practice or a subspeciality such as the diploma of obstetrics. The College tells me that it is negotiating to give provisional registration on the vocational register to people who spend two years on the family medicine program. If the Government had brought forward legislation of that sort, perhaps we would not have the problem we have today.

The Opposition cannot possibly accept legislation that needs so much negotiation to take place before it is considered sensible and before it is acceptable to the College, to the students, to the Australian Medical Association and to us. We have to tidy up this legislation. The negotiations should already have taken place. We have a need for further negotiations to take place, for example, in the area of sports medicine, in the subspecialities of general practice. As the guidelines for the College stand, the people who are doing sports medicine or who are on the family planning program-that type of medicine-would not be able to join the vocational register. I am told that the general practitioners doing sports medicine are negotiating for a parallel course. They can then apply for specialist recognition. So negotiations are taking place over yet another area before this Bill is proclaimed. We are being asked to proclaim this legislation while all these negotiations are taking place. That is not the way we normally conduct the passage of legislation in this place. It is not the way that we go about tidying it up. We cannot proclaim legislation with about four or five streams of negotiations being conducted so that eventually the legislation will be efficient. It is for these reasons that the Opposition is not supporting the proclamation of clause 10 of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief, as I know there is a lot of legislation before us. The reason I am speaking at all is that I have talked to a number of people about this legislation, and I felt that it was necessary for me to explain my position. I was originally opposed to it on the basis of the damage that it might do to women, particularly, in the profession. Several women doctors have made representations to me. I think that I have been satisfied that it will not unduly harm the women in the profession, if good sense prevails. What we have to count on or hope will happen is that people will be reasonable about it. Certainly women could be disadvantaged, especially in the family planning areas, if they were not allowed back on the register after taking courses.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make a few basic observations about the medical profession. I feel that it is not serving society any more in the way that it used to. In fact, there is a crisis of confidence in the medical profession. What is needed in medical courses is less technological training and more concentration perhaps on sensitivity training, personal growth courses--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sheil will tell you what he thinks about that.

—I suppose he will. I think that women general practitioners are far better than men general practitioners because they do have sensitivity and do operate out of a sense of feeling. We need more humility and common sense. This cannot be taught in a course; it comes from experience and from a basic feeling of well-being, I suppose, in the practitioner. The growth of alternative medicine in this country is an indication that people are turning away from traditional medicine because it is simply not answering their needs. I hope that this legislation will allow people to be trained in these areas. There is no provision for that in the legislation. I suggest that some training along the lines of personal growth should have been included.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not at all critical of the technological aspects of medicine. If I went around a corner too fast on my motorbike, hit some gravel and came off, I am sure that the doctors could stitch me together. I hope they could stitch me together. They could put in silicon here and there; they could put in titanium implants. I am sure they would be technologically qualified to do so. But what about the cold I have at this moment? What can the medical profession do about my cold? It can do nothing-zilch and zero. My cold is not solely a physical manifestation; it also has emotional aspects. I think the medical profession is too limited in its view. It looks at the human being as strictly a physical organism. It has to take in other things. I am sure that the medical practitioners in this chamber would agree.

I feel that the legislation is worth while. I am not in the business of opposing Government legislation simply for the sake of opposing it-and the Australian Democrats are not in general. I will be voting for it. On balance it is good legislation. I urge the medical profession to take a good look at itself and try to take a more holistic approach to its profession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the motion moved by Senator Cook this morning relating to the vocational registration of general practitioners (GPs). I am very sorry that Senator Glen Sheil from our National Party, who was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, is not here to speak on his own account. I think all honourable senators would agree with me that we in this chamber are very saddened for the reason that Senator Sheil is not here. He lost his wife, Dr Marjorie Sheil, who was herself a general practitioner. I am sure that all extend to him their sincerest sympathy in his very sad loss.

SPEECH.PARA: Many letters and representations have been received in my office regarding the report on the vocational registration of general practitioners. There is much to commend in encouraging general practitioners to upgrade their skills and to lift the standard of medicine they practise and the quality of health care that they deliver to the Australian community. Let there be no doubt that I strongly support the principles behind that move. However, I do not and cannot support the way in which the Government is seeking to make these changes without first gaining the full support of all those who will be expected to put the new arrangements into operation. Health policy is a far too important issue and area to be used as a testing ground.

As honourable senators are no doubt aware, when this proposal was first raised it was opposed on the grounds that it was discriminatory, that it placed too much power in the hands of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP), and that not enough was known about the details which could govern its implementation. The decision to refer this matter to a Senate select committee has been vindicated by the Committee finding a number of serious defects in the legislation. In order to address these concerns the Government has now presented to the Senate the regulations to control the operations of the vocational register. But these regulations do not address those original concerns, nor do they reflect, in my opinion, the intentions of the Senate Committee. The Committee envisaged that the regulations would provide for an alternative route for GPs to be admitted to the register other than through the RACGP.
The Government, in its reaction to the Committee's report, acknowledged this. On page 10 of its formal response, it stated:

The purpose of these regulations is to establish; an alternative way for medical practitioners to become vocationally registered, other than via the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners . . .

Yet it is clear that the Government was uttering only words and nothing else. It did not mean what it said because nowhere has this intention been reflected in the regulations which provide for the establishment of vocational registration eligibility committees and a Vocational Registration Appeals Committee. Members of these committees are to be medical practitioners with training and experience in general practice selected from panels of nominees put forward by the RACGP, the Australian Medical Association, the National Specialists Qualifications Advisory Committee and the Australian Medical Council. The requirement for these members to be experienced in general practice means that these bodies could either be dominated by, or completely made up of, RACGP members. People with an interest in the future of general practice, such as medical students, doctors in training, the deans and staff of medical schools and medical practitioners from fields other than general practice, will be excluded.

The creation of a vocational register of general practitioners has more to do with imposing controls on the medical profession than increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of the delivery of overall medical services. It is an attempt to divide the medical profession and to get the members of that profession squabbling amongst themselves.

General practice is the backbone of our health care system. I am sure that Senator Crowley would agree with that. It must be treated with extreme caution or the fabric of the whole structure will simply fall apart. But, instead of acting with caution, the Government has pushed on and struck a deal which is not supported by the vast majority of general practitioners. We have to relate this to those people who go to general practitioners when they are not feeling well and are very glad to have a GP whom they know and to whom they can relate. The deal which the Government has struck is not supported by the people who will have to operate in any changed environment-the very people who will be charged with the responsibility of putting the new arrangements into operation.

The lack of extensive consultation with all parts of the medical profession and the way in which the Government's proposals place immense power over general practice in the hands of the bureaucracy and one section of the medical profession are matters with which I cannot agree. I can tell the Senate that these objections are shared by the majority of the existing members of the medical profession; indeed, even those studying for entry into that profession. I am sure that many honourable senators have received, just as I have, hundreds of letters objecting to what is being foisted onto the medical profession. Those letters spell out in detail how the Government's plans serve only to discriminate against many general practitioners, in particular, women general practitioners; rural doctors; part time general practitioners; those working in fields such as sports medicine, student health clinics and women's health clinics; and current and future medical students.

It is for reasons such as these that I believe it is essential to oppose the proposals which give the RACGP monopoly power over entry to the vocational register which could result in a system of manpower, or womanpower, control by way of a closed shop arrangement. Any attempt to apply to the largest group in the medical profession a system of registration which does not have adequate safeguards, assurances and safety valves and which gives some members of that group the ability to advantage themselves at the expense of others should be resisted.

I believe that this proposal has more to do with the regulation and control of general practitioners than with raising the standard and quality of patient care. The principle that general practitioners should be encouraged to further their education and training and be rewarded for doing so should be encouraged and supported, but these regulations do not accurately reflect the intentions of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance. I am sorry that Senator Sheil, who served on this Committee, is not here to speak about this matter. I believe that these regulations do not address the concerns of the interested parties about the discriminatory nature of the register and the monopoly power being placed in the hands of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. These are some of the reasons why the Opposition has taken the stance that it has. I certainly will be supporting the Opposition's position on this matter and not the motion moved by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to speak to the motion moved by Senator Cook, in effect, to approve of proposed new sections 3f, 3g, and 3h of the Health Insurance Act 1973, as contained in clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. Basically, these proposed new sections would introduce a vocational register for general practitioners and a two-tier system of rebate. This whole scheme is really typical of much of what is done by this Labor Government. It is a typical case of closing the door after the horse has bolted. What is entailed in the proposals put forward is prolonged training after graduation, to ensure, as far as the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) is concerned, that we have newly registered practitioners prepared for general practice.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year, the report of the Doherty Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce-a long and detailed report-outlined a number of concerns about general practice. All of us here today would admit that there is a lot to be done in terms of general practice and continuing medical education in general practice. But let me assure the Senate that this is not a discussion about continuing medical education. I believe that continuing medical education is a process that goes on for the life of a general practitioner. This legislation is about the immediate post-registration years; it is not about doing a lifelong course. I believe that continuing medical education is important. The Opposition has said over and over again in this chamber that it supports continuing medical education, but I cannot support this legislation and I will outline some of the reasons why. The Doherty Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and Medical Workforce said in its report that a number of things needed to be done, especially with respect to medical education at an undergraduate level and in the first and second years out of medical school. It recommended:

Medical schools aim to provide exposure to general practice, early in the course as well as providing at least a month's block experience in general practices or community health centres late in the course.

The Committee recommended that medical schools increase the exposure to general practice. The Committee also recommended that the Commonwealth Government should have more money for recruiting suitably qualified staff and increased opportunities for practical training for general practice in resident medical years. The Government seems to have ignored this. Senator Cook has guaranteed places in the family medicine program. But he did not guarantee today that there will be those sorts of facilities for undergraduate training. Seven deans of Australasian medical schools, who were not even interviewed by the Committee-and I commend the Committee for its effort in reporting as quickly as it did-are referred to in a letter sent to Senator Crowley. Professor Graeme Ryan said in that letter:

As Chairman of the Committee of Deans of Australasian Medical Schools, I submit to you the view of the Deans of the seven Australian Medical Schools listed below that the Senate should not approve of clause 10 of the above Bill-
that is, the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989-
on the basis that it is ill-conceived, discriminatory and inappropriate.

The Deans of the Australian Medical Schools support the principles first, that graduates entering medical practice in any discipline should have opportunities to experience an appropriate preparatory period of supervised training and, secondly, that graduates should be encouraged to maintain their knowledge and skills through participation in continuing education programs. However, it is our firm view that the vocational registration process proposed in the above Bill, linked with different scales of remuneration and creating two classes of medical practitioner on grounds that are open to objection, is an inappropriate means of achieving these ends.

The Deans recommend that the Senate Select Committee advise the Minister for Community Services and Health of the urgent need to address constructively this issue of the resource constraints currently affecting medical undergraduate programmes in the universities, including general practice placements and supervision, as identified by the Doherty Committee. Furthermore, the Deans wish to indicate the capacity and willingness of the medical schools to develop and deliver comprehensive, high quality, continuing medical education programmes, subject to the provision of appropriate additional funding.

The Doherty report recommends that measures be taken to improve general practitioner experience in undergraduate programs. The deans of seven Australasian medical schools are recommending the same thing. But we did not see the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health address that issue today.

As I have said, the coalition is supportive of continuing medical education. But this legislation is not really about continuing medical education. I will tell the Senate why a real effort at continuing medical education is not addressed. If current general practitioners who will be admitted to the vocational register under the grandfather clause had been asked or expected to upgrade their qualifications to prove that they were engaging in appropriate standards of general practice, there would have been an outcry, just as there has been an outcry from the young medical students, graduates, young women in our universities and our resident medical officers (RMOs).

Despite the protestations of the Government and the RACGP, the proposals will discriminate against women. I do not accept the arguments that the Australian Democrats have put forward that the concerns have been adequately answered. Currently, approximately 50 per cent of our young undergraduates in medicine are females. I believe that is a tremendous achievement in a profession which in the past did not attract that percentage of young women. As Senator Walters said, when young women or young men of 18 years of age are faced with the prospect of 11 years training in some States and 10 years in others before they are fully fledged and can attract the top rebate, many will be discouraged from entering the medical profession. I believe that we will see a decline in the number of young women choosing medicine as a profession. By combining a career and child bearing and rearing, many women will take much longer to complete their fellowship examinations and training. Those who have to train part-time will take a lot longer than 11 years to complete their courses. Senator Coulter says that women will be able to use the alternative route for accreditation. But we do not have the details about this alternative. I am sure that some of the young women doctors who will be facing this problem will be interested in them.

As has already been mentioned today, doctors working exclusively or predominantly in a specialist area of general practice, such as family planning, menopausal or breast clinics, may not find themselves eligible to be placed on the register. Not much comfort can be found in the draft RACGP Guidelines for the Vocational Registration of General Practitioners which take into account those people who want to direct their attention to a specialist area. The draft says:

Restriction of the practice population to a particular social or ethnic group should not take the practice outside the definition if other criteria are met. Therefore, Aboriginal health clinics, women's health clinics and student health clinics amongst others could fall within the RACGP definition.
They only `could' fall within the definition. It goes on:

Practices which limit their services, however, to a narrow range of disease states or treatment modalities, would generally not meet that definition. Specific non-recognised specialities such as sports medicine, sexual counselling, acupuncture, hypnotherapy, where these constitute the predominant form of practice, may not qualify. Practitioners will, nevertheless, be considered on their own merits.

I do not think this is satisfactory. I think we should have seen more specific guidelines for entry to the vocational register. I am sure that a number of the women and men who specialise in sports medicine would have liked to have seen more details.

I have other concerns about this legislation. Despite what the Minister says, there is no guarantee that there will be sufficient training positions available for all doctors who require them to qualify for inclusion in the vocational register. The RACGP will have, in effect, a monopoly on the accreditation of training. Also, there are still some questions that need to be answered. I was discussing with the RACGP the other day what happens to people who go off the register for reasons of, for example, child caring or caring for an aged parent. I wanted to know whether people who are eligible to be on the register will be able to go back on the register if they go back into general practice as defined. A medical friend of mine rang the RACGP yesterday to ask what would happen if she qualified under the grandfather clause, was not engaging in general practice after 1995 for a period of time and wanted to go back on to the register. She was told by a senior administrative officer of the RACGP that if she returned to work after a break after 1995 she would have to train again. I presume by that that she would have to do the Fellowship of the Royal College of General Practitioners examination or get on to the vocational register again through the other stream. She may or may not have been misinformed, but that is the level of misinformation that seems to be around. It is difficult to evaluate if, on the one hand, I get one answer and, on the other hand, a general practitioner gets another.

Senator Cook said in his speech that the Australian Medical Association (AMA) does not oppose the legislation and recommends its endorsement. After he said that, I left the chamber and spoke to the President of the AMA, because I wanted to be sure about what he was saying. He said to me that the AMA does not accept the concept of a two-tier system and believes that a number of groups will be disadvantaged. What the AMA has agreed to is cooperating if this legislation goes through. That is a very different picture from the picture that Senator Cook put before us.

We are being asked to pass legislation which, I believe, is not about continuing medical education. It does not address the recommendations of the Doherty report. It discriminates against those people currently in training, particularly women. We have not got all the details of the alternative stream. The appeals mechanisms are not in the legislation. If some of these issues had been placed in the legislation and not in regulations, we would have been able to discuss them at the committee stage in order to iron out some of the problems that we believe exist. The legislation does not really address the issue of long term continuing medical education.

If this legislation goes through, it will be because the Australian Democrats and the Independents in this place have voted with the Government. If they do, I hope that they will be able to justify their actions. The Victoria President of the Democrats failed to convince a large gathering of Monash and Melbourne University students and RMOs which had gathered outside 400 Flinders Street in Melbourne only last Tuesday that the Democrats were representing their interests. I hope they will be able to do so after today. I call on my Democrat and Independent colleagues not to support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are talking about the regulations proposed for the vocational register of general practitioners. The coalition opposes these regulations for the operation of the vocational register of general practitioners on the grounds that they simply do not reflect the intentions of a Senate select committee that unanimously set out recommendations designed to remedy some of the major defects of the original Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. It is clear that the Government has made no attempt to understand the concerns of responsible members of the medical profession as to the monopoly power that the original clause 10, and now these regulations, give to one section of the profession.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not impugn the integrity or intentions of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP). It is a fact that the problem arose in part because the RACGP found itself negotiating with the Labor Government on behalf of the medical profession, a situation that the Government considered was to its advantage at the time. For this reason the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance recommends the participation of the Australian Medical Association (AMA), and urges the establishment of both the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee and the Vocational Registration Appeals Committee, with membership drawn from not only the RACGP but also the AMA, the Australian Medical Council (AMC) and the National Specialist Qualifications Advisory Committee (NSQAC). These essential committees would obviously enjoy the input of the RACGP, but would also reflect the broader aspects of the medical profession. That sounds particularly reasonable on the surface. The RACGP has a valuable role to play as a certifying body, but this does not mean that it should enjoy what could be an effective monopoly of registrations within the government controlled health system.

In these regulations the Labor Government perpetuates its unsatisfactory legislative proposals and fails to implement the intention of the Select Committee by giving the RACGP monopoly power over entry to the vocational register. That is really what we are on about today. It is all very well to set up committees for eligibility and appeal and deficiencies in the original legislation that the coalition firmly pointed out and then negate their independent discretion by the insistence of regulation 7 that they `must have regard to the criteria published by the RACGP' regarding eligibility. That is purely and simply contradictory. So much for the supposed intention of the regulations to establish an alternative for vocational registration, other than via the RACGP.

The scope of the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee and the Vocational Registration Appeals Committee is severely narrowed by regulation 11 (1) that specifies that their committee members must be doctors with experience and training in general practice. Quite frankly, it does not take a doctor of philosophy to work out that the AMA, the AMC and the NSQAC will be severely circumscribed as to who they may nominate to serve on the committees that will govern vocational registration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why, Senator?

—If Senator Crowley does not understand that now, heaven help her. If she does not understand that now, I feel quite sorry for the whole Committee that has obviously had to suffer her. The Australian Medical Association would be confined to nominating those of its members who are also members of the RACGP, while a specialist body, such as the NSQAC, would be hard put to nominate anyone from its own ranks. The personnel of the committees will be dominated yet again by the RACGP which just further reduces their independence. That was the reason for the Opposition in the first instance referring this matter to a committee. It was believed by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats that there must be independence on this Committee. Altogether the NSQAC and the AMC, with only one eligible member between them as defined in regulation 11, will through regulations 9 and 10 be required to submit 48 nominations for the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee and a further three for the Vocational Registration Appeals Committee. The Government has, in effect, rendered the committees unworkable from the start, either through haste or design. I do not necessarily believe that that was the intention of the Select Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Once more the coalition expresses its concern that while regulation 6 (a) specifies removal from the register once a doctor is no longer in general practice, there is absolutely no mechanism for his readmission to the register. Thus doctors who leave general practice for sports medicine, and female general practitioners taking time off for child rearing, still remain at risk from later being excluded from the register. The fact remains that the guidelines issued by the RACGP largely retain their force under these regulations and responsible members of the medical profession regard them as too restrictive. It would be a great mistake at this stage for the Senate to approve a supposedly impartial mechanism for their administration that by accident or intent will exclude the participation of even the deans and staff of medical schools besides medical practitioners from fields other than general practice.

I can only return to the criticism that I made against the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill, that these regulations point to a Labor government more concerned with controlling doctors than with raising the standards of general practice. It is an exercise in double talk to claim to implement the recommendations of the Select Committee, but to effectively deny its intention to allow for vocational registration independent of the RACGP, which continues to have an inappropriate role forced upon it. It is questionable that these regulations should proceed when extensive consultation is required with those groups in the medical profession who voiced the strongest concerns as to vocational registration in accord with RACGP guidelines, namely, women doctors and resident medical officers.

Paragraph 3.62 of the Select Committee's report acknowledged the anomalies in the registration of female doctors returning to the work force after child-bearing, a problem that was strongly raised by the coalition in debate. The Government must recognise that this essential facet of the medical work force has continued concerns regarding a vocational register and consultations should not be left to an unspecified time when the legislative and regulatory machinery is already in place. The objections of resident medical officers, working outside the family medicine program, have been acknowledged in the Committee's report. More attention has to be paid to the requirements of these dedicated young men and women who form both the next generation of specialists and general practitioners, and whose current long hours are the mainstay of our overstrained public hospital system. The `conscripted foot soldiers of the Medicare system' would be the best way to describe them. Both these groups consider that the report of the Select Committee is the beginning rather than the end of the process of consultation that must now take place if a vocational register is to be established on the grounds of medical excellence and equity rather than sectional or bureaucratic convenience.

We certainly agree with paragraph 5.30 of the Select Committee's report and its reference to inadequate consultation between the RACGP and the remainder of the profession in respect of the vocational register. This was exactly what the coalition was pointing out in the last session. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, which was formed as an academic body, through the actions of this Labor Government has been thrust into a position of undue dominance over an administrative process. This Government, through these regulations, seeks to evade the spirit of the Select Committee's recommendations. The regulations do not accurately reflect the Committee's findings.

I recognise that the Committee did a lot of hard work, that it consulted and spoke to many people. There is no doubt that many members of the Committee were highly qualified to comment. My good friend and colleague Senator Peter Baume sitting beside me was a member of that Committee. He is a very highly qualified person. Nonetheless, the Government seeks to evade the recommendations of that Select Committee. The regulations are simply inadequate and contradictory and I believe they should not be passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the approval of clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill and the motion before the chamber. When the legislation was first introduced there was extensive debate in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. We have had an inquiry with some 225 submissions submitted to it. The Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance heard 27 witnesses over four days of hearings. They were not gentle, leisurely days of hearings, but very tightly scheduled, exacting days. We have canvassed the issues very thoroughly. We have had a unanimous report. We have had tabling speeches. We have had time for the parties to consider the reports. We have had a Government response with draft regulations and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners' definitions. We have had time to consider that. The issues have been thoroughly canvassed. They have been canvassed near to death by now. What more can the Opposition want? With particular capacity to nitpick, however, the Opposition found something that might do. It supported it with out-of-date, insufficient information. I am shocked at Senator Patterson. I thought she had more perspicacity. One of the points led for the Opposition by Senator Puplick was that the deans of colleges-the date was not mentioned, but I know when it was; it was in a submission to the Committee way back in July and it is out of date-were urging us not to vote for the clause. I suppose that comment could have been picked out, as could various comments by the Australian Medical Association (AMA) and a whole number of others. But on 28 August 1989, I received a letter which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Crowley,

I have read the report of the Senate Select Committee which you chaired with great interest and I look forward to the account of parliamentary debate on the report. This is a most thorough analysis of a contentious matter and I congratulate you and your colleagues. I look forward to further progress in the education of general practitioners and the development of this important area of medical practice.
Yours sincerely,
John Biggs,
Dean,
Faculty of Medicine
University of Queensland

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not one of the ones in the letter.

—His is one of a number of letters. I have been allocated a short amount of time and I will not read them all. I seek leave to table letters that I have received that I think go to the point of how the Committee was conducted and how constructive and comprehensive it was.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I draw the Senate's attention to the editorial in the Medical Observer. With respect to the Senate Select Committee, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee handled a complex and politically sensitive task with great skill. The report succinctly summarises the issues under question and gives direction and readily achievable solutions to some of the more contentious issues.

We earlier heard another quote from this editorial which highlighted the fact that the Committee resisted the temptation to put the boot in one place or another; that we produced a restrained and useful report. It states:
It is encouraging to see that there are still corners of our parliamentary system which can address themselves to the issue at hand without getting sidetracked by the political mileage they can gain.

I cite those comments to say that we should put to rest forever the comprehensiveness or otherwise of the canvassing of these issues. They have certainly been comprehensively dealt with. They have been more than thoroughly canvassed. I seek leave to have the debate continued until this matter is resolved.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Madam Acting Deputy President. There are a few points that I want to make. I think we have heard in this place today some extraordinary arguments and some quite remarkable evidence led by the Opposition by way of justifying its opposition to this. Let me make it clear that we have had an excellent inquiry and it has produced a very good report. It was a unanimous decision and the issues have been conducted and properly canvassed. We know that is the case. All sorts of people will report it. But we come in here and find the Opposition is opposing it.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose it is true that the Opposition has a right to reject a unanimous report, that Senator Puplick, on behalf of the Opposition, can properly claim the rights of the Opposition caucus to know better. He can properly claim the right of his caucus to ignore the recommendations of his colleagues Senators Peter Baume and Glen Sheil. He can claim to maintain his proper right to political and parliamentary ineptitude of such extraordinary proportions. In fact, I think Senator Puplick's performance in here today was sufficient almost to justify Senator Bishop's campaign on recent activities in New South Wales. In fact if Senator Puplick is not judged inept, then he has to stand judged as totally disregarding of parliamentary procedures and Senate committee procedures.

Why establish committees at all? What is the point of coming back here with a comprehensive, well-covered, canvassing of the issues-the report was unanimously supported-and then saying, `Yes, we ignore that'. I might say that the Australian Democrats gave us a model of why we should establish committees. The Democrats agreed to the establishment of the Committee. They were concerned about the issues not being thoroughly canvassed; they have seen them canvassed; they feel that the complaints have been addressed and dealt with. Senator Coulter and his Democrat colleagues now see the right of that case and are going to support the clause; but not so the Opposition.

What support did Senator Baume have when he reported to the Liberal Party? I would love to have been there to hear the debate. Was it that Senator Peter Baume's canvassing of the issues was so derelict in comprehensiveness, so insufficient that Opposition members have had to say that he did not do the job?

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously did not hear what was said by me about Senator Peter Baume.
—I did hear it. The honourable senator thought he was a very nice chap and that is very good. If she should say to me--
—I did not say `a very nice chap', and you know it.

—Senator Baume was part of a unanimous committee finding and the Opposition thinks that it can overrule it. Senator Puplick led a case against the finding. Senator Puplick picked out one submission that proposed a back dating to 1 July. Why did he pick that submission? Why not pick some others? He actually ran through the issues that Senator Peter Baume and others on the Committee had all dealt with. Senator Puplick should blush. It is an appalling process from him. In fact, I think Senator Puplick's performance is disgraceful. It is no longer amazing; it is pathetically predictable. He gives evidence in what he has done of what the Opposition is: a leaderless, rudderless rabble. The AMA supported the outcome, the College supports the outcome, the Government supports it and the Opposition claimed vindication. I cannot understand how the Opposition can claim vindication in that report and then change its mind. It is a stunning example of shining self-deception.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the issue? The issue is whether general practice should be acknowledged as a significant and special area of medicine worthy of recognition. The Government achieves the most far-reaching advances which have ever been achieved in general practice in this country and yet the Opposition wants to oppose them. Are Opposition members going to say to the general practitioners of this country, `We think you should all be dudded of something like $15,000 per annum increase in income.'? That is what they are saying to the doctors of this country. `Liberal Party opposes increase in doctors fees' would make a very good headline. That is what honourable senators opposite have been saying in here. That is what they are going to vote on. Let us make no mistake about it: it is not about VREC or VRAC or whether somebody can or cannot do something. It is about whether the Opposition supports general practice, whether it is supporting an increase in fees for general practitioners. Let this be on Senator Puplick's head during the election. It is a quite amazing performance. After all this canvassing of the issues he has picked up the hair splitting exercise that he has picked up to cover his opposition to adequate remuneration and an acknowledgment of general practitioners and their contribution to this country.

Senator Puplick actually said some daft nonsense about never supporting special interest groups but preferring to support the community at large. I ask him to tell me how the community at large will be advantaged by having its general practitioners set back like this. Can he tell me how that Opposition over there could come to the conclusions it did, in the face of the evidence which Senator Baume and Senator Glen Sheil gave when they reported on that Committee? I would like to ask Senator Bjelke-Petersen, although she is no longer here, how she expected Senator Sheil was going to cope. He was going to speak in this place, she said, but then he was apparently going to speak against his own recommendations and his own Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Senator Patterson can keep saying no, but it is entirely unpersuasive. Those opposite did not convince us of anything. They have gone to one small point that they might want to make about VRECs and subcommittees. Senator Walters was talking about problems with regulations. Senator Puplick spoke about problems with regulations. They are not actually for debate today. They are not at issue today; they never have been. But apparently all this is too complex for them to follow. Are they for general practice? Are they for acknowledging the improvement of health care that is being designed under this legislation, or are they against it? By their vote they are against it. `Cop it! Cop those consequences'-that is what they are saying to the general practitioners and the people of this country: `We oppose improvements in general practice the way this legislation is proposed'.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing that absolutely fascinates me is this: I am delighted to discover, when talking to the AMA, that there are now changes in the views of the AMA, let alone our understandings. But the Opposition has discovered women. Women, do you mind! This is the party that has produced a document called Back towards the past in which the place for women, if they had a place at all, is said to be totally dependent behind picket fences; they rated hardly a mention in the document. Now they are being held up by way of justification for and defence of this extraordinary posturing they have about opposing general practice.

I appreciate very much that there are enormous time constraints and I also acknowledge the cooperation of the Opposition in trying to finish this matter this morning so as to allow us to proceed to other things. I would have to say that we have the opportunity here, in voting on this legislation, to stop the nonsense, the delaying tactics, the stupid arguments and the obfuscation of the Opposition that we have seen in this matter. If ever an issue has been thoroughly canvassed, it is this one. In fact, as we now can support this legislation, we will allow the Government to get on with the business of setting in place all the procedures and processes necessary to allow general practitioners to be properly remunerated for all those things the legislation is putting in place: the importance of good quality continuing medical education and an acknowledgment of the importance of general practice. I had thought that I might have to come in here and speak more in sorrow than in anger. I then thought it might have to be more anger than sorrow. Finally, I see that we have been rescued by humour-the Opposition is just a laughing stock. We can happily support this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In replying to the debate, let me just simply say that I do not think that anything has been adduced across the chamber in evidence to deter the Government from wanting this motion carried in full. We simply cite the fact that the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, comprising representatives from the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party, was unanimous. Our response is to adopt that positively and to meet some minor detailed changes by the Australian Democrats and the Australian Medical Association. I think all that means is that between each one of us, except perhaps now the Opposition, there is heated agreement. Nothing that has been said here should deter us from proceeding to the course of putting it to the vote. I commend the motion to the Senate.
—The question is that the motion moved by the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, relating to the approval of proposed new sections 3f, 3g and 3h of the Health Insurance Act 1973 be agreed to.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, may I seek your indulgence and the Minister's indulgence. We have now concluded the debate. I understand the matter is to be put to a vote. Because of the time, I ask the Minister whether he would consider that the vote itself be delayed to a later hour of the day and that we proceed now to matters of general business, rather than actually concluding the vote at this stage now that the debate has concluded.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —I would ask for the vote to be proceeded with but, if there is an accident, Senator Puplick-that is, people are missing-I will certainly agree to a recommittal of the vote later today.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Cook's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to sessional order, the Senate will now proceed to a discussion of matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: — I take the opportunity afforded to me by this matters of public interest debate to bring to the attention of the chamber the situation that is faced by Bruny Island, one of Australia's smallest municipalities or shires. The situation of Bruny Island is typical of the situation being faced by small councils in Australia because of the Government's outdated and out-of-touch funding policy for local government. The population based guidelines for financial assistance grants are severely affecting small councils.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the honourable member for Denison in Tasmania, Mr Duncan Kerr, made a belated attempt to blame the State Grants Commission for the lack of funds, which has been widely criticised by the Municipal Association of Tasmania and small councils around Australia. In reply the Chairman of the State Grants Commission, Mr Robert Mather, quite rightly made the point that the Commonwealth Government made no changes to the allocation recommendations made by the State Grants Commission. The allocations were based largely on population which, of course, favoured the cities and large population areas to the detriment of small councils.

For those people who are not familiar with Bruny Island, I can say that it is a very beautiful island in the south-east of Tasmania. It is separated by about a kilometre from the mainland of Tasmania by the D'Entrecasteaux Channel, an area which is regarded by many as one of the most picturesque waterways in Australia and which in the early days was world renowned for the harvesting of scallops. Unfortunately, due to overfishing it does not supply scallops these days but it is still a favourite spot for the countless number of pleasure cruises that ply the area.

The only access to Bruny Island is by way of a vehicular ferry, the Harry O'May, which was brought to Tasmania during the time of the Tasman Bridge disaster. It is now being used to ferry tourists and locals backwards and forwards between Kettering and Bruny Island. The return journey costs $10. I am pleased to say that an agreement has been reached to build a new vessel to service Bruny Island. The advent of that vessel will certainly increase the number of people who are able to visit the island. It is being built in Launceston by the Launceston Shipbuilders and is expected to be commissioned in the next two years. But the problems faced by Bruny Island are exacerbated by its low permanent population. It has only 400 residents. But during the summer months the population of Bruny Island swells to around about 6,000. This places a tremendous burden on the island's roads and services. Because the population is dispersed fairly evenly throughout the island, the road network on Bruny Island comes under severe wear and tear during the summer months. I think it would be fair to say that Bruny Island relies very heavily on tourist-based industries and they are the mainstays of those people who live there.

It has also become recognised as one of the major areas of the Tasmanian aquiculture industry. Intensive fish farming, trout, salmon, mussels, oysters and scallops are all being cultivated in waters around Bruny Island and they are sent directly to gourmet food markets around the world. In 1988-89 the municipality of Bruny received $69,079 by way of general purpose financial assistance grants, but for 1989-90 it will receive $68,407. To maintain its 1988-89 funds in real terms, Bruny should receive $74,398; so in real terms it has received a cut of some $5,991 or a percentage decrease of 8.05 per cent. And that is typical of the decreases that have been suffered over the last year or two by this outdated local government policy that this Government has put in place. It is sometimes very easy for us here in Canberra to fail to appreciate the difficulties that are being faced by those smaller councils in meeting their obligations. In this case it is clearly obvious that the Federal Government's cutbacks have seriously affected the ability of Bruny Council to operate. The cut of 8 per cent amongst the permanent population of around 400 is a significant decrease.

I am aware that the Council feels that in order to attract tourism, which it sees as being important to the future of the island's economy, it must provide the necessary infrastructure services. These cannot be provided unless the Federal Government is prepared to maintain realistic funding levels. For such a small population, Bruny Island has a limited ability to raise its own funds and as an island it suffers a very similar penalty to that faced by Tasmania itself. Every item transported to the island invokes a toll on the ferry and the small and intimate freight levels prevent growth of transport services and competition. Because of the difficulties in providing infrastructure to meet the island's growth tasks and services that would be routine elsewhere, everything becomes a major logistic exercise for the Municipality of Bruny. Bruny Island itself has 220 kilometres of roads, less than half of which are sealed, and there is a general concern among the island's residents that the increasing number of accidents on the roads is directly attributable to their poor condition. This is a typical case of what is happening all over Australia.

As well as a previously mentioned cut in general purpose financial assistance grants, Bruny has also been hurt by the general decrease in the Federal Government's road funding. In 1988-89, the total amount that Bruny Island received from ABRD, and ACTP funding was something in the order of $54,100. This represents a mere $492 for each kilometre of unsealed road on the island or $246 for each kilometre of road as a total. Because of the limited road funds available to the Bruny Council it has been forced to carry out only a patch up program of up-grading and maintenance, whilst there is an urgent need to up-grade existing services to cater for an increased vehicular movement when the new ferry comes into operation in the next two years. It is expected that traffic volumes on the island will increase by 15 and 25 per cent when that happens.

For some time the Commonwealth has maintained the road on the island which provides access to the Cape Bruny lighthouse. The road runs for approximately 18 kilometres across Bruny Island. In recent times, though, it has been decided to declare the previously Commonwealth maintained road a public road and, accordingly, responsibility for the maintenance of the road will become that of the Council. I am very disappointed, Madam Acting Deputy President, that in these circumstances the Federal Government has not been prepared to transfer the road over to the Council in a satisfactory condition. This is certainly going to again place further pressure on the Council's limited resources.

As I said earlier, the problems of Bruny Island are not unique, but I believe that importantly they provide for the Senate a general overview of the real dilemma which small rural councils must deal with on a daily basis. I believe that not only for the sake of Bruny Island but also for the sake of other similarly affected councils the Federal Government has an obligation to urgently review its commitment to local government and to provide funding at a realistic real terms level which will allow for the satisfactory provision of infrastructure services where it is so clearly evident that councils do not possess the fund raising capacity themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May last year, well over a year ago now, the Liberal, Labor and National parties combined in this chamber in a vote against the introduction of the citizens initiative process in Australia. At that time we were debating the Government's four referendum proposals and on behalf of the Australian Democrats I moved that the Constitutional Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987 be voted on together with other proposals.
