Senator Puplick, for the Opposition, moved for the adjournment of the debate of my Bill at that time. The motion he moved acknowledged that the initiative process `is worthy of careful and detailed consideration by both the people and the Parliament', and that to `unreasonably pre-empt such consideration may jeopardise the right of the people to make an informed decision on the most appropriate mechanism for achieving the concept'. Ironically enough, the result of that particular motion, which incorporated those words, was in fact to kill off any further parliamentary or public debate on the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened then in the last year with regard to this? I think it is interesting that there has been a dearth of initiatives on the part of any of those parties who voted for that particular motion. In fact, the only item that has actually occurred since that stage with regard to this matter in the parliamentary forum is my introduction in April this year of two private members' Bills, that is, the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1989 and the Legislative Initiative Bill 1989, which were looking at 5 per cent and 2 1/2 per cent respectively to petition for a referendum on specific legislative proposals put forward by the people.

I am speaking in this matters of public interest debate today to illustrate my determination and that of my Party to continue to have this particular issue as part of the political agenda. At the moment we do not have coming from the Opposition or the Government any contribution to this debate. They have contributed to stalling the debate in this place, but not to the public debate outside on what may or may not be a sensible way of proceeding with this matter.

Meanwhile, there have been in the United States several important developments in the initiative process which I think warrant discussion and which again help to show that it is working successfully in that country. As honourable senators will be aware, the United States of America has enjoyed a long history of initiative and referenda. The first referendum, in fact, took place in Massachusetts in 1778 when the State legislature passed a Constitution and submitted it to the voters. South Dakota was the first State to establish an initiative process, in 1898. Unlike Switzerland, America does not have the initiative at the federal level. Nevertheless, more than 20 states in the United States now have citizens initiative law making rights guaranteed within their Constitutions.

In 1988 Americans voted on a total of 230 such propositions. Most of these were put forward by state legislatures. However, 54 propositions were put on the ballot paper by voters' initiative. Most of these issues concerned the power of state and local governments to impose new taxes, increased rates of existing taxes or the incurring of debt by government bodies. Some of the other recent proposals included a measure mandating closure of two nuclear power stations in Massachusetts and a proposal for a 25 per cent tax on cigarettes to fund medical research and authorising a weed killing program in Alabama. Despite the high electoral workload for voters, recent surveys show a very high approval rating for the initiative process. Some 73 per cent of respondents in California found the process a good thing against a meagre 7 per cent who found it a bad thing.

Unfortunately, one of the major reasons for the continuing opposition of conservatives in the Government to my Bill has been their alleged fear that citizens initiative would somehow spark unrest and divide the nation on controversial issues. I think the recent experience in the United States clearly refutes this proposition. In fact, political scientists point to the ideologically neutral outcome of the initiative process in total.

The following data come from a survey conducted by Mr Austin Ranney, Chairman of the Department of Political Science at the University of California in Berkeley, on the 1988 election results. Of some 35 proposals that could be classified on a conservative liberal spectrum in the 1988 round the result split 18 to 17, narrowly in favour of the conservatives. These proposals were initiatives of the population and the items referred to voters by state legislatures. Twenty-four of these total proposals were direct from the people via the petitioning mechanism. Of these, there was an even break-down. Twelve proposals were voted on along conservative lines, 12 on liberal lines. Surely this is proof of the type which the conservatives in the Opposition were looking for when they adjourned the debate on my legislation last year. It certainly supports my argument at that time that the initiatives process does not favour any side in politics.

Let us look at the types of questions which were put to the people. Fifty-two per cent of Arkansans voted in approval of a ban on the use of state funds for abortion-to use an issue that is alive in this Parliament at the moment. That is, they approved a ban on the use of state funds for abortion except to save the mother's life. At the same time, on the same day, 40 per cent of Colorado voters said the state should be prohibited from using public funds. In other words, 60 per cent were opposed to the item that 52 per cent of another state voted for. While 58 per cent of Maryland voters agreed to prohibit the manufacture and sale of certain hand guns, 64 per cent of Nebraskan voters supported an issue guaranteeing people's rights to keep arms. In Massachusetts an initiative to impose regulations to protect farm animals from inhumane treatment was rejected. In California an initiative to raise cigarette taxes by 25c a pack was supported.

These types of questions of public policy, I believe, should be part of the public debate. We in this country are of the belief that, unless the outcomes happen to correspond with what we believe is correct, the people should not have a say in the matter. In other words, I believe that the opposition to my proposal comes essentially from anti-democratic feeling within the community.

I have constantly challenged government and opposition spokespeople to appear in a public debate before an audience on such matters and to explain to the people precisely why politicians do not think that they should be trusted to make decisions on these matters. It would be a fascinating debate. No-one has bothered to take it up yet. Since I have been a member of this place-since 1981-I have been asking politicians to explain to people why they should not be trusted in making decisions.

The 1988 exercise was not a fluke. In a 1986 exercise Ranney found similar results. Of 26 measures that could be placed on the conservative-liberal scorecard, the conservatives won 14 while the liberals won 12. Seventeen of the 26 measures were initiatives put forward by people's petitioning and they split nine to eight in favour of the conservatives against the liberals. It is quite clear, therefore, that the evidence over time points to the fact that the initiative process does not favour one side against another. Ranney, in summing up his research on this matter, concludes that the failure of either ideology to win clear and consistent victories is `probably the result of the fact that voters are less concerned whether a particular measure is liberal or conservative, rather whether it is right or wrong'.

Surely it is time for the Government and Opposition parties to come clean with the people on this issue and state where they stand, rather than hiding behind the types of motions that we have had to date. We have gone out of our way to try to show precisely how these matters can be implemented within our particular structure. We have put forward Bills which show very clearly the mechanisms that are necessary for the operation of such a system within our democratic structure. We have argued consistently that it would enhance parliamentary activity in Australia because it would provide an avenue for citizens to involve themselves in individual political debates.

As I have mentioned previously, and I think most senators in this place would have to agree, when one attends a meeting which can determine a subject it is a far more exciting and pointed meeting than one which can only discuss a matter because it has no power to determine it. Hence, when we in this place complain about voter apathy in this country we have got it the wrong way round. If people have no power why should they be interested? However, if people have power they will be interested and take a far greater interest in each matter.

I am sorry but I cannot guarantee that the outcome of the votes will happen to agree with what one would want. In a democratic institution, surely the best we can hope for is that citizens are informed on all matters concerned with a debate, there is a period in which that debate takes place and then a democratic vote is taken. That is what is being frustrated at this time. I believe that eventually such a process will be incorporated in our democratic structures in this country. We do need further development of democracy.

In conclusion, I go back to an occurrence in my State of Queensland in 1899 when a considerable body of opinion sought to oppose Queensland going into the Commonwealth of Australia. It is interesting to note two planks of that. One is that our Federal Constitution did not guarantee universal suffrage-of course it does not-and, secondly, it did not guarantee citizens initiative, which it does not. I am a very strong believer that at some stage our Federal Constitution will have to incorporate both of those democratic ideals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring two matters concerning Aboriginal affairs to the attention of the Senate. Before I do so, I make the observation to the previous speaker, Senator Macklin, about the extraordinary support the League of Rights, an infamous organisation in Australia, gives to the proposition for citizens initiated referenda. If there are any merits for such a process within Australia I suggest it be tested at a local government level before it is imposed at either a State or Commonwealth level of citizen participation in the democratic processes of Australia. I would be interested some time to talk with Senator Macklin further on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to matters of Aboriginal affairs-my reason for rising here this afternoon. One matter involves extraordinary good news and the other matter, unfortunately, reflects very poorly on my own State of Western Australia. The good news first though, Mr Acting Deputy President: our good friends in Australian Associated Press brought this matter to my attention. It is the quite extraordinary story of the reunification of a mother who is reputed to be aged 104 with her son who is aged either 82 or 84.

It is quite extraordinary when one considers the longevity of Aboriginal people: they are not noted, because of the deprivation that Aboriginal people have suffered in this country, for living to ripe old ages. But here we have a situation in which a woman has actually become a centenarian and her son is well on the way as well. It is also quite extraordinary because when the son was only two or three years of age he was actually taken from his mother, reportedly for his own good-a sorry reflection on the thinking of Australia as a whole and a reflection on the parliamentarians and politicians of this country in years gone by. But some stories do have a happy ending and I am glad to bring this one to the attention of the Senate. I was particularly interested in it because it is nice when one is giving some bad news also to have some good news to give at the same time.

The bad news and the reflection on my own State was brought back to my mind yesterday when I attended the launching of a book at the National Library here in Canberra by the noted Australian historian, Manning Clark. The book is called Noonkanbah. It is written by Steve Hawke with photographs by Michael Gallagher. It is a chronicle of events that occurred in Australia and, indeed, centred on Western Australia in 1979-1980.

Noonkanbah stands for, I think, everything that is bad and constitutes racist hatred in this country. It is only 10 years since the events happened. It shows that some progress has been made in Australia in the area of Aboriginal affairs since that time. I doubt whether a Noonkanbah could happen now. There are many notable names mentioned in the index to the book: two senators serving in this place get mentioned quite a number of times-Senator Chaney, who was then Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and Senator Peter Cook, who at that time was secretary of the Western Australia Trades and Labour Council. I put on record the role that Senator Cook played in defending the democratic rights of the Aboriginal people from that area of the State and also in defending the democratic rights of all citizens-all nationals-of Australia.

The book chronicles an indictment of affairs in my State because, at that time, the State government actually led the crusade to invade a sacred site, a site held sacred to the local Aboriginal people of the Noonkanbah Station in the Kimberley region of Western Australia. The State Government under the then leadership of Charles Court actually owned the rig that drilled the hole in that sacred site near Pea Hill on Noonkanbah Station. The Government went to extraordinary lengths in organising a convoy. It assembled in Perth and travelled well over 2,000 miles from Perth to the north of the State to undertake the obligations the Government felt at that time.

I hope many people read the book, reflect on it and point the finger at those people who brought this slur on not only Western Australian history and the history of Aboriginal people but also the history of Australia as a whole. I hope when they do read the book they will, in turn, take lessons from it.

I would be confident to say that a similar situation to that which occurred at Noonkanbah 10 years ago and nine years ago would not happen in Australia today. I doubt whether the Australian people would stand for it and I put on the record that many, many Australian people did oppose the actions of the then Western Australian State Government in doing what it was seeking to do. Many other names are mentioned in the book, some of whom have faded from the scene. I do not want to reflect on any but I am pleased to note that one particular name gets quite a deal of mention. That is Gil Barr, who at that time was the state secretary of the Australian Workers Union. Senator Cook would know, probably more than anybody else, just what a role Gil Barr had to play at that time. It is fair to say that the Western Australian branch of the union of which he was secretary-he later became the national secretary of the union-is noted as a conservative union. It would have been quite easy for Gil, as secretary of the union, to fold his arms and let events take place. But because he had the interests of human beings at heart he actually took action to assist. He did whatever he possibly could to inform his members of how they were being used up by the State Government, by Amax Exploration (Aust) Inc., the exploration company which was seeking to get the oil out of the area, and by CSR Ltd, another company involved.

Many other individuals are deserving of mention. I expect I will do so at a later time when I have had time to read the book. I have not at this stage read it; all I have done is look at the magnificent photographs taken by Michael Gallagher. Michael is a good friend of mine who was actually the photographer at my wedding just a few years ago. I must say that the photographs in the book do not bring back as many happy memories as the photographs Michael took of my wife and my wedding just a few years ago. It is a long time since I was united with my wife and I must say I am looking forward to the plane trip home to Perth tomorrow.

Michael and the author, Steve Hawke, are still working with the Aboriginal people. I stress the word `with', although there are people around who say nasty things about advisers, and I dare say there have been problems with some white advisers who have gone into Aboriginal communities and sought to direct the activities of various Aboriginal communities throughout Australia. Steve Hawke cannot be mentioned as being one of those people who sought to direct Aborigines. I have been with Steve in communities in the Kimberleys and know that he does not initiate actions. He responds to requests from the community and he is still to this day working in the Kimberley region on behalf of and with Aboriginal people in that region. Michael is assisting in a similar, but slightly different, way as well. I think the launching of the book by Professor Manning Clark yesterday will be good for Australia in the long term. I do not think it matters which political party individuals belong to; all of us can learn lessons from those very sad events, events we would like to forget, because they do reflect on us. I think we all can learn lessons from this very sorrowful period of Western Australian history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate a number of matters. Firstly, I wish to draw attention to the press conference that was conducted a short while ago by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. It related to an agreement that has been reached between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory governments for excisions and the provision of land on associated and neighbouring pastoral properties in the Northern Territory. This very historic agreement has been negotiated between the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister after tortuous and very extensive consultations.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that on 15 August I moved a motion in this place which drew attention to the problem in this area and the fact that legislation relating to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act had remained unproclaimed for quite some time, causing a stalemate in the negotiations. It is a pity that, after many years of seeking to get resolution in this area, particularly in the last two years, this whole matter had been stalled, very obviously by the interests of the land councils and Minister Hand, and it has taken the intervention of the Prime Minister to have the matter satisfactorily resolved. But I am pleased that that resolution was reached and was recorded today.

Another matter that needs the attention of the Senate is the tabling yesterday of the Auditor-General's report relating to the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio, in particular the administration of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account (ABTA). This report is very concerning. A whole range of issues have been raised by the Auditor-General for the second consecutive year, and he makes the point that there has been no attempt to adequately address the issues that have been raised. Again the Auditor-General brings up the points of royalty overpayments, the lack of an investment strategy, payments without delegated authority, deficiencies in the control of assets and the application of grant assessments, and a failure to review the grant program to ensure the objective of benefiting Aborigines in the Northern Territory.

The fact that the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account in effect acts as the vehicle for the transfer of funds from the royalty payments through to the Aboriginal communities and the land councils is most concerning. I have mentioned in a number of other debates and in the Estimates committees my concern that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, has in effect been fiddling with the books of the ABTA by transferring funds that should be going to community grants for administrative purposes to the land councils. That is seriously depleting the capital funds of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account and could result in very serious difficulties in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator inferred that the Minister was fiddling the books. I do not think that allegation is within the terms of parliamentary language and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—Senator Tambling, I would ask you to withdraw those accusations.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I withdraw the word `fiddling'. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has transferred very significant amounts of funds for the administrative purposes of the land councils in the Northern Territory, at the expense of grants that could otherwise be made for community purposes to the benefit of Aboriginal people. There has recently been a report by Mr Greg Crough with regard to the future of the ABTA. It now concerns me that the Minister has called for a review of that report and has engaged consultants, I believe involving funding of the order of $500 a day, to conduct the review, which will basically say that the same thing has happened-that the capital provisions of this fund are being depleted because of the very actions in this regard. This really worries me. I suggest that all senators have a good look at this report and come to the Estimates committees because I am sure there is a wealth of information that we will have to ascertain to ensure that these funds are being properly restored and used for the purposes for which they were intended.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also concerned that the accounting of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account has not been satisfactory over the past few years. The fact that there are very marked differences between the cash accounting and accrual accounting systems and how they are operated and the fact that the ledger of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account has been reconstructed will need to be very carefully considered this year in the Estimates discussions and debates. I think we will see a lot of information in that particular regard. I am, of course, concerned that Minister Hand seems to be constantly at the centre of controversial attention in this portfolio and constantly being called into question because it would appear that he is diverting attention away from the real needs of Aborigines. The sooner the Prime Minister wakes up to the option of replacing Mr Hand, the better off many Aboriginal people will be.

The other report that I would like to refer to is the Auditor-General's report into the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) for the Alligator Rivers Region of the Northern Territory. The Auditor-General's report has highlighted a number of irregularities with regard to the professional and monitoring projects, particularly with administrative procedures to make sure that the assets, personnel and administrative procedures are all in order. What the Auditor has highlighted is the fact that there were instances when it was not possible to verify satisfactorily the submission consideration and, where applicable, approval of the research projects because of inadequacies in the formal documentation. He has also recommended that the OSS formalise the development and approval processes for internal research projects and issue guidelines and procedures for the use of staff.

The fact that the Auditor has been so critical with regard to these very important evaluative projects in the uranium region of the Northern Territory is a matter of great concern. Honourable senators will be well aware that the Opposition has put forward the policy that the Office of the Supervising Scientist ought more properly to be a function of the Northern Territory Government, where it should be very closely looked at through the Mines and Energy portfolio and the Education portfolio for the research aspects, and perhaps be attached to the Northern Territory University. I will certainly be drawing this Audit report to the attention of the Northern Territory Ministers, the Hon. Barry Coulter and the Hon. Tom Harris, in the respective Mines and Energy and Education portfolios, to ensure that they could have in place the correct procedures that would pick up the errors that are obviously being exposed where the Commonwealth administration is not satisfactory in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to continue speaking on the issue of banking. Honourable senators are aware of the fact that I have been pursuing this issue as a matter of public interest for almost a year and in doing so have tabled now approaching 50 affidavits from people who make very serious allegations about the nature of banking practices in this country. Over the period of that year, of course, the issue has developed quite dramatically as a matter of public interest. I think everybody is aware of the fact that there is a great deal of debate and concern in the community over many aspects of banking. Certainly, honourable senators and many members of the public are aware of the fact that my entry point into this debate focused on very serious allegations concerning malpractice and corrupt practice.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to advise the Senate of actions on my part recently because I know that honourable senators are increasingly turning their attention to the issue as the public awareness and interest have escalated. I would also like to table further documents, and will shortly seek leave to do so, but I will explain what those documents are. It has been my practice to place on the table of the Senate affidavits which illustrate the types of allegations which are being brought to me. I have attempted to table a sampling of affidavits which range across the three broad areas of allegation, namely, asset stripping, the problem of foreign loans borrowings, which caught out approximately 1,400 small business people in this country and sent the majority of them into bankruptcy, and premature foreclosures on rural holdings. Today I seek leave of the Senate to table four further affidavits, namely, those relating to a Mr Blake, who is in disagreement with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia; to a Mr and Mrs Correy, who are in dispute with the National Australia Bank Ltd; to three members of the Carroll family, who are in dispute with the National Australia Bank; and to a Mr and Mrs Bayes, who are in dispute with the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. I seek leave of the Senate to table those as further examples of the serious allegations which are being placed before me.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —A further document I seek to table is a letter from Mr Don Sanders, who is the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and who has been corresponding with me about some of these serious allegations. It might be recalled that in earlier debates Senator Stone tabled five letters from Mr Sanders to me. It was not my choice that they be placed before the Senate, but they were placed before the Senate and incorporated in Hansard. As a result of that incorporation, there were further reactions from those who were making the allegations. Mr Sanders has subsequently responded to those reactions and I have undertaken, with the permission of the Senate, to table his correspondence so that honourable senators are fully informed as to how he has further reacted. I seek leave of the Senate to table that letter from Mr Sanders.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to advise the Senate of other actions that I have taken in relation to these matters in recent weeks. I think honourable senators are aware of the fact that possibly one of the most controversial aspects of this debate has related to a series of documents which were sought by the then Director of the 60 Minutes program under freedom of information and which were denied him. I previously have tabled in the Senate the correspondence between the 60 Minutes program and the Australian Federal Police wherein the Australian Federal Police admitted that they had assembled 140-odd pages of documents relating to 34 serious allegations of corrupt practices within the Commonwealth Bank but had refused to release those documents, with the exception of one page.

SPEECH.PARA: It was about two years ago that those documents were sought under freedom of information. I would contend, and I have contended, that in that two years the public's attitude towards the issue has dramatically changed and that in the public interest, which is allowed for under the freedom of informa- tion legislation, it is perhaps now timely that those documents be released. I have in fact sought those documents under the Freedom of Information Act, with a view to reviewing them responsibly and, if necessary, allowing access to what portion of them would be appropriate to the Senate. I have received a standard reply letter from the officer responsible for the freedom of information branch of the Australian Federal Police in which I was requested to pay the necessary fees and to fund the necessary searches involved. That would be a considerable expense. Therefore, I have sought release from those fees, once again under that section of the Act which provides for release from the fees if a matter is in the public interest. So I advise the Senate that I am seeking access to those documents in the belief that they are relevant to the very serious allegations which I have been pursuing, I believe, in the public interest.

The second thing I have done is approach Sir Ninian Stephen as the newly appointed Chairman of the new forming Australian Bank Council. The Australian Bankers Association, in response to my actions in the Senate and in response to the public clamour concerning aspects of banking, undertook to form an Australian Bank Council which will be responsible for the appointment and administration of a bank ombudsman. I have written to Sir Ninian asking that I be permitted to appear before the Bank Council. It is my intention to place before the Council all the material which I have tabled in the Senate and seek its cooperation in pursuing the matters I have raised in the Senate.

I will be watching, with a great deal of interest, as will the public, obviously, the effectiveness of the Bank Council and the subsequent appointment of an ombudsman. There has been some concern that banks could be looking at banks and some suggestion that that may not be the most effective and appropriate mechanism to explore these very serious allegations. However, I think that we should take it on its merit and allow the Council the opportunity of proving its credibility and effectiveness. I have sought, therefore, to appear before it; perhaps as the first one to appear before the Bank Council when it is formed.

So, by way of updating the Senate as to where this issue stands and my actions in relation to it, I advise it of four things: I will continue to table affidavits; I will seek to place those affidavits simultaneously before the newly formed Bank Council of Australia; I will be seeking access to what I consider to be critical documents under the Freedom of Information Act; and I have sought the cooperation of the Minister for Justice, Senator Michael Tate, in obtaining those documents. In earlier debate, he indicated an interest in the serious allegations which I have tabled before the Senate and I seek his cooperation in obtaining those documents in the public interest. Therefore, I will continue with the process that I initiated almost 12 months ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the last few remaining minutes of this debate to speak about the mining industry and its importance to my State of Tasmania. Even though Tasmania is the smallest and least populous State in the Commonwealth, it is mineral resources rich and it makes a significant contribution to Australian mining exports. The industry has an annual production worth nearly $1,000m and produces more than 50 per cent of the State's export earnings. In addition, the mining industry employs more than 7,000 Tasmanians and, indirectly, employs 14,000 people in ancillary industries. For more than a century mining and mineral processing have been the mainstay of the Tasmanian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: As early as 1642 the presence of mineral riches on the west coast was indicated by the swinging compass on Abel Tasman's ship, the Heemskirk. The first mine in Tasmania was a convict coalmine which was opened in 1834 on the Tasman Peninsula. Alluvial gold workings began on a small scale in the north in about 1851. However, it was not until 1871, when a huge tin deposit was discovered at Mount Bischoff, that the mining industry really started to boom. Some of the minerals mined in Tasmania today and in the past include sheelite, gold, tin, copper, zinc, coal, clay, silver, lead, silica and tungsten. Of the 19 major mines and mining fields that have operated in the State, nine are still operating today.

The mining industry today consists of three sectors: mining, mineral processing and exploration. The future of all three sectors is currently facing uncertainty due to the Labor-Greens alliance and the World Heritage boundary nominations that are being sought. Whilst the nominations proposed by Tasmania's Premier, Michael Field, earlier this week do not encroach upon the State's west coast mineral rich belt, should the Greens have the boundaries further extended, thanks to Senator Richardson, then the mining industry faces a very insecure future. The Director of the National Key Centre for Ore Deposit and Exploration Studies at the University of Tasmania has joined the Tasmanian Chamber of Mines in expressing concern about the push by the conservation movement for additional areas to be added to the World Heritage nomination.

The additional areas being pushed for nomination included parts of the resource rich Mount Read volcanic belt and adjacent Dundas Trough. The Mount Read volcanic belt and Dundas sequences form a unique mineralised geological terrain that has produced some of the major mines in the world. New deposits remain to be discovered, but only if this ground remains available for future research and exploration. Even without the nomination being pushed for by the Green Independents, the mining industry stands to lose mining resources in the Denison Range and the Lemonthyme areas with moderate to high mineral potential.

When the accord was signed between the Labor Party and the Green Independents in May this year, the mining industry expressed a hope that the alliance would maintain the climate necessary for the sustenance and growth of the State's major industry. The mining industry was referring then to $860m worth of mining investments on the drawing board for the period 1990 to 1996. These investments would be in addition to the $800m worth of projects in process or about to begin in 1989. Mr Deputy President, these are significant figures.

An economy as small as Tasmania's and so dependent on the mining industry cannot afford to have these potential investments curtailed. What is completely incongruous about this whole matter is that the mining industry occupies less than one per cent of the State's land area and that this amount is to be reduced even further, thus jeopardising the jobs of some 21,000 Tasmanians and 50 per cent of the State's export earnings, to increase the area of the State locked up for eternity from a staggering 20 per cent.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Minister will recall telling Senator Alston on Monday that the question of compensating the airlines was not a live proposal and telling me yesterday that possible compensation for the cost to the airlines of not standing down employees was now a live option. Will the Minister confirm that the only people the Government is prepared to consider for compensation, either directly or by the backdoor route of making payments to employees not being stood down, are the airline companies?

—I think I have made it clear in numerous answers to the Senate that the question of compensation was first used in Question Time here in relation to compensating the airlines on a whole range of matters, including loss of profits and so on, as a result of the dispute. I also think I made it quite clear yesterday, and before, that late last week the Government had received from the airlines a request which, as I understand it, related to the question of--
—Recompense.

—Recompense-or how the question of their losses sustained by keeping on the job employees who might otherwise have been stood down would be dealt with by the Government. In respect of that issue I said yesterday-and I repeat-that the Government has not considered the request, but will do so in due course.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I can understand the Minister being somewhat obsessed by the convolutions of his earlier answers, but the specific question I asked him did not relate at all to the matters he raised but to whether the Government is prepared to consider for compensation, one way or another, the airlines but no other persons who are injured by this dispute-none of the other businesses which may or may not have to stand down employees. Is the Government taking the position that only the airlines will be considered for compensation?
—Or recompense.
—Yes, or recompense.
—I repeat that the Government has received a request from the airlines in respect of employees not stood down and that in due course the Government will consider that request.

—My question to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs concerns the application for permanent residency by Imam Hilaly. Has the Minister made a decision on the application? If so, what is that decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. After having given very careful consideration to all the issues involved, I have made a decision on this case. Imam Hilaly has been in Australia as a temporary resident for a number of years. He recently applied for permanent residence under the employer-nominated scheme. The correct forms and fees have been lodged. Key issues in considering the application involve allegations against Imam Hilaly that, first, he was a divisive influence in the Lebanese community; second, he made a racist and inflammatory attack on Jews; and, third, he is an agent of or associated with the Libyan regime. I concluded that there was some evidence to support the first contention, overwhelming evidence to support the second contention, and insubstantial evidence to support the third contention.

ANSWER.PARA: Factors or arguments to be considered in favour of the imam were his major involvement in social work in the community; his constructive role in the Salman Rushdie affair and in a recent fracas at Arncliffe Mosque; his determination-lately got, I admit-to learn English; a stated commitment to multiculturalism; and a willingness to enter into dialogue with divergent groups in Australian society. I was also cognisant of the fact that the imam's spouse and four children, two of whom are Australian citizens, have resided in Australia for a number of years.

When considering the imam's disgraceful attack on Jews, consideration was also given to his subsequent statement in which he retracted those remarks. That retraction was in a letter to the Prime Minister dated 23 June and I intend to have it published, to constitute a public apology on behalf of the imam. The attack on the Jewish people certainly disqualified, in my own mind, any application from the imam for permanent residency in this country at this time.

I have decided that further evidence is required regarding the Imam's commitment to play a positive role in promoting harmony between religious groups in this country. In order to test this commitment I have decided to offer the Imam a further 12 months temporary entry permit, at the end of which time any application for permanent residence will be measured against the role he plays over the next year. Applications for permanent residency by his spouse and two of his children will be considered separately and are expected to be finalised shortly.

While I have received a great deal of correspondence from individuals and groups both for and against the imam, the case has been determined solely on its merits and not as a result of any lobbying. This case and others like it-and I stress the words `others like it'-have highlighted the need to establish new guidelines for the issue of visas for religious leaders. Such guidelines will be issued before the end of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer explain how the Government can consider paying money, whether it is recompense or compensation or whatever, in one way or another to the airline companies which have not stood down any employees and the Government's refusal to consider any form of compensation to business in the tourist industry which have not stood down employees or compensation to employees in the tourism and other industries who have been stood down as a result of this dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first and most important point to make is that the Government has not made any decisions to compensate anybody in this instance. There are, however, two precedents that I am aware of where governments have paid compensation. This Government compensated those firms which were seriously disadvantaged because of the actions of the building workers union--
—The BLF.

—Thank you: the Builders Labourers Federation-while it was being deregistered. There is another precedent from 1980, when the Fraser Government imposed Claytons sanctions on trade with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics following the Russian invasion of Afghanistan. I used the term `Claytons sanctions' quite advisedly because the Fraser Government took good care to see that it did not impose any quantitatively serious impediments on trade with the Soviet Union. In particular, it did nothing about wool. As we know, eventually Nareen wool was photographed being loaded on to a ship at Portland for dispatch to the Soviet Union. The Nareen wool may well have been protecting the Red Army from the Afghan chill ultimately.

ANSWER.PARA: The Fraser Government also decided that we would not export any more wheat to the Soviet Union in 1980 than we had exported in the previous year. It just so happened that in the previous year exports to the Soviet Union were the highest ever recorded-by a significant margin. The National Party, or the Country Party, or whatever it called itself in those days, would not have allowed anything to impede the wheat or wool trade with the Soviet Union-or any high volume trade at all. But some firms were disadvantaged. I do not remember the total amount of money but it was not a great deal, probably several million. Firms that were disadvantaged because of the Claytons sanctions were paid compensation by the Fraser Government. So there are precedents for governments paying compensation, but I repeat that no decision has been made by this Government in this instance to compensate anybody.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his view of history. However, I am interested in the current problems of industries in Australia, the tourist industry in particular. I ask whether the Minister is saying that this Government will consider paying compensation, in money or some other form, to airline industries which are not standing down employees, but will not consider paying compensation to people in the tourist industry who have taken the same action. Alternatively, if employees are stood down, will the Government compensate the employees if they make such a request? Would the Government consider compensating them?

—The original question and, even more so, the supplementary question drift into the realms of hypothetical questions. I am asked, `Would the Government consider . . .?'. I suppose one could argue that the Government should consider anything. It might even consider whether any policy that the Opposition puts up on anything-if it ever gets around to putting up any policies on anything that matters-has worthy elements. A reasonable person should consider anything but, I repeat, no decisions have been made.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What are the implications for reform in South Africa of the election results there today?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The voting results most recently to hand this morning for the white House of the South African Parliament indicate that the Afrikaner National Party, under the leadership of De Klerk, has suffered electoral losses to the left and right wing parties, but will retain government in its own right. In any comment on the South African election it is crucially important to remember that it was a democratic election in name only. To determine a national government of a country with a franchise of only 15 per cent of the population is, on any view, to embark on a travesty of the democratic process. That travesty is no less when one takes into account the so-called coloured and Indian chambers, which lack any significant power and have an esteem to match, and for which the voting turnout, not unexpectedly in those circumstances, was extremely low.

ANSWER.PARA: The preliminary counting for the white chamber indicates that the National Party may have suffered a loss of some 32 seats, representing a swing of 15 per cent against it. That would leave it with about 90 of the 166 seats in the new Parliament-a fairly slim majority, but one which would, as I have said, be sufficient for it to retain government in its own right without the need to enter into a coalition with either the Conservative Party or the reformist Democratic Party. The right wing Conservative Party appears likely to win 38 to 40 seats, which is a gain of some 16, although representing an increase of only about 4 per cent in its vote. The Democratic Party is expected to obtain a total of 36 to 38 seats, a gain of about 20, representing an increase of fully 11 per cent in its vote.

The preliminary election results that I have described have been regarded by commentators in South Africa as indicating a thrust towards reform, since the Democratic Party is regarded in South Africa as the big winner. There is some point in that to the extent that it has gained an increase in its vote of some 11 per cent, with the Conservatives gaining only 4 per cent and failing to break out of the Conservative Party's farming heartland-having, it seems, won only one seat outside the Transvaal. We have all noted that Mr De Klerk, who seems assured of shortly being elected President by members of the ruling National Party, has met recently with leaders of the frontline states to discuss South Africa's future. I note also, as we all have, that he has made a number of comments in recent months which suggest at least some disposition towards reform.

The onus is now on the South African Government to act to bring blacks back into the mainstream of South Africa's political and economic life, and there must remain some real, considerable doubt as to whether the newly elected Government is genuinely committed to this. The reality, as we all have to appreciate, is that none of the white political parties in South Africa is yet prepared to grant full political democratic rights to blacks. The Conservatives, of course, want a return to full-blooded apartheid, but even a majority of the Democratic Party, together with the National Party, argue for that vague concept of group rights as an alternative to the concept of equal individual rights, which we would uphold and which are generally sought by non-white South Africans. I conclude by saying that there is a long way to go yet before we can talk of South Africa and democracy in the same breath.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, concerns the Electrona silicon plant near Hobart. Is the Minister aware of the serious health-threatening problems of air pollution with silica dust at the Electrona plant? Is he aware that in Australia the allowable level of silica is presently 5,000 micrograms per cubic metre but that, in recognition of the toxic nature of silica, the United States of America has recently reduced its allowable level to 200 micrograms per cubic metre, a reduction by a factor of 25? What, if any, overriding controls on occupational and environmental health does the Commonwealth possess, and will these powers be invoked in this case to prevent the significant hazard to which workers at and residents near the Electrona plant are exposed?
—I thank Senator Coulter for bringing this matter to my attention.
—Didn't you know about it either?

—Senator Walters is right. I did not know about it until it was brought to my attention by Senator Coulter, but I thank him for doing so. As he says, it is a serious matter. However, because I was not aware of it I think the prudent and reasonable thing for me to do is to refer it to my colleague the Minister for Community Services and Health and obtain an answer for Senator Coulter as soon as I possibly can.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Despite assurances given by the Minister, concern continues to be expressed about the future of the Women's Information Service in Hobart. Can the Minister inform all those who are worried about it what her plans are for the Service, now that there is a State government in Tasmania more sympathetic to the idea of running such a service? Is there likely to be any sudden transfer of the function, and can she guarantee that the type of assistance given by the Women's Information Service will not be lost or reduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to put it on the public record that there is no intention to close the Tasmanian Women's Information Service. I am sorry that Tasmanian women have been alarmed by rumours that the service will close because there is absolutely no intention on the part of the Federal Government to close the service, nor, indeed, is there any such intention in any other quarter.

ANSWER.PARA: In order to answer this question I need to remind honourable senators that it was the Federal Government which established the Tasmanian Women's Information Service, because the State governments in two States had avoided their responsibilities and failed to provide women's policy units in Premiers' departments. Therefore, in 1984 in Queensland, and 1985 in Tasmania, the Federal Government set up the women's information services to fill the gap in those two States. However, it has always been the intention-and I am sure that many Tasmanian women appreciate this-that those services would eventually be provided by State Labor governments.

Now that there is a Labor-Independent Government in Tasmania, obviously the time has come to start talking about the future of the Tasmanian Women's Information Service. I have spoken with the Minister responsible, Ms Fran Bladel. She has assured me that the Tasmanian Government is looking forward to fulfilling its responsibilities to Tasmanian women and, as a first step, Premier Field has established a women's policy unit in his department. For the time being there is absolutely no intention to change the operation of the Women's Information Service. However, in the longer term there will be a smooth transition from Federal to State responsibility. I am confident that Tasmanian women will notice a difference. They will have not only the Women's Information Service but also the benefits of a Labor Government committed to a women's policy, a women's policy unit and an adviser in the Premier's Department. A whole range of strategies will be implemented. I can assure Senator Coates that there will be no sudden transfer and no diminution of service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the Prime Minister's confident predictions yesterday that planes from the domestic airlines will soon be back in the air. I also refer to the report in this morning's Melbourne Age:

QUESTION.PARA: The Industrial Relations Minister, Mr Morris, said last night that the airlines had recruited enough pilots and expected to be back in the air in `these next few days'.
Can the Minister tell the Senate how many aircraft will be airborne this coming weekend and how many more are expected to be operating by the following weekend?

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot tell Senator Stone either of those things. If I could, obviously I would be intruding in a matter that is very much in the hands of the airlines.
—Have you no idea at all?

—I would be doing what Senator Stone did this morning on the AM program when he told the pilots how to run their dispute. I know that it is nice to get on the AM program and say something, but I listened for five minutes and could not gain any elucidation from what Senator Stone was saying. I am not going to buy into that; I cannot answer the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We have widespread newspaper reports this morning that the dispute is, to all intents and purposes, well on the way to being over. As against that, we have a letter from the President of the Australian Federation of Airline Pilots to Sir Peter Abeles saying:

QUESTION.PARA: You say in your letter that some Ansett pilots have returned. We do not believe you. We challenge you to state publicly the number of pilots that have returned, and explain publicly why, if pilots have returned, not one Ansett aircraft is in the air.
I ask the Minister: Who is lying? Is Mr McCarthy lying? Is he? Is he lying? Or are Sir Peter Abeles, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations lying?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a supplementary question at all; it is just a bit of windbaggery by Senator Stone.
—Who is lying?
—Whatever my function is, it is not to be inside the head of Sir Peter Abeles or the--
—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations lying?
—It is not my job to work out what they are thinking and what they are saying.
—You don't care whether they are lying.

—Don't be silly, Senator. If Senator Stone wants to make moral judgments on Friday night at the Press Club or somewhere, he can go and do it, but I will not come in here and make moral judgments about who is telling the truth about particular circumstances. If Senator Stone wants to do that he can do it-he can do it on the AM program tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the nature of South Africa's current international financial transactions of an official nature? In the Australian Government's view, what are the implications of those transactions for domestic policies in South Africa including apartheid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —South Africa is in a parlous financial situation. Its reserves of foreign currency in gold are barely sufficient to cover five weeks imports and the country has virtually no access to international loans. As Finance Minister Du Plessis has said, South Africa has been operating abroad on a cash basis for the last four years. Four years ago South Africa defaulted on its repayments on overseas loans and it remains in default. When foreign banks responded in 1985 to the revulsion to apartheid shown by their customers and shareholders by ceasing new lending, the Reserve Bank of South Africa and the Government concluded that the country could not repay its debts. They unilaterally declared a moratorium on debt repayment and imposed a rescheduling arrangement on foreign bank loans totalling $US13 billion. When the current rescheduling agreement expires on 30 June next year, some $US12 billion will still be owing and overdue for repayment. At the same time, bond repayments of over $2 billion are also due. South Africa simply will not be able to meet these repayment obligations.

ANSWER.PARA: The South African economy is being strangled by its lack of access to foreign capital, so-called financial sanctions, and the flight of domestic capital. Recent history shows that if the economy is allowed to grow at much more than 2 per cent a current account deficit results, but the country cannot fund a current account deficit. Indeed, it has to run a current account surplus if it is to make any progress in repaying its overdue debt. South Africa has a rapidly growing population and work force. It needs growth of 4 per cent or more to create the jobs to stop unemployment rising further from the current level of around 30 per cent.

Foreign banks will not lend to South Africa to get it out of this hole because apartheid and political unrest associated with it make the country a poor credit risk and because dealing with South Africa puts at risk other business. So many of their customers react negatively as they do to apartheid. There is no prospect whatever of the international financial community resuming any normal relations with South Africa while the Republic refuses to go down the path of genuine reform. That financial pressure will get tighter and tighter. That is the subject and substance of the effort that Australia has been making to draw international attention to the phenomenon of financial sanctions. It is important that it be appreciated. The final point I make, without labouring the point any further, is that the only way out of that dilemma for South Africa is genuine political reform. The sooner the newly elected government appreciates that and goes down that path, the better it will be for everyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and follows his refusal to answer the question asked by Senator Lewis. Can the Minister give the Senate a clear assurance that the Government will consider all requests for compensation or recompense by any businesses suffering loss or damage from the pilots strike on the same basis?
—I am not sure what Senator Chaney means by an `assurance that the Government will consider'.
—Apply the same principles.
—I am willing to consider almost anything. For a while I even considered the proposition that Mr Peacock might be a better Opposition Leader than Mr Howard.
—You didn't really, did you?

—After considering it, I decided that he would not be, but I did consider it. I will consider almost any proposition. But if Senator Chaney means a guarantee that there will be a formal proposal put to Cabinet to consider this, I cannot give any such assurance because the Prime Minister controls the Cabinet agenda, not me.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The failure of the Minister to answer the question again is the reason I ask a supplementary question. Yesterday the Prime Minister said that the only matter that can be on the agenda is the possibility of recompense for the unique circumstances of the airlines. I ask the Minister: Does that mean that the Government will apply one set of principles to the airlines and a different set of principles to everybody else?

—The first question asked whether I would consider something, whether the Government would consider something, and whether I would give an assurance that certain matters would be put formally on the Cabinet agenda-an assurance which I cannot give. I have now been asked to let Senator Chaney know in advance what decisions the Government might make about propositions that have not yet been put to it.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether it is true that Australian troops were involved in the United States (US)-Republic of Korea Team Spirit exercise this year which is the largest ever held in this annual series and which is a major impediment to improved relations between North Korea and South Korea. If so, how many Australian troops were involved, what were they doing there and why were they there, given that Australia is supposed to be developing a strategy of self-reliance and Korea is hardly within Australia's sphere of strategic interest as outlined in the Dibb report and the White Paper on the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities? I also ask whether Australian troops or observers have been involved in earlier Team Spirit exercises and, if so, when. Finally, I ask the Minister whether he is aware of remarks made by the commander of the 43,000 United States forces in South Korea last month that there will be no military need for an American troop presence in South Korea after the mid-1990s if current trends continue. Does the Australian Government support such a move for United States withdrawal from South Korea?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian involvement in Exercise Team Spirit in March of this year consisted of seven officers and was as follows: one major and three captains were attached to the command post of the exercise at the invitation of the US Army. Three captains, attached to US units based in Hawaii, participated in the exercise as part of their normal duties as exchange officers with the US Army. The attachment of the four Australian-based officers to the exercise headquarters provided an opportunity for them to observe the operation of a higher level headquarters involved in commanding and controlling a large scale exercise. This experience was directly relevant to Exercise Kangaroo 89 as the skills involved are the same for large scale exercises, whatever the scenario. The participation of the three exchange officers enables them to carry out duties of their exchange postings which are designed to enhance Australian Defence Force (ADF) training opportunities and knowledge. It also increases their inter-operability with the US forces.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that previous ADF involvement in the Exercise Team Spirit has comprised a participation by ADF officers on exchange with US units. The question of any withdrawal of US forces from South Korea is a matter entirely for the Governments of the United States and South Korea to determine. They will determine that issue, one assumes, in the light of their own judgments as to what is occurring on the peninsula. Obviously, the Australian Government would welcome any reduction in tension in the area and any development that would lead to that would be welcomed by us.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMPANY TAX: PAYMENT BY SMALL BUSINESS SECTOR

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister again to the Government's punitive Budget decision to require payment of 85 per cent of company tax within 15 days of the end of the financial year-a decision which will have a devastating impact on business, especially small business. Will the Minister confirm as reported in the current issue of Business Review Weekly that the Australian Taxation Office will enforce its view of non-deductability of borrowings used to pay tax which will further add to the problems posed by this decision? In view of this likely further penalty flowing from this Budget measure and the Minister's undertaking last Friday that the Government will look at the impact of the decision, has the Government done so and is it prepared either to rescind or modify the Budget announcement?
—I cannot confirm what appeared in the Business Review Weekly. I will speak to the Treasurer about the matter and see whether I can find an appropriate answer.
—The Tax Office is running the country? It is not you? You do not know?

—I certainly do not know the answer to this question but I suppose that is the difference between the two of us: you are a know-all and I am not. I do not know the answer to this question and I will seek to obtain an answer. As to any further consideration of the decision announced in the Budget, I have already spoken to the Treasurer about the matter. I have received no response at this stage.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. There have been recent media reports that insulin may not be available from pharmacies because of a decision by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. Can the Minister assure the Senate that insulin is still readily available?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of claims that pharmacists will be unable to stock insulin because of the recent decision by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. I am disappointed that some people are seeking to create what can only be regarded as totally unnecessary concerns among diabetics on this issue. The claim is that pharmacists will not be able to stock insulin and other high cost drugs because the mark-up is to be abolished and because wholesalers apply a surcharge. The Department of Community Services and Health has discussed this issue with wholesalers and manufacturers. I can inform Senator Childs that the claims are spurious.

ANSWER.PARA: Wholesalers apply surcharges and discounts to the price of products from the manufacturer to encourage efficient ordering and payment practices. The National Distributors Association advises that on average it is providing more discounts in dollar terms than surcharges; that is, chemists are, in fact, gaining an advantage. In the case of insulin the price to the manufacturer of five ampoules of human insulin is $88.50. Wholesalers advise that they supply to chemists with a surcharge of $3.54 but with a discount of 7.5 per cent if payment is made within the normal settlement period of 25 to 30 days. A chemist who pays his or her bill on time gets the insulin at a discounted price of $85.14. Pharmacists using the automated claims transmission system get paid by the Health Insurance Commission within 15 days.

Peter Staples, the Minister responsible for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, has assured the Diabetics Foundation that the Government will not let supplies of insulin be disrupted. That organisation accepts his assurances. Diabetics in Australia share my concern that they are being used in what can only be regarded as a totally unnecessary scare campaign. I have among my papers a news release from the National Office of Diabetes Australia. I will table that document because it supports the remarks I have just made.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the renewed violence in Bougainville, including the blowing up of an electricity pylon and the attack on two buses transporting workers. Is it the case that the rebels included a former member of the Papua New Guinea defence forces who defected after being trained in Australia in the use of explosives as part of our defence cooperation program? Is the Minister satisfied that in the decision to reopen the mine, adequate provisions have been taken to ensure the safety of workers, including the many Australians employed at the mine?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen speculation about the identity of one of the rebels in the terms that Senator Hill uses. I am not sure whether I am in a position to confirm that but I will see what I can say further on that subject. The decision to re-open the mine, which was unfortunately and dramatically countermanded by further incidents a few hours afterwards, was one that was jointly taken by the Papua New Guinea Government and the mine owners Bougainville Copper Ltd. It was a matter essentially for those parties and it did not involve participation in any way of the Australian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: We remain very concerned about the conditions for and safety of Australian residents on Bougainville. A few weeks ago the Australian High Commission in Port Moresby put out a notice, the terms of which I will be happy to communicate to Senator Hill if he has not seen it already, indicating the risk factor that manifestly existed so far as it concerned Australian residents there-not that they needed to be reminded of that officially. It constituted a formal notification of our concern. Beyond that all I can say is that the situation remains tense and volatile and we are keeping it under close review.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there increased risk to the Australians in re-opening the mine?

—I am not in a position to make an assessment of whether there is any increased risk associated with the opening of the mine. The situation remains inherently risky, volatile and very difficult. Beyond that I do not think it would be appropriate for me to comment further at this stage.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence on the floor of the Senate of a delegation from the Supreme Soviet of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, led by Nicolai Dementey, Deputy Chairman of the Supreme Soviet. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LIVING AREAS ON PASTORAL LEASES

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs advise the Senate of the outcome of the protracted negotiations between the Commonwealth Government and the Northern Territory Government on the provision of living areas for Aboriginal people on cattle stations in the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a matter of very great satisfaction, I know, to the Prime Minister that during Question Time in the House of Representatives he has already been able to inform that House that a most significant agreement on the matter raised by Senator Collins has been signed by him on behalf of the Commonwealth Government and by Chief Minister Marshall Perron on behalf of the Northern Territory Government. In fact, it might suit the convenience of Senator Collins and honourable senators if I were to table the joint press release by the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, together with the memorandum of agreement between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory on the granting of community living areas in Northern Territory pastoral leases. I now do that.

ANSWER.PARA: The agreement is a complex and detailed one and I shall here only summarise its main provisions. They are as follows. The agreement constitutes a package of cooperative and coordinated actions by the two governments which, taken together, address the issue comprehensively. The Commonwealth will provide land for relevant groups of Aboriginal people on stock-routes and reserves under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. We will then proclaim amendments passed in 1987 which will mean that claims not scheduled will lapse. The Northern Territory, for its part, will legislate to provide living areas on pastoral leases under special freehold title which will provide a number of particular protections on matters of concern to Aboriginal people. These protections relate to such matters as protection against alienation of land, the question of compulsory acquisition, mining, and access to the land.

A detailed procedure has been agreed for processing of applications and this provides for referral, if necessary, to a special tribunal and the right of appeal to the Northern Territory Supreme Court. The land councils will be empowered, under Northern Territory legislation, to act for Aboriginals seeking excisions if the Aboriginals concerned so request this. The Commonwealth will provide the necessary approval under the land rights Act. Agreed criteria have been established for consideration of applications. Both governments are pledged to seek passage of relevant legislation as early as next month. A joint review group will be established to monitor progress and will report regularly to the Prime Minister, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Chief Minister.

The Prime Minister sincerely commends the attitude of give and take shown by Mr Perron in the negotiations in a joint effort with the Commonwealth Government to arrive at a practical and acceptable package. That attitude was reciprocated on the Commonwealth side. Without this approach by both governments, agreement could never have been achieved on such a highly complex and contentious matter. The Prime Minister also pays tribute to the tenacity, determination and dedication of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, in the process which has culminated in this agreement. It will stand as an enduring achievement of truly historic importance.

In this agreement none of the parties with interests in the issue have achieved everything they would ideally have wanted. But what we have is a basis for moving ahead rapidly to meet the urgent practical requirement of land for those Australians who, for too long, have been the most disadvantaged in our community. We have the means at last of removing what has been, for far too long, a stain on Australia's international reputation and a source of social and economic injustice for Aboriginals in the Northern Territory. The Prime Minister and this chamber trust that this agreement and the legislation required under it will receive prompt and unqualified bipartisan support.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the Minister to allegations about the disappearance of drugs from the Sydney office of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the alleged payment by police of money to a prostitute in order to allow her to buy heroin. The Minister will recall that this matter was raised by Senator Chaney in a question on 20 December last year. Is it a fact that a large force of Federal police officers-perhaps as many as 20 officers-travelled to Darwin to videotape a New South Wales police officer against whom charges were subsequently brought? Is it a fact that the serious charge or charges against this officer have now been dropped and that he faces only a relatively minor charge as a result of this operation? What was the cost of the Darwin operation? Why were the charges later dropped? Is it a fact that there has now been a third internal AFP investigation into this matter? Finally, is the report of that inquiry now before the Director of Public Prosecutions and are charges likely against any Federal police officers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would exercise some caution in answering the question simply because, to my knowledge, criminal charges relating to these matters are already before the criminal courts in New South Wales. It would not be helpful, obviously, to prejudice any matters that might be considered by those courts. I will elaborate on that in a second.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the number of police officers who may have travelled to Darwin to take part in the surveillance which was part of the operation concerned, I think about six may have gone-they would have been mainly technical officers-to provide for the videotaping that took place, there not being that number of technically able police officers available in the ordinary Australian Federal Police contingent in Darwin.

As to the particular charge which I think Senator Puplick is referring to, there were originally two charges: one of attempting to pervert the course of justice, and one of obstructing police. The first charge was dropped on the advice of the Director of Public Prosecutions, but that leaves the second charge extant. Further internal investigations are being undertaken into allegations which follow from the matters currently before the courts-and there are matters currently before the courts-and those investigations have not yet been completed.

I recall the question asked by Senator Chaney. Senator Robert Hill, who was then the shadow Minister for justice, took an interest in this matter also. I recall that during the Australian Police Ministers Council meeting in Adelaide in mid-May this year-it may have been a Friday-we had a working breakfast with Senator Hill and the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember the breakfast.
—Yes, I paid for it, and could not claim it on my travelling allowance.
—That is why it is memorable.

—That is why it is memorable. The main course, as it were, in that particular breakfast was an outline of the proposed restructuring of the Australian Federal Police. During that breakfast Senator Hill was given a brief outline of the operation in Darwin and the underlying concerns about it. I recall that Senator Hill did raise the matter of my offering a detailed briefing to him in answer to Senator Chaney's question of December. As I said, I have no desire whatsoever to prejudice the fair trial of those who are already before the courts. I stand ready to provide a fuller briefing on these matters to the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Brown-who has taken Senator Hill's previous function back in order to allow Senator Hill to concentrate on Senator Evans-if requested by him to do so.
—What are the costs? Do you have any idea?
—I will have to find out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence on the floor of the Senate of the New Building Subcommittee of the Select Services Committee of the House of Commons led by Mr Raymond Powell, MP. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome our visitors to the Senate and I trust that their visit to this building and also to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories seen reports that the New South Wales Minister for Environment, Mr Tim Moore, has claimed that the Federal Government has barred New South Wales authorities from conducting a full pollution study of Sydney's airport despite serious claims that airport fuel is fouling Botany Bay? Is it true that 27 fuel spills have leaked into Botany Bay? Is there any environmental threat to Botany Bay? Further, has the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) prevented State Pollution Control Commission (SPCC) officials from inspecting any facilities at Kingsford-Smith Airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly am aware of some criticisms that have been made by Mr Moore about the airport. I think this is the third occasion over the last month or so that he has accused the Commonwealth of perpetrating some environmental disasters. He got the previous two wrong and he got this one wrong as well. It is wrong in a number of ways. It is disappointing that the facts could be so distorted. First, it is claimed that the FAC has prevented officials of the State Pollution Control Commission from visiting the airport. In fact, the opposite is the case.
