The FAC has informed the State Pollution Control Commission that it can visit the airport any time it likes. All that is required is that it notify the FAC first. Obviously, vehicles and personnel cannot be roaming around the perimeters of a busy airport-I must admit that in the last few days it might not have been quite so busy-such as Kingsford-Smith, which is by far the busiest in the country, without some proper regard to safety and security. There is no impediment to the officials making those visits. All they have to do is let the FAC know first. The FAC has advised the Pollution Control Commission of this. I am at a loss to know why Mr Moore would continue with these claims.

ANSWER.PARA: At a meeting on 1 September the FAC sought cooperation with the Pollution Control Commission. The Commission was invited to send a representative on the next quarterly water sampling inspection, which will be held some time this month. A copy of the drainage proposals for Kingsford-Smith, prepared by Sinclair Knight and Partners Pty Ltd, was sent to the State Pollution Control Commission on 17 August. At the meeting on 1 September the SPCC requested the drainage plans of the airport and they were handed over a few days later, on 5 September. Every request from the State Pollution Control Commission so far made to the Federal Airports Corporation has been met.

The honourable senator asked about the number of spills. I think he cited 27 spills. Spills are commonplace at Kingsford-Smith. They are usually caused by overfilling. My understanding is that there were something like 40 over the last 12 months. Most of these spills are in the 10- to 20-litre range. They are very small indeed. It is not true to think that those spills immediately waft into Botany Bay and cause a problem. In fact, again, the opposite applies. At Kingsford-Smith there is protection on both sides of the international and the domestic terminals. They are protected by oil traps. The traps ensure that the spills on the apron area do not pollute Botany Bay. They are regularly checked, as of course is the water in Botany Bay. Australian Construction Services currently clean these oil traps, these flame traps, on a 12 monthly basis. As well, they clean them as required, which means after each spill. Waste from these affected flame traps or receptor pits is collected by an authorised disposal contractor and is disposed of in an authorised area, as approved by the Trade Waste Authority.

When one goes right through this exercise one will realise that all of the claims Mr Moore has made are false. One has to wonder why he would make them and why he made that claim only last week about Garden Island when he wrongly accused the Department of Defence of a breach of State laws, whereas it turned out to be a subcontractor, and he wrongly accused the Commonwealth of attempting to claim Crown immunity for that subcontractor-all of which was wrong. This goes back to the difficulty that Mr Moore and his colleague Senator Puplick have in never having an environmental win. Rather than debate forests, rather than debate coastal destruction in New South Wales, they have to come up with a series of untruths like these. It is disappointing but we, of course, have to get used to it. The great thing is that everybody in the real world knows just how pathetic the Liberal Party is on the environment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer him to his speech at the launch of `Australian Sport-The Next Step' on Monday, 21 August. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: A new body known as the Australian Sports Drug Agency is currently being established to replace the anti-drugs campaign.
He further said:

In October, the second world anti-doping conference will take place in Moscow. The main purpose of this conference is to finalise an international anti-doping charter. The new Australian Sports Agency will be the first to implement the key aspects.

When will the members of that Australian Sports Drug Agency be announced? Will that agency be totally independent? As the Moscow conference is only about three weeks away, will the agency be represented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I did announce the formation of that independent authority. At present I am exploring with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories just how we will go about permanently setting it up. It already exists in the sense that the unit which was attached to the Australian Sports Commission will now form the core of the new body. Its chief officer, Steve Haynes, will be going to Moscow for the conference to which the honourable senator has referred. We have to decide whether we will give this new body a legislative base.

ANSWER.PARA: The great complaint people in the sports community have about drug testing in sport is that often there is a suspicion or a suggestion that athletes involved may have been tipped off by sporting officials about the fact that they were going to be tested. We have to have a body that in some way can guarantee that that will not occur. At present my intention would be to give this new body a legislative base and have it report directly to the Minister, and the Minister would then report to Parliament. In that way, no sporting official, no doctor attached to a national sporting organisation, would have a role in the selection of athletes. It is only by that method that we can absolutely guarantee that our testing program will be carried out in a thorough manner and will be proper. I think that an announcement can be made very shortly on the names of the people who will be in the council that will oversee that drug agency. I think in a very short space of time that will have been done.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOVIET UNION: APPROACH TO ASIA-PACIFIC REGION

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade comment on the Soviet Union's approach to the Asia-Pacific region since President Gorbachev's statements in Vladivostok in July 1986 and Krasnojarsk in September 1988? Could the Minister provide an assessment of the progress that has been made so far in the development of a basis for constructive dialogue on economic and security issues in the region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has noted with a great deal of interest the major changes in Soviet foreign policy under President Gorbachev as articulated elsewhere in those two speeches, in particular the prior- ity attached to developing a greater role in the Asia-Pacific region. Our own response has been guided by a commitment to promoting a broader and more constructive bilateral relationship with the Soviet Union within the framework, of course, of our alliance commitments and consistent with maintaining stable and predictable relations in the region.

ANSWER.PARA: We share the view that it is important and timely to develop a dialogue on security issues in this region and begin to examine systematically the scope for measures that would reduce the risk of conflict and allow undiminished security at lower levels of armaments. At the same time we consider some of the other ideas in Mr Gorbachev's strategic agenda in the Vladivostok and Krasnojarsk speeches to be impractical and others to be unduly biased in favour of Soviet interests-for example, the asymmetric proposal that the Soviet give up Cam Ranh Bay in return for the United States of America giving up its bases in the Philippines.

An important element of the Asia-Pacific policy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is to enlist the participation of regional countries in the economic development of the Soviet Far East. We have signalled our strong interest in participating in that process, given the importance of the Soviet Far East as a region with major development potential and one which would make a natural trading partner for Australia. It offers very considerable opportunities for trade, technology transfer and joint ventures in the long term.

In pursuance of that kind of perspective and in response to a Soviet invitation, my Department and Austrade are currently planning an Australian trade exhibition in Vladivostok in July next year. It is also proposed to organise information and cultural activities to promote a better understanding in the region of Australia and its people. Australian companies have been strongly supportive of that exhibition, with some 25 to 30 expected to participate. We believe that that will further demonstrate both Australian Government commitment to, and Australian business interest in, the development of bilateral, political and economic relations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 August Senator Sanders asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question relating to recycled paper. I seek leave to incorporate the question and answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The question and answer read as follows-
Senator Sanders asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 8 August 1989:
(1) What is the total amount of paper used annually by the Minister's department or departments and what is the value of this paper.
(2) What steps has the Minister taken to institute the use of recycled paper by the department or departments in his portfolio.
(3) If no such steps have been taken, why not.
(4) When does the Minister anticipate that this will occur.
(5) What steps has the Minister taken, or will the Minister take, to co-ordinate the use, collection, and processing of recycled paper in his department(s) with other departments.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) My Department estimates that it spent approximately $140,000 on paper and paper products during 1988-89. This would represent in quantity approximately 19,000 reams. It does not include paper used by printers in producing publications commissioned by the Department.

(2) to (5) As I announced in my Statement on the Environment on 20 July 1989, the Ministers for Administrative Services and the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories have been investigating the possible use of recycled and unbleached paper in Commonwealth Government offices. A comprehensive review of the potential for using products made from recycled and unbleached paper has now been initiated. As announced by the two Ministers on 5 September 1989, the review will look at such issues as the qualities of recycled paper products, the costs involved, the positive and negative aspects of using recycled paper and what suitable uses can be identified. The review is being guided by a steering committee of senior officers from the Department of Administrative Services, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The review is in addition to a pilot study operating in the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

Also, Commonwealth and State Environment Ministers recently agreed to set up a working group to develop standards for recycled paper for government use and to examine further used for low grade recycled paper. In addition, all portfolio Ministers have been asked to report to Senator Richardson on the wastepaper recycling strategies which their departments have adopted and ways in which those strategies may be improved or extended.

I intend to issue a report early next year on the progress being made in relation to the measures announced in the Statement, including the investigations into the use of recycled paper by departments and their wastepaper recycling strategies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Patterson asked me a question, at the end of which she asked whether I could get an answer for her by the close of business today. I promised to get her an answer as soon as was reasonably possible. I now have an answer. Since the answer is lengthy, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

I firstly acknowledge some of the information raised by the Honourable Senator in the introduction to his Question. The figures she quotes demonstrate the cost-effectiveness of the Home and Community Care Program introduced by this Government in 1985-86 in helping people with disabilities stay at home where they generally prefer to be.

Following budgetary decisions by the Victorian Government to reduce indexation of the program for 1989-90 to 12%, there is little scope for funding new services or expanding existing services in Victoria this year given current commitments.

The Extended Hours Home Care demonstration project run by the City of Hawthorn was running well over budget and the bridging funding it sought to 31 December 1989 represented a 100% increase over and above its previous funding level.

The project's bid was considered on the same basis as other projects in similar circumstances. Bridging funding of $45,050, representing extension of funding at the previously approved level plus 6% general cost indexation, was recommended for his joint approval to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care by the Victorian Minister for Community Services. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care gave his approval on 22 June 1989.

It is the responsibility of the Victorian Department of Community Services to inform the Council of this decision and to pay out these funds in a timely fashion and it would seem that this has not occurred.
The Minister for Housing and Aged Care is taking the matter up with the Victorian Minister for Community Services to obtain an explanation as a matter of priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation on the grounds of having been misrepresented. I refer to an article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald written by Milton Cockburn headed `Stone adds confusion to air debate'. Mr Cockburn begins his article by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Confusion within the Opposition ranks over its attitude towards the pilots' dispute continued yesterday when it spokesman on finance, Senator Stone, called on the airlines to negotiate directly with the pilots' federation.

In doing so, he put himself in conflict with the former Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, who has consistently encouraged the settlement of the dispute by means of the airlines reaching individual contracts with their pilots, free of union interference.

In Parliament on Tuesday night, Mr Howard said: `We believe in allowing employers and employees to bargain at an enterprise level because we believe that those bargains are more likely to produce productivity outcomes.'
Mr Cockburn concludes his article with the following paragraph:
To add further confusion, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, yesterday supported the idea of voluntary contracts between the airlines and pilots, bypassing the pilots' federation.
First of all, may I put on the record what I actually said in my address to the National Press Club yesterday on which this totally mischievous article by Mr Cockburn is based. I said:
Why, above all, has Mr Hawke seemingly not been prepared to countenance-indeed, why has he not encouraged-the airlines entering into negotiations with their ex-employees, including-
note the word `including'-
through the body (the Australian Federation of Air Pilots) which these people clearly and overwhelmingly still seem to wish to represent them?

That is what I actually said. Let me now go on to point out what Mr Peacock said in the House of Representatives yesterday when he is supposed to have been at odds with what I said. Mr Peacock said-and I quote two passages from his speaking notes:
Under our industrial relations system the pilots and the airlines would have faced two choices . . .
Leaving aside the first choice, the second one is:
or they . . . negotiated a voluntary agreement, either on an individual basis or through a union, which binding on both parties.
At a later point in his remarks, the Leader of the Opposition said:
Clearly, the Government, as the owner of Australian Airlines, should encourage the management of Australian Airlines to begin negotiations with the pilots, either individually or through their union.

I put it to the Senate that this article of Mr Cockburn's in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning simply seeks a mischievous end-it is attempting to create divisions where no divisions exist. I put it on the public record that, from the outset of this debate, our spokesman on these matters, Senator Chaney, and other Opposition spokesmen have consistently said that, in the end, this dispute will be settled only by getting the parties to it around the table. The question of how they get around the table-whether the employers meet with the employees individually or whether the employees wish to be represented, as surely it is their natural right to be if they so desire, by an association-is entirely irrelevant.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failures and inconsistencies of the Government's industrial relations policy as demonstrated by the pilots' dispute.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate has had two parliamentary delegations visit it-one from the Soviet Union and one from the United Kingdom. Those delegations come from very different countries and represent very different parliaments. A delegation from any part of the world that visited Australia at this time would be shocked to find what is supposed to be a modern country without an airline system. It would find that it had to come to a country which, in terms of its capacity to move people around, has Third World status. It is not just with respect to the airline service that this country has a Third World status. This afternoon the Opposition is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The failures and inconsistencies of the Government's industrial relations policy as demonstrated by the pilots dispute.
The reason we are not debating the pilots dispute alone is that the pilots dispute is symptomatic of why this country is on the slide.

We should look at what this Government, its industrial relations system and the accord have delivered to the Australian people since Bob Hawke, the people's Prime Minister, was elected to power. This is what has happened to wages and salaries, to the income of Australians, under the famous accord: in the first year of the Hawke Government, incomes in real terms fell by 2 1/2 per cent. That was this Government's first gift to the nation in the year after the drought had broken and we got the salvation of Bob Hawke. The following year we appeared to have turned a corner. That year real incomes in Australia went up by 0.8 per cent but, in the following year, they went down again by minus 1.9 per cent. The following year they went down by minus 1.4 per cent; the following year by minus 0.4 per cent; and last year, at least, they went up by one per cent. We might have thought that, after all this sacrifice and all this effort under the accord, this brilliant Government and its brilliant industrial relations system, we had turned the corner. But look at what the Government's Budget tells us we are going to get this year. The people of Australia will get a 7 per cent income increase-that is the Government's figure-and inflation will be 7 1/2 per cent. So, once again, we continue down the track.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have opposed every wage increase in the last five years. Every increase in the last five years was opposed by Senator Chaney.

—My caterwauling little opponent, Senator Button, who is not prepared to take part in this debate-he is prepared to sit in this chamber and shout-ignores the fact that the Government has delivered declining real wages to Australia. He keeps telling us that this is because of good economic management and because the Government is saving Australia. Look at what has been achieved at the same time: this country owed about $30 billion overseas and now it owes $110 billion. At the same time as our living standards have declined, this Government has put us into hock by another $80 billion. In other words, this country has Third World status under this Government and it is steadily getting worse. That is why the Opposition is contemptuous of the failure of the accord and the failure of this Government's industrial relations policy. The key reason why the people of Australia are feeling poorer, why their living standards are declining and, at the same time, why they are getting deeper into debt, is that there is no productivity increase in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the official figures-not some figures brought out by the Liberal Party of Australia or by the National Party of Australia-published by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) we find that, while other countries have increased their productivity, ours is declining. The figure given by the OECD for total factor productivity for Australia over the three years 1987 to 1990 is minus 0.2 per cent. Each Australian is producing less instead of producing more and that is why we say the accord is a straitjacket. This country is going down the tube because it cannot lift its productivity under the regime which has been imposed by this Government. Look at the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics brought out in the Australian national accounts in just this year:

Labour productivity estimates continue to show very little change from 1984-85 base year, with the trend estimate of GDP per hour worked declining by 0.1 per cent for the March quarter 1989 and GDP per employed person declining by 0.9 per cent.

That is what is happening in Australia. We are going backwards, not forwards. Principally, that is because of the industrial relations system and the working of the blessed accord, which we are continually being told is such a marvellous addition to Australia.

In this morning's Australian Financial Review there is an excellent article about the impact of the Government's superannuation and savings policies. On the editorial page, one finds a description of what is happening to productivity. The report says:
The Australian Chamber of Manufactures predicts labour productivity will barely improve at all over the next two fiscal years.
By contrast, Japanese labour productivity has soared, climbing at 4.8 per cent a year in the decade up to 1985. It is still rising by more than 3 per cent a year.
The article finishes by saying this:

If Australia's labour productivity curve doesn't make an amazing change for the better, before long Australian industry will be back to where it was before the last devaluation: out of the race and stumbling.

Australian industry will be stumbling like the Minister at the table, Senator Button, who raises his hands in the air and says, `I don't know what to do'. That is Senator Button's contribution to getting Australia out of its present difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a lie.

—He does not involve himself in the debate; he just sits there shouting, trying to stop the Opposition putting its views. The central core point around which this whole debate revolves is the failure of Australia to make way when the countries around us are progressing at an amazing rate. The truth is that our inflexible, failed accord lies at the heart of that problem. This difficulty we have with our airlines is just one symptom of the malaise, one of the reasons why Australians have turned against the accord, and why an article in the Sydney Morning Herald this week is headlined `The Accord gets the thumbs down'.

SPEECH.PARA: The unions themselves doubt the system. The trade union movement has not yet accepted the national wage case. Week after week the unions beaver away trying to work out whether they can get rises they believe are necessary under the national wage case. There is no commitment as yet from the trade union movement to the Industrial Relations Commission and its decision on the national wage case.

This whole dispute exemplifies the bureaucratic approach of the Government, the typically Australian gun-at-the-head approach which has been adopted by the airline pilots and which is totally rejected by the Opposition, but which flows from the bureaucratic straitjacket that the Australian work force finds itself in. We find a hindering of sensible negotiations by the Government and behaviour by the Prime Minister which is quite extraordinary-his abuse of the participants and his discouragement of effective negotiations; and, of course, his holding out the offer of Government money, taxpayers' money, to his mates in the airlines so that they can follow the Government's wishes in this matter and prolong the negotiating process. We have seen the Ministers, including Senator Button, squirming in the Senate during the course of this week. They know that it is unconscionable that only the airlines should be given compensation in a dispute which is smashing the tourism industry of Australia, large and small business alike; yet this bunch of bandits is prepared to say that the only people who will get consideration in this matter are the airlines and to hell with those Australians who are suffering from its failure of policy.

The ultimate irony coming from the Australian Labor Party, from the people who supposedly defend the centralised wage fixing system, is that when this dispute commenced and we said, `If you want the system to work, go back to what Mr Willis said in 1987: you cannot have an effective system without effective compliance provisions', once again the Government was not prepared to give the centralised system teeth. There is no consistency in the Government's approach. On the one hand, it will not give the centralised system the teeth which would give the Industrial Relations Commission some authority. The only authority it offers it is the bully-boy tactics of the trade union movement. It refused that, and yet it goes ahead now and adopts one element of our policy and says that it will embrace sanctions outside the centralised wage fixing system. This dispute is typical of what is wrong with Australia-gun-at-the-head industrial negotiation, huge damage being done to the Australian economy and the Government offering no reasonable way out. The Government's handling of this is completely wrong: abusive, prolonging the negotiation process and grossly inconsistent.

I remind the Minister and the next speaker of the inconsistencies of the Government: support for the centralised system, but no support for effective compliance provisions; years of rejection of the use of the common law; and years of rejection of the Trade Practices Act. How many times in this Senate have we had to vote to defend the provisions of the Trade Practices Act against the Labor Party's attempt to repeal it? How many times has the Labor Party come out and said that the worst thing for trying to settle an industrial dispute is the use of sanctions and penalties? In a debate in this chamber a few weeks ago, Senator Aulich, in one of the few things he has said in this chamber that have ever been quoted, reaffirmed Labor Party policy in that respect. What did the Government do a few days later? It turned around and embraced the whole proposal that there should be the use of sanctions in the common law and the Trade Practices Act. Of course, when we said that it would be a valuable addition to the industrial relations system of Australia that we move to a system of direct contracts, what did the Labor Party say? Year after year it rejected that as an approach to industrial relations; now it is embracing one other shred of our policy to try to find its way out of the dilemma in which it finds itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have got no answers.

—That is patently clear. Our approach is to change the framework so that employers and employees are encouraged to work together. But our framework is not in place. The framework in place is the Government's legal framework which was legislated last year over our objections, with the Government rejecting all our amendments. This dispute is taking place under its legal framework, under the accord. None of that has been changed or can be changed by the Opposition, and the travail that Australia is going through at the moment with this airline dispute is a travail that is completely within the framework of the Government's administration and industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: When the airline pilots were still within the centralised system, what was our suggestion? We offered the Government the capacity to change the law to put some genuine compliance into the system; the Government refused. When they went outside the system, what was our response? We said yes, legal sanctions could be used. We supported that, as we always have at Mudginberri, at Dollar Sweets and all these great disputes. The Government suddenly changed its mind. We said weeks ago that what the Government should be doing is encouraging constructive discussions between the airlines and the pilots on the basis of gaining productivity increases which would enable the pilots to get a sizeable rise and the airlines to share in the benefits of that productivity increase. It has taken weeks for that move to get any support from the Government, and even then the Government has done nothing to encourage its own airline, Australian Airlines, to move to the forefront of this dispute. The Government is terrified that its own accord will be threatened and is terrified of a wages breakout.

I repeat: the positive outcome for Australia and the positive option for this dispute is not a wages breakout but a productivity breakout. It is clear that there is a capacity for the pilots to greatly increase their productivity. It is clear that there is a capacity for some of that productivity gain to be shared with the pilots and still leave the airlines in a more competitive position.

There are lots of red herrings in this debate. What is the role of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots? We say that it is no business of the Government's what the role of the Federation is. It is no business of anybody except the airline pilots. We have said that there should be negotiations between the pilots and their employers. We say that that is the central fact and that whether the pilots choose to use agents or choose to have a union is for the pilots and not for the Government or politicians. That is a matter which the Government should leave alone. We think the pilots should be free to decide who, if anyone, represents them. The airlines, in their turn, should be free to deal with the pilots or the Federation, as they wish. We do not believe there should be a restriction on the freedom to enter into contracts. We believe that those restrictions are properly imposed by the competitive pressures that are going to be and must be applied to the airlines. The Opposition has made it clear that not only does it support the deregulation of the airlines but also it supports the consideration of continued interlining so that there will be continuous economic pressures and non-economic decisions can be made.

By agreement between the parties, the speaking time in this one-hour debate in which four people wish to participate will be restricted. Let me make clear what I see as the essentials of the Opposition's position. We do not support the pilots and their gun-at-the-head tactics. We do not support the Government's inflammation of this dispute. Most of all, we do not support the system which has led to both the conflict and the impasse. We reject the failures of the accord and the failures of the Government's whole approach to industrial relations. What we do support is negotiation on a win-win basis-the productivity breakout which will enable pilots to be better off and which will demonstrate to the whole of the Australian work force that there is a constructive alternative to Labor's declining living standards. We do support sanctions. If rules are broken inside or outside the system there should be proper sanctions and penalties. I hope that, in light of his Prime Minister's change of mind, Senator Aulich might recant his rejection of sanctions in the last debate in which he participated.

Finally, we support the full use of all available strike-breaking methods. We congratulate the Government for accepting that strike-breaking is legitimate, even by using the armed forces as they are being used in this case. We think the stifling of an essential service such as an airline service is properly met by the use of the full force of government to try to ease the pain of the Australian people. It is time we threw out the accord and the industrial relations approach of the Government and adopted the approach that is advocated by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy Presi- dent--
—Do up your tie.

—It was done up before Senator Chaney spoke but the parliamentary representatives of the New Right and the H.R. Nicholls Society have performed so badly in this debate that I thought it was appropriate to fly my H.R. Nicholls Society tie at half-mast. I think this is the fifth attempt that Senator Chaney has had to put on record the Opposition's position in this airline pilots dispute and the current action being taken by the Australian federation of air pirates. He has failed again to do so. He has called on Senator Aulich to recant his rejection of sanctions. A good place for Senator Chaney to start would be to call upon the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) to recant his rejection of sanctions because the Leader of the Opposition has specifically done so. We have to give Senator Chaney full marks for his cheek in raising this matter of public importance. He has certainly decided to be brazen in terms of the wording of this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: On the subject of inconsistency, I would like to quote-and very little of this has been canvassed in the Parliament to date-what Senator Chaney's Leader, the Leader of the Opposition, has said on the question of the Opposition's industrial relations policy in respect of the actions currently being taken by the Australian federation of air pirates. Before doing so, I will read a couple of other quotes of what has been said by the Leader of the Opposition. On 23 August this year Mr Peacock said:
The pilots campaign is completely unjustified, a powerful trade union holding a loaded gun at the head of employers.
That is true; I agree with that. On 25 August he said:
It is a classic case where you've got to go beyond the employer-employee fight and look after the national interest and the Government is correct.
Perhaps Senator Chaney should refer to that. On 31 August-this is from the first of two separate interviews given on the same day-he said:
. . . now and the national interest demands that the Prime Minister work to get those parties together and the Opposition has been calling upon him to do just that . . .
In a second interview on the same day he said:
There is not a role in this dispute for the Government. In fact this is one of the requirements that Australia needs for governments to stay out of disputes.

Senator Chaney has the hide to come in here and talk about consistency. The Leader of the Opposition gave a most extraordinary major press conference on where the Opposition stood on this airline pilots dispute and what its industrial relations policy was. If Senator Chaney is looking for consistency, he should not look there. At that press conference a journalist asked Mr Peacock the following final question:
In 3/4 of an hour you have not yet given us one specific answer on how the dispute . . . can be resolved.
Mr Peacock replied:

I'll wait . . . we have spent the majority of the time interestingly enough and if I might say it is an interesting example of some of you at work of questioning me of what we would do if we were in government. That is fair enough and I think I'm reasonable in answering and I've indicated the way we would handle the matter in government. But the reality is we are not in government. Something you seem to overlook.
I do not think anyone would overlook that. He continued:

But when you say to me you've not given me a plausible answer as to how you would settle this dispute today. To settle that dispute today operating in the system that belongs to the Government I have said to you there should be a sanctions power there.
At the conclusion of the press conference he said:

I would have been operating in a system where there was a sanctions power to compel them to stop the dispute but this government has walked away from each and every element of that . . . That is succinct and to the point and very different to the Government. I really must go to the next meeting. Thank you.

I would have gone to the next meeting too if I had delivered a performance as bad as that. I refer to pages 10 and 11 of the transcript of that same press conference where, in respect of sanctions, Mr Peacock is reported as saying:
. . . you don't fix some artificial limit in negotiation between politician and representatives of the union movement, you leave this to the enterprise.
The transcript continues:
JOURNALIST: So you're saying that's the only sanction, the market forces are the only sanction?
PEACOCK: Well, it's a pretty real sanction.
JOURNALIST: But are you saying that you wouldn't impose any other sanction?
PEACOCK: No, I wouldn't be imposing sanctions.

I give people the right to go before the Commission or a court and argue this is right, this is wrong, if they can establish their locus standi. But, the reality is, the real constraint on them is the economy itself and . . . the market.
In the same press conference he contradicted himself categorically.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a total misrepresentation. That's not a sanction in that sense.
—The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate wants to know whether we can perhaps clarify--
—That's a total misrepresentation, Collins, and you know it.
—All right, let Mr Peacock clarify this misrepresentation. In order to put this confusion to bed, let me quote Mr Peacock again. In terms of the Opposition's policy, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, the Act spells out a whole variety of interested persons and well, any other registered organisation could state a case, it may well not be accepted. But the reality is the legislation gives you the power to enter into these voluntary arrangements provided the wage increases are offset by increases in productivity. Now what will, in fact, happen, I mean, the real determinant is not whether someone will state a case and seek to argue that they have some right under the legislation. You know what'll happen, the company will go broke. That company will go broke if it enters into some wage arrangement that is not offset by productivity and that's its decision. I mean, if it wants to commit economic suicide, I mean, the real constraint is not some party seeking to go before the Commission, albeit that others could, albeit that others could. I mean, you can always seek to, some form of locus standi. Whether the Commission or a court will give it to you, whether you designate people to have that right, at the end of the day, the real constraint on the company that enters into some arrangement is not offset by productivity is that it walks over the cliff.

That clarifies entirely the position of the Opposition on this question. Senator Alston has an absolute hide to suggest that anyone could possibly misrepresent this collection of absolute gibberish which purports to be, courtesy of his Leader, the position of the Opposition on its industrial relations policy and how it would solve the airline pilots dispute.

In the same press conference his Leader says first of all that he will have sanctions and then he says that he will not have them. Then we get a statement from the Leader of the Opposition about whether he is going to have some sort of central system. He then goes on to say that he will have a system but even if people opt out of the system the sanctions will follow them. He absolutely confirms that to the disbelief of the journalists present. He says that the sanctions will still operate even when people opt out of the system. He says further in the same press conference-and time prevents me from quoting more of it, unfortunately-that, in fact, the sanctions will not follow people if they opt out of the system. He was completely unable to give anyone a sensible answer as to what determined whether people opted in or out of the system. The fact is that the Opposition has performed absolutely abysmally in its contribution to what is potentially one of the most serious industrial disputes that this nation has seen. Almost every member on the Opposition front bench adopts a different position when speaking on the subject. They have absolutely confused this issue with respect to their policies to the extent that their Leader in a single press conference contradicted himself about 50 times on the major elements that underlie this dispute.

Perhaps I was a bit hard on the Leader of the Opposition the other day when I accused him of not being able to follow a consistent position publicly, because he really does have his work cut out for him in having the job at the end of the day of coordinating and explaining away all the contradictory statements on any policy, including this one, that are issued by the various members of his front bench. I think it was very apt to quote Bonar Law the other day. I said then that he had the same trouble with his colleagues when he uttered these immortal words in 1912, `Of course, I must follow them; I am their leader'. In that sense, Mr Peacock certainly has problems. Mr Peacock does not need the collection he has on the front bench to contradict each other to cause himself a problem: he does a pretty good job by himself.

The fact is that in respect of the current dispute the Government always wanted the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to negotiate for its increase within the centralised wage fixing system. The reality is that the Federation could have done that in precisely the same way Senator Chaney put forward when he concluded his speech. The pilots would have had the opportunity within that system to negotiate for productivity increases. The fact is that they chose not to do that. They chose to behave like the industrial thugs they have always behaved like since 1959. As I said before, the then President of their Federation, when introducing the Minister for Civil Aviation to the Federation's conference in 1966, said, `This Federation is unique; we can do anything we like'. That has consistently been the attitude of the Federation. We should not forget-as people seem to be forgetting-the major agenda item. It is not simply the 30 per cent wage increase. It is, as it has always been, to get out of the system-not just the government system; any system, including the Opposition's system. The Opposition, of course, chooses to ignore that.

The airline pilots have always considered themselves to be a law unto themselves, a special elite group that can hold this country to ransom. As I pointed out the other day, the difficulty is that the major difference between the airline pilots disputes of the 1950s, the 1960s and now is that the aviation industry in this country has reached such a point of pre-eminence-in the exercise of commerce, our balance of trade and our export earnings, with tourism now being our major export earner-that the realities of the aviation industry in terms of 1,600 people being able to hold this country to ransom can no longer be ignored.

As a senator for the Northern Territory, I say again that perhaps it is time that this Government, or any future government, had a very close look at its future relationship with that small group of people who have a technological stranglehold on their industry and a capacity to bring this country very quickly to its knees. It is no good ignoring the fact that they have a capacity that is not possessed by any other group of workers of their size. They have the capacity to cause major economic damage to Australia because of their bloody-minded pursuit of absolutely intolerable wage claims. There is nothing new about that. They have always behaved in that way. Therefore, what is different about the current dispute? It is not the inconsistencies of the Government's position that have caused the problem. The problem for the Australian Federation of Air Pilots is that this Government has been far too consistent for it, as have the airlines. The standover and blackmail tactics that the Federation has always used in the past have not worked to this point. The Government will not cave in to the totally outrageous demands of this small group of blackmailers- and that is what they are-in the way the Opposition wants the Government to do. I am glad to say that to this point in time neither have the airlines. As I said before, the history of this union is the reason that its members behave like bloody-minded bastards. There are two good reasons for that. The first is that they have always behaved like that and the second is that they have always won.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not know whether Senator Collins has had the opportunity to read the release by Senator Vanstone yesterday, but I draw his attention to those in the public gallery behind him who have presumably come along here today to get some idea of the calibre of parliamentary debate. Whether or not that term is unparliamentary, I would have thought he would have had the decency to refrain from using it in those circumstances.
—I believe that the expression is in common usage.
—So are a lot of other words in your vocabulary.
—Order!

—I would like to finish what I was saying. I had some reservations about using the expression in here even though it is a common colloquial expression. I checked with some people the other day and declined to use it. But having heard Senator Tambling use it in the chamber with absolute impunity only three days ago, I thought that obviously the rules had changed. Perhaps Senator Alston should have a word with the National Party Whip.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask for your ruling as to whether it is an acceptable parliamentary term in these circumstances. The only explanation given by Senator Collins is that someone else seems to have regarded it as acceptable. I simply invite you to rule that in these circumstances what Senator Collins says is unacceptable.
—I withdraw if the honourable senator finds the term offensive.
—Thank you, Senator Collins.

—One thing I must say is this: if the honourable senator thinks that is an unreasonable term to apply to the damage that is being done to this country by this small group, I have to say that because of the absolute lack of obvious consideration and concern that those 1,600 people have for the 21,000 fellow workers in their industry that are likely to be on the scrap heap very shortly and the hundreds of thousands of people involved in Australia's tourist and service industries that are bleeding to death-they are certainly bleeding to death in the Northern Territory-it will be a very long time indeed before their fellow Australians forgive them, if they ever do, for the attitude they are showing currently.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the airline pilots Federation could go back into the system that operates successfully and has operated successfully in this country for the last seven years. It could negotiate on top of what it conceded in the memorandum it issued to its members last year was `the best system of wages and conditions in the world for airline pilots'. Despite the fact that it has already said that, it could go back to that system and negotiate a further increase based on productivity. That is precisely what the Government urges it to do and it is precisely what I am urging it to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are speaking today on a matter of public importance put forward by Senator Chaney, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failures and inconsistencies of the Government's industrial relations policy as demonstrated by the pilots' dispute.

I begin by noting the apparent readiness expressed by Senator Collins, who has just ceased speaking, to shed every last drop of the Australian tourism industry's blood in the interests of maintaining the dogmatic position taken up by his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by the Government in this matter. The position just stated by Senator Collins is that it does not matter how long this dispute goes on, the Government will stick to the same position that it began with, namely that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots is to be crushed. Senator Collins also said or implied that it does not matter if the tourist industry bleeds to death in the process.

I will consider first the failures of the Government's industrial relations policy as demonstrated by the pilots dispute. There is no doubt about the failures. Even before the pilots dispute, we had the air traffic controllers in Sydney holding the country to ransom as a result of the total incapacity under the rigid guidelines of the accord to do anything different. Now we understand-because of press reports published in the last few days-that a shonky deal is being cooked up between the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) and the air traffic controllers in Sydney, whereby they will get an increase in their emoluments which goes well beyond what one had understood to be the guidelines laid down in the recent Industrial Relations Commission judgment. I make no comment about that other than point out the total failure of the accord, as demonstrated in that instance.

At about the same time a disgraceful situation was developing with Qantas Airways Ltd aircraft maintenance engineers. I remind the Senate that for some years Qantas maintenance engineers, who are extremely well- qualified technical people, had serviced foreign aircraft in this country. But under the rigid guidelines of the accord-within this procrustean bed into which the accord has chained the wages system of this country-Qantas was unable to pay its aircraft maintenance engineers the wages that were required to be paid to keep them in the jobs. What is the result of that? It is twofold. First of all, Qantas is no longer able to service foreign aircraft in this country because it no longer has enough aircraft maintenance engineers to do so. Secondly, Qantas aircraft themselves are now being serviced overseas in Hong Kong and Singapore. As a matter of fact, in both places they are being serviced in some cases by the very same people who previously serviced them here because they are now working in Hong Kong and Singapore.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another victory for the accord!

—Another victory for the accord, as Senator Chaney quite rightly says. In the last few days baggage handlers in Sydney-I think they belong to the Transport Workers Union-went out to demonstrate that under this accord they are not satisfied either. They will make a little trouble in due course and they will give the accord a bit of a flick across the wrist in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look now at the pilots themselves. About 10 days ago the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, said that if the pilots would only be reasonable they too could get more than they could under the accord. They too could get 12 per cent, he said, compared with the 6 per cent they are supposed to get under the accord. Mr Morris was inviting these people to do a shonky deal-in his terms, that is the only way one could describe it because, after all, he is supposed to be supporting the accord-and to get twice the amount laid down under this arrangement. The pilots did not accept that position, and I do not blame them.

Let us go on to the more general point about the Government's failures. The failures of this Government's industrial relations policy constitute one of the two major reasons why Mr Hawke has flung himself into this dispute so violently and in such an inflammatory manner from the very outset. The other major reason-but I do not propose to take time on it-is to support his friend Sir Peter Abeles and Ansett Airlines of Australia, but we will pass that by.

Mr Hawke has flung himself into this dispute in a frantic attempt to prop up his failed accord and to prop up the personal standing and position of Mr Bill Kelty, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, who used to be known as the sorcerer's apprentice. I think today Mr Hawke is Mr Kelty's apprentice and that role reversal is evident for all to see. We all know who is running the country: it is Mr Kelty. If ever there was an apprentice, it is our present Prime Minister.

Have a look at what Mr Padraic McGuinness said in a sparkling article in this morning's Australian newspaper. In writing about the extraordinary conduct of the Prime Minister in this matter, Mr McGuinness said:
. . . in the last couple of weeks the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, has done himself immense political harm, and may well be mortally wounded.
Mr McGuinness went on to say:
. . . never has the Prime Minister looked so bad.
There is no doubt that Bob Hawke has handled this crisis appallingly badly.

From his initial abuse of the pilots, to the aggressive and increasingly irrational way in which he has defended government policy, to the total abandonment of any semblance of principle with respect to the rights of associations of employees, he has shown himself to be totally rattled and out of control of the situation.
He has made it quite clear that when it comes to a crunch he does not believe that any limits should be placed on the disciplinary measures that can be taken against unions.
There is disturbing evidence in all this that Mr Hawke is out of control.
His abusiveness and hysteria have made any careful consideration of the issues impossible.
Mr McGuinness concluded this aspect of his remarks by saying:
It seems impossible that Mr Hawke can emerge from the pilots' dispute with his reputation for responsibility and reasonably sensible behaviour in his job untarnished.

Amen to that! Let us come to the second part of the matter of public importance raised by Senator Chaney-the question of the inconsistencies within the Government's present policies. If the failures are obvious, that is nothing compared to the obviousness of the inconsistencies demonstrated in the pilots dispute. Let us look at just a few of these inconsistencies; I probably will not have time to talk about all of them.

First of all, we have a Prime Minister who only three years ago described the H. R. Nicholls Society as being made up of, I think he said, economic troglodytes and political illiterates. I am going to ask Senator Collins to send the Prime Minister the H. R. Nicholls Society tie that he has been good enough to wear here today so that the Prime Minister can put it on. I am very glad to see that the Prime Minister has taken on a great many of the Society's policies. We will hold him to them in due course when we are in office. When disputes of this or other kinds take place when we are in government we will hold Mr Hawke and the Australian Labor Party to the policies that he is now so busily espousing.

That is the first little bit of inconsistency on Mr Hawke's part. However, I am bound to say that I welcome that aspect. But what is Mr Hawke doing now? He is supporting use of the common law in industrial disputes. I welcome that. But do honourable senators remember what Mr Hawke said about the use of the common law when it was being invoked in, for example, the Dollar Sweets case? He regarded it as outrageous. Indeed, this Government, when it brought forward its Industrial Relations Bill only nine months or so ago, actually wanted to outlaw the use of the common law in industrial relations disputes. Now the Government is busy encouraging its use. What an extraordinary flip-flop in policy on the part of your Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —And yours too.

—No, not my Prime Minister. I will take a lot, but I will not take that. The Prime Minister also supports the use of sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act. Do honourable senators remember what he said about that when those sections were being so successfully invoked in the famous Mudginberri case? They remember what he said about that. The Prime Minister has moved with lightning speed to have the Industrial Relations Commission cancel the air pilots award. Compare that with the snail's pace of his action in relation to the Builders Labourers Federation. Indeed, compare the snail's pace of the action-indeed, there was no action at all-to clean up the restrictive practices, overmanning and general featherbedding on our waterfront.

SPEECH.PARA: Another inconsistency, on past performance, is the Prime Minister inviting international airlines to carry domestic passengers between Australian capital cities. I welcome that very much. At least a few passengers are being carried around the country. But this is totally inconsistent with anything the Government has said previously-with what Senator Evans used to say when he was Minister for Transport and Communications, for example. The Prime Minister has enthusiastically applauded the bringing in of charter aircraft from abroad and foreign pilots to break the dispute. Let me make it quite clear that I do not object to any of those measures; I am just talking about the inconsistencies of this Government's policy.

Compare these attitudes with the Government's attitude to our coastal shipping or trans-Tasman shipping shambles. When are we going to hear the Prime Minister talk about the need to bring in foreign ships to operate along our coastlines or across the Tasman? When will the Government propose bringing in foreign crews to crew Australian ships on the Australian coast? That situation is exactly comparable with that in the airlines today. We would welcome that just as much as we welcome what has been done in respect of the airlines. Hurry on the day! Let us be quite clear about the inconsistencies which the actions of the Prime Minister-to the dismay of his colleagues and his own party room-are bringing about. We have seen the Prime Minister bring in the troops-the Royal Australian Air Force-to break the strike. Now that is okay too. When the Prime Minister, as we look forward to him doing, actually does something about the waterfront and provokes a strike on the wharves, I trust he will bring in the troops to deal with the Waterside Workers Federation in just the same way.

This is to say nothing about the total confusion and inconsistencies which have arisen over the matter of so-called compensation-or, as I see the Prime Minister prefers to call it, recompense. The Macquarie Dictionary defines compensation as meaning recompense, and recompense as meaning compensation, but the Prime Minister appears to find them totally different. He says we must not talk about them being the same thing; it is quite wrong to do that. Madam Acting Deputy President, you would be defying the Prime Minister if you said that. You would not do a thing like that. It is hard to follow the Prime Minister's logic in this matter, so I will be very careful to get it straight. The fact of the matter is that the Prime Minister has been trying to draw what Michelle Grattan in this morning's Age called a `nonsense distinction'-she could have used a harsher word, but she is a gentle woman and I understand her restraint in this matter-between giving recompense to the airlines for not standing people down, because Bill Kelty says they cannot, and not giving recompense to the tourist industry, where many people have actually been stood down. Those people, and many others who might be stood down but have not been yet, will not be recompensed. I find it a little difficult to follow that, but I have no doubt that at some stage the Prime Minister will explain it to his party room. I hope his party room will find it more intelligible than I do.

I have one final question. I have noticed throughout this dispute that Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd (TNT) shares on the market have not fallen. Why is that? Why do our share markets not assume that TNT will make a large loss out of this matter-Ansett Airlines of Australia being a subsidiary of TNT-and that the value of TNT shares will depreciate? Why have our financial markets not assumed that? What do they know that we do not? What has Ansett Airlines told the markets that we have not been told publicly?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Stone, your time has expired. I call Senator Aulich.
—Tell us the principle. The principle is: if you are a unionist you get compensation; if you are a small business you don't. Is that how it works?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not incredible that I have not said even one word in this debate and Senator Alston is already displaying his bad manners and ignorance by interjecting? I cannot believe it. He should wait until I have finished my speech, from which he will be able to learn something.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is once again debating a motion by Senator Chaney criticising the Government for its handling of industrial relations in this country and, in this particular case, the airline pilots dispute. This has not been a good fortnight for Senator Chaney. He has had more kicks from this side of the House over this issue than Peter Hudson on a good day. In the last week in his own party room he has been given the boot on a number of occasions by people such as Senator Knowles and others, who have accused him of being muddled and confused in his thinking about industrial relations.

We feel sympathetic. We know that Senator Chaney has a problem in this area in that he has to keep rolling up the same old policy that was proved to be a failure even before the Opposition parties managed to make it to government. In addition, he has had the problem on his hands of spokespersons on behalf of his party, from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) to the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt), making statements which have been totally contradictory on this issue. I know it is difficult because, on the one hand, the Opposition has a policy which is inadequate to deal with this issue and, on the other hand, its members are trying to interpret it in various ways.

The contradictory statements have come, first, from Senator Chaney's Leader, Mr Peacock; secondly, from his trusted former Leader, John Howard; and thirdly, from his very close friend and admirer, Senator Stone. Senator Chaney has been in the middle of contradictory statements made by people who probably cannot hold a candle to him in terms of competency. At the same time, Senator Chaney has proved, on any number of occasions in this chamber, that his theoretical views on industrial relations are not bad. But when it comes down to practicalities-to trying to work out what to do in the middle of a massive industrial dispute which is destroying this nation's economy, which is destroying its tourist industry, which is leaving ordinary travellers stranded around the country, and which will leave 21,000 people unemployed if something is not done soon-Senator Chaney is not in the picture.

To a large extent it is because his Party is moving towards solving industrial relations problems in this country through an almost total reliance upon the notion of collective bargaining-free enterprise bargaining, letting the marketplace decide and allowing employers and employees to sort things out between themselves. Unfortunately, what has happened is that the airline industry and the pilots have done just that, and we have seen the results. We have a policy put forward by the Liberal Party which says, `Go and sort it out yourselves. We would like to see voluntary agreements made in the marketplace between employers and employees'. But when they do it Senator Chaney panics, because he knows, like everyone else, that collective bargaining does not work.

The Government has told Senator Chaney in this chamber on any number of occasions, the employers in the community have told him, the unions have told him and people within his own party such as Ian Macphee, who was a very good Minister for Industrial Relations, have told him that collective bargaining will not work. Yet what has happened? He has looked at the overseas examples. He has seen just how collective bargaining has failed in the United States of America and the United Kingdom-seven-month strikes in the coal industry, transport industry problems and airline employees taken away in chains in the United States. That has been the product of people moving outside a system such as we have in this country; a controlled, centralised wage fixing system which has served this country well for the last 90 years or so.

Yet what does Senator Chaney do? He wants to borrow a fantastic idea straight from the American and British systems and try to apply it to Australian conditions. The airline pilots are applying it for Senator Chaney, and they are showing how badly off his policy is in dealing with the practicalities of solving industrial disputes in this country. We have told him once, and we have told him before, and the whole of the industrial relations community has given him that message, yet he still has not learned. He must be punch drunk. He would be out on a technical knockout if he were in the boxing ring. He would be taken away. He will not learn. He comes in here for the fifth time in two weeks proposing collective bargaining as a solution for Australia's industrial relations problems. What a farce. Yet he has Senator Stone, Andrew Peacock, Ian Macphee and John Howard all contradicting him. What is this man to do to make the industrial relations policy of the Opposition credible? He cannot. That is why he may be moving to the House of Representatives some time after the next election.

I will quote some examples to show where those in the leadership of the Liberal Party are totally at odds with each other. The people of Australia have a right to know where the Liberal Party stands on industrial relations, where it stands on this issue. Let me quote what Andrew Peacock said on the AM program on 25 August 1989. I cannot put on his voice; nobody can. That takes years of practising before a mirror, but--

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is against Standing Orders.
—And it is against Standing Orders. Andrew Peacock said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's a classic case where you've got to go beyond the employer-employee fight and look after the national interest. And the Government is correct.
On the 7.30 Report on 22 August 1989 Senator Chaney totally contradicted his Leader when he said:
The pilots and the employers could, I believe, work out a better arrangement than they've got at present. That's up to them.
Ian Macphee, the former industrial relations Minister, in a major speech to the Victorian employers on 29 August, said:
It is hard to see room for collective bargaining in Australia.

I have given three examples of leaders of the Opposition, in some forum or another, contradicting themselves over this major issue. Where does the Government stand on this issue? Let us make it quite clear: we do not believe that industrial relations will be solved totally in the courts. We accept that common law action in the courts--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! Common ground.

—Listen carefully, Senator Chaney, because you are a slow learner. I will repeat it: first, we do not believe that access to the courts, constant running to the courts to solve industrial disputes, should be the rule of the day in industrial relations. In exceptional cases, recourse to the courts may be necessary. But an industrial relations system cannot be run on that basis. Secondly, industrial relations is not just about what goes on in the Industrial Relations Commission with the lawyers and the official representatives. It is about relationships created in the community between employers, employees, organisations representing them, and the government of the day. That special relationship has basically been the accord, which symbolises that special relationship that has grown over the last eight years or so. It has been improved upon and it has been made flexible to deal with changes in the economic situation to try to improve Australia's competitiveness in the world situation after 20 years or so of hiding behind the walls of tariff barriers and so on that Australia has built around itself.

SPEECH.PARA: What must be acknowledged in this House and has been acknowledged out in the community at large is that the trade union movement has lifted its game tremendously. It has worked with the Government and with employers. In a sense, the accord has paid the unions back for the responsible approach that they have taken. No-one elsewhere in the world, with a few exceptions of people so used to the collective bargaining principles of their countries, who has studied the improvement of industrial relations in this country could criticise the operations of the accord. The only people who so criticise it are people such as Senator Alston on the other side, who was employed by employers in the bad old days when they lost time after time, when they gave in to the toughest unions, the most strategically placed unions, the standover unions. It was people such as Senator Alston who in the end went to water and who gave us the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF), the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) and those standover merchants who have used their political and industrial muscle to strangle this country.

It was this Government-not those opposite-that deregistered the BLF, a union, because it was not operating properly within the system. It is this Government that has taken on the Air Pilots Federation-the air pirates, as my colleague Senator Collins has called them. This Government has said, `Enough is enough. You are a strong union. You are a union strategically placed to bring this country to its knees but you are not going to bring this country to its knees. You will be stood up to for the first time in 20 or 30 years'. And this Government did it. It was long overdue and we do not apologise for the tactics that this Government has used or that the employers in this airline industry have used to bring that union into line. We did it-a government that those opposite accuse of being soft on the union movement. We have said, `We will run a centralised, orderly industrial relations system'. And we have insisted that it be run in an orderly way. Those that step outside it, in the way that the Federation pilots have done, supported by the Liberal Party of Australia, will get their comeuppance not only in the marketplace but also in other places.

They have gone out into the marketplace to improve conditions and wages that are already some of the best in the world. In fact, they were described by one of the pilots' key officers as `the' best in the world. They have gone out into the marketplace-and boy, have they gone into the marketplace! They have kicked the barrows over, kicked the owners of the barrows out, driven the customers away, knocked the vegetables around the marketplace; they have destroyed the marketplace not only for us and the tourist industry but also for themselves. This Government has said, `Enough is enough'. We have had the courage to take them on. We do not resile from any of the tactics that have been used with this recalcitrant, arrogant union.

If honourable members want to know about their arrogance, they ought to go back to the very early days when Mr Swartz became Minister for Civil Aviation. To indicate the arrogance of that union I will once again read what Captain R. Holt, President of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots-the very organisation holding this country to ransom-said when welcoming the then Liberal Minister for Civil Aviation, Mr Swartz, to the AFAP convention in 1967. Not much has changed with the Air Pilots Federation since then. In front of the press and his members he said:
This Federation has an industrial strength that is unique. We can do anything that we like-we can do anything lawful that we like.

He gave that message to the people of Australia and the government of the day in front of the Minister. It has taken until now to get a government in office that would take on the Builders Labourers Federation, that would restructure industrial relations to benefit the economy and everyone and future generations, and that has now taken on the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. Those opposite have stood back tacitly supporting them; we have taken them on. This is the fifth occasion on which those opposite have come into this place to defend the notion of collective bargaining and the pirates of the Federation of Air Pilots. Those opposite have fallen down in such a way that Senator Chaney, who has had so many kicks this week, ought to retire to the party room and make peace with those that have tried to stand over him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate on the matter of public importance has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of something urgent that has come up since Question Time, I seek the indulgence of the Senate to address a question through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to the President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the President through you: Has he received a letter from the Office of the Auditor-General setting out untruths in the documents submitted by the Aboriginal Development Commission to support its estimates now before the Senate? If so, when was it received? Will the President make it available to honourable senators to enable them better to prepare for the Estimates exercise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. During the heat of the debate on the matter of public importance, Senator Collins claimed that I had used the same unacceptable phrase that he used-`bloody-minded bastards'. I have certainly never used that phrase in this Parliament. In fact, the phrase that Senator Collins may have been alluding to was in the debate on the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill on 1 September, when I said the following:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Minister got himself into strife last year, because he made the wrong appointments to the Commission, who in turn engaged in this bastardry, then we should transfer the responsibility straight back to the Minister.

I draw the Senate's attention and Senator Collins's attention to the definition in the Macquarie Dictionary relating to bastard, which reads: `illegitimate child: something irregular, inferior, spurious, or unusual; an unpleasant or despicable person'-amongst other descriptions. The way that I used the word `bastard' certainly fits this last definition. I also draw to Senator Collins's attention the other definition, which reads: `of abnormal or irregular shape or size; of unusual make or proportions'. I ask Senator Collins to get his act into shape.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)-by leave-proposed:
That notwithstanding anything contained in the Sessional Orders, the hours of meeting of the Senate on Thursday, 7 September 1989, be 10 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. and 8 p.m. to 10.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Opposition will oppose this motion. I thank the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) for moving it because had he not done so by leave now I think we would have been debating the motion retrospectively after the adjournment. I assume he would have had to negative the adjournment question and we would have been in something of a shambles. I acknowledge the Minister's sense in bringing the matter on now.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion actually proposes that instead of the Senate adjourning at 6.30 p.m., as has been proposed since the sitting commenced before the Budget, we sit again after dinner between 8 p.m. and 10.30 p.m. It is my understanding that that in part gives rise to the possibility that we might sit beyond that time with a view to completing the passage of major legislation which is currently before the Senate, namely, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation.

I indicate to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate and to the Senate the two reasons why we do not believe what is being proposed is reasonable. The first-I suppose in one sense it is the lesser reason-is that as far as possible the Senate should proceed in a predictable way so that people can make arrangements with some satisfaction and hope that they can meet them. That is less weighty today than usual because a large number of senators are stranded here until tomorrow in any event. A number of senators will be inconvenienced in the sense that the plans they have made in contemplation of the Senate rising at 6.30 p.m. will be destroyed. More importantly, a number of senators have to get to Sydney to catch aircraft early tomorrow morning and their travel arrangements will be significantly hindered.

At this early stage of the session-I remind the Senate that we are only in the third week of sitting-we have been making orderly progress with the Government's program. It is most unusual to require additional periods of sitting at this stage. For all those reasons I think the arrangements which have been before us for some considerable time should be left in place. I say to the Manager of Government Business that as is usual we would expect late in the session to have the customary negotiations about extended periods of sittings to meet the program. I think it is very early in the day to be calling upon us to do that.

The more significant reason why I suggest that we should not do what is proposed is the significance of the particular legislation that we have in front of us at the moment. The Senate is debating the ATSIC legislation which has been the subject of an extensive parliamentary committee inquiry and of an extensive parliamentary debate. It is legislation which will have a major impact on Aboriginal affairs in Australia and it is extremely contentious.
