We have gone beyond the second reading debate, which was an orderly debate of a high standard. We are now into the committee stage. I have asked Senator Peter Baume to support me in this debate because he has the conduct of this Bill for the Opposition. He is therefore more closely across the detail of what the Senate is doing in committee than I am.

I think what Senator Peter Baume will tell us will illustrate that not only is the Opposition raising matters of considerable significance but it is also raising matters which, in a large number of cases, are finding favour with the Government and which are leading to the amendment of this important legislation. I have not been able to be involved in the committee debate in the way in which I would have liked but it is my understanding that the National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia, the Australian Democrats and the Government are engaged in a very serious but also very fruitful debate which is achieving significant changes to the legislation. Many of those changes are being made virtually on a consensual basis after hearing argument.

I suppose it is only a couple of times a year that we take a major piece of legislation and give it what I would regard as major consideration. That is not novel. That has been the case for the 15 or so years that I have been here. Senator Gareth Evans would remember some of the debates in the mid-70s on matters like the Trade Practices Act. But I recall-if I might raise the name without reminding the Senate of very divisive matters-the then Attorney-General, Senator Murphy, saying at the end of the debate on the Trade Practices Bill that he was satisfied that we had a very significantly improved Bill as a result of the Senate's consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens once a decade.

—No, we can look at a very recent example in the war crimes legislation where I would acknowledge that in discussions and negotiations with Senator Gareth Evans and with Senator Tate we obtained Government agreement to some 60 per cent of the amendments that were being put forward in a most contentious and difficult Bill which greatly affects the constituency that Senator Robert Ray has primary responsibility for-the migrant community.

SPEECH.PARA: My fundamental point-I make this very seriously to the Australian Democrats and to the Government-is that we are not engaged in some short term political exercise. I very much doubt that there is enormous political significance in the detailed consideration which is being given to the ATSIC legislation; but I suggest that there is major substantive significance. In an area where everyone would agree there are great difficulties, I believe it would be tragic if the consideration of the large remaining number of amendments were to be conducted under the pressure of an extended and, subsequently, a late sitting. I think that that would be completely contrary to the careful consideration at the Select Committee level, then in the second reading debate and so far in the Committee of the Whole debate which I think has been a classically proper and appropriate parliamentary effort. I would therefore hope that there would be no extension of Senate sittings in the way in which it is proposed by this motion. I would certainly be quite bitterly opposed to any suggestion that we should sit late into the night-the early hours-to force-feed a most sensitive and difficult piece of legislation and thereby to trade off for the gain of a few hours of parliamentary time some significant advantage which might apply.

We have a great deal of political argy-bargying in this chamber. I am well aware that the two Ministers that I have already mentioned seem to get most irate when I sound at all serious about a matter. I suggest that these are matters of substance which are worthy of consideration by the Government and by the Australian Democrats. I would welcome Senator Reid, if that is her wish, and Senator Peter Baume, if it is his wish, indicating in a little more detail to the Senate the significance of the remaining matters which we have before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The virus which I am carrying at the moment is making life difficult and I hope my voice will last. I will not speak terribly long.
—That is another reason for not sitting on.

—It will not be a pleasure to sit on but if necessary I will, of course, abide by the wish of the Senate. Senator Chaney has addressed this question to vary the hours of meeting this day so that the Government can give further consideration, as I think it wishes to do, to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) package of legislation, which is enormous. It is not just a Bill of the kind that we get through the Senate in several hundreds every year. This is a package to restructure an entire portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot recall a legislative package of this complexity, certainly not in the area of Aboriginal affairs and I doubt in very many other areas. It therefore requires from the Senate proper consideration. It does not require any kind of unduly long consideration but it requires proper consideration. That includes an adequate committee stage debate. The Senate has proceeded with care and without undue delay to this stage. For a start there is not just one Bill; there are three Bills in this package. With the modern communications available to honourable senators now and with the help of the Table Office I have obtained a print-out relating to the other two Bills in the package. I note that the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill 1989 was passed by this place on 1 September very quickly. That committee stage was not prolonged; it was very brief indeed. The Government indicated that it would accept all of the Opposition's amendments. There were 17 amendments put into that legislation. The Opposition's view would be that the legislation was thereby improved.

The Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill 1989 was debated in committee for a day or so. We moved 16 amendments and the debate continued. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, which is the main piece of legislation, brings together a number of different legislative matters. I just indicate for a start that we have yet to consider the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Development Commission which could have been the subject of a Bill on its own. It is a major legislative offering and will have to be examined. We have 11 pages of amendments covering it.

We have not taken this debate lightly, but we have not prolonged it unduly. When people have agreed with our amendments, we have stopped the debate straight away and proceeded to the next. When the debate resumes I hope that we can dispose of three or four amendments-they have been the subject of discussion off-stage-in just a couple of moments. There is no point in prolonging the discussion.

I have just pulled out for my own interest a list of the amendments which so far have been inserted into the package. I advise honourable senators that by proceeding with care we have so far inserted 83 amendments in the package of three Bills, and more amendments are proposed. If the agreement holds, two or three more will go in straight away. It is a very substantial group of amendments. I seek leave to incorporate the print-out of the clauses in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. What remains in the legislation is vital. I have taken the time to look at our schedule of amendments. I am aware that there are several Australian Democrat amendments. I do not imagine that they will take a lot of time to consider because again I am certain that they will succeed, since we have amendments in the same form. Therefore they will have support from a majority of senators. We still have to deal with questions such as the continued role of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the right to privacy, the regional council structure under the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, electoral processes-I interpolate here that I think Senator Coulter will recall that the Senate Select Committee into the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs looked at the question of electoral processes at some length, and there are many loose ends there which have to be clarified-the Corporation, which as I said earlier is an enormous subject in itself, the reports of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, Queensland community councils, the interim Commission and the entry into force of the Act and transitional proposals, after which the Committee has to direct its attention to the preamble. I do not want to say much about that, except that I think it is a very significant part of the Bill and may take some time. If we do sit, we will not prolong debate. We will not take any more time over any amendment or clause than we have to. We will certainly try to deal with them in good order. When they are disposed of, we will go on to the next one. Even so, if we do sit, it will take considerable time to deal with the rest of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to echo what Senator Chaney has said. It has been a pleasure to be a senator while this debate has been going on because it has been possible-by examining each clause, negotiating and getting the support of excellent officers and the parliamentary counsel-to improve the legislation as we have gone along. I hoped that we could do this. I wish the debate to continue in that kind of spirit. It is all right to be threatened with sitting all night; that is a legitimate tactic. Senator Robert Ray often tells us that in politics these things ebb and flow. I understand that and I do not mind. We will sit for as long as the Senate says that we should sit. All I am saying is that the task I have been given is to try to deal with the amendments in good order and not to take an unduly long time. That is what we intend to do. If it is the Senate's view to sit all night, how long will we sit? Will we sit until 10.30 p.m., 2 a.m. or sunrise? It does not matter. I do not welcome the prospect for a number of reasons, but if that is what we have to do, we will do it.

I urge the Senate to have regard to what has been done so far in the ATSIC Bill, which has been quite creditable. I think that it has reflected credit on the Government, the Australian Democrats and the Opposition. We would like to see it continue that way. I do not like the idea of being put under pressure to hurry the Bill through. I hope that we can continue to deal with it in an orderly fashion. That is the way the Opposition would prefer to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in supporting the motion that the Senate sit until 10.30 tonight. I support it for the reasons given by Senator Chaney and Senator Peter Baume. This has been an excellent, first class and fascinating debate. It has been conducted in a way which suggests that rationality has struck with a vengeance. The amendments that have already been passed show that it has been an effective debate. Fairly obviously it will take a great deal of time to consider the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Bill and we have to provide for that in the timetable. Because it is a very good debate, we need more time.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney mentioned that some honourable senators have to leave tonight. I am sure that the Whips will accommodate those people by arranging pairs and whatever. The number of people who have engaged in the debate is quite small, but they have been effective. Quite frankly, the Australian Democrats have to agree with the Government's motion-as we have agreed with the motions of other governments-to provide time for good debates. We have had plenty of debates in this place about the need for more Committee time. We have to find it. Unfortunately, that means sitting longer, not only in this ad hoc way but also, as I have said many time in the past, for extra weeks. No-one likes that idea, least of all the electorate. Unless we find the time we will not have the types of debate that we are having at the moment.

The pressure of business, if anybody has bothered to notice, is pushing the amount of time for legislation into a small hole. We have to open it up. Unfortunately, the only time we can open up debates on legislation-Senator Peter Baume certainly knows this, as does Senator Chaney, having been Whips-is at the end of the day. That is unfortunate, but everything comes before legislation. If we want to sit down and be rational about it, we might arrange it in another way, but it will take more time than we have between now and December to get some change to the sessional orders or Standing Orders. It is obvious that we have to open up some time towards the end of the day. Honourable senators may be aware that we used to sit very long hours. When I became a member of this Parliament we sat into the early morning many times.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had a silly Whip then.

—The balance of power in the chamber changed. The Liberal and National parties previously had the balance of power in this place. Senator Chipp, quite properly-after a wrestle with his heart-decided that there were far saner ways of living and that we ought to have set hours. We have been more rational than the other place and I hope that will continue. The debate that we have had so far on the ATSIC Bill has demonstrated that if we can open up some more time we will get better legislation. I am surprised that we are trying to prevent this. I think that we can accommodate those people who will be inconvenienced. The rest of us will be here until tomorrow anyhow because there are no planes. It seems to me that this is an ideal opportunity to get a couple more hours for a very good debate.

—I support Senator Chaney. A number of honourable senators have to leave tonight. A number of advisers have already left. The person working for me has spent many hours-I am not sure how many-on this legislation. She has had to leave. I do not know about Senator Peter Baume's adviser--
—She has gone.

—She has gone too, I am advised. She has been sitting in the advisers box for the last few days advising Senator Peter Baume on all aspects of the legislation. It will be harder for us to carry on the debate without the advice of those two people. Of course, Senator Tate will have four or five Government advisers assisting him, which will put him at a decided advantage. This debate is not only interesting but has been carried out in good spirit, with everyone working in harmony to try to reach a compromise. We are not debating some mickey mouse legislation; this legislation will affect the lives of 300,000 Australians. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill will affect the black community of Australia.
—It will affect the lives of all Australians.

—As Senator Stone rightly points out, it will affect not only black Australians but all Australians. There is no way in the world that the Opposition has tried to filibuster. We did not bring on a matter of public importance on Tuesday. We could have stacked the speakers list, but only two people have participated in the debate. Senator Tambling has been coming in on the odd occasion to participate in the debate, but Senator Peter Baume is carrying the main load. There can be no suggestion that we are trying to extend the debate. We want to get the answers right regarding the legislation. I will find it more difficult to proceed with this legislation without a person to advise me in the chamber. Our researchers have spent, I would say, hundreds of hours going through the legislation in order to get the amendments correct. If those people are out of the game, we run the grave risk of not making the correct decisions. I cannot see how debating this legislation today for an extra couple of hours will make any difference. We should finish debating it the next time we sit. We will not come up with the right results by pushing this legislation through like meat through a sausage machine. If the legislation were not so important I would not mind, but this legislation requires concentration, and it requires advice, which the Opposition does not now have. Senator Coulter seems to be able to bat on on his own and does it quite well. It will not make any difference whether we debate this legislation for an extra couple of hours today. If debating this legislation for an extra couple of hours will mean that we get it right, then let us take a couple of hours when the Senate comes back in a couple of weeks. We will then know that we are going to have the right answers. If we do it in an ad hoc way, anything could happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reflect briefly upon the words of Senator Peter Baume and Senator Macklin. The debate so far has been excellent. It has been a real debate. I have really enjoyed the way in which Senator Peter Baume has put his amendments. So far, we have been debating his amendments. He has explained them well. The quality of the argument has been excellent and we have got exactly the same from Senator Tate. As Senator Baume has pointed out, a number of amendments have been accepted and we have been able to abstract the principles from others which have been debated and to come up with a form of words that better suits both sides of the chamber. A number of changes have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that that process takes quite a lot of time. It is precisely for that reason we should not be seeking to cut this debate off. Therefore, I support the motion that we go through until 10.30 p.m. It is a reasonable time; it is not excessive. The only proviso I make is that, if we are debating a particular group, we should finish that group and finish the debate at a suitable time. At least it will give us another couple of hours, as Senator Macklin has said. That is what we need in this debate-more time. It is clear that we will not finish the debate tonight. We will need time beyond that, but at least we will get in another couple of hours. We should have that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —To bring on an extra sitting at night at this stage when the pilots strike is on is very thoughtless. I know people who have made arrangements for tomorrow, and in order to meet those commitments they have to leave Canberra by car tonight. That normally would not be the case. They would normally catch the early plane out tomorrow morning. Some of them are driving themselves and some are being driven. Either way, with the highways as clogged as they are at present, I think it is a very foolish way to be doing our business.

SPEECH.PARA: It is only the third week of the session and people normally make arrangements for the end of the sitting weeks. They are entitled to do so. All of us know that at the end of a session we sit later and that our sitting pattern may be altered; we take that into account when we make arrangements. We could talk about the impact of this proposal on health. We certainly can talk about the debate. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) cannot suggest that there has been any delay in this debate. I have heard enough of it to be able to say that unequivocally.

So far some 83 amendments have been carried. If those amendments had taken only 15 minutes each, it would have taken about 21 hours of committee debate. In addition, there are clauses to which no amendments have been made. This clearly indicates that all those participating in the debate have been extremely diligent, especially Senator Peter Baume, Senator Coulter and the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). There have been a few others who have participated from time to time. From the number of amendments that have been put, I think it almost comes into the category of being historic that so much has been done in the time. Anybody listening would know that it has been done expeditiously and with goodwill.

There are a number of reasons why sitting on tonight is foolish. If we sit until 10.30 p.m., that is bad enough, but we do not know whether there is the threat of some arrangements to negate the adjournment at that time. That hangs over our heads as well, which makes my argument about the arrangements for people travelling and the like even more pertinent. I suggest that the Manager of Government Business reconsider the proposal and make arrangements for the scheduling of this debate for some other time. He knows how many amendments there have been and to suddenly bring this proposal on, when people have had no opportunity to make other arrangements, is not in the best interests of the operation of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be quite brief because many of the points I was going to make have been made by others and I see no point in repeating them, although I think it fair to underline one or two of them. The point about predictability of our schedules has already been made by others, most recently by Senator Reid. It is intolerable that we were told yesterday that the change in our programs would occur today at this stage in the session. I have to say honestly that it does not personally affect me if we sit here tonight until 10.30 p.m. I am stranded here tonight because of the airline dispute and I have not made engagements here in Canberra as many other people have. So it will not affect me. I will sit here tonight and I will take part in the debate, which otherwise I perhaps would not have had time to do. I have not been able to participate in this debate except on one or two brief occasions.
—We will be going until sunrise.

—I assure the Minister that that was not in my mind. I simply make the point that I am not in the position that many honourable senators who have been referred to are in. They have made arrangements either to drive to Sydney or to drive elsewhere in New South Wales. If they are stranded here in Canberra and have made arrangements here they are now faced with the prospect of cancelling them. I am not in that situation, so I am not pleading those things. As I have said, because of that I will be able to take part in the debate, so I shall. But that is predictability for you.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point which has been the centre of the debate, which I also want to underline is that, although I have not taken much part in the debate personally, I have certainly been watching it and listening to it a good deal in my room on our communication system. I would just like to underline what Senator Macklin, Senator Coulter and everybody else have said. This has been an extraordinary debate. It has probably been the highest quality debate I have witnessed, in the two years that I have been in the Senate at any rate. Perhaps the quality of the debate cannot be more succinctly expressed than by noting that, as Senator Peter Baume said, so far 83 amendments to these three Bills have already been accepted by the Government. To my mind, that is enough to suggest that the last thing we should be trying to do is truncate the debate or conduct a debate when people are bleary-eyed and tired out of their minds. I am not suggesting that they would be by 10.30 tonight, but I am certainly suggesting that they would be if the debate were to go beyond that time.

When the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) responds to this debate-as I assume he will do-I would like him to indicate quite clearly to the Senate his intention as far as the adjournment tonight is concerned. We will then know much more clearly where we stand. Senator Coulter indicated that he had a view about that, but it was not altogether crystal clear. Anyway, I would like to know what Senator Ray's view is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The first point made by Senator Chaney was that he wanted predictability. I guess that it is for that reason that I gave notice of this motion yesterday. I was under pressure earlier in the week to sit Wednesday and Thursday nights, but I made the decision not to press for Wednesday night because we had had two late night sittings. But I gave notice of this motion yesterday to put people on notice in case they had other functions to attend or had made other arrangements. I could have deferred the matter we dealt with this morning, brought the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation on this morning, waited until the adjournment tonight and simply negated the adjournment, having stitched up some sort of deal. Then no-one would have had any notice at all and no-one would have had a dinner break. It is for that reason that I gave notice of this motion yesterday, at least to try to establish a dinner break and further consideration of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: A point raised by Senator Reid and Senator Chaney, with some validity, is that some people may have to leave here a little earlier than normal tonight. Certainly, from the Government's point of view we raise no objection to the extension of pairs if that will facilitate that operation. I accept the point that there has been no filibuster in the ATSIC debate. I also hope that honourable senators will accept that a lot of other time has been absorbed in the last 12 sitting days that probably has not left us the normal percentage of time to deal with government business. I might say that that is a normal function at the start of a parliament. The percentage tends to ease up as the sittings go on. I am not alleging that there has been some subversive filibuster in other matters in order to delay the ATSIC legislation, but we are 12 sitting days into the program. We have got no legislation through yet and we are not likely to do so tonight, no matter what we do.

I should make the point that once we finish this sitting period, we go into Estimates committees for two weeks. So we will have only four full sitting days in the next sitting period, on each of which a matter of public importance will be put forward-I do not quibble about that because honourable senators opposite must have at least two a week-which means that in September we will have very little time to debate the ATSIC legislation. One other piece of legislation will be brought into the Senate in that period because it has a 1 October start-up date. That has been put off for quite a while. It was considered last session--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that?

—It is health legislation. It will be coming back in the next two-week sitting period and it will have to have priority over the ATSIC legislation. That may leave us in a position where we have had 20 sitting days and are only halfway through the ATSIC legislation.
—I think we are a bit more than halfway through it.

—Are we? That is very encouraging. Even if my motion is carried in five minutes' time, we will be dealing with General Business for 2 1/2 hours and I guess it will be about 9 o'clock tonight before we get to ATSIC; so it will not be a long debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter indicated what I think is the general feeling in terms of the 10.30 adjournment; that is, if we are very close to getting a set of clauses through, we will probably proceed to 11.00 or 11.15. If the debate looks like going on until midnight or beyond we will pack up our bags and go at 10.30. I do not think we have contemplated a sunrise sitting at this stage. I admit that, quite clearly, we threatened Opposition senators with that over the war crimes legislation to bomb them to the negotiating table. If honourable senators remember, we all came together, agreed on a four-day debate, and came in on time. Again, I thought it took a lot of the steam out of the debate. People could concentrate on the actual issues rather than the pressure of time-whether they should deliberately delay it or speed it up.

I still support the motion. If we have caused anyone any inconvenience tonight, I regret that. I take it that some people are embarking on international travel and have to travel to Sydney tonight to facilitate that process. But we make the offer of extra pairs. As it is, having just spent 45 minutes debating this matter it looks as though we will spend a maximum of one or 1 1/2 hours debating the ATSIC legislation this evening, depending on how we go with General Business. I do not imagine that that will take too much less than 2 1/2 hours.

I put all honourable senators on notice so that no-one can accuse me of intolerable activity that, if the debate on ATSIC slows down too much-already we are sitting an extra week in September-we might have to sit an extra week starting 16 October, which means that we will be sitting three weeks in a row, followed by a break, another three weeks in a row, another break and then probably four weeks in a row. It is a very intensive schedule. There are another 72 Bills listed essential for passage. In reality that means that at least 50 of them will be absolutely essential. Twenty-two absolutely essential items for passage always at the last minute become not so essential. That does not take account of any other Bills that may come up in between.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is the election?
—Senator Reid asked me when the election is to be. It will be held exactly 33 days after the issue of the writs.

That the motion (Senator Robert Ray's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE DISCIPLINE LEGISLATION BOARD OF REVIEW

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to speak today on the report of the Defence Force Discipline Legislation Board of Review. Twenty years of work went into the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and a further three years were spent on drafting regulations. Rules of procedure, a law manual for use by the services, training courses for people who would need to work in the system and further amendments to the 1982 Act were needed before the Act was finally able to come into force on 3 July 1985. The disciplinary codes of the defence forces have been brought into one single uniform code. But at that time it was recognised that a review would be needed of the Act. Therefore, it was decided that this review should take place three years after the Act came into operation. In fact, that is what has happened and the report of that review is now before us.

I would like to congratulate Mr Justice Connor and the other members of the board of review for doing a very thorough job which took a year to complete. They travelled virtually all around Australia, studied 79 submissions and talked to servicemen at bases all around the country. I, for one, am very pleased to have received this report. I think it will go quite a long way to making sure that the new disciplinary code of the defence forces works to its optimum effectiveness and efficiency. One should not forget the importance of discipline to the defence forces. It is a vital element in the effectiveness and efficiency of the Force.

The report concludes that the new code is operating reasonably satisfactorily and that it has been generally accepted by the forces. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the board of review says that service members want a disciplinary system that is well-founded and works efficiently and effectively not only in peacetime but also in respect of active service. That is a very important criterion for a discipline code for the defence forces.

As I read the report, I was impressed with the 53 recommendations which have been made. Obviously, time does not allow me to canvass them all. However, we should be alert to the fact that a number of the recommendations relate to matters which were raised by the Judge Advocate-General in his report for the period 1 January to 31 December 1987. A number of the matters that he raised in that report have, rightly, been adopted. For example, it was felt that certain minor service convictions should not carry over as convictions in civilian life. The view was expressed that, in some cases, the penalties for use or possession of cannabis where the amount involved is over 25 grams were not sufficient. This has now been remedied. Also the question of whether people, while they are suspended from duty awaiting trial, should receive salary and allowances has been dealt with.

The board of review had to resolve a difficult problem about the right to hold general searches of personnel, premises and vehicles at random and at will, especially of personnel and vehicles leaving defence establishments. That recommendation has been accepted and implemented. On the matter of the procedure of service tribunals, there has been a limited acceptance of the situation where lawyers appear in summary trials. This has been a matter of concern to the Royal Australian Navy and the Army. To some extent, that has been dealt with in the recommendations. There has also been a response to the need for a less cumbersome procedure for dealing with minor summary offences.

One matter which has been addressed but not resolved according to the recommendation of the Judge Advocate-General relates to the question of the binding effect of the Judge Advocate-General's rulings. A question was raised about consistency in rulings, but the review board had decided that this has not proved to be a problem and did not need action. I commend the report of the Defence Force Discipline Legislation Board of Review. It is an excellent report which will serve the defence forces well.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSAL TO UPGRADE AND REFURBISH THE SOUTHERN ENTRY TO THE ADMINISTRATIVE BUILDING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper relates to a proposal to upgrade and refurbish the southern entry to the administrative building. I do not know whether the Senate has any views on this or whether individual senators wish to express a view. My concern is the manner in which this matter is being dealt with. Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I draw the attention of the Senate to some very interesting remarks in the 1988-89 annual report of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) which I think will no doubt be the subject of comment by other senators and members in the weeks ahead. At the outset the Bureau notes:

During the year the Commonwealth Ombudsman undertook an investigation into the administration by the ABS of the 1988-89 household expenditure survey. In his report of 1 May 1989, the Ombudsman said, inter alia, that he did `not consider that the Statistician was wrong to implement the original 1988 HES without tabling it' in Parliament under section 6 of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975 and `that the HES is not oppressive or unreasonably intrusive, bearing in mind the public interest in collection of the information and the protections for privacy'.

I draw attention to that because the question of whether or not the ABS has been following the correct procedures for tabling survey questions before the Parliament for its perusal has been followed. That question has wider implications for parliamentary scrutiny of government and privacy concerns of members of the community. The ABS statement I have just quoted does not adequately reflect the disquiet of the Ombudsman on a number of points. For the record I will detail just one example. On page 2 of its annual report the Bureau states:

The Ombudsman made 5 recommendations in his report. The first 3, which were about internal administrative matters, have been implemented by the ABS. The fourth and fifth recommendations were concerned with, respectively, consideration of financial compensation and amendment to statistics legislation. With respect to these, the Minister Assisting the Treasurer decided to defer considering whether financial compensation should be paid to persons directed to participate in the household expenditure survey until the next such survey in 3 or 4 years' time, and-
this is the significant part-

having regard to advice from the Attorney-General's Department, did not see any need to amend statistics legislation to clarify the powers and responsibilities of the Statistician, particularly with respect to tabling new proposals.
What did the Ombudsman actually have to say about this? In a letter to the Australian Statistician, Mr Castles, dated 28 August last the Ombudsman noted:

. . . the Minister Assisting the Treasurer has decided that, having regard to the advice of the Attorney-General's Department dated 16 June 1989, he does not see the need for amendment to statistics legislation.
He went on to say:

I do not feel that the Attorney-General's Department advice is really an adequate response to my recommendation, in the light of the underlying reasoning set out in my report. I do not, for example, consider that the fact that the Department-
that is, the Attorney-General's Department-
considers a particular legal interpretation to be correct meets my observation that a number of experienced lawyers-
I understand there are seven such experienced lawyers-
have reached other conclusions as to the meaning of the legislation. Whilst I have great respect for the Department's skills, it is not infallible-
I think we can say that again-
and it is such doubt which I think should be resolved by amendment of the legislation.

I would have to say that the treatment of that view expressed by the Ombudsman-he is not a man who expresses views on such matters lightly-by the Bureau in its report is somewhat less than adequate. I understand that others may have similar points to make about this report and I therefore conclude my remarks at this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak to the 1988-89 annual report of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). I am extremely concerned about the report. It contains a considerable amount of information about the household expenditure survey, as Senator Stone has already indicated. I believe that the Bureau of Statistics has misled the Senate. It is because of that that I am extremely concerned. As Senator Stone said when he quoted from page 2, the Commonwealth Ombudsman has said, inter alia, that he does not consider that the Australian Statistician was wrong to implement the original 1988 survey without tabling it and that the household expenditure survey was not oppressive or unreasonably intrusive, bearing in mind the public interest in the collection of information and the protections for privacy. I will quote directly from the Ombudsman's report in answering a question as to whether the survey was unreasonably intrusive and burdensome. The Ombudsman stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There seems little doubt that there are aspects of the survey which are intrusive and burdensome.

Yet the Statistician's report tells us that the Ombudsman did not find the survey intrusive and burdensome. It depends on how we read that report. It is misleading for the chief Statistician to release an annual report and not give the full picture. The chief Statistician also said that the Ombudsman did not consider that it was wrong to implement the original survey without tabling it. Yet the Ombudsman said that it would be in the best interests of the ABS to table that survey. That was done. Perhaps even more importantly, or just as importantly, the Assistant Statistician, in a minute that I have before me, stated:

The Household Expenditure Survey is the most burdensome household expenditure survey undertaken by the ABS and is also considered to be highly intrusive by some members of the community. As a consequence, the survey tends to generate Ministerials arising from complaints by constituents to their Local Members of Parliament. Being able to say that the survey had been tabled and subject to parliamentary scrutiny then becomes a very useful ABS tactic.
I therefore seek your approval to table the 1988/89 Household Expenditure Survey.

That was signed by Mr Giles, the Assistant Statistician. It was written to Mr W. McLennan, the Deputy Statistician. The fact that Mr Castles has claimed that the survey was not burdensome and intrusive when the Assistant Statistician, Social Branch, in a minute to the Deputy Statistician claims that it is the worst they have ever had, and the Ombudsman says there is no doubt that it is-yet according to the annual report Mr Castles blithely claims that the Ombudsman found that it was not intrusive-I believe is of great concern to this chamber and it is of great concern that the ABS would mislead the chamber in that way. As honourable senators know, we have only five minutes to speak on this report. Because of the very short time I have, I will speak also on the next paper to come before us, the annual report of the Australian Statistics Advisory Council, because that paper also makes reference to whether it should be compulsory or voluntary for these surveys to be conducted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the 1988-89 annual report of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). Last year there was a whole chapter on privacy and this year there is a whole appendix on the household expenditure survey. The ABS has devoted many pages of its 20-page appendix to defending itself against a charge that was never made. Opponents of the household expenditure survey have not questioned the need for such a survey, but have questioned the necessity for it to be compulsory and, as Senator Walters said, its burdensome nature. We have objected to the number of questions; there are many more than in previous years. There has been little justification of how these relate to the ostensible purpose of the survey, namely, to update the basket of goods and services in the consumer price index. Perhaps ABS can explain why investment expenditures are included in consumption expenditure?

SPEECH.PARA: The survey is burdensome and intrusive. I said, when we were debating whether it was legal when it had not been tabled, that the Bureau had not put forward an adequate explanation as to why it was compulsory. There is no sound social or scientific evidence to suggest that any better data is obtained from a compulsory survey than from a voluntary survey. The Bureau put up some spurious study from Germany which failed to convince me, as I am sure it failed to convince anyone on this side of politics, that it was necessary that it be compulsory.

The other criticism that was levelled was not about whether the survey should be conducted, but about the shabby conduct of the ABS in making a mistake about the need for tabling and then pulling a number of swifties to cover up the mistake: claims that the 1983 tabling document covered the 1988-89 survey; the tabling of the proposal among 45 other proposals with effect from a date two days subsequent to tabling; the misleading advice sent to the Attorney-General's Department; and so forth.

The appendix on household expenditure surveys gives a most selective history. It is quite fascinating to see on page 173 the jump from point 82 to point 83, taking us from 20 April 1988 to 21 June 1988. Nothing is said in between about the debate that went on about the compulsory versus voluntary nature of the survey and the fact that the ABS had not tabled it. It is the most selective and appalling dot point history of expenditure surveys in Australia I have ever seen.

I finish my comments by saying that the other day-I hope the Australian Labor Party takes note-I had a call from a lifetime Labor voter. She said that she had discovered the difference between the Labor and Liberal parties. She said, `I now know that the Labor Party wants to know how often I pick my nose every day. It wants to know that sort of detail'. She had had an exchange with the ABS which was totally inappropriate. I object to any citizen, especially a constituent, being treated in the way she was treated by the ABS. Over the telephone she was asked how tall she was and what her weight was. When she answered the question about her weight, the person told her that she ought to go on a diet and that she would be sent a form to fill in. The form had apparently been lost. It was a disgusting performance. This woman was concerned and upset when she rang me. She is right about the difference between the Labor and Liberal parties. For people who do not know the difference, it is that the Labor Party wants to interfere in people's business and the Liberal Party wants to stay out of it. These surveys should be voluntary and not compulsory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Senator Walters has already foreshadowed that she wishes to speak also to the annual report of the Australian Statistics Advisory Council so that she can follow up on her remarks on the national health survey. I will therefore not speak about that aspect of this paper, but about a quite different aspect.

The matter I wish to refer to in the report is referred to on pages 12 and 13. It relates to the treatment of mortgage interest charges in the consumer price index (CPI). Honourable senators will recall that during the last major review of the calculation of the CPI it was decided to incorporate price changes for home mortgage interest payments. The statisticians have two principal ways of making those measurements, known respectively as the debt profile approach and the simple revaluation method. At the time of inclusion of mortgage interest charges in the CPI, the two methods, which are both in their own ways equally valid measurements, were producing practically identical results and it did not appear to anybody, therefore, that the choice of one or the other would affect very much the development of the index. Without going into technicalities, it was decided at that time by the Australian Bureau of Statistics to adopt the simple revaluation method.

It is ironic that subsequently the Statistician decided to change that and that that apparently technical and, in a way, rather esoteric issue should blow up into a major political issue. We all know that after the disastrous December quarter CPI result of 2.1 per cent, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) sought to put pressure on the Bureau of Statistics to change to the alternative method of calculation because that was by that time producing lower figures for the CPI. Subsequently, the ABS did indeed change its methodology, stating when it did so for the record that no political pressure had been involved in the decision. With respect to the matter, the annual report of the Australian Statistics Advisory Council on page 13 states:
During Council's consideration of the matter many members expressed concern-
that is, before the change was made-
at the prospect of changing the measurement method for mortgage interest charges between the major five to six yearly reviews.
There is a review every five or six years and changes are often made at those times. The report continues:

While accepting the technical arguments for making the change, they pointed out that to do so in mid-stream, so soon after public criticism by Government leaders, could be widely interpreted as succumbing to political pressure. It was felt that such a perception could seriously damage the credibility of the ABS as an independent provider of impartial and reliable official statistics. Council recognised that the Statistician was responsible for decisions on how the CPI should be measured, but, in view of the importance it attached to maintaining public confidence in the integrity of the ABS, Council suggested that the Statistician give strong consideration to deferring any adjustments until the time of the next major review of the index.

Council notes that in the event the Statistician considered that he should not accept its recommendation and the change to the `debt profile' method was made for the March quarter CPI calculation. The criticism predicted by Council eventuated but, possibly because of the technical nature of the issues involved, was not sustained for a long period and the Bureau emerged relatively unscathed. Council accepts that the Statistician's decision was made after his careful consideration of its views and in the genuine belief that it would produce the most reliable figures.

The Council is here saying that in the end the Government got away with it. In the end, because of the technical nature of the change, the criticism was not sustained. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the Council, a very high level body, has put on the record its serious disquiet that this major change in methodology was made between the normal five to six yearly changes and that by doing so the Bureau's integrity was put at risk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to speak on the Australian Statistics Advisory Council. I am concerned about the methods adopted in its 1988-89 annual report. On page 10 it criticises the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) household surveys. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the year the ABS has had to contend with an unprecedented level of adverse publicity and Council was anxious to assist and support the Bureau in this difficult period.

The task was made difficult because the ABS refused to table the household expenditure survey before it implemented it. That was totally different from what had occurred with any previous survey. Previous surveys had been voluntary; this one was compulsory. That indicates to me that the difference was quite considerable.

Because members of the Opposition were very concerned that the ABS had taken an illegal stance they sought and received legal opinions from very prominent queen's counsel. All were to the effect that the ABS had acted illegally in not tabling the survey in the Parliament. The ABS sought legal opinion only from the Attorney-General's Department. In requesting that opinion, it did not tell the Department that one survey was voluntary while the other was compulsory. It was established during the Estimates hearings that the Attorney-General's Department did not receive that information. That explains why the Attorney-General's Department gave a different opinion. We asked the Bureau of Statistics to seek alternative legal opinion, which of course, it refused to do because it was sure that the opinion would not uphold the legality of its action. The Ombudsman also reported as follows:
All published legal opinions other than those of the Attorney-General's Department came down on the side of the 1988 HES being a new proposal and therefore falling within s.6(3) of the ABS Act . . .
That meant, of course, that it should be voluntary. The report continued:

I understand that the Department saw these other opinions and maintained its own view. Nevertheless, insofar as they identify problems in the interpretation of the Act, the views of the other legal experts cannot lightly be dismissed.
In answer to the question as to whether the original 1988 household expenditure survey was a new proposal, the Ombudsman said:
If a definitive answer is required, then it would seem necessary for the matter to be tested in court . . .

This was not possible because at no stage did the Bureau inform people who refused to complete the survey that it was compulsory. Those conducting the survey told people it was compulsory but the Bureau, because it refused to have the matter tested before the court, refused to direct those people who would not complete the survey to fulfil their survey obligations. As I said earlier, I believe that the Bureau of Statistics has misled the Parliament in its annual report.
