SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports and papers.

The report of the Auditor-General on the Australian Customs Service (ACS) in relation to passenger and crew processing, presented earlier this afternoon, is quite interesting. It relates to an audit done at Sydney and Hobart international airports, representing the two extremes of airports in Australia. Sydney takes over 50 per cent of the seven million-odd passengers coming into and out of the country each year and Hobart deals with only 0.3 per cent. The customs audit by the Auditor-General found that by and large the processing of inward and outward passengers and aircrew was satisfactory within the legislative and resource framework in which customs has to operate. That is a very important qualification. Some of the failings brought up in the Auditor-General's report stem from both the legislative restrictions in relation to body searches, which I will come to later, and the resource framework.

This Government has cut back severely on the Australian Customs Service. It is only small, with about 5,000 employees, but it is very productive from the point of view of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth raises through the activities of the Australian Customs Service in excess of $12 billion or $14 billion per year in tariff and excise levies. Its productivity works out at in excess of $2m per employee for Consolidated Revenue.

Customs has a number of functions. One is the control of narcotics and prohibited goods entering this country through the customs barrier. It seems to me an incredibly foolish policy to deny Customs $1m or $2m to implement its duties more fully so that these dangerous and lethal substances are denied entry to Australia-to deny the Service the resource on the one hand and then, on the other hand, through social services and the police and security functions, try to clean up the mess after the products have come into the country.

To allow the importation of narcotic drugs without doing all we can to stop it means a very big increase in costs associated with the welfare program; the health bill; hospitalisation; looking after broken families; detection services of the Australian Federal Police-a big amount-and the State police; and putting people through the courts and then locking them up and feeding them at taxpayers' expense. A dollar spent on increasing the customs barrier control would be paid back tenfold or twentyfold by subsequent avoidance of costs to the community. But that is a matter for this Government.

This Government is not terribly keen to put all its resources into preventing the ingress of narcotics into this country. While I am sure that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is at the table, is extraordinarily conscientious in what he is doing with the Australian Federal Police in trying on the one hand to detect the source of drugs in the producing countries and the pathways by which they enter Australia and, on the other, to track them within this country, I am quite sure that if he were able to speak frankly he would say that he is very severely limited by the resources that the Government has allocated to the Federal Police through his Department.

Turning back to the report itself, the Auditor-General found that passengers were being processed efficiently. It is worth noting that in Australia Customs performs a range of duties which in some countries are a function of other departments. It is a one-stop service when one enters an Australian airport. The primary customs barrier provides the identification of the passenger first of all and thereby carries out an immigration check. There is also a security check carried out in respect of Australian or international police requirements. There is a quarantine check carried out to see whether people are carrying prohibited or proscribed plant life. There is, of course, a narcotics and prohibited imports check-a true Customs function. All of those checks are carried out by one Customs officer at the primary barrier. Given the range of tests that have to be run through, and the fact that there may be 1,500 passengers trying to get through Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport in one batch, it really is a considerable administrative load, and some degree of delay is inevitable. Nevertheless, Customs has a target for processing passengers through the primary barrier within a certain period of time, and usually it reaches that target.

I want to turn now to the weaknesses exposed in the Auditor-General's report. The first one deals with general security arrangements in relation to Sydney Airport. Sydney Airport suffers from two security faults. I do not want to go into those in detail but they relate to the inadequate design of the international terminal which does not allow for crowd control, surveillance of passenger movement and all the other things which are needed in an ideal case and which, in Australia, are best served in the new Perth International Airport.

The other failure that relates to security in Sydney Airport, that the Auditor-General's report draws attention to, is the number of agencies at the airport, ranging from the Federal Airports Corporation to four or five other bodies which issue security passes. Wherever there are a number of authorities issuing identification cards and security clearances for people to work in secure areas, there are difficulties in coordination. One of the things that surprise me is that Customs has no knowledge of, control over or liaison with the authorities issuing security passes. There is quite a large section in the report concerning general security matters at Sydney. Of course, some of those can be remedied, but the design of Sydney's international airport terminal is inadequate and, while it is being extended at considerable expense, it will still be a long way short of an ideal international terminal, and I think that is rather sad for Australia's tourist trade.

The next point that is raised is the insufficient use of frisk searches. At the present time Customs officers have no authority to do anything other than a body search of a passenger entering Australia, and for them to carry that out certain stringent tests are required. The Customs officer who orders a body search-and by `body search' I mean the passenger's clothing is removed, in suitable secure circumstances, and it may, and almost always does, involve an X-ray examination to ensure that drugs or other contraband are not concealed in any of the internal body cavities-is ordering a major undertaking. Passengers do not like it. In fact, they object very strongly when a Customs officer suggests that this should be done.

Because of the requirement that a Customs officer who orders a search must stand before a court, or his peers, and give good reason why he ordered the search, it is not used as often as it should be. When one recognises that, at the end of the day, it is really intuition that leads a Customs officer to demand a search-he obviously cannot see secreted packets of heroin in the large bowel, or wherever they might be hidden-he really has to stand up and say, `It was my intuition that led me to believe that this passenger was a suspect'. Of course, that statement can be attacked very readily by lawyers in courts of laws. They may ask, `Why did you have that suspicion?', and all the rest of it. It places a very great restriction on Customs officers.

There is undoubtedly a lot of smuggling going on where passengers conceal narcotics outside their body but under their clothing. If this is done carefully there is no way of detecting it without being able to frisk down a passenger. I am pleased that the Government has agreed to amend the regulations in the near future to allow Customs officers, again with suitable provisos of having reasonable suspicions, to pat down passengers-give them a frisk to see that there is nothing concealed under their shirts or blouses, or anywhere else under their clothing. I believe that will be both a deterrent to and detection of smugglers who, at the present time, are getting through the primary barrier.

The next point that the Auditor-General's report raises is the lack of sufficient data on the extent and nature of prohibited goods carried by passengers and crew to assess the effectiveness of the subprogram. I do not quite follow that. Unless a Customs officer knows what is coming into the country-and it is quite impossible to know what is being imported illegally in the way of prohibited goods and narcotics-there really cannot be a performance indicator. I find that part of the report less than convincing. However, it relates to what is driving Customs officers at the present time, and that is their risk assessment philosophy.

The whole Customs operation is based on the risk assessment philosophy. It means that, in the light of what intelligence Customs officers have and their intuition through dealing with passengers, they decide where they should concentrate their efforts, and where they should look. This has developed a great deal in recent years and it is a very valid procedure that Customs officers are following. It is also true to say that Customs officers have developed and expanded the risk assessment philosophy purely as a consequence of the restrictions on resources as a consequence of the Government cutting funds to the Australian Customs Service. The Australian Customs Service, for example, can no longer maintain 24-hour barrier controls with a Customs officer on the wharves in many ports of Australia. In Wollongong, Geelong and Newcastle, for example, it cannot be done because there is not the money to pay staffing costs. It costs money to keep people on the dockside for 24 hours a day. They have to be paid extra between 5 o'clock in the evening and 9 o'clock in the morning. They have to be paid double time and treble time at weekends and during public holidays. Because the Government has cut back funds to the ACS it has had to reduce the permanent dockside officers at the barrier controls and develop this risk assessment philosophy.

I do not make any secret of the fact that I think the Department has been put in a very invidious position by the Government's actions. It is quite wrong just to cut funds to all departments without assessing the consequences of cutting those funds and the real needs of the departments. The argument, in my book, is not whether risk assessment philosophy should replace round-the-clock surveillance at the barrier; it is a matter of a blend of both. People have to be there on the docks 24 hours a day. The number may be reduced, but they have to be there and used together with the risk assessment philosophy. But if the risk assessment philosophy is to be run, it turns on having good intelligence and getting good intelligence turns on having more money put into it. This cannot be done on the cheap in the way the Government thinks it can.

The Government takes a lot of pride in the risk assessment philosophy and the contraband enforcement teams (CETs)-the flying squads that have replaced the permanent officers on the wharves. It points to the fact that the CETs are having good successes, and that the permanent officers on the wharves rarely make drug apprehensions. That is to misunderstand the situation completely. The fact that an officer who is on the wharf 24 hours a day does not make an arrest does not mean he is not doing his job. His very presence there acts as a deterrent. If a seaman knows that for 24 hours a day, seven days a week there is a Customs officer lurking around the dockside and looking at his ship, when he comes down the gangway, he is far less inclined to come down with a couple of kilograms of heroin or buddha sticks under his arm than if he knows the dockside is completely clear and all he has to do is run the balance of probabilities against a CET team. The risk assessment philosophy is one of the Government's weaknesses in discharging its Customs duties.

The next criticism by the Auditor-General's Office relates to domestic passengers. This is particularly relevant at present because international airline carriers are operating in the capitals of Australia. They are picking up interline passengers; in other words, domestic passengers. I have put out some press releases on this because I believe that there is an increased risk of penetration of drugs into the Australian community through this system. The Government has given Customs no extra resources to cope with the extra load. If one puts aside the totally irrational statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he was challenged on this in the other place last week, when he just went out of his mind and said that we were trying to smear him and debase the Government and all the rest of it-the usual nonsense and rantings of the Prime Minister-one sees that opportunities are provided for domestic passengers to mix with international passengers. I have no doubt at all that this is being exploited by international drug couriers.

The Government's answer is that it really does not matter now because all passengers travelling on those services have to clear customs when they reach the airport to which they are travelling. Domestic passengers are not screened off at one level with international passengers going through the Customs area. That might be the sort of excuse that satisfies the Australian press but it is a long way short of the truth. An international passenger or someone arriving from overseas who goes through a Customs barrier has to present a passport. When a passport is examined by a Customs officer, the relevant details are typed in and the officer knows whether the passenger has a police record or something like that; there is no secret about it. An assessment is made on the risk of the passenger entering the country.

It is not possible to do that with domestic passengers who do not carry a passport and are not identified by anything other than their boarding card. There is simply no way that Customs can carry out a risk assessment of a domestic passenger arriving in Sydney, Brisbane, Perth or wherever. While the Auditor-General's report was written long before the pilots strike, it is concerned about this matter. It takes up a full page of its short, 15-page report. It draws attention to the risks involved of mixing domestic passengers with international ones.

The second last matter I wish to raise is aircrew processing procedures. The Auditor-General finds fault with the fact that Customs does not check overseas aircrew entering and leaving the country. Although the report does not say so, that is absolutely inexcusable. There is no reason at all for Customs to go soft on overseas aircrew. I agree with the Customs assessment that they are a low risk group. By and large they are a high income group and have a great deal invested in their professional careers. Captains of aircraft and flightcrew will not risk a good lifestyle by trying to smuggle drugs, but there are always exceptions. If one studies what goes on in the Customs world one knows that in the past stewards have been apprehended for trying to evade Customs procedures. It is wrong that the check is not made because the processing of aircrews is simple and quick. It should not be treated with the levity that the Auditor-General found was being applied at both Hobart Airport and Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

The final matter I want to raise is the dog detector unit. The Australian Customs Service is using dogs quite extensively at present. The dogs are very successful in detecting drugs through their sense of smell. The Auditor-General commented that dogs were not being used to sniff passengers' hand luggage. I find that proposition quite alarming. I have always had doubts about the practicality of some of the tests that the Auditor-General's Office applies in some of its audits, particularly in the Department of Defence. Sometimes it really does not know how things are done. I do not think it has seen dog teams working. When a dog finds even a letter with some cannabis in it, the dog really carries on. Screening all passengers coming to Australia by having dogs run past them so their hand luggage, clothing or personal smells set off the dogs would create the most enormous reaction from passengers. If a dog took to them, having smelled a bit of cannabis, I do not think they would do it again. It is not a practical thing to do: it is not practical even to talk about it.

We ought to have more dogs. Again, if Customs had more resources, it could train more dog teams. A team consists of a handler, a Customs officer and the dog. They are matched one to the other. They do their individual training. It takes many months to train them and there is a cost involved. Compared with electronic sniffers and some of the huge machines built around the world that cost up to $5m each which try to detect drugs in luggage or letters-at the end of the day they do not work-the dog teams provide a very cheap and effective way of going about it. But it takes time and money to train them. The answer is for Customs to have more resources so that it can do more in the way of training dog teams. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start with an expression of concern about the manner in which these reports are being presented to the Senate. I hope that the President takes on board the fact that it is difficult to deal with these matters with any coherence when in fact it is impossible for us to see these reports before they are tabled by the President. Fortunately, the reports we are considering were tabled at an earlier hour this day in the House of Representatives and, as a result, became available to us. It is quite improper that we are not given the opportunity to debate these reports unless there is a fortuitous arrangement by which they are tabled in the House of Representatives earlier than they are tabled here.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the Clerk will refer this to the President and that the President will take it on board. It is quite wrong that this situation should obtain. For example, Auditor-General's reports presented I think yesterday or the day before which we did not have the opportunity to speak to were deferred and went on the Notice Paper, with the result that one is now listed as item No. 110-presumably it will never come up-and one is listed as item No. 120 on the Notice Paper. The whole purpose of these Auditor-General's reports is to improve the accountability of government bodies to this Parliament. While it is true that we will have the opportunity to pursue them in the Senate Estimates committees and to ask questions of the public servants involved, the opportunity should be available to us when these reports are brought down to raise matters of very great significance, as Senator MacGibbon has just done.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was purely by chance that I had it.

—As Senator MacGibbon says, it was purely by chance that he got hold of that report. As I said, otherwise it would not have been available to us until it was tabled. That is the only moment that we are given the opportunity of debating these matters, otherwise they get put on the bottom of the general Notice Paper such as item No. 120. One of the reports is of major significance. It is entitled Accountability, Independence and Objectivity: A response to Report 296 of the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts. This report's recommendations are aimed at ending the tyranny of this Government's control over the Auditor-General. That tyranny has been expressed in grossly unsatisfactory funding and other arrangements of the Auditor-General, as outlined in the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts report No. 296 which is termed The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament. The Auditor-General responds to the report of the Joint Committee favourably. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a strong Australian Audit Office is essential for maintenance of the accountability of Federal Government organisations and officials of the Parliament.
I apologise for reading some of these points into the Hansard but I think they are absolutely vital. The Auditor-General's response continues:

Accountability is the essence of our democratic form of government. It is the liability assumed by all of those who exercise authority to account for the manner in which they have fulfilled the responsibilities entrusted to them, a liability ultimately to the Australian people owed by Parliament, by the Government and, thus, by every government agency.

Accountability is the fundamental prerequisite for preventing the abuse of delegated power, and for ensuring, instead, that power is directed to the achievement of broadly accepted national goals with the greatest possible degree of efficiency, effectiveness, probity and prudence. A key component of accountability is a strong and viable Audit Office.

And I add: not an Audit Office under the thumb of an authoritarian Minister for Finance which, I would submit to this chamber, has been happening in recent times. I stress that the conclusion of the Auditor-General's response is of major significance. The conclusion states:

Report 296 represents the first fundamental appraisal of AAO since its establishment in 1901. It says that the AAO at a minimum could be described `as having major problems' and `at a maximum was in a state of crisis'. The AAO is doing all it can to `trade its way out of problems' by increasing productivity, improving training, adopting more appropriate organisational arrangements, liaising with and using the private sector and so on. But it is clear that Government help is needed also.
The Committee's Report and the actions that might flow from it are profoundly important-
according to the Auditor-General-

to the viability of the AAO. A generally favourable response on the part of the Government, and hence a reformed AAO, can be of great assistance in achieving the Government's goals for the public sector of greater emphasis on results, a commercial approach where appropriate, improved efficiency, effectiveness and accountability.

The broad directions proposed in the Report are consistent with equivalent steps already taken in the United Kingdom (1983), New Zealand (1989) and Canada (1977). The Report has also been favourably received internationally, by Australian State Auditors-General, the Australian Society of Accountants, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and by the accounting and auditing profession.

The Committee's Report indicates bi-partisan support from the Parliament for a substantially strengthened AAO. But it is not only the Parliament which needs an effective AAO. Such a body is essential also to provide unbiased assessments to governments, so that the Executive will be better informed in making decisions on its allocation of resources among the many competing programs and activities; and so that the Executive will know more about its component parts, including government business enterprises and companies, are doing.
This then is a warning from Mr Taylor, the Auditor-General. He concludes:

On the other hand, if it should be decided that the AAO will continue under present arrangements and general funding levels, I believe it must inevitably fall further and further behind which will be in no-one's interests.

In other words, this Government must respond to this cri de coeur from the Auditor-General, strongly supported by the bi-partisan report of the Public Accounts Committee. The recommendations made by that Public Accounts Committee are basically supported by the Auditor-General. For example, recommendation 1 states:
The Audit Act 1901 be repealed, and replaced by two new laws; a Financial Administration Act and an Audit Act.
The Auditor-General responds:

This recommendation is supported. The new Audit Act should not simply be a replica of the audit provisions of the old Act, but a rewritten Act taking into account the legislative amendments proposed throughout Report 296. The development of the new Act should be given high priority in the Government's legislative calendar. An Audit Bill could be introduced ahead of a Financial Administration Bill.

I hope the Government takes on board that it should be given a high priority. I do not know what that priority is under this Government. The second recommendation which is also endorsed and supported by the Auditor-General states:

A Parliamentary Committee be established to advise the Auditor-General on Parliament's audit priority and to consider the Australian Audit Office's finances in detail. The Committee will report to Parliament.

This recommendation also deals with a lot of other matters relating to its membership of the proposed Audit Committee of Parliament. This is absolutely vital. The response from the Auditor-General in supporting recommendation 2 is:

. . . The ultimate decision on the amount to be provided in the budget for the AAO is, of course, a matter the Government will decide. The essence of the Committee recommendation, however, is that there should be some special machinery in place to give the Parliament greater input into the consideration of the AAO's finances. This is supported. In time, when a new funding basis for the AAO has been established, a convention may emerge whereby, as in some other comparable countries the Government generally accepts the annual funding levels recommended by the Committee.

I stress that point. The funding levels would not be dictated by the Minister for Finance. It seems to me that in some instances the Minister for Finance may even have a vested interest in not providing adequate funding if a detailed Auditor-General's report would embarrass the Government or would embarrass some mandarins who may well be close to their respective Ministers. Certainly, some Ministers have been embarrassed by the revelations of the Auditor-General. In this chamber we have seen what the Auditor-General's view was of this Government's administration of the building of this new Parliament House and the lack of cost control which added multimillions of dollars to its cost. The Auditor-General continues:

. . . the financing of a national audit office is new to Australia, but it is by no means unusual in other countries, including the United Kingdom and Canada. In both Canada and the United Kingdom, a committee of the Parliament reviews the national audit office budget, and this provides a better-based approach while preserving the ultimate responsibility of the Government for the budget it put to the Parliament.
The next recommendation which the Auditor-General supports is:
Future audit legislation state unequivocally that the Auditor-General is an officer of the Parliament in order to emphasise the Auditor-General's relationship with Parliament.
I add: rather than with the Executive. I strongly support that recommendation. The Auditor-General said:
The new Audit Act should reaffirm that the Auditor-General is the independent external auditor of the executive and has a statutory responsibility to report to Parliament.
There are many other recommendations and I will not take the Senate through them all but recommendation 5, which the Auditor-General also supports, is:

Auditors-General be appointed by the Governor-General in Council and shall not be removed except by the Governor-General in Council, on an address from both Houses of the Parliament in the same session, praying for such removal on the grounds of proved misbehaviour or incapacity.
One final recommendation I want to stress states:

Legislation be introduced to establish the Australian Audit Office as a statutory authority, and to permit the Auditor-General to determine the terms and conditions of employment of Australian Audit Office staff.
The Auditor-General responds:

. . . The principle underlying the Committee's recommendation was the extent of executive control of the resources available to the AAO and how they can be deployed. The Committee considered that executive Government controls over the Auditor-General's staff are inconsistent with the role of the Auditor-General being independent of the executive.
I must say that I say amen to all that. This is a very significant report. No doubt Senator Watson, when he has the opportunity, would like to speak further on that report.

I will deal now very speedily with some of the many other reports which have been thrust on us. I regret that matters of such moment have to be dealt with so quickly when there are very serious matters involved in them. For example, the Auditor-General's report into the Public Broadcasting Foundation Ltd is quite damning. It states:
Financial management of the company was of a low standard and the systems and controls in place were inadequate.
The AAO was unable to reconcile the grants received by the company for administration with reported expenditure. Total administrative expenses of $174232 were incurred by the PBF in 1987-88.
The AAO review was hampered by the absence of any person within the company with any detailed knowledge of the operations.

The financial statements of the company were considered inadequate in terms of the Companies Act and normal disclosure of the Company's total operations. In particular, the disclosure of grant receipts and disbursements was incomplete.
From the foregoing the AAO concluded that the company was inadequately managed and that the systems and controls in place were inadequate.

This is another of this Government's great organisations about which, no doubt, the Minister is monumentally proud. There is another report into the Department of Administrative Services' leasing expenditure. Unfortunately, I now have to deal very briefly with the Auditor-General's view. He stated:
. . . control over leased property required further improvement to ensure continued economy and cost effectiveness.
. . . a need to monitor the level of dead rent as a performance indicator and to discharge the estate management responsibilities.

The report, in fact, detailed the volumes of dead rent. For example, the amount of dead rent paid in 1987-88 in Queensland was $395,000. The dead rent paid for the first four months in 1988-89 was $220,000. The amount of dead rent paid in 1987-88 in Western Australia was approximately $410,000. The Auditor-General stated:

In Queensland and Western Australia, though noting that the percentage of dead rent was not significant in 1987-88, AAO recommended the establishment of a level/rate of dead rent which APG considers acceptable, against which APG could assess its performance in this area.

The quite proper response from the Department of Administrative Services was that no level of dead rent is acceptable. I think the taxpayers would accept that view. I hope that, as a result of the Auditor-General's inquiries, this matter is massively improved.

Many other matters relating to the Administrative Services portfolio I intend to take up in the Senate Estimates committees, but there is no doubt that these matters involving clear wastes of Government money have to be fixed up. For example, in the Procurement and Stores Division of the Administrative Services portfolio in Townsville it was found that, after introducing a microcomputer based purchasing and stores control system, testing indicated a 30 per cent error rate between stock balances recorded on the system and physical stocks. So these reports go on. In view of their importance, I am sure that other senators will wish to raise many matters. For example, in the report on the Department of Defence the Auditor-General stated:
a proliferation of documents and reports and poorly co-ordinated document processing which were leading to delays and lack of control indicated streamlining was needed.
Mainframe computer and support systems were not capturing relevant operation data . . .
As there are so many of these reports, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Acting Deputy President, may I say at the outset that it is a pleasure to see you for the first time, on my part at least, occupying that position. I understand that you have done so earlier, but I could not have been in the Senate at the time. Because there are time constraints upon us and because I am aware that we particularly wish to move on to discussion of order of the day No. 116, the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits Determination Revocation and Tribunal Membership) Amendment Bill 1989, I wish to make four very quick points relating to the motion moved by Senator Michael Baume that the Senate should take note of the remaining papers tabled by the President this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I want to add my support to the remarks made by Senator Michael Baume in his opening comments on these reports; namely, the procedures that are now being adopted in relation to the tabling of these papers. I want to say without elaboration that the points made by Senator Baume in that regard are extremely pertinent and that the manner in which these reports are now being handled represents a significant constraint upon the effectiveness and the efficiency of the Senate in handling them. I trust that these comments and those of Senator Baume will be taken into full consideration by the President and by the Government.

My remaining comments will now relate to the report by the Auditor-General to which Senator Baume directed the bulk of his remarks, which is a response to report 296 of the parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts, entitled Accountability, Independence and Objectivity. That was a most significant report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and by definition, therefore, the comments by the Auditor-General on that report are also likely to be highly significant. I want to quote merely three paragraphs from the foreword to that report. The Auditor-General states:
Of course, the most significant recommendations require decisions by the Government, including decisions on future funding levels.

The Australian Audit Office is at a crossroads. It has introduced a variety of changes aimed at increasing productivity significantly and improving its service to the Parliament, the Government, its other clients and the community generally.
Other changes are now required if it is to sustain this momentum-otherwise it will continue to fall further and further behind because its operational base is insufficient to sustain momentum.
I think those last words in the foreword to the Auditor-General's report are also contained in paragraph 5.5 of the report, which constitutes part of the Auditor-General's conclusions.

My third comment arising out of this report is simply to note paragraph 5.4 in chapter 5. I think this paragraph may already have been quoted by Senator Baume, but I regard it of such importance that I think it worth quoting again. The Auditor-General states:
The Committee's Report indicates bi-partisan support from the Parliament for a substantially strengthened AAO.
That is the Australian Audit Office. To continue:

But it is not only the Parliament which needs an effective AAO. Such a body is essential also to provide unbiased assessments to governments, so that the Executive will be better informed in making decisions on its allocation of resources among the many competing programs and activities; and so that the Executive will know more about what its component parts, including government business enterprises and companies, are doing.

I stress the dichotomy there between the Parliament on the one hand and the Executive on the other. The office of the Auditor-General-and I will come to this as my final point in one moment-is and certainly should be seen as an office responsible to the Parliament. But it is entirely false and, I think, entirely deplorable that under this Government there appears to have grown up the view that, because the Auditor-General's office is a creature-and I do not use that word in any pejorative sense-of the Parliament, in some sense it is an enemy of the Executive. That ought not to be the case. In any case, I pick up the key point made by the Auditor-General that the Executive itself needs the resources and the services of the AAO in order better to carry out its own responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —A temporary embarrassment may lead to a long term benefit.
—As Senator Baume says, a temporary embarrassment to the Executive may lead to a longer term benefit not merely for the Executive but certainly for the Parliament and the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: My final point simply is to take particular note of recommendation 3 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and of the Auditor-General's response to it which are set out on page 36 of the appendix to the report. The recommendation is that `future audit legislation state unequivocally that the Auditor-General is an officer of the Parliament in order to emphasise the Auditor-General's relationship with Parliament'. There is no constitution in the United Kingdom from which these structures are basically derived under the Westminster system. But, certainly, in the unwritten constitution, if you like, that prevails in the United Kingdom, one could say it is a constitutional fundamental that the office of the Auditor-General is an office of the Parliament. To the extent that there is any doubt about that matter in this country, there is not the slightest doubt in my mind that that doubt should certainly be resolved in the manner which has been suggested. I close on that point not because one could not say a great deal more arising from this report and, indeed, the other reports to which Senator Michael Baume has referred in his motion but because we have time constraints upon us.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO EUROPEAN PARLIAMENTARY INSTITUTIONS AND ITALY 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to European Parliamentary Institutions and Italy in 1988. I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important delegation which has an important task to perform. This year's delegation will shortly visit the European parliamentary institutions to seek to ram home and reinforce the messages that have been presented so strongly by delegations from this Parliament in Europe in recent years. There can be no more crucial time than now for these delegations to spread that message. Right now Europe is in the process-particularly in the Common Market area-of becoming a closer, tighter unit. In 1992 there is to be a dramatic reduction in the barriers between members of the European Community. The expansion of the European Community to include countries such as Portugal, Spain and, of course, Greece raises additional questions and problems. It also raises the possibility of additional threats and challenges to Australia. Is this to be a fortress Europe, or is it to be a place where Australia will have greater opportunities because it will be a bigger, better and bouncier market for our goods?

SPEECH.PARA: I came back from the visit by this delegation with very little confidence that Australia would substantially benefit from Europe in 1992. A recent private visit to the United Kingdom to discuss this matter with industrialists, bureaucrats and politicians has simply underlined my concerns. While I do not fear the development of a fortress Europe in 1992, I fear that there will be a more introspective Europe, that there will be a greater prospect of European investment finding appropriate niches and greater opportunities within Europe and that the volume left over which can be taken up by countries such as Australia may well be diminished.

We will be a less attractive home for European investment when countries such as Portugal and Spain join the European Community. I believe that these countries are about to undergo an industrial revolution. Their ancient agricultural practices will be reformed. The rural communities will be urbanised, thus providing a large pool of labour-perhaps cheap and unskilled-which will be available to those entrepreneurs who might prefer to invest in Europe rather than risk investing their money far away from home. Already we have seen evidence of Japanese car manufacturers, for example, wanting to build car plants in Spain. Some of the entrepreneurs I spoke to in Britain talked about increasing their interest and involvement in Portugal where they considered there were great opportunities, particularly for an upgrading and a sophistication of agricultural production which at the moment in so many instances seems to be little more than at a subsistence level in many parts of that country. There is a problem and I can only encourage the current delegation to read the report which we are now debating and to press with great vigour the matters that we have raised and are concerned about with the politicians and bureaucrats they will meet in Europe.

I thank the people we met in Europe who provided us with great hospitality and immense assistance. In particular, I would like to thank the Italian Government of which we were guests for a week or so. It was most hospitable. One must remember that so many Australians are of Italian descent. There is clearly a strong link between our two countries. I hope our visit underlined, confirmed and assisted the strength of that link. One should also give special thanks to the Australian Ambassador in Brussels, Mr Peter Curtis, and his special assistant, Jean Page, for their help and dedication in ensuring that the delegation had every opportunity to put Australia's case to our European colleagues. We should also thank the many European parliamentarians and officials who gave us a very good hearing. They went out of their way to be hospitable and to devote a considerable amount of time to listening to our complaints and seeking to answer many of them, even though their answers in many instances seemed to me to be inadequate.

I remind the Senate that it is all very well talking about a richer, more effective, more united, stronger Europe making itself a better market. But has Europe become a better market for Australia since Britain joined the Common Market? The answer is that Australian exports to Europe-when we include Britain-are still suffering as the result of the loss of our special relationship with the United Kingdom. It may well be that that loss will be picked up in the event of Europe not turning into a fortress Europe, being more outward looking and being prepared to undo some of the disgraceful-and I use that word advisedly-agricultural policies which are deliberately aimed at blocking more efficient, more effective Australian exports from entering the United Kingdom.

I was glad to have the opportunity to address the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe on this very matter. I stressed that what Europe was doing was disadvantaging not only Australia but also the Europeans themselves, particularly in terms of employment. The evidence of the adverse employment effects of the current agricultural policies in Europe-conversely, the beneficial macro-economic consequences of a genuine reform of farm support policies-is growing all the time. It points to the fact that the domestic agricultural policies pursued in most Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries have been failures. They have sought to achieve social and other objectives by inappropriate mechanisms in agricultural policy. They impose costs that go well beyond the direct and obvious budgetary costs and beyond the transfers from consumers to subsidised producers. They reduce growth rates and they increase employment. This is a dramatic fact.

Some of the estimates of the unemployment effects are astonishing. For example, a recent study in Germany suggested that agricultural liberalisation could lead to as many as 850,000 extra jobs. Current agricultural support policies have been responsible, according to some estimates, for increasing European Community unemployment by as many as three million. So there is clearly a mutual interest in the Europeans stopping these politically attractive devices they have for blocking our agricultural trade and adopting the same sorts of policies of relaxation of trade barriers that they find so attractive in manufactured goods but so unattractive in primary products, where the political implications are so serious.

I want to express some concern about the nature of these delegations. There was a debate on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) at the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. In that debate, Mr Mountford, the leader of the Australian delegation, made a speech strongly supporting a recommendation that the United States of America (USA), the United Kingdom (UK) and Singapore consider adopting an urgent timetable for their return to membership of UNESCO. They had withdrawn from UNESCO because that body had become a political ramp using funding, largely from the United States, for the purposes of political propagandising in so many of the developing countries of the world.

Quite frankly, the Opposition has some difficulty with that proposition. I was particularly annoyed that Mr Mountford, in his speech to the Assembly, said that the call for the USA, the UK and Singapore to consider adopting an urgent timetable to return to UNESCO was not simply the Government's policy but also was the Parliament's view. That is simply not so. No delegation leader has the right, in my view, to say that that is the Parliament's view about a matter as contentious as this when it has not been before this chamber. In fact, it is the strong view of many of us in the Opposition that the United States acted quite properly in withdrawing from UNESCO. Until there is clear, unequivocal evidence that the ramps have been corrected-and I must say that the new head of UNESCO was a very impressive person, and I acknowledge that he gave us clear indications of his intention to fix those things up-I do not think it is proper that Australia should be seen as supporting the urgent return of these countries to UNESCO.

Even worse, when I sought to put the Opposition's view in the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, I was gagged and prevented from doing so by a majority vote of the delegation. This was done by the simple procedure of telling me that the head of the delegation was the person who indicated to the President of the Assembly what the Australian speaking list was to be and I would not be on that list, with the result that, if I stood, I would not be recognised by the Chair. That is a disgrace. It was put to that Assembly that it was the view of the Australian Parliament that the US and the UK should urgently consider returning to UNESCO. That is false, and I was prevented from being given the opportunity of stressing that there was a contrary view in Australia.

It seems to me that there is a need for this Parliament to indicate to the leaders of such delegations that they have no right, firstly, to bind the Parliament and, secondly, to censor members of the Opposition who seek to ensure that an honest and proper view is given about a division of opinion in Australia as to the correct course. I was told by the majority of this delegation that it was improper to suggest that there was any view other than a Government view in these matters. In fact, that is not so. This was a parliamentary delegation, not a Government delegation. For members of the Australian Labor Party to ride roughshod, with their normal arrogance, over members of the Opposition in this way is an absolute disgrace. I hope that the President-and I intend to draw this matter to his attention-and the Speaker will ensure that guidelines are brought down to make certain that, if there is an opposite view on a contentious matter, the Opposition will not be censored in this disgraceful and jack-booted way.

Apart from that matter, I wish to commend all those involved with this visit. It was a very worthwhile one both for the members of the delegation and, I hope, for those people to whom we had the opportunity to outline our concerns. I hope that those concerns have been taken on board. There is no doubt that, within the communities themselves, there are specific worries. For example, we had the opportunity of talking to some people in Italy who are deeply concerned about the implications of the pasta decision. Around Europe we were well and truly favourably welcomed and we had the opportunity, which was appropriate indeed in view of the recent fiftieth anniversary of the outbreak of World War II, to visit the war graves in Flanders and to place a wreath at the Menin Gate. I thank the Senate for giving me the opportunity to make this statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this evening the President of the Senate tabled a letter from the Auditor-General over the signature of the First Assistant Auditor-General, J. S. O'Neill, with regard to the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). Of course, this relates to the ongoing financial saga in this area. I find the letter from the Australian Audit Office (AAO) tabled this evening most concerning, because it relates to the 1989-90 Budget Papers for estimates coming up which include a review of the figures in the ADC annual report of 1987-88. What has been highlighted by this most concerning letter is that a number of statements made in the Estimates papers which have been presented to the Senate for consideration are now said by the Auditor-General, in very plain English and a number of times through the letter, to be incorrect. For example, at page 133 the ADC says that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) requested the Auditor-General to conduct an efficiency audit of the ADC's systems, et cetera, and that the Auditor-General agreed. The Auditor-General states:

SPEECH.PARA: That is incorrect. The special audit was an audit of accounts and records and conducted under provisions of the Audit Act different from those concerning efficiency audits.

There are four instances where these differences of opinion have arisen and the ADC says that the Audit Office significantly widened the scope of its audit. This is countered by the Auditor-General. He says:

That is incorrect. In accordance with normal auditing practice, the scope of the audit was not restricted at the start of the audit, and AAO made it clear to ADC in November 1988 that the audit would not be confined to Canberra or to projects mentioned in Senate Estimates Committee E in October 1988 . . .
Further, at page 134 the ADC says that the recommendations contained in the special audit report generally had already been implemented. The Auditor-General says:
That is incorrect. Later work by AAO and by ADC's internal auditors, Price Waterhouse, indicates that the defects in ADC's administration identified in the special audit had not been corrected. . . .
The ADC says that the internal auditors produced two reports in April 1989 which found that the ADC's procedures were adequate. The Auditor-General says:
That is incorrect. The internal auditors' report dated 3 April 1989 states clearly that ADC's procedures are still unsatisfactory. . .

I believe it is an unprecedented move by the Auditor-General to write to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives and say, in effect, that the documentation that has been presented for the Senate's consideration of Estimates is totally incorrect; therefore, it is false. Who must accept responsibility for this? It must be sheeted home wholly and solely to the Minister responsible-the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who we have said over and over again has shown scant regard for the proper administration of his portfolio.

The fact that the Auditor-General, in an unprecedented move, wrote direct to the President and to the Speaker has highlighted once again total inefficiency, inadequacies and, I would suggest, a major oversight in ministerial control. It is again a matter that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) must have regard to. It is a matter for the Prime Minister to again review Mr Hand's appointment as a Minister of the Crown.

DEBATE.TITLE: PULP MILLS: MODERN TECHNOLOGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 May 1989 Federal Ministers Button, Kerin and Richardson announced that the Australian Federal Government wished to ensure that pulp mills built in Australia be developed using the best available technology and environmental standards, and that provision be made for periodic upgrading of key technology consistent with the best international practices. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) was requested to review relevant technical issues in Sweden, Finland and Canada and to advise the Government on technical and environmental issues. This report, Pulp Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection, is the result of that investigation. It is relevant at this time because of proposals to build pulp mills in Australia, including the one at Wesley Vale and one in the south-west of Western Australia. The power for the proposed mill in the south-west of Western Australia-that is, the Western Australian chip and pulp mill-is likely to come from a proposed new open cut coal mine and proposed new power station which are scheduled to be sited in the beautiful Western Australian national park area of Mount Lesueur. I refer briefly to a leaflet entitled `National Park to Mine to Pulp Mill', which has been put out by the Friends of Lesueur, the Conservation Council and the Australian Conservation Foundation in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The CSIRO report under debate highlights the environmental problems of the pulp mill, dwelling on the poisonous effects of by-products. It does not say much about the consumption of timber. The proposed Western Australian pulp mill would use 1.15 million tonnes of wood chips per year. Currently, the Western Australian Chip and Pulp Corporation is licensed to export 900,000 tonnes per annum. This is a potential disaster for existing trees and a big boost to the greenhouse effect.

In view of the Australian Democrats' well broadcast concern for a sustainable environment, I would make some comments on the potential toxicity of pulp mill effluent, especially as it affects aquatic life. I quote from page 4 in the opening summary of the report:

The most environmentally sound, economically achievable way of disposing of effluents is to discharge them into the ocean. Effluents from a number of older mills in the northern hemisphere have created some environmental problems. In considering the key question of the impact of the effluents on the flora and fauna of the receiving waters it is concluded that: A mill, when efficiently operated, will result in no significant short term ecological impact.

However, on page 14 a description is given of some of the things that happen as a result of chronic toxicity when chlorate and other pulp mill by-products are discharged into water containing living plants and animals. Under the heading `Toxic Effects of Effluent on Aquatic Life', it says:

. . . pollution-induced habitat destruction . . . can gradually destroy whole populations of animals indirectly through the poisoning of plants that provide their food, shelter, nursery or breeding sites. . . . But chronic toxicity remains a concern. . .
The days are gone when we can simply ignore the long term impact of chemical pollution.

An interesting section of the report appears on page 53 under the heading `Decision Making Processes'. In Western Australia we are not happy with the decision-making process, because the Government makes all the decisions seemingly on criteria of profitability-that is, to itself and its well-known mates-and enormous efforts are made by citizens to change some decisions, usually without success. I cite the Kwinana petrochemical plant, which is an exception, because there is a very public quarrel going on about that at the moment.

I also refer briefly to the fact that the report dismisses the wood efficient, thermo-mechanical pulping process and also distorts the facts on future needs for unbleached paper. Unbleached paper is the fastest growing section of the paper industry and the demand for it is burgeoning. In fact, in Western Australia Coles supermarkets sold out of their supply of unbleached toilet paper very quickly. I also draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that in Western Australia a firm called Ethical and Recycled Products sells non-kraft chlorine bleached recycled paper and envelopes which are sold at the same price as bleached envelopes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH (PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS DETERMINATION REVOCATION AND TRIBUNAL MEMBERSHIP) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 September, on motion by Senator Puplick:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits Determination Revocation and Tribunal Membership) Amendment Bill 1989. It opposes it in the Senate and if it is carried in the Senate will oppose it in the House of Representatives, where it will be defeated. This Bill deserves to be defeated. As a Bill it is a fraud, a travesty and a sham. I assert that it reflects no credit on the sponsors of it. It reveals a depth of hypocrisy which is mind-boggling and it reveals the Opposition at its most cynical. I assert that this Bill is an unprincipled attempt to grandstand and to chase populist votes with no attention to substance. They are strong words. They are what some people might regard as the common rhetorical flourish of a government. I want to establish them as measured and considered words in this debate and to do so by giving a clear exposition of what the record reveals about this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing one must say of this Bill is that it does essentially three things. Termed `A Bill for an Act to amend the National Health Act 1953 to revoke a determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal', it is designed to revoke a determination of an independent tribunal made after sitting for 2 1/2 years and after hearing 160 or so submissions and representations, and to do so in a way which calls the democratic process itself into question. Secondly, it proposes to `provide qualified membership of the Tribunal, and for related purposes'. That is its euphemistic description of how it proposes to stack the Tribunal so that the appellants in this case can have their representatives on the Board and bring down the decision they seek. If one were to put it in colloquial terms this Bill takes the whistle from the umpire and overrules him. Then it sacks him. Then, in a move that would make a follower of Tammany Hall blush, it replaces the umpire with representatives of the people who claim to be offended so that then, it would assert, justice can be done.

I think this type of process, if it were allowed to pass in this Parliament, would attack what is a fundamental foundation of democracy in that the Parliament should not interfere with the role of the judiciary. In this case the people that it is proposed to interfere with are people of judicial standing. They are people who sit impartially on an independent body to make a determination based on the evidence before them. They have done that. Whether or not pharmacists have properly conducted themselves before that inquiry is a matter for people to make observations about. I make this observation about the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. I believe that it has behaved incompetently and not in the best interests of its membership. It has not addressed itself to the issues in the way in which it sought to cooperate with an inquiry about pharmacists' remuneration.

But that is the problem for pharmacists and for the Guild. It is not a problem for the independent inquiry and it is not a reason why Parliament should interfere with an independent decision. I think that it touches on the very foundation of the separation of powers for this Bill even to be contemplated. It throws up the question: why would anyone want to do that? I am afraid the horrible answer to that question is that some people think there are a few votes in it. The Government is involved in the question of pharmaceutical benefits for the reason that Australian taxpayers contribute massively to the income of pharmacists. Therefore, every Australian taxpayer has a vested interest in knowing that his tax dollar is wisely spent. In 1988-89 Australian taxpayers paid $580m in subsidies to pharmacists.

The other reason why the Government is involved is that in the past there have been proven examples of abuse and overcharging which all parties in this chamber have accepted. Therefore, there is a role for the Government, given this level of public expenditure for which we have a role in any case and given the track record of this industry, which is a reason for even closer scrutiny. I come to my third reason as to why the Government has an interest in having regulation in this industry properly and independently determined. One of the reasons why there is such an expenditure of public moneys is that the Government needs, in the benevolent and compassionate society that in Australia we aspire to, to ensure that the chronically ill, those who cannot afford it, and the underprivileged in this country have access to medication and drugs which enable them to start back on the road to good health.

If the cost of drugs is determined on the basis of who can afford to buy them, the country that enables that type of operation to proceed discriminates positively against the poor, the chronically ill and the underprivileged. This country aspires to a more compassionate approach. Because it therefore interferes in the free market of pharmaceutical trade, because it subsidises that trade to the tune of $580m and because this industry has a proven track record of overcharging and maladministration, there is a clear public role.

I have said that the industry has a clear record of overcharging. What is that record? The record is best picked up if one goes back to September 1980 when the Fraser Government was in office. In September of that year a committee of the House of Representatives reported after it conducted an inquiry into alleged overpayments to pharmacists in which it was alleged that overpayments from the public purse amounted to $253m. This was a committee of the House. It was a committee that involved representatives from all the political parties in the other chamber. It came down with a unanimous report. It reported errors in pharmaceutical subsidies totalling $175m. That was a bipartisan finding. The break-up of how those errors occurred was: $126m in overpayments in the allocation of labour costs; $62m in an analysis of the cost of goods sold; and $47m in updating the structural index. As I said, those overpayments totalled $175m.

This was a committee involving all parties. All the parties agreed to that report. On the basis of that report, and this question goes to the credibility of the industry when it makes its claims now-I repeat that it found that level of misallocation of public funds-the then Liberal Government in the guise of Mr MacKellar, Fraser's Minister for Health, introduced legislation into the Parliament to put above the political conflict the issue of the setting of pharmaceutical fees. It would be very instructive for honourable senators to read in Hansard the debates surrounding the introduction of the MacKellar Bill to render an independent tribunal in charge of the setting of these fees. Many of the things that are being said out of the mouths of members of the Liberal Party, the National Party and, I am sorry to have to say, the Australian Democrats, in this debate are in direct contradistinction to what was said at the time following the Public Accounts Committee's findings.

The MacKellar legislation enshrined the status quo. Since coming to power, we have not interfered with it. We have accepted the veracity of the Public Accounts Committee's findings. Indeed, in 1981 the Labor Party supported the MacKellar legislation. The National Party supported it and, in the Senate, Senator Don Chipp made a very direct and informative speech in support of the independence of the setting of these charges. He made a very good speech saying why that was necessary and why it should be fenced off and be beyond the interference of the Parliament. Because Senator Coulter has now joined us in the chamber, I say that in 1981 both Senator Chipp and Senator Mason made quite important speeches-and I ask the Democrats to examine those speeches-in support of the principle which now obtains and which the Bill before the chamber would overturn. It is passing strange to me that the Democrats would contemplate overturning two of their founding fathers' most impressive speeches in this chamber by voting for this Bill tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Founding parents.

—I accept the Democrats-style amendment to my remark. What those former senators sought to do at that time is encapsulated in a slogan which I sometimes find offensive when applied to us, but it is one the Democrats made their own. Senator Mason and Senator Chipp in that debate sought `to keep the bastards honest'. The `bastards' at that time were the pharmacists. The Democrats at the time believed that the way to keep them honest was by having an independent tribunal, which we now have, a tribunal made up of representatives of business and economics and chaired by someone nominated by the President of what was then the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Importantly, the Tribunal was to be a layman's court-perhaps I should change my expression to a layperson's court-so that individuals not skilled in legal presentation and legal argument could come before it, make representations and be heard on their merits without recourse to legal form and substance. It was to be a court that would operate on that basis. The Democrats supported it then. The Liberal Party introduced it, the National Party supported it, but this legislation would overturn it. One should ask oneself why. As I have said, the only conclusion we can come to is that it is a blatant chase after a populist vote.

What would the legislation do if it were carried? It would put pharmacists in charge of determining what they would receive in remuneration because the legislation proposes to stack a three-person bench with two representatives of pharmacists. In a vote, the pharmacists would have a two to one majority. It proposes to set up this chamber as a court of appeal from an independent body. What will we be interfering with next? Shall we decide to invite ourselves into arguments that the High Court might have settled? Is that a proper area for political interference? This is an independent body with judicial status and it remains statutorily independent. This legislation proposes to interfere with its judicial status. It might be that honourable senators would argue that the decision was wrong. It might be that that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely what we are arguing.

—I do not concede that argument for one minute, but it may also be that on other occasions independent judicial bodies have made decisions which people regard as wrong. Is that a basis for the Parliament to interfere in that process? Would Senator Coulter set himself up as a jury or a special court of appeal on decisions made by the High Court, the Federal Court, the Supreme Courts in the States or the Industrial Relations Commission? If he would, on what basis would he do it in our democratic system and how would he come to that conclusion? Would it be because people complained or because they said they would vote for him if he did? Would it mean that, if the air pilots came in here and said they wanted the Parliament to legislate their salaries, a majority on the other side would do so because a few airline pilots might vote for them?

SPEECH.PARA: In the interests of constructive and rational debate, I ask honourable senators to pause, wait, examine and think in terms of the importance of what they are doing if they want to vote for this Bill, because it touches directly on the foundations of our democratic system with respect to the separation of powers and the way in which governments should have their hands off the tiller when it comes to the settlement of issues as complex and complicated as this. I remind honourable senators that this independent Tribunal has sat for over 2 1/2 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Headed by a previous Labor member and previous Labour Minister.

—I will take that interjection because it is a disgusting example of an effort to sully the reputation of a person of high standard, high standing and high community respect. I take that to be a direct slur against the reputation of Deputy President Riordan, who is the Chairman of the Remuneration Tribunal. For the record, I say that it is a disgusting slur.
—Why is it a slur?

—It is a disgusting slur in the way in which Senator Walters intended to inflict those words, and she should be reprimanded for that. The choice of who chaired this Tribunal rested with the President of the Industrial Relations Commission, President Maddern. If we want to go into the background of people in the arbitration system, we would see that they have all come from one of three areas-government, employers or unions. Justice Maddern made his reputation as an advocate over many years for the employers. Would Senator Walters say that this man now on the Bench properly discharging the weighty responsibilities of being a president, a man regarded in the community by people on all sides with respect, has somehow breached the oath of his commission and has chosen a Labor person to do Labor's business? That is a ridiculous, disgusting allegation and one that is rejected entirely by the Government. Those who have made it should be dealt with accordingly. As I said in Question Time the other day, it is a pity that there is not in the existing Act a provision for contempt. I would guess that Senator Walters would not be game to repeat those words in public if there was, because she would be in contempt of the Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: Now I turn to the subject. This decision has been commonly portrayed by people opposed to it as a Government decision. It is not a Government decision; it is an independent decision. Pharmacists may find the decision not to their taste, but all of us who have been in the work force and at some time have gone through the arbitration process may have found the decisions made by independent arbitrators not to our taste. However, we have worn them and accepted them because those are the rules. This Bill attempts to change the rules, bias the game, and deliver to the appellants the right to decide their futures. That is totally unconscionable. If the precedent were set, workers would be elected to sit directly on the board of the Industrial Relations Commission to make decisions about their own wages; and that is a ridiculous proposition.

The other comment I make is that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Peter Staples, made overtures to the Pharmacy Guild of Australia during the course of the hearings and sought to find common ground with it. He made generous offers to get a common front so that the arbitration process would be either unnecessary or related to the margins of the pharmacists' claim. The Pharmacy Guild-I believe incompetently led-rejected those propositions. The Pharmacy Guild tried to sully and put a slur on the independence of the database that the Tribunal used. It did so by calling upon its members not to cooperate in the survey that was being conducted to compile the database. When it believed it had succeeded in not getting sufficient cooperation, it then said that the database was inadequate because an insufficient number of people had responded.

The reality is that the database methodology was advised by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I do not think anyone here wants to sully the reputation of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It approved the methodology, and at completion said that the methodology was sound. At one stage during the course of the compilation of the database it also said that there were not sufficient samples. Then sufficient samples were taken by telephone in order to get a critical mass of input from which there could be a reasonable extrapolation of results. That is what has occurred. There has been no cooperation from the pharmacists to compile an accurate database-none at all. The database is essential to determine what the pharmacists' rates of remuneration should be. I reject the claim of an inadequate database too.

In the time that I have left there are many other things that I could say but I conclude my remarks at this juncture by saying that Mr Staples has sought further talks with the Pharmacy Guild to discuss with pharmacists their involvement in the establishment of an essential pharmacy allowance so that remote and isolated communities can be properly served and, if necessary, supported by public subsidies to keep their doors open to render a service in remote areas or areas where there is underservicing. The Minister has sought the Guild's involvement in an inquiry into the restructuring of pharmacies and has suggested that the allowance of $50,000 over three years to help accommodate that restructuring is still on the negotiating table and should be explored, and he has proposed that there be further discussion over the professional practice allowance as well. If the Guild wants to pursue negotiations there are ways on the table in which some of what the Guild sees as problems with the decision can be ameliorated.

As I said, I conclude by making those observations in the context of what I regard as a quite fantastic position-in the extraordinary sense of that word-taken in Western Australia by the Guild. I am advised that today it has decided that its pharmacists will charge above the legal limit. They will not just pick up what they believe the decision will take from them but will make a windfall profit as well. It is not a matter of recovering the ground that they argue they are losing; they want to make a profit on top of that. In doing so, they breach the rules of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme itself. The Guild is urging its members to commit a breach of the National Health Act. This illegal act by pharmacists can only penalise people who are chronically ill, who are in need of medication, who cannot afford to pay the higher rates or who are pensioners. This is consistent with the pilots' approach-thumb your nose at society, do not obey the rules, charge what you want, create a free market, and take the public subsidy as well. On last year's figures the public subsidy was $580m. As I said, this is a quite fantastic position taken by the Guild in Western Australia. If this Bill were to pass it would give succour to that type of approach. For that reason, along with all the others I have put, this Bill should be defeated. If it passes here, it will be defeated in the other chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me first of all disabuse the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) in relation to some of the things that he said. He implied in his remarks that, no matter what judgment a tribunal makes or how damaging the results of its deliberations, we should slavishly accept its determinations. I cannot accept that position. In this case it is clear that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal decision is not only wrong but also extremely damaging. Moreover, I point Senator Cook to the Remuneration Tribunal's decisions in relation to parliamentary salaries in which quite clearly for reasons of public popularity the Government has sought to interfere. There is certainly an adequate precedent for the Government to interfere with tribunal decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures do not stack up. The determination, as I will show, is totally wrong. It will not succeed in doing what the Government says it hopes to do. Let us begin by accepting that some months ago the Government announced that it wanted to pull $20m to $30m out of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). That is the basis from which this whole program has proceeded. The result of the determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal is that many pharmacists will just close their doors. It may be that we have too many pharmacists, but this is not the way to cause their pharmacies to close and, as I will show, it is not a way by which the Government will be able to reduce the amount that it pays out under the PBS. Unfortunately many pharmacies which close will be those which provide the most needed services such as those in small towns and isolated suburban areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—It is true, although Senator Cook tries to interject, that provision is offered for special payment in those cases. It means that those pharmacies will be dependent upon largess and an arbitrary determination of to whom and for how long those extra payments will be made. The present determination, if implemented, will be a severe penalty to pharmacists. It will cause a real reduction of more than 20 per cent-23 per cent or so according to one estimate-in PBS income to pharmacists. Senator Cook has said that in times past pharmacists have made an illegitimate gain from the sale of pharmaceuticals. Even if that were true, does he imply that somehow or other the Government should get back at pharmacists? Is this a reprisal? Surely that is not the way to run a government pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
—That is not what I implied either.

—That was certainly the implication of the Minister's remarks. The 20-odd per cent reduction in real income to pharmacists through the PBS is in addition to a 12 per cent real reduction in income which has been suffered by pharmacists over the last 12 months. The 28 August decision of $1.05 per prescription and the total elimination of the mark-up component is the basis of this very substantial reduction in the remuneration of pharmacists under the PBS. The pharmacies which will survive will do so by cutting costs. The only way they can do that is by reducing staff. That will result in a drastic reduction in service to the public and the lowering of standards of pharmacy practice in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Staples was reported today as saying-and again holding this out as a threat-that he will be prepared to open supermarket pharmacies.
