I do not want to see pharmacies run as they are in South-East Asia, where one goes to the local corner store and buys antibiotics or whatever without any control or supervision and without any professional competence in the provision of those pharmaceuticals.

It is a matter of concern that the costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme are increasing. The Government has said that it anticipates an increase from $1 billion to about $1.2 billion-the American billion: 1.2 thousand million-in just one year. But this piecemeal approach of taking $92m over two years out of the pockets of pharmacists is not the way to go. Let me illustrate that by way of a question which was asked of Senator Cook today in this chamber by a member of his own Party. In relation to the supply of insulin he was asked whether it was likely that pharmacists would not stock insulin on the shelves. Insulin costs some $80, I think. Of that $80, when the fee which the patient pays goes from $11 to $12, the Government will pick up $68.

TALK.START.PARA: —The taxpayer picks it up.

—All right, the taxpayer will pick it up through the Government. The way in which that $68 is split between the pharmaceutical chemical company which makes the insulin and the pharmacist who dispenses it does not make any difference. The taxpayer will still be picking up $68 of that $80 cost, and that is the essential point in the fallacy that the Government is proposing. The cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is determined by prescriptions written by doctors. It is not determined by the pharmacists who dispense those pharmaceuticals; it is determined by the numbers and kinds of prescriptions which are written and the cost of those prescriptions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has determined which drugs will be put on the PBS and, accordingly, a certain amount of money must be picked up by the Government. The majority goes to the pharmaceutical manufacturing companies and the minority goes to the pharmacists. The Government is seeking to change that split, but this will not alter by one dollar the overall cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. A review of the whole pharmaceutical benefits scheme would be needed to do that. There would need to be a change in the nature of the drugs that are put on the list, an instruction to doctors to change their prescribing habits or a change in the pattern of the use of pharmaceuticals by the community. Those are the things which will change the total cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to the taxpayer via the Government; not the amount that is paid to pharmacists. Presumably, the same number of prescriptions will be dispensed and the same cost will be borne, but drugs will simply be distributed by fewer pharmacies.

As I have said, it may be desirable for there to be fewer pharmacies, but that is a different argument and this is not the way to tackle that problem, if it be a problem. Even if we accept that we should reduce the number of pharmacies, surely it might be better to control the number of pharmacists by simply training fewer pharmacists in our universities. It does not make a great deal of sense to put pharmacists through tertiary training in universities or institutes and then have them unemployed at the other end-thrown on the scrap heap. That does not make any sense at all; it is absolutely crazy. This Government has introduced a tertiary fee structure under which a graduate repays those fees to the Government once his income reaches a certain level. But there is no way that people who finish up on the scrap heap because they cannot find employment will be able to repay their tertiary fees. If we really have too many pharmacies, let us look at that problem and address it in other ways. But do not spend tens of thousands of dollars putting students through a tertiary course and then throw them on the scrap heap.

I turn to the question of services which pharmacists provide, for which they are not reimbursed and which will be seriously affected as a consequence of what this Government is doing. Many pharmacists provide home delivery services for pensioners and people who cannot get to a pharmacy. The costs of those services are borne by the pharmacists. Pharmacies also employ high school children to make deliveries on pushbikes out of school hours. So these services involve a redistribution of income and part-time employment for a large number of people. If we are really going to reduce the benefits to pharmacists in this way, those services will simply disappear or a lesser service will be provided to the public.

The Minister said that it was inappropriate for people who are supporting this legislation to speak in any derogatory or critical way about the data on which this Tribunal decision was based. It may be true that the pharmacists discouraged people from contributing to the survey. But let us have a look at that survey. There are 5,600 pharmacists in Australia and there were 53 replies to the survey. Less than one per cent replied. I have a certain background in statistics and epidemiology and, from my own knowledge, I would say that is a totally inappropriate sample on which to base a decision that affects the other 99-plus per cent of pharmacists, particularly when one recognises--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was topped up with another 94 telephone surveys.

—One should recognise that that data collection was done at a time when substantial changes to the PBS were already in train-changes which had not worked themselves through the PBS system. I think the data is certainly challengeable. Mr Lee, the Director of the Statistical Methods Section, appeared before the Tribunal on 29 April and said:

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of non-response to the survey is particularly important, as any substantial amount of non-response can throw serious doubts on the validity of the survey results. If non-response appears to be a significant problem-
and the Minister has admitted that non-response was a significant problem-
the value of proceeding with the survey should be re-examined closely.
The Minister has said, quite rightly, that there was an additional survey by way of the telephone. That is a very unsatisfactory basis on which to proceed with this sort of determination.

I return to the two basic points. Firstly, we should not slavishly accept a Tribunal decision when that decision is wrong and when it is very damaging. Of course, we have the precedent of the Government itself interfering with a tribunal decision, so it ill behoves the Government to say we should not make some comment upon those decisions. Secondly, the cost of the PBS to the taxpayer is a function of the number and types of prescriptions which are totally determined by the prescribing doctor against the range of drugs which are supplied under the PBS by government decision. It has nothing whatsoever to do with the amount of the reimbursement which goes to the pharmacist-the split between the pharmacist and the pharmaceutical manufacturing company.

My final point is that the Minister reflected on our honesty and integrity. He clearly reflected on the second part of Senator Puplick's Bill, which seeks to change the composition of the Tribunal. The Australian Democrats agree with Senator Cook on this. We do find that an inappropriate way to proceed and, accordingly, in the committee stage we will seek to separate this Bill into two parts. We will support the first part, namely, the non-acceptance of the Tribunal's determination in this instance, but we will be voting against the second part. So, presumably, on that occasion we will be voting with the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My impression of the debate over the last few weeks on the changes that have now been announced by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal is that there is an enormous amount of confusion, very little light and a great deal of heat in respect of this issue. On checking with my office today I found that the situation is exactly as I had suspected. Members of the Australian Pharmaceutical Guild are not only angry and puzzled by the decisions of the Tribunal, but also feel let down by the Guild. Their level of knowledge and understanding of the procedure and of the decision is very low. Whether this is simply as a result of ineptitude, the difficulties of communication or deliberate misinformation I am not in a position to say. However, instead of holding public meetings, shutting their shops, spending a great deal of time collecting signatures and putting out a lot of very misleading information, the Guild could certainly be using its time a great deal more effectively by informing and instructing its members about the processes and giving them some guidance.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout this process the Government has been very happy to negotiate. Prior to the matter going to the Tribunal a series of offers was made to the Guild which, once again, very few of the Guild members were properly informed about. At that stage we were talking about a package that could be taken as a joint submission between the Government and the Guild. This package included a 10 per cent mark-up, a $50,000 amalgamation offer, limited control over new pharmacies, an essential pharmacy allowance, and differential fees for low volume pharmacies. Despite our best efforts, these offers, which would have been highly acceptable to a vast proportion of pharmacists, were rejected. The Tribunal therefore made a decision on the basis of the information before it.
We have heard criticisms about the size of the sample actually studied. That in itself is a misleading criticism. The Tribunal's data base inquiry final report states:
The Tribunal has not determined this level of fee as a result of a simple arithmetical exercise-
as some people would have us believe-

but has made a judgment based on the evidence in its totality and after having regard to all of the submissions which were made by each of the principal parties, the various associations and bodies and the very many individuals who responded to the advertisements published in the major daily newspapers and circulated in each of the States.

There were 628 submissions before the inquiry. As a proportion of the total number of pharmacists in Australia, that is 12 per cent-a not insignificant sample of people who were concerned enough to make the effort to make a submission to the Tribunal. This is a considerably wider response from the industry than some would have us believe. I reiterate what was said by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook): The sample itself was determined on a totally valid basis. I will read this for the benefit of those who simply do not know what the decision was, because for some reason or other they have not taken the trouble to read it. The decision states:

The total fee will be constituted by the two elements stated earlier and will be separately adjusted on a regular basis in accordance with criteria laid down in this decision. In accordance with the statutory provisions there will also be an annual review . . .

This is not saying that this is the full stop for the end of time. There will be an annual review with a public hearing for the purpose of generally reviewing the fees to ensure they remain fair and reasonable and to hear any submissions and/or to review any material submitted by a party, organisation or interested person relating to any suggested inequities or other relevant consideration. Additional reviews to consider any special circumstances will be considered as appropriate.
This is not the decision of a tribunal which is shutting the door to any submissions from any quarter. In fact, it looks like a very wide open tribunal. It goes on to say:
The first element in the new base fee will be an amount of $2.45 which is to cover the cost of labour in supplying an item covered by the NHS.

That is the national health scheme. Senator Coulter would have us believe that there are to be no savings whatsoever from the changes announced by the Tribunal within the last week or so. Added to this $2.45 is the second element in the new fee concerned with non-labour costs, which has been fixed at $1.05 per item dispensed. The base fee will be reduced from $4.55 to $3.50. This is exactly what the chemists are complaining about-a reduction of $1.05c on every prescription. I would be very surprised if that did not add up to a significant saving for the Government. I am not a mathematical genius but I do know that $3.50 is considerably less than $4.55. If it is not, what is all the fuss about? The new rate represents the maximum amount, which is justified as a matter of equity and fairness having regard to all the available evidence, not just the result of that one survey which Senator Coulter has problems with. The report states:

It represents a significant reduction in pharmacists remuneration . . . should be phased in by making three adjustments each equal to 35 cents per RP item; the first effective on and from 1 October 1989, a second reduction of 35 cents effective on and from 1 May 1990 and the third reduction of 35 cents effective on and from November 1990.

This has been done on the basis that the studies done by the Tribunal have shown very clearly that over the last decade there has been quite an outstanding increase in the profitability of pharmacists because principally they have been depending quite heavily on the Government mark-up and dispensing fee, though as we know only about 30 per cent of the profits of pharmacies come from their dispensing of pharmaceutical benefits. However, the Commonwealth provided estimates to the Tribunal of gross pharmacy profits over the last decade and compared the movement over the previous five years to the movement in two general indicators. These are commonly used indicators, ones with which we are all familiar. Gross pharmacy profits rose by 85 per cent in those five years, the consumer price index rose by 43 per cent and average weekly earnings rose by 39 per cent. On the basis of these findings, and of all the different positions in those 628 submissions put before the Tribunal, it was decided that the time had come when there should be a cap placed on the dispensing fee and that it should be done in such a way as to leave it open to the industry and to the Government to make further submissions as the situation changed.

Given the great increase in profits over this time-as we understand it much of that occurred between 1984 and 1986-it seems probable that many people have gone into the industry believing that the level of profits would continue to increase. This has meant that in many cases there are far too many pharmacies. It has been acknowledged by Senator Coulter and many other people that it is an overpopulated industry, to say the least.

Today we heard some very disturbing news from Western Australia as a result of the meeting held there by pharmacists this afternoon. They shut up shop for a couple of hours and then issued a communique. As far as I know this is unique in the nation-I certainly hope so anyway. This indicates once again what I said earlier-they simply do not understand the decision; they have no idea of how it will be implemented. Honourable senators opposite will be interested to hear that they have decided that a strategy committee will be appointed to quantify reductions to pharmacists caused by the recent decision and that all Western Australian pharmacists commence recouping from the public the Government's subsidy reduction of $1.05 for each pharmaceutical benefits scheme item dispensed according to a timetable.

I have just read what the Tribunal's plan is-it is not an immediate reduction of $1.05; it is a reduction of $1.05 over the next 15 months, the first reduction of 35c to take place on 1 October. They are not just recouping the loss of that 35c. They are intending to recoup the whole $1.05-a windfall profit-from 1 October from the general public, from 1 November from concession card holders, from 1 December from pensioners and from 1 January from repatriation patients. I find it absolutely unbelievable that such a level of irresponsibility could exist in an industry which purports to be one of providing the community with an essential service and one that the community simply cannot do without.

Once again, having taken this decision and having put themselves out completely on a limb, I am afraid the chemists will look very foolish when eventually-if they ever get around to it-they look closely at the decision that has been made. The chemists will also find that in addition to the determination in relation to the dispensing fee there are other elements which will be of enormous importance to many of them. Where a pharmacy is classified as an essential pharmacy the Tribunal says that there is a convincing argument for a factor to be included in the fee to meet the cost of a replacement pharmacist during a pharmacist's annual leave. Otherwise, it is possible that there may be no pharmaceutical services available in that locality. So essential pharmacies-pharmacies in outer urban areas, pharmacies where there are people with very little mobility, pharmacies in rural areas where there are no others within some distance-will have the capacity to attract an essential fee. There will also be an extra fee for essential pharmacies of $5.40 payable on and from 1 October 1989 to be adjusted in the same manner as is prescribed for other prescriptions. In addition, there will also be a dangerous drug fee. It has been decided that $2 be that initial prescription fee payable on and from 1 October 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very temporary.
—I do not know on what basis my colleague from Western Australia would say that that was a very temporary fee.
—If you hang around a bit later, I will tell you why.

—I base my statement on the Tribunal's operations in the past. For eight years we have had Tribunal decisions. The Tribunal in that time has brought down 12 determinations on remuneration of pharmacists under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The Government of the day has not always agreed with the determinations but has always respected and abided by the decisions. That does not mean that decisions are slavishly accepted; it means that the Tribunal, having been set up by Senator Coulter's honoured colleague Senator Chipp and others some years ago, is respected and that its findings are accepted as the findings of those independent people who have made their decisions on the basis of the best information available.

SPEECH.PARA: I observe that the foresight that was shown by the Government in 1981 and the words of Senator Chipp at that time do not seem to be echoed these days. In fact, I might almost be tempted to say that the shoes left by Senator Chipp have not necessarily been very well filled in the intervening years. There is no doubt whatsoever that the density of pharmacies in some areas has grown to quite ludicrous levels. I am quite stunned to discover that out of roughly 5,600 pharmacies in Australia about 1,300 are in Western Australia. That means that Western Australia is very oversupplied with pharmacies. That may well be the reason for this extraordinary decision this afternoon: the competition is just far too much for many of them.

This Government is very well aware that the pharmaceutical industry represents a very wide range of businesses-businesses which in some cases are more like the American drug store and sell absolutely everything from newspapers to jewellery and perfumery; take the dry cleaning; process photographs; are open 24 hours a day and are doing very nicely indeed. At the other end of the scale we have a country pharmacy which is depended upon by people in a particular town. The fact that it exists is absolutely essential to the well-being of those people. We believe it is essential that the interests of all of these pharmacies are taken into account. In that case, blanket decisions in relation to areas other than dispensing cannot be made.

As I said earlier, the door is open for negotiations with the pharmacists and their representatives. It has always been the case. We are very happy to see arrangements made which secure the existence of central pharmacies. We are not very happy to go on subsidising pharmacies that are struggling along in areas where there are far too many pharmacies and where this subsidy is of no advantage to anybody, let alone the consumers and certainly not to the taxpayers. There is very little point at this stage in trying to overturn the decision of the Tribunal, which was made on the basis of the best information available. In addition to that, the reasons for which the Tribunal was established in 1981 are as valid today as they were then. There is no doubt in my mind that there is no justification whatsoever for these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —`The priorities of this Government in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme remain: that is to maintain effective pharmacy to supply the best drugs and to protect the aged and chronically ill'. These words, may I remind the Senate, form part of a speech by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) in the House of Representatives in May this year. Yet what have we seen since then? No effective pharmacy and no action by the Government to maintain reliable and substantial services to the community. Instead we see crisis after crisis in the delivery of good pharmaceutical services. After listening to Senator Giles speak before me I am convinced that the Government wants to close many of these pharmacies. The Government does not believe in private enterprise; it does not believe in free enterprise.
—It does not support these small businesses.

—Pharmacies are small businesses. That is the trouble. The Government wants to socialise the pharmacy businesses. That is what I can see is happening. I believe that it is time we stopped the rot, which is what the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits Determination Revocation and Tribunal Membership) Amendment Bill 1989 that Senator Puplick has introduced on behalf of the coalition is meant to do. We are all aware of recent reports that, as a result of current Government plans to slash pharmacists' dispensing fees by 23 per cent, many services provided by these chemists will disappear. It will mean cutting the cost of dispensable drug scripts by $1.05. These changes would cost each pharmacy $25,000.
—Disgraceful!

—It is disgraceful. Ultimately it will mean that 1,000 of Australia's 5,609 chemists will close. I have no doubt that that is what the Government wants to happen. Changes which involve the freezing of gross margins and the redistribution of the current pool of $503m among pharmacies take no account of the impact of operating in a climate of high inflation, high rents, high interest rates and other high overheads, including staff wage rises flowing from the tax-wage trade-off. And who is responsible for those costs? This present Labor Government, no less.

SPEECH.PARA: Pharmacies in Kingaroy have drawn my attention to the fact that past governments and Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal decisions have already caused pharmacists to lose about 14 per cent in income over the past 12 months. The Tribunal's statement that the result has not been reached without regard to the consequences which are likely to follow raises serious questions as to just what its intention might be. Perhaps the clue lies in its final recommendation that there should be an inquiry to consider an appropriate restructure of pharmacy outlets.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would Joh have done?

—I am sure Joh would have shown the right attitude. He certainly would not have done what the Labor Party is doing; I can assure the honourable senator of that. Quite clearly, the likely consequences of the Tribunal's latest attack on pharmacies will be the curtailment of many of the services which pharmacists currently offer and the closure of even more pharmacies, leaving pensioners and families with children without ready access to the professional services of a local pharmacy. We have heard on the news and read in the newspapers talk about having supermarket pharmacies. I do not believe that any of these moves would be in the best interests of the health care of the community, which has an extremely high regard for the front-line role pharmacists play in delivering that care.

SPEECH.PARA: These are just some of the problems, as I see it. I have received mail from pharmacists. They say: `Why should I accept no mark-up? Do you know any retailer who sells goods at cost? It costs me money to get it on the shelf. It costs me money to keep it there'-with an overdraft, as honourable senators can imagine and, `it costs me money when a doctor orders a part pack and the rest may be wasted. It costs me money when stock goes out of date and has to be thrown out. It costs me money because I cannot return some indate stock, for example, flu vaccines'. These are some of the problems that have been drawn to my attention by pharmacists in our area, and I think that we ought to consider them tonight. Many honourable senators will have received, as I have, hundreds of letters, from pharmacists pleading with us to help them in their predicament.

While there may be some grounds for rationalisation in terms of the overall number of pharmacies, I am concerned that the Government's current actions may result in closures of pharmacies in areas which can least afford them. Country towns where there is only one pharmacy will be particularly disadvantaged and unfairly penalised. That will happen in a number of small towns in our home area. In fact, I read in the Courier-Mail, our Queensland newspaper, that up to one-third of country pharmacies will be forced to close because of cutbacks proposed to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. This will bring undue medical hardship to the residents of these towns as well as severe financial and social loss to local communities.

During the past few weeks I thought that surely there must be some action that the Government can take to ensure that so many pharmacies will not be forced to close. However, because of what appears to be a total abrogation by the Government of its responsibilities in this area, we now have to propose such changes as are before us today. An article in the Courier-Mail headed, `Many chemists facing ruin, guild predicts', states:
Pharmaceutical Society of Australia national director, Dr Beresford Scott, yesterday predicted the PB scheme would show signs of collapse as early as next week.
Dr Scott said he did not accept the tribunal's decision could not be waived.

The Government says that it cannot be waived. What about the Remuneration Tribunal's decision in relation to the salary of members of parliament? What about its decision in relation to providing stamps for members of the House of Representatives? These are some of the reasons why I cannot see why it is not possible to change the Tribunal's decision. Pharmacists have a vital role to play in the delivery of health care to the community. The value of pharmacists' professional skills in providing counselling aimed at ensuring that patients follow appropriate medication usage regimes cannot be underestimated.

I can assure all honourable senators that I will work to overcome inequities in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the changed remuneration package for pharmacists to ensure that the community, wherever it is-in the country, in provincial towns or in the major cities-continues to have ready access to pharmaceuticals and the services of professional pharmacists. That is why I support the Bill that Senator Puplick has introduced into the Senate on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we are debating the results of this Government's disastrous health policy. Because of the ridiculous philosophy of this Government we find that the cost of Dr Blewett's health policy has blown out of all proportion and the Government is trying to save money by attacking the pharmacists and forcing them to pay some of this blow-out.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the history of the behaviour of this Government towards the pharmacists over the last couple of years. First, the Government demanded that the pharmacists change their payment system to a computer-based system. Pharmacists were under threat of a delay in Government payments if they did not comply. The Government insisted that the pharmacists bear the cost of this new system; otherwise their cash flow would be severely disrupted. Last September the Government removed 53 drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits list and replaced them with cheaper generic drugs. According to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, the Government hoped to save $40m over three years. Expensive drugs were allowed to be issued only with special permission. Can the Government pretend that this was in the best interests of the patients? That had nothing to do with it. It was to save money and save money only, and in the process it reduced the pharmacists' incomes once again. Patients, primarily pensioners, were told that the drug they had become used to, which they knew suited them and which they had no reaction to, would no longer be available and they must accept a cheaper drug as a substitute.

We are all aware that this did not work. The Government was forced to put many of those drugs back on the list. As a result, we had dreadful confusion. Not to be defeated, the Government then doubled the number of drugs allowed to be put on each prescription. Again, this was not for the benefit of the patient or in the interests of good medicine; it was purely and simply to save money, mainly because the Government did not want its precious Medicare philosophy to be acknowledged as a failure.

We then move to the present situation. The Government has set up the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to rule on fees payable to pharmacists to supply drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Who are the members of this committee? First, the Chairman is Mr Joseph Riordan, a former Australian Labor Party member for Phillip and Federal Minister for Housing and Construction between 1972 and 1975. When I interjected about this the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) said that this was a dreadful slur on this gentleman. My comment is only that I do not believe he knows a lot about the pharmaceutical profession. There are two other members of the Tribunal: Margaret Jackson, an accountant; and Professor Jeffrey Richardson, an economist. They are hardly a trio of experts in this area even though they have undoubted expertise in other areas. Hence, the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits Determination Revocation and Tribunal Membership) Amendment Bill would add to that Tribunal an additional two members with the necessary knowledge.

Senator Cook has told the Senate that the Tribunal, having made its decision to cut 23 per cent from pharmacy dispensing fees, cannot be ignored: the Government has no option; it must accept the Tribunal's decision. This is a lot of rubbish. Of course the Government has the power to refuse to accept the Tribunal's recommendations. The decision cuts $1.05 from each prescription and abolishes the present 25 per cent mark-up on the wholesale price of drugs.

Let us see what this is likely to do to Australian pharmacies and to the patients if the Minister persists in this way. Let us look at the No. 1 priority; that is, the best interests of the Australian people's health. What will this do for patients? I can assure the Senate that it will do immeasurable harm to the patients. One thousand pharmacies-and that is a conservative estimate-will close if this decision goes ahead. How can the pharmacies be expected to absorb this cost? The Government expects to save $20m for the remainder of this year. How much will it save in the full year? In all, the Government expects to save $31m from its Budget. Let me quote a member of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Lamb, who is one of the two pharmacists in this Parliament. He is reported to have said that the decision showed that the Tribunal was out of touch. He called for the Government to work out a new system of remuneration. I note that Senator Aulich is not speaking in this debate. An article in the Examiner today describes a phone link conversation that Senator Aulich had with the pharmacists. It reads:
Senator Aulich was sympathetic to the current situation and showed a good understanding of the ramifications of the decisions in Northern Tasmanian pharmacies.
He indicated to us that he would be talking to the Minister for Community Services, Mr Staples, to put to him some of the points raised by us.

But Senator Aulich does not have the courage to come in here and say those things. He says it to the pharmacists back home, but at no stage will he say those things in the Senate. We will see how Senator Aulich votes on this Bill. Back home he tells the pharmacists that he is in sympathy with them, that they have made valid points, and that he agrees, but we will see how he votes on this Bill.

I have spoken in this place before about how this Government works. We have seen its methods time and again, particularly those of the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett. When his precious Medicare scheme is threatened he immediately attacks a member of the medical profession. Honourable senators will remember the doctor bashing that went on a few years ago when Dr Blewett accused doctors of fraud and overservicing to the tune of $120m. At that stage he was preparing the Australian community for a bit of doctor bashing. He was attempting to convince people that they could not trust their family doctors. He implied that they were all crooks. He then took action to cut doctors' incomes. His grossly inaccurate claims were finally dispelled by the Department of Community Services and Health, which said that those figures were a mistake, that there was no fraud to the tune of $120m, that there was no tag at all.

Then the pathologists were abused. Their individual incomes-not the taxable incomes but the gross incomes-were leaked to the media. Pathologists, who traditionally employ large numbers of staff, had their gross incomes leaked as though the figures were their take-home pay. The pathologists finally took the Government to court and won their case. But the community had been softened up by Dr Blewett and the Government. They were saying that the pathologists were a lot of rogues. Now the Government is attacking the pharmacists. Let me read some media headlines to the Senate. One reads, `Government may legislate to stop drugs ``rip offs'' '. Another one reads, `How chemists rip you off on prescriptions'. Once again, the Government is softening up members of the community, trying to convince them that they cannot trust their local chemists. They have been accused of ripping off up to $25m by overcharging on prescriptions. Once again, there is nothing to substantiate the claims at all. It is reported that the Department said:
While we have no hard evidence on the extent of the problem . . .
There is no evidence at all. Once again Blewett and his crowd were softening up the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is common courtesy when referring to Ministers of the Crown, members of parliament or senators to use their proper titles, irrespective of how heated we are at the particular time. I ask that you draw that to the attention of the honourable senator who is speaking.
—Senator Walters, will you please refer to--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I certainly will. Dr Blewett once again is trying to soften up the community. He has no evidence at all of any rip-offs by the chemists. Once again he is using the same tactic. He is saying, `You can't trust your local pharmacist'. Now the Tribunal has made a decision. All those slurs were made before the Tribunal's decision was handed down. The Government, having tried to get the people on side, having tried to get them not to trust their chemists, is saying to them, `We're going to cut them down because they are a bunch of crooks'. Let me tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President--
—Again, I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. The term `bunch of crooks' is clearly unparliamentary and ought to be withdrawn.
—I cannot uphold that point of order.

—Who is the Government copying in all this abuse? Who is the Government copying in all this softening up? It is Hitler. Let me explain to the Senate what Hitler did. He embarked upon an identical exercise before he marched into Czechoslovakia and before he marched into Poland. It was exactly the same softening up process against the Jews. Hitler used identical methods. He abused various groups of people and then marched in and took action against them, expecting to get the community on side so the people would not object to his abuses. The same method is being used by this Government. We are all used to these methods. But the people are asking: Why is it that it is only under this Government that the doctors and the nurses have been on strike? Now we have the pharmacists on strike. Never before have these professions been on strike until this Government comes in and uses these sorts of methods against them.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened to Senator Giles tonight. She said, `We've got too many pharmacists. We should close the pharmacies down'. That is her answer. Mr Staples is saying, `We'll put their stock on the supermarket shelves. That is how we'll close them down'. That will not work. The people are awake to the methods being used by this Government. They will not tolerate this any longer. The pharmacists are spreading the word. The people who use their pharmacies are being told what is happening. We heard tonight on the news that hundreds of thousands of pharmacists and their staff are on strike all over Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to spend very long contributing to this debate tonight. But I rise out of a sense of anger and, I think, frustration because of some very ill-considered remarks that were made by the previous speaker, Senator Walters. The remarks are particularly disgraceful this week because of the history of this week. It is this week that people right across the world are remembering the fiftieth anniversary of the start of the Second World War, a war that destroyed many people and almost destroyed a race of people. To draw an analogy between the happenings of 50 years ago and an economic and political dispute between a section of the Australian community and the Government is really scraping the bottom of the barrel.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McGauran is trying to interject. His time here is very limited. I have heard many outrageous comments which unfortunately have come from all sides of the chamber. But I really think that we have hit the pits tonight for the sake of winning a few votes. We have heard an analogy drawn between the happenings in Australia today at a series of meetings and the desecration of a race of people some years ago by one infamous individual. It is unfortunate, indeed pathetic, that the chamber cannot take some action against outrageous, outlandish and scurrilous claims such as those we have just heard.

I regret having had to intrude in the debate; I have used only two minutes. I hope that the point is made. If we want to score points, we can do it in political and economic debate, but we ought to be a little sensitive to the feelings of those many people, not only Australians, who are hurting very deeply this week because of this anniversary. Senator Panizza can shake his head. If he is prepared to tolerate it from his side of the chamber, he can tolerate the admonition that goes with it from this side of the chamber. The race from which Senator Panizza evolved was intimately involved in that terrible crisis that befell the world. The race that I come from was neutral, but my people suffered as well. I really think it is the pits that we have stooped to those low levels to win a few votes and to satisfy a few constituents. We can do it in other ways.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for very long, but I want to make a few points regarding country pharmacies. I am sorry that Senator Cook and Senator Giles are not in the chamber, as they remarked on this matter earlier. If the Government succeeds in its attempt to rationalise the number of pharmacies in the cities, people in the cities will then have to drive an extra five or six kilometres to get to a pharmacist. What is more, people in the cities always have access to pharmacies that are open for 24 hours. But, as Senator Walsh will tell us, it is a far different story in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook told us that he was going to keep the country pharmacies open with a subsidy on the number of scripts they dealt with. When Senator Giles was speaking earlier I interjected and said that that would be a temporary measure. That situation will remain while a pharmacist is prepared to stay in a country town. As soon as he is too old or wants to move out, for education or for any other purpose, no-one will take his place. In my home town we have a pharmacist who is over 80 years old and who cannot get anyone to take his place. A qualified pharmacist in the district who is a farmer shows him some mercy by helping him out at weekends to give him a holiday every now and then. That is the only way that we have kept our pharmacist. He would have gone long ago if that were not the position.

I come back to the point that a pharmacist who is kept in a town only by a subsidy will never be replaced once he has gone. That is when the trouble will start. The doctor may then be given permission to dispense drugs himself or the stock will be taken over to the hospital and there will be a limit on the hours in which people will be able to get drugs. As Senator Giles or some other honourable senator said, the patent medicines will then go into self-service stores. That may be so but, if that happens, people will lose the free advice that a pharmacist always gives them if they purchase patent medicines from him rather than go to the doctor. More people will then go to the doctor and so this Government will be copping more bills. A pharmacist in a country town does a lot of other things in the paramedical field. He generally runs the ambulance and helps in a number of other areas. If he leaves it will be an even bigger loss to the town.

Senator Giles suggested that we should adopt the American system. As a former matron of a hospital and a former country person, she ought to have another think. Professionalism would be lost if a corner drug store dispensed drugs that, if taken in the wrong quantities, are highly dangerous. Senator Peter Baume, who is a medical practitioner, will tell honourable senators what can happen if mistakes are made and someone dispenses a drug of the wrong strength. Professionalism will go out of the door. I think the Government, and especially Senator Giles, should have another good look at this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to close the debate on the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits Determination Revocation and Tribunal Membership) Amendment Bill 1989. The purpose of this Bill is twofold: firstly, it overturns the decision of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal dated 28 August 1989, which has been the subject of the primary debate tonight; and, secondly, it makes changes in the membership of the Tribunal and the way in which the Tribunal shall conduct its inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal very briefly, as I am conscious of the time limitations, with the principal comments made by way of criticism by Senator Cook when he spoke this evening. However, before I do so I place on record my thanks to my colleagues Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Walters and Senator Panizza for their contributions to the debate tonight and, in particular, for their forbearance in keeping their remarks brief, because I know that each of them would have wanted to speak at considerable length. I also thank my colleagues Senator Boswell, Senator Susan Knowles and Senator Watson, who did not participate in the debate this evening despite the fact that they are extremely well informed on this subject and who would have made very powerful and detailed contributions to the debate this evening. I place on record my thanks to them for their forbearance.

The three points of importance which Senator Cook made and to which I turn are these. Firstly, he says that this Bill is an attack upon the independence of a tribunal and that that is somehow incorrect and illegitimate-the same point made by Mr Staples in a press release which he put out on 30 August, and in which he called for what he described as `respect for the umpire'. In fact, that would carry some weight had it not occurred in the same week that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) went before his Caucus and said to his Caucus, for a purely political purpose, `Let us overturn the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal dealing with parliamentary salaries'-not just a decision which is prospective but a determination which has already been accepted and which people have been notified will come into effect in progressive stages-or were we not to get back into this Parliament, a piece of legislation to alter the remuneration provided for members of the judiciary after they had had their wages and salaries determined by an independent tribunal.

At the end of the day there is one far more overriding principle than this question of the independence of tribunals and judiciary determinations-that is, the absolute and overriding principle of the supremacy of the elected Parliament. That is a point from which no derogation can be accepted at the end of the day. No matter what the Tribunal says, this Parliament is supreme. Indeed, if the High Court of Australia says something that this Parliament does not like, the Parliament often legislates to the contrary. We have in the House of Representatives at the moment a piece of legislation seeking to overturn, in effect, a decision of the High Court made in relation to the immunity of Commonwealth instrumentalities. So the supremacy of this Parliament is the overriding and overwhelming issue to be addressed. Senator Cook, in Cabinet and Caucus meetings, undoubtedly did not front the Prime Minister on Monday or Tuesday this week and say, `We must not do anything about interfering with the Remuneration Tribunal determination on salaries because there is perceived to be a greater public interest in taking action'.

The second thing, to which Senator Coulter also alluded, was somehow an indication that changing the membership of the Tribunal was improper. The proposal in the Bill which I have presented is that the Tribunal, instead of consisting of a chairman who shall be a member of the Industrial Relations Commission and two other persons, shall consist of the Chairman, who shall be a member of the Industrial Relations Commission, and two other persons appointed by the Minister from persons who have qualifications, knowledge and experience relevant to the pharmaceutical profession or industry. It does not say that they shall be pharmacists. It does not say that they shall be nominated by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia or by any other particular body. For instance, it might be an economist who has practised long in the area of health economics with a specialist relationship with and knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry. It might be a statistician or an epidemiologist with qualifications relevant to the pharmaceutical industry. It might be a manufacturer of pharmaceuticals. It might be somebody who has been involved in clinical trials on pharmaceuticals. It simply says that they shall be persons who have qualifications, knowledge and experience relevant to the pharmaceutical profession or industry.

I remind Senator Cook of a debate that took place earlier today. The Minister was establishing a vocational registration eligibility committee (VREC), and he put on that vocational registration eligibility committee a ministerial nominee and four other persons, two to be nominated by the Australian Medical Association (AMA) and two to be nominated by the Royal Australasian College of General Practitioners (RACGP), the people immediately involved. That was the principle of the body set up by legislation passed today in terms of the VREC and VRAC-vocational registration appeals committee-arrangements that we were talking about earlier today who had those particular qualifications relevant to the job. In fact, they removed representatives of the Australian Medical Council, I think it was, and a body called NSQAC-the National Specialist Qualification Advisory Committee-because they were not regarded as having the qualifications which were better represented by having two AMA and two RACGP representatives.

I also remind Senator Cook of the other debate we had here some time ago over the determination by the Pathology Services Advisory Committee. He will recall that that committee has five members. The Chairman, as with the Chairman of this particular committee, is a judge of the Industrial Relations Commission. If my memory serves me correctly, it is Mr Justice Munro. The Pathology Services Advisory Committee has to have nominations from the Royal Australian College of Pathologists. So the tribunal that makes the determination about pathology services has as direct representatives nominees of the pathologists.

This proposal advanced by the Opposition today does not go that far. It does not say that they have to be pharmacists, it does not say that they have to be nominated by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia or any other professional body; simply, that they have to have qualifications which the Minister regards as meeting the determination of being relevant in terms of their knowledge and experience so far as the pharmaceutical profession or industry is concerned. For the life of me I cannot see that that constitutes any improper attempt to put the whistle into somebody's else's mouth, which was basically the analogy that Senator Cook wanted to draw. Frankly, I think that is an unsustainable argument.

The third point that Senator Cook raised was the question of whether this determination was made on the basis of best available evidence. I would like to canvass that at considerable length, but I will not. If honourable senators look at the speech which my colleague Senator Watson made on 5 September at pages 1010-1017 of the Hansard, they will see the most erudite analysis of the flaws in the Tribunal's determination. Senator Watson analyses in considerable detail the forecasts, the methodology and the relationship between pharmacists' gross income, the cost of pharmaceutical goods, labour costs and the costs which the Government has already imposed on the real income of pharmacists over the course of the last couple of years. He draws attention in that speech to the Government's submission to the Tribunal about the proprietor's notional salary being taken at $15 an hour and how unrealistic that is, and the question of the restructuring of the dispensing fee. For those who want to see a most trenchant analysis of the flawed methodology of the Tribunal, I commend to them a reading of Senator Watson's analysis.

Regarding the quality of the survey, those who look at the page numbered 9 in the Data Base Inquiry Final Report of 28 August will see the very limited number of responses. For example, in the survey of pharmacies in Victoria, only 6 per cent of pharmacists responded to that particular questionnaire; it was only 32 per cent overall. I make only two other brief comments about the actual nature of the Tribunal report. On the page numbered 10, in a table which deals with the cost of dispensing per prescription, there are some figures which I do not believe add up, particularly the figure of $3.55 which is given as the current salary rate arising from a study of 150 pharmacies. The table gives the updated cost at 1 August 1989 as $3.55, but if one reads through the rest of the Tribunal determination one will see that they in fact work on the basis that it was only $3.50. So its own internal methodology is a bit suspect.

The final point I make is about the question of treating the umpire with proper respect. I draw attention to another page 10 in this report in relation to the Tribunal's comment about the comment made by His Honour Mr Justice Northrop in the case of Pharmacy Guild of Australia and Another v. Riordan and Others. I read two paragraphs only:
In his decision in Pharmacy Guild of Australia and Anor v. Riordan and Ors, Northrop J. in referring to the Tribunal's duty in determining the Commonwealth price said:
`The Tribunal is not concerned to determine the remuneration of approved pharmacists'.
The report then continues with these immortal words:
This comment by his Honour is not to be taken too literally.

Frankly, when the Tribunal finds itself in a position of saying that the comment made by His Honour Mr Justice Northrop, a most senior judge of the Federal Court of Australia, is not to be taken too literally, I think one is entitled to wonder precisely what the argument amounts to about having respect for the umpire's decision. I think one is entitled to raise that matter.

I make several points in conclusion. Senator Coulter has raised the question of insulin today. I shall read only one of the many hundreds of telegrams which I have received, this one from a pharmacist in West Hobart:
Why should I dispense drugs at a loss?

Insulin is a life-saving drug to those who use it. Under the proposed remuneration package struck, the Government will pay $86.80 cost of drug for the NHS quantity and $4.20 dispensing fee, a total of $91.00. The actual cost of the NHS quantity is $92.01. Net loss on dispensing will be $1.01.
Why should I dispense the prescription at a loss?

It is a fair and legitimate question. It is probably the reason that, in the Launceston Examiner of 7 September 1989, Senator Aulich, who had spent some little time running away from his comments about the use of judicial power in industrial disputes, has been quoted in an article. It says:
Senator Aulich was sympathetic to the current situation-
this is in relation to pharmacists in northern Tasmania-
and showed a good understanding-
I interpolate: by telephone, at a distance, and certainly not in Tasmania itself-
of the ramifications of this decision in Northern Tasmanian pharmacies.
`He indicated to us that he would be talking to the Minister for Community Services, Mr Staples, to put to him some of the points raised by us'.
All I can say to the pharmacists of northern Tasmania is that they ought to find themselves a senator who is more persuasive with members of his own Government.

Mr Staples has now said that his intention will be to split the pharmacy profession by moving to isolate the big tough pharmacists, as he describes them, compared with the smaller moderate pharmacists-a tactic of divide and conquer, which this Government believes is the correct way to proceed, whether it happens to be in industrial relations or in the provision of health services. It is perhaps churlish of me to say that I was intrigued by an interview which took place on 3AW when Neil Mitchell interviewed Mr Staples. Mr Mitchell put the question to him:

Good afternoon, Mr Staples, wouldn't you think it true that one of the main reasons that you are pursuing a vendetta against the pharmacists is that you yourself flunked out of pharmacy school, and failed exam.
Far be it from me to be churlish and go on with the rest of the interview to demonstrate whether or not that was true. Nevertheless, it does make interesting reading.

I conclude by saying that we believe that the case for the disallowance of this determination is overwhelming. I reject Senator Cook's comments in terms of the independence of the umpire, thereby vitiating the right of the Parliament, and the attempt to provide for the qualifications of members of the Tribunal as somehow being illegitimate. I certainly reject his attack upon the pharmacy profession which he characterises as being involved in gross and systematic overcharging and thievery from the public purse. I reject the underlying assumption that the Tribunal decision is well-founded. I refer again to the excellent contribution by Senator Watson on that particular matter. I therefore have great pleasure in commending to the Senate the passage of the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits Determination Revocation and Tribunal Membership) Amendment Bill 1989.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-take together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to the fact that the Opposition proposes a technical rewording of clause 2. Currently clause 2 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent or 30 September 1989, whichever is the earlier.
I am advised that this should be recast to read as follows:
If this Act receives the Royal Assent on a day after 30 September 1989, it shall be deemed to have commenced on 30 September 1989.
Therefore, I move:
1. Page 1, clause 2, lines 10 to 12, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Commencement
``2. (1) Subject to subsection (2), this Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent.
``(2) If this Act receives the Royal Assent on a day after 30 September 1989, it shall be deemed to have commenced on 30 September 1989.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite happy to accept the amendment to the Bill as proposed by Senator Puplick in his last form of words. I ask the Senate to reject clauses 1 to 3, as amended. I do so not because there is something particularly offensive about clauses 1 and 2-if there is to be a Bill it would reflect the words that are in the technical form as set out in clauses 1 and 2-but because we are opposed to the Bill we reject those as well. The substantive provision on which we wish to focus our remarks is clause 3, which we reject. Clause 3 is headed `Disallowance of PBRT decision' and states:

SPEECH.PARA: The determination of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal dated 28 August 1989 and made under section 98b of the Principal Act is and shall be of no force or effect.

That is a very serious proposition. If one were to approach this issue with clean hands, an open mind and a reasonable cast of view as to what in all the circumstances is a proper course, one would have to say that what has been put in the debate in here, in the wider public forums and through the media, does not constitute in any way, shape or form a body of reasonable evidence to move this chamber to interference with a decision impartially arrived at by a tribunal properly appointed and bearing the oath and commission of its status after spending 2 1/2 years hearing evidence and receiving over 160 submissions. I put it to the chamber that it should reject these clauses because, even if it were to believe that substantive doubt has been cast, there has been no serious effort to try to see whether the prima facie belief that the Opposition holds is true.

One of the standard provisions for which this chamber has become famous, and for which the Australian Democrats in particular have made a name for themselves, is to refer any controversial matter to a committee of the Senate so it can inquire into the matter further. No effort has been made by anyone to do that. If there was a degree of seriousness about the belief that the Democrats may hold, I would have expected a proper form and procedure to be engaged in. That has not been done. The Opposition proposes to overturn a decision of a commission that has held a proper inquiry for 2 1/2 years and to do it on the basis of no substantial evidence whatsoever. I would suggest that what has been put forward is hearsay, argument by assertion, and loud and ringing statements by vested interests. Moreover, in my view, they are vested interests that have been misled or incompetently led in the presentation of their case to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. But that is a matter for the membership. They wished to interfere with the proceedings of the Tribunal by trying to wreck the database on which the Tribunal's decisions were to be founded. Although they failed to do that, because I believe the database is sound, they now wish to try to destroy the Tribunal because they choose not to like the decision.

I cast the minds of honourable senators back to an inquiry of the Public Accounts Committee in 1980. On a bipartisan basis in the House of Representatives, the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party found that there had been misappropriation and misuse of public funds to the level of $160m-plus. I remind honourable senator that that Public Accounts Committee investigated allegations that in excess of $250m of public funds had been used inappropriately in pharmacy operations in Australia. Based on the findings the then Liberal Government, with the support of the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, enacted this very legislation that it is now proposed be set aside. I suggest that, given the history, the charge, the investigation, the acceptance of the allegations to a large extent, bipartisan legislation and the setting up of an impartial tribunal, it requires a better answer than simply coming in here on the basis of hearsay. Many statements were made before people even read the decision. A better answer than that is required. If this Bill were passed it would be a travesty and a reflection on those who voted for the proposition.

If we measure what has been put, not by beyond reasonable doubt, which is a criminal standard of proof, but by balance of probabilities, which is the civil standard of proof, this chamber, on what it has before it to prompt this debate, fails the test on evidentiary grounds. If we then argue that there ought to be an appropriate procedure, this chamber fails the test on developing an appropriate procedure to get the evidentiary base. On those two bases alone, the proposal cannot and ought not succeed.

I spent a bit of time in my primary address directing myself to what this proposal does. We have set up an independent tribunal which has functioned under the laws of this country since 1981. To this point it has survived a coalition Government and a Labor Government. It has developed a substantial reputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The membership has changed, though.

—I will respond to that interjection because I have taken the opportunity to read the speeches made in 1981, including Senator Watson's contribution to the debate as to why the Tribunal should be independent. In Senator Watson's contribution to the debate some time in May 1981, as reported in Hansard, he asserted the need for independence and non-interference. He cited a history of where political interference in these decisions in the past had created controversy. Senator Watson has therefore invited me now to ask him why he has changed his mind and why he thinks political expediency should be the basis of decision-making in an area such as this.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the honourable senator's interjection was of a different colour. His interjection cast a reflection on the independence of the Tribunal. I have dealt with this question a couple of times, but I need to deal with it again. It seems that the Opposition believes that the independence of the Tribunal can be freely impugned because its Chairman at one stage was a Labor politician. That seems to be the basis of the argument. I have said before that it is a slanderous proposition and I do not in any way resile from that, but I make this point again: the Chairman of the Tribunal did not choose himself, nor was he appointed by this Government. The Chairman of the Tribunal was chosen by the President of the then Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Anyone who impugns the choice of chairman impugns the President of the Commission because he chose someone he thought was appropriately equipped to chair this body.

If Senator Watson wants to have resort to what I regard as slander-that is, to cite the previous record-then he might well say that no judge is safe because he may at one time have represented a defendant who was found guilty and therefore he is suspect; he might say that a judge who may at one time have been a member of the Labor Party is suspect. But I go back to this point: if the honourable senator thinks that the history of an individual should be held against him in the exercise of his judicial authority, I point out that the President of the Arbitration Commission was for a long time the leading employers' advocate in this country and was identified more with the honourable senator's side of politics than with ours. I do not in any sense put forward this argument, but the honourable senator invites me to do so by his implication that the President of the Commission is somehow trying to put in a Labor fix. That is a ridiculous and stupid proposition and it should be withdrawn. I hope Senator Watson will find it within himself to do so.

Neither the evidentiary nor the procedural base exists. The procedural base exists only in the figment of the imagination of those opposite because they have a convenient majority in this chamber at the moment. One can speculate about why there is a convenient majority-perhaps because there are grubby votes in it; because there is a public outcry; because there is disaffection; and because pharmacists are embarking upon a campaign to assert themselves over their consumers in a way which leaves open questions of their duty to their consumers and their professional ethics. Nonetheless, they are conducting that campaign. Thus it is that on that very seamy, very suspect political basis we have a unity of view in the Opposition. There is neither the evidence nor the procedure to support it. The procedures adopted by the Opposition parties when in government are the procedures we have observed and they should be followed.

Before I conclude, I make one other comment. In the debate in this chamber and the wider public debate there has been a fudging of a very important distinction. On the news tonight, I saw people protesting against the Government's decision, as they termed it, through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. The Government has not made a decision; the Government is bound by the decision of an independent, judicially appointed body.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bound! You are not bound; come on.

—We are bound by that. I invite Senator Panizza to read the second reading speech of Mr MacKellar when he was Minister for Health. He said that the Government and the pharmacists will be bound, and that is the truth of the matter. But those who chase grubby votes in the gutter will not want to draw that very clear and real distinction because it does not suit their case. I ask that these clauses be struck out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make only two points because we are supporting these clauses and I think we can dispense with them quite quickly. Earlier, Senator Puplick read out figures in relation to the costs of dispensing particular drugs and the remuneration to the pharmacist for dispensing them. He showed that the costs were greater than the remuneration. The pharmacist had posed the question: `Why should I dispense an agent if it is going to cost me more to dispense it than not to dispense it?'. Senator Cook asked for evidence. That is one fact.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I make, and I link it with the first, was made by Senator Giles. She totally demolished the Government's case when she said that, in cases where pharmacies were essential, the Government would make an extra payment. It follows automatically from that remark that all those pharmacies that do not get the extra payment will go to the wall. It follows absolutely from that remark that those pharmacies that are regarded as essential will get an extra payment. If they do not need an extra payment, why is the Government giving it to them? Those pharmacies that do not get an extra payment will go to the wall. The Government will determine through that mechanism which pharmacies will go to the wall or simply continue to sell stockings and so forth. Perhaps they will take the American path and sell ice-creams and many other things. That is the evidence, and on that evidence alone we support clause 3. We believe the determination should be overthrown.
Amendment agreed to.
Question put:
That clauses 1 to 3, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 4 and 5-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not prepared to support these clauses. For reasons which I indicated at the second reading stage of this debate, we do not believe that what the Opposition has proposed is appropriate. Honourable senators will be aware that I have introduced a private member's Bill which suggests an alternative course to this. In any case, neither of these clauses is a matter of urgency and the matter can afford to be delayed and debated at another stage. We are not supporting these clauses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the adoption of clauses 4 and 5. The most obnoxious of the two clauses is clause 4 regarding Tribunal membership. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Subsection 98a (2) of the Principal Act is amended by omitting paragraph (b) and substituting the following paragraph:
``(b) 2 additional members, appointed by the Minister from persons who have qualifications, knowledge and experience relevant to the pharmaceutical profession or industry.''.

As I have said, this is the more obnoxious of the two provisions. However, clause 5 introduces, for want of a better term, a note of hilarity into the debate by saying something totally meaningless. It says:

``(2a) In an inquiry under subsection (1) the Tribunal shall have regard to the need to ensure that variations in the Commonwealth price of any pharmaceutical benefits have the effect of facilitating the efficient and effective provision of national health care services.''.

That element is considered in any judgment anyway, but it is in the mind of the beholder what an efficient national health care service is. This clause is introduced simply because outrageous, unsubstantiated, unproven and untested allegations are being made about what the effect of the current Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal's decision will be upon the delivery of pharma- ceuticals across the range. Not only are those allegations unproven, but they omit to acknowledge the fact that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) has embarked on a series of discussions with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia about such matters as the professional allowance and-I cannot recall its precise term-the isolation allowance. It is an allowance which would be provided by the Government to ensure that isolated pharmacies are kept open to serve areas on the ground of geographical need or that they are underserviced. Clause 5 suggests that the Government is not mindful of the need to provide a spread of services based on regions and meeting need. Indeed, the Government has been prepared to put its money where its mouth is in offering subsidies to maintain that spread of service and meet those needs.

Clause 5 suggests that the obverse is true and that, somehow or other, the Tribunal should be saddled with making all of these decisions without the necessary access to the public purse to guarantee that the effect of those decisions will be real. Since, according to the 1988-89 Budget, the Government has put $580m into this proposal as subsidies for pharmacists, I think it ought to be acknowledged as having a huge stake in delivering the services that are required. I think, therefore, that this is an obsolete and unnecessary provision. But, as I said, it is not the more objectionable of the two.

The more objectionable is the one in which the Tribunal is fixed to bring about the decision one wants. I welcome the Australian Democrats to the fold on this aspect, because I understand that Senator Coulter has indicated that they will be supporting the Government's position on this. Indeed, so did Don Chipp when he spoke in the debate in 1981. In 1981 Senators Chipp and Mason, both speaking on behalf of the Australian Democrats, supported-on a Bill introduced into this chamber by Senator Messner, as the Minister representing the then Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar-the provision that the Tribunal panel be constituted in its present way, and that it have regard to economic and accounting principles. This provision has been down-played in the addresses in support of it by the Opposition. It has been suggested that any range of people with a passing knowledge or whiff of experience of pharmaceuticals might qualify in the eye of the Minister.
Senator Chaney interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is no likelihood of any other business being transacted tonight.

—That is true, but we will have to move suspension of Standing Orders and do all sorts of things if you want a vote. We will have to move it tonight. I am not trying to interrupt you, Minister, but we have got until 10.30. I am alerting you to the fact that we can negative the adjournment question and carry on into the night if that is your wish.

—Let us see how the debate unfolds. This amendment impugns the reputation of two of the members of the Tribunal who have sat on the hearings thus far. It is a direct assertion, by its very existence, that those people did not bring to the evidence and to the 2 1/2 years of hearings the scrutiny that was necessary to make a sound judgment. Therefore, it is an inappropriate provision.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, it has been brought forward because of the public outcry of which I spoke earlier; a public outcry which seemingly has startled the horses in the Opposition to chase votes; a public outcry which is based on prejudice and bigotry. There is a sense that the pharmacists are entitled to what they want irrespective of the determination of an independent Tribunal. This proposal fixes the Tribunal in a way in which maybe the appellant can obtain what he thinks is justice, without necessarily weighting the Tribunal in a proper, balanced way in order to have the breadth of experience necessary to make objective judgments about what the level of pharmaceutical payments should be. For those reasons, and in recognition of the support we have from the Australian Democrats, I oppose these two clauses.
Clauses negatived.
Title agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
