DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Airline Pilots Strike-Australian Labor Party-Imam Al Hilaly: Permanent Residence-Child Migrant Scheme-Standing Committee on Community Affairs: Report-Timber Industry, Tasmania-Australian Wheat Board-Yugoslav Secret Police

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do a deal with honourable senators: when the pilots go back to work I will stop speaking on the adjournment. This afternoon during another debate I used some fairly direct language in reference to members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. I do not resile one iota from what I said. One of the reasons I used that direct language was that representatives of the Federation have not expressed the slightest concern about and have shown a complete lack of interest in the effect the dispute is having on every section of the Australian community.
—That is quite untrue, Senator.

—If Senator Stone wants to defend the Australian federation of air pirates, he can go ahead; he is welcome to do it. The pilots have been criticised by the most extraordinary array of leading lights in our community including, of course, very recently the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, John Elliott, who would not be described as a bleeding heart leftie. Of course, John Elliott tipped a great bucket on the centralised wage fixing system at the same time. I quote what he said about the pilots in an interview on The World Today on Monday, 4 September:

SPEECH.PARA: I am no supporter of the pilots. I've checked the numbers out. The pilots on our corporate aircraft that I fly, fly nearly twice as many hours as TAA and Ansett pilots and I reckon they sit around too much. It's just that the planes are not flying. The pilots in the United States on domestic airlines fly 2 1/2 times the hours of the pilots in Australia. So there's something wrong.
There certainly is. One of the interesting things happening in the pilots dispute is the education of the public-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—Senator Maguire is quite right-it is happening. People are being educated in terms of what formerly has been an area that very few people knew about; that is, the salaries and conditions of Australian pilots. I know personally of former Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines pilots who are now very busily flying for charter companies. They have broken their own strike. This is happening not only in the Northern Territory but right around Australia. I have also recently been told of pilots who hold legal qualifications and actually run thriving legal practices as well as flying aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: The other day a person I know told me about an Ansett pilot who runs a very thriving bobcat hire business. Before the air pilots dispute started this fellow was always intrigued that this Ansett pilot could make $80,000 a year from operating a bobcat. He could not work out how this pilot, who had told him that he operated a bobcat himself, could possibly run a $80,000 a year bobcat hire company while flying an Ansett jet. Since all of the information has come out about the pilots' working conditions, and since he now knows that the pilot works only three days out of seven for the company that pays him, he knows perfectly well how he makes $80,000 a year out of a bobcat hiring business.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many days do grain loaders in Queensland work?

—If I am provoked beyond endurance I will carry on for half an hour. I rose tonight to tell a story about a small group of young Australians who have been affected by the air pilots dispute and who were here in Parliament House yesterday. Tonight I will hand out some brickbats and some bouquets. The brickbats are certainly for the airline pilots of Australia. Late last year a group of schoolchildren from Berry Springs School in the Northern Territory-not the upper end of town I can assure you, Mr Acting Deputy President-planned a trip to Canberra and the snow. An entire class of primary school children has been fundraising for that trip for the whole of this year. I am sure many honourable senators know that it is a very painful job raising money for that kind of excursion for kids whose parents simply cannot afford, out of their own pockets, to send them off.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been actively engaged in assisting the children in that fundraising. I went out to the school and told them what they would find down here. Not surprisingly, not only was the fundraising part of their entire school year but also the trip to Canberra was built into the class curriculum for the whole year as an educational and learning exercise. And a very excited bunch of kids they were. When I went out to the school a couple of weeks ago, before the strike started, to plan the final part of the trip, all the kids were in the classroom armed with their maps of Canberra and Parliament House. I handed out the worksheets that had been sent to me from the Education Office in this place and we had a session on Parliament House.

I am not telling this as some sort of bleeding heart story that I have dug up. It happens to be the cold hard truth. At three o'clock when I had finished with these kids the principal of the school said, `Come outside'. The buses were lined up outside to take the kids away. There was one kid-obviously I am not going to name him-climbing onto the bus with a green plastic garbage bag clutched to his chest with a grin on his face like a Cheshire cat. The principal said, `I want to take you outside and to introduce you to this kid. We have just told him today that he will go on the trip. We are fully funding him because his parents are pensioners and cannot send him and he has just been into St Vincent de Paul to get his winter clothes'. If honourable senators had seen this kid they would have thought that he had just come from Marks and Spencer. I shook hands with him and he said, `I am going on the trip'. I said, `Yes, that is terrific'. He said, `I have got all of these clothes-jumpers and things-for nothing'. I said, `That's great'.

A few days later the pilots went on strike. This was calamity for this small group of kids. They had been raising money for the entire year. The entire trip was supposed to last only a week, flying each way. Then there was a problem. Had the kids not come on the trip they would have had to pay out almost $5,000 in cancellation fees which the operators probably not unreasonably would not have refunded. The kids had been booked to be provided with ski gear, lessons and motel accommodation, the fees for which the operators were not prepared to waive. Not only would the planning and the fundraising of an entire year for these kids have been ruined but also they would have had to shell out $5,000 of that hard won money for a trip that they would not have gone on.

A decision was made, very reluctantly under the circumstances, to come by bus instead. It turned out to be a horror trip. I was hoping that they would arrive here at Parliament House saying, `We had a great time on the bus; it was wonderful and we had a terrific time'. In fact, they had a miserable time as was demonstrated when they arrived here yesterday and as Senator Tambling will attest. He was kind enough to help me entertain them, along with Senator McMullan. I am grateful to both honourable senators for doing that.

This is what happened: because there is so much pressure being placed on the bus companies because of the airline pilots strike, these kids were kept on that bus for all but one hour-50 minutes to be exact-between Darwin and Alice Springs; that is a journey of 1,000 miles. The bus was not even allowed to pull up so the kids could have something to eat. It had one hour off the road between Alice Springs and Adelaide: that is a second journey of 1,000 miles. So the kids had two hours out of the bus in a trip of 2,000 miles. They spent 3 days and 3 nights on the bus. They arrived here like zombies yesterday morning. The teacher who accompanied them said, `We have to come to Parliament House because our trip has been so totally ruined that we cannot fit everything in unless we do something today'. I said to her, `Look, I will tell you what we will do. Let the kids sleep for half a day. Come over to Parliament House at one o'clock. Senator Tambling and Senator McMullan have offered to help. We will turn it on for them. We will put on a special afternoon tea for them. We will try to make their visit reasonable'.

The kids arrived here at one o'clock and I took them up to my room. I wish I had had a camera. Thinking about it, I said to one of the journalists tonight, `I should have gone up to the press gallery and got a photographer, brought him down and had him take a picture of the scene in my office'. I left the kids in my office for 10 minutes to make sure that the rest of the visit was organised. When I came back there were 22 bodies lying around my room. It was an incredible sight: 22 kids lying fast asleep on the floor of my office. We woke them up. We took them up to one of the committee rooms and they went to sleep having afternoon tea. Kids were sitting around the walls of the room going to sleep. We took them around Parliament House. At four o'clock yesterday afternoon we were due to walk down the hill to look at the old Parliament House.

In handing out bouquets I want to sincerely thank the officers of the Parliamentary Education Office for the things they did for the kids yesterday. At 4 o'clock we called it off. I said to the teachers, `This is just cruel to these kids. I am sorry about this but there is nothing we can do. The kids are dead on their feet. Forget about old Parliament House'. So we cancelled it. I have to give some thanks to someone else tonight, and that is the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Hawke. I know that Opposition members will not like hearing this but I have to tell them.

As soon as the kids arrived here, tired as they were, every one of them said, `Are we going to see Bob Hawke? Are we going to see Bob Hawke?'. Their faces were long enough and I said, `No, you will not be able to see Bob Hawke'. Their faces dropped three feet. They said, `We came all the way down here to see Bob Hawke'. I thought: `Well, why not give it a go. He can only tell me to go and jump in the creek'. So I went over to the Prime Minister's office and I pleaded the case. Busy as he is, the Prime Minister agreed to see all of these kids at a quarter to two on Monday afternoon. I want to express my thanks to him for doing that. The best part of the trip so far has been when I was able to tell these kids yesterday afternoon that Bob Hawke was going to see them on Monday afternoon in his office. It was like giving them a shot of adrenalin.

I went over to the National Capital Village tonight to tell the teachers that I was going to tell this story in the Senate tonight. This is just one small group of Australians that have been profoundly mucked around by the pilots strike and have had what would have been an exciting, interesting and long-planned trip almost totally ruined by this dispute. The teachers asked me to express their thanks to the owner and operator of the National Capital Village apartments, Tom Shanahan, who, the teachers told me tonight, has gone absolutely overboard, far and away beyond the normal services that he would have provided for his guests, to make things easier for these kids and to give them a good time. He has laid on free bus tours for them. The service they have got over there is fantastic. It really has made up a lot for some of the bad parts of the trip. So I want to express my thanks publicly to Tom Shanahan and to the staff at his motel for helping these kids in the way in which they have. I also want to thank the Prime Minister for agreeing to have a special session with these kids in his office at a quarter to two on Monday afternoon when I bring them over here.

The reason I have raised this matter tonight is to draw attention to the inconvenience that has occurred because of the pilots dispute. These kids had an absolutely miserable trip down to Canberra. The length of the trip has been doubled from one week to two weeks because of the bus trip. Of course, if the pilots strike is not resolved, after a bare weekend in the snow, after this three days and nights on the bus, the return journey will be just as bad. The teachers told me of the travelling arrangements on the bus. The group arrived in Alice Springs four and a half hours ahead of schedule and it arrived in Adelaide five and a half hours ahead of schedule. That is the time that the group would normally have spent off the bus at the various stops. This group comprises 10-year-old and 12-year-old primary school kids. The group spent only two hours off a bus in a 3,000 mile trip-three days and three nights. For the three nights they were on the bus half the kids slept across the seats; the other half slept on the floor of the bus under the seat so that they could stretch out. They swapped around the second night; the kids on the floor slept on the seats and the kids on the seats slept on the floor. So they had a great trip. I raise this matter in the Senate tonight to draw attention to the fact that after they come back from the snow on Sunday night, if the pilots dispute is not resolved, these kids are faced with the prospect of three days and three nights going back home on the bus next week, which is not a prospect they are particularly excited about.

I must say to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots that I would like to see as many of its members sign those contracts that have been offered to them by Ansett and Australian Airlines, to go back to work to the already well paid jobs that they do, to go back to the centralised wage fixing system that operates and can operate to their benefit, to take the pay increases on top of the salaries that they are already getting and that will be offered by that system, to put the Australian economy back to work and to stop inconveniencing their fellow Australians to the extent to which they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak tonight. I will be but two minutes. Senator Collins presumably in a not unreasonable way asked whether there was somebody to defend the pilots and it shall not be me. But I want to refer him to one commentator that said with some passion, some feeling and some indignation that there are attempts by some politicians to paint the pilots as some greedy, avaricious, self-centred group of people with no concern for anyone else. That was Bob Hawke.
—He is spot on.
—Spot on, Senator Collins says.
—You can put me on that list.

—That was Bob Hawke in 1974 when the pilots were asking for a 46 per cent wage increase and they settled finally for 27 per cent. The 27 per cent wage increase was agreed to by the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), one R.J. Hawke. When the Government of the day had the audacity to interfere in that private treaty what did Mr Hawke have to say? He condemned Charlie Jones, the then Minister for Transport. He condemned Clyde Cameron, the then Minister for Industrial Relations, and he said, `They do not represent the Government. I am going over their heads to Gough Whitlam'.
—He virtually had Charlie Jones sacked.

—Charlie Jones said, `The agreement might have been made, the wages might have been paid, the increase might have been granted but they will never say Charlie Jones agreed to it. Bob Hawke agreed to it'.
—That is right; Charlie Jones is an honest man.
—Charlie Jones was, by comparison, an honest man. Mr Hawke said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very serious difference.
The difference was that Hawke wanted 27 per cent for the pilots and the Government wanted intervention. Mr Hawke continued:
I can't think of a more serious difference since the Federal Labor Government came to power.
Mr Whitlam did not agree with me that Mr Cameron's intervention in the Qantas pilots' case was contrary to ALP policy, Mr Hawke said.
Mr Hawke was saying that it was contrary to Australian Labor Party policy for the Government to intervene in that dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got it wrong, Senator.

—No, I have not. I am quoting the honourable senator's beloved Leader who actually stepped out of his office and shone light upon some poor wretched kids who had come down on a bus as a result of the pilots strike. In an article published on 26 August 1974, the then President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Hawke, attacked the Minister for Transport, Mr Jones, over his handling of Australia's international airline, Qantas Airways Ltd. He attacked him viciously and brutally and said that he had no business interfering. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke criticised Mr Jones for not allowing `the uninhibited processes of collective negotiations' to operate when this had been--

TALK.START.PARA: —He was President of the trade union movement.

—I see. So when he was the President of the ACTU he could afford to be an irresponsible citizen, but now that he is the Prime Minister he has to assume responsibility. Is that what the honourable senator is saying to me? In other words, he can be two separate people, with two separate positions, with different degrees of responsibility.
—Do you think there is a difference? That doesn't surprise me, I might add.
—Of course there is a difference. On one occasion he is being paid by the taxpayers--
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask both Senator Collins and Senator Crichton-Browne to direct their remarks through the Chair.
—I was just about to do that.

—My apologies to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for not directing my comments through the Chair. The question that was being asked of me by Senator Collins was whether a distinction could be drawn in the responsibilities of Mr Hawke as the President of the ACTU and Mr Hawke as the Prime Minister. The answer is quite simple: both positions require responsible judgments made on behalf of all Australians with due consideration for Australia's economy. If the pilot were worth a 27 per cent increase then, I find it in stark contradiction to the new up-beat macho man we presently have living in the Lodge, who suddenly decides that his primary object in life, immediately prior to the election, is to crush the pilots. It was fine then, but it is not fine now.

SPEECH.PARA: I am only responding to Senator Collins's invitation to find somebody who has sympathy for the pilots. I do not have sympathy for their bid. Nobody that I know of on my side of politics has any sympathy for their bid. It is interesting to find beating in the soul of the Prime Minister of Australia a man who previously is on the record as supporting this sort of ambit claim first time around. Mr Hawke criticised Mr Charlie Jones, who had the audacity or the temerity, one might say, to suggest that 27 per cent was too much in 1974, and for not allowing the uninhibited processes of collective negotiations to operate when this had been part of the Labor Party's platform in both the 1972 and the 1974 polls. Mr Charlie Jones, finally in frustration, and ultimately I suspect in rage when he could no longer deal with this leader of the ACTU, said, `If I have to deal with people like you, Mr Hawke, I will sell the airline'. Mr Hawke's comment simply was that that did not seem an appropriate response to this claim of 27 per cent, which amounted to blackmail.
I simply conclude by saying: at least we know that there is one person who is on the public record in this Parliament supporting claims of 27 per cent, and that is the Prime Minister of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise two matters of major concern tonight affecting very large sections of the Australian community, particularly ethnic groups and some elements of the Jewish community and the Muslim community, and certainly many people of Lebanese descent. The first matter I want to raise, like the second, relates to the blatant political activities of the Australian Labor Party involving a disgraceful misuse of the positions of members of the Labor Party to bring about, for political purposes, a quite improper end. The first matter relates to a letter to the Hon. J. Johnson, the President of the Legislative Council of New South Wales.
—Johnno.

—Johnno Johnson, of 19 Eastmore Place, Maroubra, New South Wales, 2035. It is from the office of the Mayor in the Council Chambers of Mascot, 2020, and it is headed with the Council's crest. It is dated 4 July 1989 and the reference is RH:JA. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Johnno,
A number of Kingsford-Smith pre-selection voters have now contacted me and related telephone conversations had with you shortly before the ballot.
That is, the ballot for preselection for the Federal seat of Kingsford-Smith, soon to be vacated by the present Deputy Prime Minister, the Hon. Lionel Bowen. The letter continues:
Some of those even admitted not voting for me, after they had promised to do so, following your conversation with them.

Each of those persons conveyed to me your urging to vote for the ``Christian person'' and the ``good catholic'', being a suitable person to be in the Federal Parliament. Each of those persons advised me that the view you conveyed was that Jews were not suitable parliamentary material. Two couples in your branch said you were not so subtle telling them they should not vote for the ``Jew Boy from Botany''.

Whilst you can expect quite a bit of criticism, fair or unfair, during a pre-selection campaign (and Brereton's people did their fair share). I take extreme offence at your method of seeking support for your favoured candidate. Let me tell you, this ``Jew Boy'' had most of his family murdered during the Holocaust and has a mother who still bears the scars of her years in Concentration Camps-their sole crime being that they were Jewish.

Jews are all right if they donate money to the Labor Party, but how dare they try to get into Parliament. I felt physically ill when invited to your reception for Syd Einfeld, organised by the Jewish Board of Deputies. I could not attend and play any part in your gross hypocrisy.

This ``Jew Boy'' considers if a person like you, with the anti-semitic views you espouse, can rise to the high office as the President of the Legislative Council within the Labor Party, then there is something very wrong with our Party.

This ``Jew Boy'' is going to stay involved in the political process at whatever level, and will fight to ensure that, never again, will there be an attempt by anyone to persuade rank and file numbers by the reprehensible views that have been espoused. In my opinion, millions of people did not die 45 years ago in vain and I propose to fight to ensure they did not.
Yours faithfully.
ALD. RON HOENIG
MAYOR OF BOTANY
I seek leave to table that letter.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robert Ray

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have shown it to us first, but I will take your word.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. That is the first matter relating to an official of the Labor Party in a high position, a position of power, misusing that position for political purposes. Let me now tell the Senate about a meeting that took place yesterday in the office of the Speaker of this Parliament, Mr Leo McLeay. I am told on very good authority that the meeting was attended by some Labor heavyweights including Mr Keating and Mr Punch. That meeting was also attended by Imam Al Hilaly and several of his supporters. Imam Al Hilaly at the time had an application before the Minister for Immigration, Senator Robert Ray, for permanent residence. As I understand it, that meeting was held to enable those who attended to seek to influence the Minister in his decision. Arising out of that meeting, I was advised early this morning that Messrs Keating, Punch and McLeay have proposed that the Minister grant permanent resident status to the imam's wife and temporary status to the imam. I was, therefore, not surprised when, at Question Time, the Minister made the most extraordinary announcement in this area that I have heard for many years, in which-I will deal with it in a minute-he basically granted an additional temporary status to the imam. That is an incredible decision which is without precedent to my knowledge, allowing him, in other words, to have stayed for eight years on continuing temporary entry permits. These permits have been continually renewed in extraordinary circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the proposition about which I was told this morning is that the Minister grant permanent resident status to the imam's wife. So I was not surprised to see in the Minister's statement that consideration of the permanent resident status of the imam's wife and two children born outside Australia-two of his four children-would take place shortly. If the Labor Party wants to continue to play heavy politics with immigration, I suppose one can say that it is continuing a very strong tradition. We all know how Mr Hurford ordered that this man be deported in 1986 following the imam's breaking of an undertaking to leave. But when Mr Hurford was replaced by Mr Young, the Labor Party magically found reasons why this man, who Mr Hurford discovered was not a fit and proper person to be a permanent resident, should suddenly become a fit and proper person to be a permanent resident.

Immediately before the last Federal election, in July 1987 we had the extraordinary situation of the imam's visa being magically extended yet again by this Government. There was a great big thankyou dinner. I heard tonight from Senator Collins that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has time to do lots of interesting things, such as meeting school children. He had enough time to attend the great thankyou dinner held by this group along with an incredible galaxy of what the Labor Party would prefer to call stars-I tend to look upon them more as comets-at which the supporters of Imam Al Hilaly expressed their gratitude. No doubt those of them who were enrolled also expressed their gratitude at the polls.

Since then the imam has been here almost on probation, if you like. He was warned at that time. Certainly Mr Hurford left no doubts in anyone's mind about his view of the imam. But from then on the imam had to behave. He had to ensure that he made no divisive statements; that he would accept the clear and bipartisan political views in Australia, that in a multicultural society one should not seek to be divisive. We all know that the imam has continually disregarded-not just on a one-off occasion-that admonition. We know that even despite the standover tactics employed by some of his supporters and the strong-arming to silence the imam's opponents, there is a large collection of people who have been prepared to object to his presence in Australia, particularly people from the Muslim community. It is not correct to suggest that this is simply an anti-Muslim pro-Jewish plot to get rid of this man. The submission to the Minister from his own Department--

TALK.START.PARA: —The draft.

—The draft submission to the Minister from his own Department lists quite a few groups which have, as recently as May and June of this year, expressed opposition to the imam's being here. There are some, it is true, written and verbal representations, from those people who want him to stay; but there appear to be very few that are remarkably recent relative to those that are very old, going back to 1982. I am very disappointed to see the names of some people on that list. I will not go further than that, except to say that I cannot understand how anyone taking an objective view of this matter could do anything other than establish that the facts reveal that this man has been divisive while he was on probation. What is he going to be like if he receives permanent residence and there are no sanctions available? What sort of power will a man like this exercise when he has already shown an arrogant disregard for the rules while he was on probation?

SPEECH.PARA: I stress to the Minister that if he is concerned that allegations of standover tactics on the part of the imam's supporters are baseless, he might try a little harder to find the facts than his Department appears to have tried. I am not saying that the imam necessarily encouraged some of the thuggish activities on the part of some of his supporters, but I am saying that some of the stand-over tactics and thuggery by some of his supporters are simply not acceptable in the Australian community.

The Minister might well say, `But I have not granted him permanent residence yet. All I have done is given him a 12-month temporary entry permit in order to test the bona fides of the imam's statements that he is now in favour of a multicultural society and that he does not think one should say naughty or divisive things'. Except for the fact that it is moderately inappropriate, it is some sort of conversion on the road to Damascus.

TALK.START.PARA: —That happens.

—If it has happened, I wonder why in this great conversion speech, in this letter to the Prime Minister, which clears his soul, which purifies him, he simply says, `I retract those remarks'. The Minister will remember that the New South Wales Ethnic Affairs Commission suggested a retraction and an apology. There is no apology here. There is no intention of apologising, as the Minister well knows. This is a retraction for convenience, because he knew darned well that if this retraction did not take place there would be no temporary entry visa and certainly there would be no permanent residency. So, as the Minister suggests, apparently there has been a conversion on the road to Damascus.
—I did not say that at all.
—You inferred that you thought it was very likely that it could be--
—I said it is possible in any case.
—If that is the straw you are clutching at, you will drown.
—I am just sick of you misrepresenting it-absolutely sick of it.

—There is no misrepresentation here. There are facts which you and your Department have chosen to overlook, ignore, minimise and diminish in order to suit a political book because of representations from Mr McLeay, Mr Keating and others.
—Order! I ask Senator Baume to address his remarks through the Chair.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, thank you for reminding me of that. The volume of interjections encouraged me to bypass you.
—I am glad we do not have a lie detector on you right now.
—I will acknowledge that interjection to demonstrate the sort of person this Minister is.
—You are base and false, Senator.
—That is absolute nonsense, Minister, and you know it. This Minister prefers to be involved in personal abuse--
—You are the one who is being abusive.
—I am saying that a disgraceful decision has been made on the basis--
—On the basis of other representations, that is not true.
—Order! Senator Baume will address his remarks through the Chair. I ask the Minister to cease interjecting.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. These representations, made to this group yesterday, certainly took place. The people were photographed by the Special Broadcasting Service coming out of Mr McLeay's room. Perhaps they came down to discuss something else such as the coming of spring or where the road to Damascus really is. I know what happened at that meeting. I know what that meeting was all about. The Minister should not pretend that people do not know what is going on. I say to the Minister that his statement on the decision of Imam Al Hilaly is absolutely incredible on the evidence. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Three key objections are raised as to his suitability for permanent residence:
1) That he is a divisive influence on the Lebanese community of Australia.
The Minister's response was:
There is some evidence to support the first contention . . .

There is only some evidence, but at least it is supporting. I suppose that we could call that strike one. There is certainly no attempt to brush aside that evidence because it is so transparently true. The second matter was:
2) That on 18 September 1988 he was guilty of a racist and inflammatory attack on Jews.
The Minister's response was:
There is . . . overwhelming evidence to support the second contention.
The third question is a double-barrelled question:
3) That he is closely associated with, or is a puppet of, the Libyan regime.

Honourable senators should notice the way those two quite different propositions are lumped together. What curious integrity prompts someone to do that, because they are different? What does the Government do? It demolishes that aunt sally by saying:
There is . . . insubstantial evidence to support the third contention.

The Minister knows perfectly well that there is overwhelming evidence to establish that the imam is closely associated with the Libyan regime. It is false, it is misleading of this Parliament and it is a disgrace for this Minister to pretend that there is insubstantial evidence to support the fact that he is closely associated with the Libyan regime. I will read the evidence. It is in the draft submission to the Minister, this Minister who says it does not exist and that it is insubstantial. I wish to quote from paragraph 61 of the draft that I have that the Minister denigrates by saying it was stolen out of a letterbox. He has not denied the facts, but he says that it was stolen out of a letterbox. I can assure the Minister that I did not steal it out of any letterbox. But the Minister, by attempting to denigrate the facts, because they do not happen to suit him, by disregarding this document and saying that it was stolen out of a letterbox, is attempting a pathetic cover-up. In this submission the Department says to the Minister:

There is evidence indicating that the Imam Hilaly's presence in Australia has the support of the Government of Libya or its agents. That Government has contributed not insubstantial sums to support the organizations which fund, inter alia, the Imam's expenses. Such expenses include the legal expenses for the Federal Court appeal against the Government's decision of 1986 not to grant Imam Hilaly permanent residence and for the Commonwealth's (successful) appeal to the Full Federal Court.

In other words, all the legal bases for why this man should go are magically overturned, not by the law but by this politically inspired Government. In responding to questions like this Imam Al Hilaly has indicated:
I also personally did not receive one cent out of this amount.
He also said:
I have not received any money and this report (a contemporary media account) is incorrect.
The report goes on:

Literally and physically, it is accepted that the Imam did not receive one cent from the grant from an agency supported by the Libyan Government. However, it is open to hold that the Imam did benefit from those funds which entered a pool of funds from which monies are paid, inter alia, for the Imam's purposes.
So he does not get the money; he just gets it. It is absolutely incredible! The report also states:

Further, the Imam indicated that he was unaware of the grant `until the press announced this'. In responding to a question as to why the Imam did not refute contrary views in `The Australian' of 16 December 1987, the Imam indicated, `Today, (16 August 1989) this is the first time I've become aware that The Australian newspaper have written something like this about me.'
Maybe that was before his conversion on the way to Damascus. The report continues:

In pursuing the general theme, the Imam said that he visited Libya for an international conference some two years ago. According to Departmental records, this visit was between June and September 1987 when Imam Hilaly travelled out of Australia. The fare for this visit was also provided by an agency supported by the Libyan Government.

But our Minister here says, `Oh, no. There is insubstantial evidence to show that he is closely associated with the Libyan regime'. What an incredible, disgraceful and deliberate misleading of this place!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That is an imputation of an improper motive and I ask that it be withdrawn.

—I withdraw the imputation of an improper motive and say: what a disgraceful thing to appear, whatever the motive. The report refers to the impact of the Libyan Government's activities in this region and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Your views on this matter and the relevance of it to Australia might or might not be relevant to the consideration of the Imam's application in light of all the evidence. It is noteworthy, however, that the relevant Australian Government agency has, on the information then available to it, indicated no objection to the Imam's continued presence in Australia. If you do not agree with that view, you would be expected to have a reasonable basis for differing with that view.

I have already asked the Minister, one way or another, to say what the word `then' means in this report. When was this report received from the relevant governmental agency? What was the relevant governmental agency? Is it still true that there is no objection on these grounds? It seems to me that the Department was preparing the way for an appropriate response when it heavied the Minister to come to the view that this was not a matter of substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't have it both ways.
—I think departments read the wind pretty well. They read the breeze. I will read one more section:

SPEECH.PARA: You might hold that answers to questions put to Imam Hilaly on this most sensitive question do not allay reasonably held concerns about the Imam's links with Libya which, to our knowledge, commenced in 1973.

This is no sudden, new exciting involvement: they commenced in 1973. They are longstanding. Despite that, the Minister can still say that there is insubstantial evidence to support the contention that he is closely associated with the Libyan regime. I agree with the Minister that there is insubstantial evidence to support the allegation that he is a puppet of the Libyan regime. I suggest to the Minister that it may have been a more honourable course to have separated those two propositions out.

What concerns me immensely about this is the recognition and the admission by the Minister in his statement and by almost everyone concerned that this man has been a major divisive influence in Australia. I am particularly concerned that the Minister's decision to examine the rights to permanent residence of the wife and two children separately from the right of the husband creates an absurd situation, because it colours the inevitable request by the imam in 12 months' time when the decision will be made in respect of his application for permanent residence. If in the next two weeks this Minister says, `The wife and children haven't been divisive, surely they can stay', what problems does that create for the person-it will not be this Minister-who in 12 months' time will be making a decision about whether the imam himself will be granted permanent residence. The clear thing that this Minister keeps avoiding is that what he has done by granting temporary residence to the imam, and the prospect of agreeing with his New South Wales right wing heavy mates to grant permanent residence to the imam's wife and two children, is to influence the outcome of the imam's application for permanent residence in a year's time, to make it just that much harder to get this person out of Australia.

The Minister said in this place this week: `I will make a decision on the matter later this week, based on the facts, not on prejudices, and based on a whole variety of matters, but not on the basis of political pressure or representation'. We know the representations took place. Are we seriously suggesting that Mr McLeay and his colleagues, having decided to propose this course of action that permanent citizenship be provided for the imam's wife and temporary citizenship be provided for the imam, did not in fact come to the Minister with it? Is that really being suggested? Is it not remarkable then that it just happens to be what seems to be emerging in this case? Although the decision is not made on the basis of political representation, it just coincidentally looks as though that is what is happening. I believe this matter is absolutely disgraceful. I do not know of anyone else who has received anything like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Michael Baume for giving me notice that he was going to raise the second matter on the adjournment tonight. He raised similar matters last Friday, but I was told only as he got to his feet. The geography of this particular building means that, if one wants to hear what a senator is going to say, on the journey down to the chamber one misses half of it. That is the reason that I did not come in on Friday.

SPEECH.PARA: I have nothing else to thank Senator Baume for. I regard his speech tonight as a typical example of the thing I criticised the Imam Hilaly for. It is nothing else than one-sided, bigoted, biased and smearing. Senator Baume has read the draft report. I inform him that the final report is not substantially different. But he has read it only in a one-eyed way. I do not have that luxury. I have to look at all the facts, not only in that report but in the whole file on the Imam Hilaly. I cannot take a position where I let my prejudices affect my judgment.

I think it would be pretty well recognised-not by Senator Baume, because he is not from Victoria-that if there are two groups within Victoria that have supported me very strongly in politics, it is the Jewish community of Victoria and the Christian Lebanese community of Victoria. That goes back long before I entered representative politics, in which I have had a long involvement. When Mrs Sadat could not deliver the key lecture last year, it is not a coincidence that I was invited to do so.

I wish to place on record that, despite what Senator Baume says, I made this decision objectively and without giving in to representations. At no stage have I said that I have not had representations. For heaven's sake, I have had everyone ringing me on it. At every function I have gone to I have had representations made to me. At a luncheon in Sydney some of the most prominent members of the Jewish community put to me the case against Imam Hilaly. At a dinner in Sydney some of the most respected figures in the Christian Lebanese community put the case against Imam Hilaly. I have had members of the Islamic community argue to me that Imam Hilaly should not be in this country. I have listened to their representations. I have had Labor politicians come to me on both sides of the argument. Of course, Mr McLeay has made representations to me. So have other Labor members, saying that he should go. I was advised from the first week in this job by the New South Wales State Director, and an expert on these things, that I had to make up my mind on the facts and not on representations.

One can go back right through the record for a year, during which time I have had to shut up on the issue. After Imam Hilaly's disgraceful speech on 18 September, I did not utter a word. If I had, it would have been seen as prejudging the case and I would have been in court the moment I decided upon any one of the three or four options. It has been very hard for me not to say anything about this particular subject for a whole year. Of course, I would like this matter to have been resolved three months ago. The proposition was put to us that the imam would like to go to Mecca for the Haj-the sort of grant I would have made to the leader of any other religion: this being the pre-eminent thing in the religious calendar, that person should participate. That delayed the decision by two to three months more than it should have.

What Senator Baume has not acknowledged tonight is things I had to look at. One of the key factors in Minister Hurford's decision that the imam should go-and it is not for me to judge between Minister Young's opinion and Minister Hurford's opinion; they both based it on their view of the facts-was that the imam in the first few years in this country showed no inclination at all to learn English, which is part of the contract of anyone coming to this country. One of the things I have looked at within the last 12 months is that he has made massive efforts to learn English, to fit into this country. That was one of the factors I looked at.

A second factor I looked at is this: right at the height of the disturbances in Sydney on the Salman Rushdie affair, who was the only leading Islamic figure that came out and called for a peaceful solution, who condemned violence and said that Salman Rushdie should not be killed? It was Imam Hilaly. Senator Baume should acknowledge that tonight, if he wants to put a fair case. When what I describe as disgraceful incidents occurred at Arncliffe between the so-called Hizbollah and Amal groups, which groups came in under Senator Baume's Government, I might say, with its active sponsorship-it was not just a question of who made it under the system but who was deliberately brought here as a tool of government policy-who was the only religious leader in the Islamic community to come out and call for peace and to offer to mediate? It was Imam Hilaly. Imam Hilaly has, on two occasions, tried relatively successfully to meet with the Jewish community since his great sin of 18 September. There has been no acknowledgment from Senator Baume tonight that those things occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —And no apologies.

—The views of apology for Senator Baume, for me and for someone of Islamic faith are entirely different in their approach to these matters. In Imam Hilaly's mind his retraction would be seen as a major apology in this particular area. Senator Baume has put forward a very one-sided case.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to move onto part of the substance of this matter. I do not care whether Imam Hilaly met with some of his local members of parliament this week. I could not care less. Senator Baume makes the assertion that my right wing mates heavied me. I am about to tell him that they cannot and they never will. They know not to try. I come from Victoria. I come from a political position where I have one luxury in life: no-one can heavy me.

I have never granted an immigration case to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the year that I have been Minister. I have granted it to some other people if the case is just, but I have not granted them a case because it has not been strong enough. The one thing I want to do in the immigration portfolio is to take the fix out, to stop political patronage where one person gets a jump ahead of the other. Why do honourable senators think I fought so hard to get rid of ministerial discretion? I saw one of the former Opposition Ministers spend $1.5m trying to get rid of a drug pusher. The day after he left the ministry the next Liberal Minister walked in and gave him permanent residence in this country. That is the sort of thing that has happened in immigration far too often. It is the sort of thing that I am trying to eliminate out of the immigration area.

When I approached the Hilaly case I had to approach it fairly and with an open mind. My political instincts were probably the other way to which I made the decision. I can assure Senator Baume-he will produce no proof tonight-that I was not politically heavied in any way. There is no way I ever will be. I decided a long time ago that life was too short to be a toady and a whippy.

Let me return to the facts against the Imam. Clearly they are there, although Senator Baume has only adduced one tonight, and that was his speech. The fact that he was divisive does not necessarily mean he has to go. It happens to be a divisive community. One of the judgments we have to make is that if he went and the vacuum has to be filled, would that community be better off or not? I do not know. The second point-this is the one I concede-is that his speech on 18 September, in which he slandered the Jewish people of Australia and the world, was a disgraceful one. It was a disgraceful speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —You listen to his sermons too.

—I have listened to a lot of sermons I disagree with over the years. I bring to this matter a complete neutrality, being a card-carrying atheist. I do not like or dislike any particular religion for that reason. I have also said that I do not accept his explanation that he was distinguishing between Jews and Zionist Jews. I find it difficult to understand what the subtlety is because people will take offence.

SPEECH.PARA: Because Senator Baume has produced nothing against the imam, he says that he has to be condemned forever for that speech. That speech cost him permanent residence. Without that speech I would have had to look at his file and say, `Here is an employer nomination case'. It has clearly been advertised. It is clearly a unique job. It cannot be filled within Australia. He is clearly qualified for the job. He has paid all his fees. He has met every other requirement, including health and character assessments. The one thing we have to determine on public policy interest is whether he should be allowed to have permanent residence. Without the speech of 18 September the answer would have been unequivocally yes. However it happened. I have overwhelmingly noted in my mind some of his actions since then. Senator Baume might respond, `Oh, he is behaving himself because he knew his visa was up'. That may be true. That is the reason I wanted to test it over a further 12-month period. Senator Baume says that this is a unique case. This is not unique. A lot of people have been in this country on a temporary visa or other methods for seven, eight or nine years. That is a testament to a very poor immigration Act and a susceptibility to legal appeals, et cetera, much of which, I concede, post-19 December this year, when the new Act is proclaimed, will disappear.

I want to go on to a couple of other points. Senator Baume says that it is wrong to consider Mrs Hilaly's case. Why? Does she have no rights? She has lived here for seven years. She has two children who are Australian citizens. Am I supposed to take the sexist attitude that I will judge only the old man but am not allowed to judge the claims of Mrs Hilaly and the kids? Honourable senators have to remember that the benefit of the doubt always goes to people whose kids are Australian citizens. The exception is when there has been a massive breach of immigration law. Long term, we are not going to have that problem. In 1986 we said that children born in Australia to people other than permanent residents will not be Australian citizens, but there were some born before that. The general attitude of Liberal and Labor governments has been that in those cases we regularise the status of the parents in accordance with their children's citizenship. That is another thing that leads us towards saying that Mrs Hilaly also has rights. She has the right to be judged by herself, not on her husband's actions. I am not guaranteeing that the judgment will result in permanent residence because she will not be applying under the employer nomination scheme. She would have to apply under the compassionate section of the Act, which is much harder to approve and much harder to achieve. She has the right to do it; she has done it. I have the right at some stage to make a judgment on it. In summary, I reject a lot of the accusations that Senator Baume has made tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not answered anything about Libya. You have not answered that at all.

—Let me move on to Libya. Senator Baume has read from the file. He has read that part of the file which says, `You may be entitled to either accept this or that'. A lot of people go to Libya. We have a senator sitting in the back of this chamber who led a delegation to Libya. Is Senator Baume suggesting that the honourable senator is not entitled to be here because she visited Libya? The key question is not that there is some connection between the imam and Libya; there are key connections between a lot of religious groups and a lot of countries overseas. But the key question that was not proved in my mind is that he was being directed from Libya.
—He was being funded; you have admitted that.
—The organisation has received funds from Libya at one stage.
—To pay his expenses.

—What it does with the expenses is not the imam's fault. Senator Baume has not proved anything and I do not know; he could be right. He could have received some of his expenses from Libya. But Senator Baume does not know that and I do not know that.
—He did.
—No, he does not.
—The Department said that it was for that purpose.

—The Department did not say that. It said it is possible to hold that the money given to the organisation could have gone to his expenses. I say: `So what!'. Does that absolutely debar the imam from pursuing his rights in this country?
—And when was the ASIO inquiry-or whatever it was-which then took place?

—I do not know and Senator Baume would not expect me to comment on that. I am not going to. I will never comment on a view expressed to me, whether or not it has ever been expressed by a security organisation. I take that attitude. I wear the lumps, but I am not going to vary on that policy. I put on the public record that it is not as though everyone shares Senator Baume's views. I will quote from a press release from the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas, Mr Ruddock, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to issue Imam Hilaly with a 12 month temporary entry permit, in order to test his bona fides is reasonable.

I am not the only one that takes that attitude. I put on the record, in case I fall for the sort of debating tactics of Senator Baume, that he goes on to criticise me over Mrs Hilaly. Quite clearly, I accept that the criticism is well intended. He also goes on to say that he would not have given permanent residence on this occasion to Imam Hilaly. I agree with my shadow Minister on that. I think we have seen tonight that Senator Baume's attack has been so one-sided and so blinkered. I think that is a tragedy. It does not do him credit just to put one side when he has at least got access, in the document he claims to have, to both sides of the argument. As Minister, I had to take both sides into account. I knew that the decision would not be popular, but one would have to concede that no decision in this matter would be popular. It could be said that I have squibbed the decision one way or the other. I deny that on the basis of the trend of events. We had a disgraceful event almost 12 months ago and three or four factors in the meantime have mitigated it. I have not added, but I could have, that for all the imam's faults-he is a bit like Bruce Ruxton in one sense-no-one here would criticise his social work. No-one would criticise the hours he has put in helping Islamic youth, Islamic women's groups and so forth. He has done a lot of good work in that area. Even Four Corners had to be gracious enough to acknowledge that.

I do not accept Senator Baume's categorisation of this case, but one thing I want to put on the record is that I made up my mind on the facts of the matter and not on the representations. However, I do not deny that I had representations. Heaven forbid! I never sought the representations, I might say, but the subject would come up if I attended a dinner in Sydney with prominent members of the Jewish community who wanted to discuss a range of issues-foreign affairs, our attitude to Israel, or the Australian Government's attitude to Palestine Liberation Organisation recognition. Of course, views were put to me by the Jewish community. At dinner with the major Christian Lebanese leaders in Sydney their attitude would be put to me very strongly. When certain members of the Islamic Council make a courtesy call on me, the subject is raised. At fund-raising functions in Sydney the opposing sides have bowed to, smiled at and toasted each other and then come to see me separately to ask me to get rid of the imam or to keep him. These things happen.

However, the imam is on notice in one sense: he had better behave himself for the next 12 months. Irrespective of whether Mrs Hilaly gains Australian citizenship, he will be judged on his record over the next 12 months. If that record is in any way imperfect, he will be departing for the country of his origin.

Senator Baume raised another subject of which I have imperfect knowledge. However, I should put the record straight in one sense. There is still no evidence that Mr Johnson uttered the remarks it is claimed that he did. There is no evidence; there is a claim. I have known Johnno Johnson for nigh on 20 years. I know he is a very deeply religious man. I know of his very deeply held religious views. In that 20 years he has also known that I am a card-carrying atheist, yet I have never known him once to raise a religious issue or make a sectarian remark. I find it very hard to believe the allegations made in the letter tabled today. I say in all honesty: I have never met Alderman Ron Hoenig, so I will say nothing about him. But I have known Johnno Johnson for 20 years and I find the allegation very hard to believe.

The degree of sectarianism that exists in the Labor Party now is minimal. I joined the Labor Party in 1966 in the Victorian branch, and sectarianism was then rife as a result of the split. It was not anti-Semitism, but a strict Catholic-Mason break-up. Fortunately, within eight years of my joining the Labor Party-not due to any effect that I had on it-I saw sectarianism disappear entirely from the Victorian branch. At least in the Victorian branch-and I hope it is the case Australia wide-I have never seen anti-Semitism, with one exception.

A number of members of the Jewish community have represented the Labor Party in this Parliament in the last 20 years. Joe Berinson, Barry Cohen, Dick Klugman, Moss Cass and others have served with great distinction. Members of the Jewish community have also served with great distinction on the Liberal side. I would hate to think that anyone is ever judged on his religious background these days when seeking preselection or election to Parliament. If what is claimed occurred-I still say I do not think it did-I would be absolutely ashamed to be a member of the Labor Party. It is true that from time to time each party-I can point to both sides here-has someone on the abrasive side, William Hartley being such a one. I was on the National Executive; I voted to expel him; we expelled him. With that we cleaned out of the Labor Party a lot of those potential sentiments. That was one of the proudest days of my life, and I am not normally proud to see anyone expelled.

From my knowledge of Johnno Johnson I find the charge hard to accept. I cannot disprove it tonight, nor do I know on what basis it was made. I know that in the heat of preselections a variety of malicious accusations are made. Sometimes it is the Cardinal Richelieu false assassination attempt. I am not saying that this letter constitutes that, but it has been known. Senator Baume would know that the odd desperate candidate has been known to bomb his own backyard in an attempt to get publicity. We saw that most recently in the last State election in Western Australia with a gentleman-not a member of Senator Baume's party or mine-who is now embroiled in many court cases. That has occurred. It is a possibility that this letter falls into that category; I do not know.

But I do know Johnno Johnson. I have never known him make a sectarian remark in the 20 years I have known him. I know how distressed he will be by this and I am sure that within the next day or two he will put the public record straight. I know him to be an honourable man and I cannot imagine his making the sort of sectarian remark attributed to him. I regret that the incident has occurred. I apologise to the chamber as I am not duty Minister but have detained honourable senators for some time. I think it is time we allowed the next speaker to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night in his adjournment speech in this chamber, Senator Panizza invited me to put up or shut up, to take up the challenge that he has made to me to repeat my allegations outside this place so that we could settle that matter once and for all. I refer to page 1127 of Hansard. The first part of the invitation is illogical because I have already both put up and shut up. The central cause of Senator Panizza's purported concern appears to be the fact that I stated that people who had been shipped to Australia under the British child migrant scheme had worked on his family property. I quote from page 426 of the Senate Hansard of 18 August. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: In my responding speech my intention was to demonstrate that Senator Panizza was in a special position to know more about the child migrant scheme than any others. I used information given to me from four different sources to which I have again returned today. Two of them claim to have been told by Senator Panizza himself that former boys from the child migrant institutions had worked on the family property, but in no way did I intend my words to imply that the boys were harshly treated, of tender years, or anything of that nature.

I regret that that statement and whatever Senator Panizza read into it has caused him so much concern. I cannot retract it. I cannot apologise for it because I believe it to be true. I believe my sources, which I do not intend to give. The sources are not all interconnected. I do not intend to reveal my sources in any way, just as Mr Ruddock, the Opposition spokesman on immigration and ethnic affairs, it was reported in the Australian today, would not say how he obtained a letter which has been referred to in a previous debate. He said he had not spoken to the people involved. I ask why Senator Panizza would demand a different course from me, a course not demanded of a shadow Minister in his own Party. Why would people on two separate occasions say that Senator Panizza had said one thing to them and then say in the Senate that that was not true? On 18 August Senator Panizza said at page 425 of Hansard:
I categorically state before every member in this chamber that no child migrant from that institution or any other like institution has either worked or holidayed on our family property. . .

The second part of Senator Panizza's invitation was to repeat the allegations outside this place so that we could settle the matter once and for all. That was the first time that Senator Panizza had invited me to repeat my so-called allegations outside so that we could settle the matter once and for all. It was quite the reverse, in fact. Previously Senator Panizza had said to me privately, and more than once, that if I said the same words outside this place he would serve a very expensive writ on me. He also telephoned the Secretary of the Child Migrant Friendship Society of Western Australia and spent half an hour on the telephone, according to the lady in question, intimidating her with talk of a writ-so much so that her husband phoned my Perth office in great distress.
On 4 September Senator Knowles asked me to apologise for making statements which I had not made. I refer to statements made by Senator Knowles and reported on page 927 of Hansard:
. . . Mrs Pearce has quite categorically stated that she has not contacted other senators as Senator Jenkins has claimed . . .
As I said at the time, that is gross misrepresentation. I did not say that Mrs Pearce had contacted other senators. I said-and I quote from page 273 of Hansard of 17 August:
These people came to me having in past times gone to other parliamentary representatives.
I quote from page 359 of Hansard of 17 August:
Mrs Pearce reiterated to me today that she and other members of the society had previously approached Labor and Liberal members of Parliament in Western Australia . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they?

—Senator Panizza asks, `Where are they?'. In March 1989 Mrs Pearce of Western Australia corresponded with the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke; the Leader of the State Opposition, Mr Barry MacKinnon; the then Leader of the Federal Opposition, Mr John Howard; and the then shadow Minister for immigration, Mr Alan Cadman. Mr MacKinnon replied courteously and promptly within two weeks, importing that it was a Federal issue on which I was an appropriate representative but inviting further contact with him if he could be of further help. Mr Howard's office replied that on 11 May 1989 the letter was passed to Mr Peacock from whom no further reply or acknowledgment had been received. The society was pleased with the response from Senator Robert Ray to whom the letter was referred by the Prime Minister. The response, dated 27 July 1989, promised the child migrants certificates of entry and permanent status but not Australian citizenship. The society attributes this good fortune to my work in raising the issue in the first place in June. Several individual members of the society have assured me that they had previously contacted other members of parliament for assistance without effect. However, I now know of at least one Western Australian State Labor Party member who has very kindly decided to assist, and that is Dr Judyth Watson, MLA. I was not told, nor have I ever claimed, that Senator Knowles was approached-or, for that matter, any specific Western Australian senator.
—You inferred that, and you know it.

—Only that members of Parliament, both Labor and Liberal, were approached. I now refer to another statement that Senator Knowles made on 4 September which is reported on page 927 of Hansard. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in view of the position of Mrs Pearce, who has quite clearly laid it down that she would like Senator Jenkins to apologise to clear this matter once and for all.
When Mrs Pearce read that statement in a copy of Hansard she was amazed, but no more so than when she read another statement on the same page which said:
. . . Mrs Pearce has quite categorically stated that she has not contacted other senators as Senator Jenkins has claimed . . .
Senator Knowles quite cunningly had read to Mrs Pearce over the telephone a statement from Hansard with a notable omission. On page 359 of Hansard I said:
Mrs Pearce reiterated to me today that she . . . and other members of the society had previously approached Labor and Liberal members of Parliament . . .
Mrs Pearce has stated to me that Senator Knowles chose to omit the words `and other members of the society'. Mrs Pearce said that she feels harassed by Senator Knowles's approach-

TALK.START.PARA: —Start telling the truth.
—and that she, Mrs Pearce, did not state that she would like me to apologise.
—You have lied up to now; start telling the truth.
—Order! Senator Panizza, you will withdraw that remark.
—Yes, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will withdraw that remark and speak later.

—I am trying to be restrained, Mr Acting Deputy President. The situation was exactly the opposite from that described by Senator Knowles. She told Mrs Pearce on 13 August, I believe, that she, Senator Knowles, wanted me to apologise and requested Mrs Pearce to pass that message on to me. As honourable senators here will understand, it was a very embarrassed Mrs Pearce who subsequently telephoned. Imagine one senator telephoning a constituent and asking her to telephone another senator to ask that senator to apologise to the first senator! What an extraordinary situation!

SPEECH.PARA: I subsequently wrote to Senator Knowles asking her to communicate with me directly and to the point. This whole saga is extraordinary and I am afraid that it does not place my Western Australian Liberal colleagues in a good light. I have been pressed by Senator Knowles and Senator Panizza to speak out for some two weeks. Both honourable senators have been mischievous. I believe that they either have not really understood or simply do not care about the damage that they have done to former child migrants-both those who form a part of the membership of the Child Migrant Friendship Society and those who do not.

When I delivered a speech on this issue in the adjournment debate on 16 June I narrated the past and present plight of former child migrants. I made no mention of any other member of parliament or any other matter at all. I did not mention that some former child migrants had contacted other members of parliament. I made a speech on that subject, and that alone. On 16 August Senator Panizza chose to dispute the accuracy of what I said. He impugned my motives and said that everybody knew about the child migrant scheme and that if there had been abuses the children would have complained. I disputed Senator Panizza's statements. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an article in the Sunday Telegraph of 3 September-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the other Western Australian senator?
—Order! I will delay the request for incorporation for a moment while the article is being shown to honourable senators.
—Who is the other Western Australian who had child labour on their property? Have you the courage to answer that one?

—Senator Panizza and Senator Knowles have treated this in an extraordinary way-I think that can be seen right now-and, in fact, a bullying way, with a distinct double standard. If the coalition is downright rude and blatantly misrepresents, that is described as the cut and thrust of politics, but if an honourable senator on the other benches offers a word of criticism of any sort then there is over-the-edge reaction from those coalition senators. Apologies are sought, a writ is threatened, and vicious and tasteless accusations are made. I would say it is a classic example of Liberal game-playing.

SPEECH.PARA: On 29 August Senator Knowles delivered what must be one of the most tasteless and malicious personal attacks ever delivered in this chamber in the new Parliament House. I have already dealt with some of the matters that were mentioned in that speech. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask Senator Knowles, who says that I accused my colleague Senator Panizza of various wrongdoings, whether she would kindly state what those wrongdoings are. I have not accused Senator Panizza of doing anything wrong, only with being wrong. Senator Knowles has asked me to give the name of other senators to whom I was referring. I do not wish to do that and I will not do it because I certainly would not wish anybody else to be harassed in the same way. Also, I do not think it would do any good whatsoever.

With regard to the other offensive and untrue gossip, in Senator Knowles's speech on 29 August she referred to a meeting in my office with a group identifiable as a Canadian delegation under the political exchange program. I can state quite categorically that the hearsay detailed by Senator Knowles is totally untrue. In essence, Senator Knowles said that I could not answer most of the questions put to me by the members of the delegation, and I did not provide them with Party platforms and policies. On these untrue reports, I am awaiting comments from the chairman of the political exchange program, Sir Robert Cotton, to whom I wrote last week. In the meantime, I have had verbal contact with an independent witness of the briefing which Senator Knowles has misrepresented who denied that there was any dissatisfaction with my performance or the materials I distributed. Those materials were one full volume of State policies given to the leader of the group, a Federal Party platform for the 1987 Federal election, and copies of the objectives and principles of the Party. I am amazed that Senator Knowles should attribute uncouth behaviour to the members of the Canadian delegation. This must obviously be investigated because of its very serious implications for international relationships under the political exchange program. I suggest Senator Knowles has degraded herself and her Party by admitting her unethical participation in such behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I at no time attributed uncouth behaviour to the Canadian delegation and I seek a withdrawal of that comment. I take offence at it.
—If Senator Knowles takes offence at the remark, I ask Senator Jenkins whether she would be prepared to withdraw it.
—I will withdraw the statement and read directly from Hansard with regard to it. I quote from page 538 of the Senate Hansard dated 29 August 1989:

SPEECH.PARA: I can cite the case of a recent delegation that came to Western Australia and was supposed to be briefed by Senator Jenkins on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The members of that delegation left in utter amazement to repeat to other people who they met in further meetings during the course of the week in Western Australia that she could not answer most of their questions. Secondly, she could not provide them with party platforms and policies.

As I said earlier, I believe that when we have people on political exchange delegations to this country, we should not accuse them of gossiping and repeating allegations of that sort. That is most improper.

I now seek leave to table copies of two letters which were written to Senator Panizza. First of all, I will read just the first paragraph of each of those letters. The first one is dated 22 August 1988 and states:

I read your address to the Senate and the papers. I was shocked and dumbfounded about your lack of knowledge on the Child Migrant issue. I was that child that was locked in the parlour with the dead nun.

I do not wish to read the rest of that letter because it is a rather horrendous account. However, I seek leave to table it and, at the same time, I seek leave to table the second letter. The second letter is dated 24 August, addressed to Senator Panizza, and the first paragraph reads:
Dear Sir,

I have been a Liberal supporter all of my voting life. I also take a very broad view of life around me. Unfortunately I read your address to the Senate and your Comments to the Western Australian news paper on 17.8.89 which totally stunned me, as I am married to an ex-Child Migrant.
I seek leave to table the letters.
Leave granted.
