LOST CHILDREN OF THE EMPIRE STRIKE BACK

In 1967, 90 children sailed from Southampton dock, England, for a new life in Australia. They were to be the last contingent of Britain's child migration scheme-a more acceptable phrase than child exportation-that had lasted 350 years and exiled some 150,000 boys and girls as young as three, to outposts of the British Empire.
Mostly the children did not want to go and remained permanently affected by their experiences.

Abuse and deception, according to Philip Bean and Joy Meville, the authors of Lost Children Of The Empire, characterised the Australian schemes. The recollections of some of these children-now adult men and women-should shame and horrify Australians.

Nigel Fitzgibbon was one of about 10,000 British children who were shipped to Australia after World War II. The systematic abuse of some of these children in Australian institutions is one of the blackest spots in the whole history of child migration.

On August 15, 1947, Nigel boarded SS Astaurius with about 250 boys and girls destined for orphanages in Australia. Both his parents were in fact alive, even if they hadn't been contacted for permission for their son to go to Australia.
After arriving at Fremantle, Nigel was despatched in a group of 20 to Bindoon Boys' Town, a Catholic orphanage in the bush about 120km north of Perth.
Nigel was impressed by the green hills and grape- vines but, on arrival at the orphanage, found there was little chance to admire the view:

`After we'd had our new clothes taken from us, we were given some khaki clothes and next day started fitting into the routine. Being on a farm, there were cows to milk first thing in the morning and that sort of thing.

There was no real education but we didn't care. At the time, the Brother in charge was a good man but a few months later he left and we got told about this man, Brother Keaney, coming back, And he arrived.
He started pulling boys out of the classrooms, 'cos he wanted to start massive building projects.'

Within three years the boys had built three large two-storey buildings with spacious hallways and chapels, dormitories and schoolrooms. Each building was made of stone and granite that the boys brought from the bush and cemented in place.
As well as that, they built dams by hand, numerous farm buildings and Roman Catholic monuments.
Nigel recalls it being nothing more than sheer slave labor, from dawn to late evening, made even worse by the primitive tools they were given to use.
The boys were emaciated from an inadequate diet: gruel for breakfast, which was mixed with bran from the chicken feed.
Nigel also claims a number of the Brothers sexually abused the boys.
But what really seems to have broken Nigel's spirit and left a life-long scar, is the sheer physical brutality and sadism of one brother.
The brother had a special stick with a 303 bullet on the end of it with which he hit and prodded the children in certain areas.
On one occasion the Brother hurt Nigel badly, and he inspected the injured area for some time after a particularly cruel incident.

`you can't forget those things and I think it made a lot of kids there very hardened. A lot of those kids never married, and if they did have a relationship with a woman, a normal relationship with a woman, it often didn't last because you never felt the tenderness the feel of a close relationship with anyone, in your young life. You saw violence, day after day.'

Nigel left Bindoon when he was 17 and, despite his experiences, gave the impression of having made a go at life. He joined the army and was there for 22 years, becoming a Warrant Officer, Class 1, and winning lots of medals.
He married and had children, though his marriage was not a great success. He is now separated, which he mostly attributes to his life at Bindoon.

Another boy at Bindoon never forgot the ``disgusting job of cleaning out sewage pits'' and being told they could build themselves a swimming pool. ``We all worked really hard on construction only to discover that it was a dam for the orchards-although we never saw a piece of fruit. I remember often having no shoes, although my oldest sister tells me that money was sent for shoes.''
The boys often foraged for food. As one said:
`We would get porridge in the mornings and a cup of tea. At lunch, we'd get toast. And then for dinner we might get a rabbit-we'd go out and trap them or we'd literally dig them out of the ground.'
One remembered his first day at Bindoon, aged 12, ``started with Brother Keaney hitting me on the head with a walking stick''.

One ex-Christian Brother, who spent some years at Bindoon and saved at least three from drowning in the swimming hole, wrote to one of those he had saved after seeing him on television talking about his experiences.

He admitted that, looking back, it might have been a blessing if the creek had claimed them in view of what terrible lives some had ultimately led, ``suicides, alcohol, broken marriages, loneliness, desertions-a life of misery.''

Some of the sexual abuse of children that took place in orphanages run by the Christian Brothers was criminal. At least half a dozen boys had to have corrective surgery, yet none of the doctors involved ever reported the cases, nor did they report the general injuries that took place under suspicious circumstances and placed boys in hospital.

Colin Reidy, who went to Clontarf Orphanage, recalls: `The Brothers often came to the bed and pulled your clothes back and tried to fondle you and that was one of the reasons I was singled out, because I wouldn't take it: I would kick and spit. Because I flatly refused to go along with it, I knew I was in a lot of trouble, so I would rush down to the priest at eleven at night and wake him up and talk to him and he kept promising to do something about it, but he never did.'

There were children who cried in bed at night, afraid to wake up the next morning. There were children who no longer cried. Some, reacting to the cruelty inflicted upon them, would in turn inflict their anger on smaller boys by beating them, or they would be cruel to animals.
The girls sent out to Australia faced a bleak childhood, too. One girl had a particularly severe beating by a reverend mother, which affected her into adult life.
Many said that one of the worst things at Goodwood Orphanage was that they received no care or kindness. As one girl said:

`What I missed most was a bit of love. You had no one, you had the girls you come out with but they were in the same boat as you. Some of the nuns were nice, but still they didn't give you the love you needed.'
* From Lost Children Of The Empire, by Philip Bean and Joy Melville. Published by Unwin Hyman. Distributed by Allen & Unwin Australia. $29.95.

SPEECH.PARA: To get this help we had to prove a case of real need which we did only to be told we did not fit into the guidelines as no trauma occurred. It was then we turned to Senator J. Jenkins as both major parties were not prepared to listen to us.

I said at the start of my remarks that I was making them only at the invitation of Senator Knowles and Senator Panizza. I had chosen to be silent. I had no wish to make these sorts of remarks, but after continuous misrepresentation I really felt that I had no option.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been an extraordinary night in the Senate and I will do my little bit to make it dull, colourless and brief so that we can go back to debating just about everything else on the agenda of the human schedule.
—There is nothing unusual in that in one of your speeches.

—Never mind. I can take on Senator Puplick about whether Melbourne will beat Collingwood, which will be much better than some of the stuff we have heard here tonight. I wish to talk briefly to the Government response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, Income Support for the Retired and the Aged: An Agenda for Reform, and to pick up on a couple of comments made in the Senate about this report during the tabling of papers on Monday. On Monday Senator Messner commented that he felt that the Government had dealt shabbily with the Senate and the Standing Committee on Community Affairs report on retirement incomes, essentially because he wanted to make much of the brevity of the report. The Committee's report was a valuable part of the process that led to the Government's retirement incomes statement. The Government's retirement incomes policy is the result of one of the most sustained exercises in policy development research and consultation that this Government or any government has seen. The Government's response to the Committee's report acknowledged the important role the Committee's work played, as a close reading of the response reveals. For the information of honourable senators I seek leave to incorporate the Government's response to that report into Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Government Response to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs Report `Income Support for the Retired and the Aged: An Agenda for Reform'.

The following document provides the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs report ``Income Support for the Retired and the Aged: An Agenda for Reform''. This report was released during the period that the Government was developing the first ever comprehensive national policy on retirement income. The Government's retirement income policy was released as part of the 1989-90 Budget.

The Government has taken account of the views expressed in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. In line with the broad objectives of the Federal Government, the Committee aimed to turn the two systems of income support, that is the social security system and the occupational superannuation system, towards the common purpose of providing more adequate, equitable and cost-effective retirement income provision for all Australians.

The Government has undertaken extensive consultations in the process of developing its retirement income policy which is fair, adequate, secure and sustainable. We believe that it was crucial for the interested parties to be involved in the development of this historic policy.

Most of the recommendations made by the Senate Standing Committee have been taken up by the Government. Some recommendations were not consistent with the Government's judgment on the best long term community interest or with the views expressed by the community in its consultations with the Government and, therefore, have not been adopted.

The Government believes that a flexible and sustainable retirement income policy which delivers fair and adequate incomes needs to build on the twin pillars of the age pension system and private saving, especially through superannuation.

The centrepiece of the Government's retirement income policy is its commitment to maintain the age pension as an adequate base level of income for older people who have not had the opportunity to save during their working lives. It will be possible to meet the expectation of higher living standards for the retired in the future only if we can improve on our current levels of saving and if we can provide better employment opportunities for older workers and for women.

Consistent with recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee, the Government recognises that the level of the age and service pensions, as well as rent assistance, pensioner concessions and the amount of tax and income test free income determine income adequacy for most retirees. We remain committed to maintaining and improving the adequacy of the age pension. Labor's longstanding commitment to an age pension of 25 per cent of AWE will not only be met but exceeded in April 1990.

The Government will undertake a major restructuring on the income test and tax interaction to improve the level of income adequacy for age pensioners and increase incentives for savings. We will implement a three stage reform of the income test and tax overlap so that from July 1995, no age or service pensioner will be required to pay tax. This will be achieved by better integration of the pension and tax systems. From 1995 age pensioners will deal only with the Department of Social Security.

The Government is committed to ensuring that people in the workforce have opportunities to save more for their retirement years. It will ensure that superannuation contributes to increased adequacy of retirement income by extending superannuation coverage across the labour force; improving superannuation benefits; ensuring that superannuation benefits are not lost when an employee changes jobs; making superannuation more responsive to women's patterns of working; and seeking to ensure that superannuation is not wasted before or at retirement.

The Government will maintain an individual's current free choice to receive a lump sum superannuation benefit. However, we are concerned that superannuation should be used for retirement purposes and we are committed to providing people with realistic opportunities and incentives to use their lump sums to provide regular income.
Attachment A
REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY AFFAIRS,
AUGUST 1988:
``Income Support for the Retired and the Aged, An Agenda for Reform''
Part One-Income Support Provided through the Social Security System
Recommendation 1.
That the level of age and service pensions be increased to reflect more closely the income needs of those wholly dependent on this source of income support during their retirement and old age.
Response

For those pensioners with no other income, the Federal Government remains committed to maintaining and improving the adequacy of the age pension. Labor's longstanding commitment to an age pension of 25 per cent of AWE will not only be met but exceeded in April 1990. There will be a special increase in April 1990 of $2 a week for single pensioners and $3.30 a week for married pensioner couples on top of indexation. The Government is committed to further increases over time and will continue to monitor the circumstances of those pensioners with no income other than the pension.
Recommendation 2.
That the Government increase the current level of rent assistance available to low-income age and service pensioners who are required to seek accommodation in the private rental market.
Reponse

In the 1988-89 Budget, the Government announced a series of phased increases to raise the level of rent assistance from $15 a week in 1988 to $20 a week in June 1990. Families with children were given extra payments in recognition of the extra costs they face.
Further increases are contained in the 1989-90 Budget. Rent assistance which is paid to age and service pensioners in private rental accommodation will be increased by:
$5 a week in December 1989
an additional $5 a week in June 1990 (announced last year)
a further $5 a week in September 1990; and
will be indexed twice yearly in line with the Consumer Price Index from March 1991.

These increases in rent assistance will improve the incomes of our poorest pensioners. They will mean that the level of rent assistance by September 1990 for age pensioners will have at least doubled since December 1988. For the first time ever, they will also have the security of indexation of rent assistance as well as of the age pension.
Recommendation 3.

That prior to increasing the level of rent assistance, the Commonwealth negotiate with the Governments of the States and the Northern Territory to devise appropriate leasing and rent control mechanisms to ensure that increases in the level of rent assistance do not generate corresponding increases in rental charges by landlords and agents.
Response
The Social Security Review concluded, on the basis of overseas and Australian evidence, that increased rental assistance will have little or no effect on the level of rents.
Recommendation 4.

That the Government take steps to ensure that adjustments to pension rates related to changes in the Consumer Price Index take effect no more than 2 months after the end of the relevant Consumer Price Index review period.
Response
In the 1989 April Economic Statement the Government committed itself to reducing the lag between price increases and pension increases by 12 weeks in 3 stages:
by 4 weeks in November 1989;
by a further 4 weeks in April 1990; and
by a further 4 weeks in September 1990.

Indexation will continue to be six monthly but will be in March and September compared to the current arrangements of June and December. As of September 1990 indexation adjustments will take place 12 weeks after the end of the relevant Consumer Price Index period. This will provide pensioners with the speediest CPI indexation in history.
Recommendation 5.
That the Government initiate a review of the taxation treatment of age and service pensioners with a view to:

(a) reducing the impact of the income tax burden on pensioners with low or modest incomes by either (i) regularly adjusting the special pensioner tax rebate in line with increases in the level of pensions, (ii) adjusting the ordinary tax threshold, or (iii) exempting pensioners from paying income tax altogether;

(b) improving the administration of the present taxation system as it affects pensioners by amending the present provisional income tax system and/or improving measures to facilitate the withholding of income tax at its source when income is received; and
(c) determining whether the measures announced in the 1988-89 Budget fully address the particular problems of surviving pensioner spouses following the death of their husband or wife.
Response

The Federal Government will implement a three-stage reform of the income test and tax overlap. The first stage which was announced in April 1989 will make the income test free area for pensioners 100 per cent tax free by July 1990. This will eliminate tax payable on non-pension income within the pension free area and simplify the way in which the social security system interacts with the tax system. The free area for a single pensioner is currently $40 a week. It is $70 a week for married pensioner couples.

The second stage of the Federal Government's reform is to index annually the income test free area, for social security and veterans' pensioners, from 1 July 1991. The free area will continue to be 100 per cent tax free. The free area has never before been indexed by any Federal Government. Maintaining its real value will give pensioners greater certainty in organising their finances.
The third stage of the Federal Government's reform will address the position of pensioners who have income above the income test free area-that is, part rate pensioners.

The Federal Government is committed to introducing from 1995 a better integrated system of social security and tax administration for age and service pensioners and to reducing combined pension withdrawal and tax rates. This will be achieved by removing all age and service pensioners-both full rate and part rate-from the tax system and making part rate pensioners subject only to the withdrawal rate on the pension entitlement. This means that from 1995 no age or service pensioner will pay income tax. The present high EMTRs will be reduced substantially to 50 per cent.
A reform introduced in the 1988-89 Budget ensured that all pensioners receiving the pensioner tax rebate are exempted from paying provisional tax.
Pensioners already have the option of having tax instalments deducted from their pension.
The tax burden of surviving pensioner spouses was reduced in the 1988-89 budget by the exemption from tax of the special temporary allowance.
Recommendation 6.

That the Government extend entitlement to Commonwealth pensioner fringe benefits (i.e. the present range of free pharmaceuticals, hearing aid services, and telephone rental, postable and certain travel concessions) to all recipients of age and service pensions.
Response

In November 1983 the Government indexed the income limits for the Pensioner Health Benefit (PHB) card. This change meant that the income limits for Commonwealth fringe benefits maintained their real value and that more age pensioners than ever before are now eligible for fringe benefits. The proportion of age pensioners eligible for a PHB card has increased from 78 per cent in 1983 to 84 per cent currently.
Since 1988 pensioners have been entitled to retain eligibility for the PHB card for up to three months if their income rises by no more than 25 per cent above the PHB income text limits.

Extension of Commonwealth pensioner fringe benefits free of an income test to all recipients of age and service pensions would be costly and not as well targeted as other changes that the Government has chosen to introduce now.
Recommendation 7.
That the age of eligibility for the age pension for women be increased from 60 to 65 years thereby establishing a common age of pension entitlement for both men and women.
Recommendation 8.

That the adjustment to the age of eligibility for the age pension for women be phased in gradually over a period of 5 years and that this period of adjustment commence at a time to be determined by the Government, but not later than 1992.
Recommendation 9.

That, during the phasing-in period, the wife's pension and the widow's pension continue to be made available to those women aged 60-64 years who are eligible for such pensions, and that the special benefit be made available to those single women aged 60-64 years who are ineligible to receive any other form of government assistance but who are deemed to be in special need.
Response to 7, 8 & 9

The Government will monitor the progress of women's participation in superannuation and labour market opportunities, particularly during the period from 1995 when improved vesting and preservation standards apply, before there is any consideration of an increase in the age pension eligibility age for women.

The Government intends to design an education program during 1989-90 to educate the community on the benefit of saving for retirement with specific attention to the retirement income needs of women and increasing the opportunities for older workers.

The Government's commitment to award restructuring emphasises the need to improve career paths for women as an avenue to providing better opportunities for women in the labour market and in regard to wage issues.
The Government believes that extension of award superannuation is the best means of providing superannuation to the majority of women who currently receive no superannuation.
Changes will be made to personal superannuation which will be of particular benefit to women including:
from 1 July 1990 people working as little as 10 hours a week will be allowed to contribute to personal superannuation and receive a tax deduction;
people will be able to continue to contribute to superannuation and receive a tax deduction for up to two years while outside the paid workforce;

changes to the administration of reasonable benefit limits (RBLs) will assist people who experience rises and falls in their income throughout their working life: it is intended that RBLs will be based on the highest average salary received by a person before age 65 in any three consecutive years;
a base salary of $25,000 will be adopted for RBL purposes which will ensure that people with low incomes have an entitlement to a reasonable level of concessionally taxed benefits;

access to superannuation concessions for the self employed and for employees with little or no employer sponsored superannuation will be improved by increasing the limits on contributions which these people can make and which can be counted as deductions against their taxable income; and
the pension RBL will be increased to provide for pensions indexed to the CPI with an 85 per cent reversionary benefit to a surviving spouse.
The Government does not intend to alter the qualifying age for wife's pension.
Class B Widow's pension was phased out from 1 July 1987.
Recommendation 10.

That the Government develop a flexible system of age pension entitlement whereby people approaching the above recommended uniform age of pension entitlement of 65 years may be given the choice of qualifying for a part pension up to 5 years earlier by receiving a rate of assistance reduced on a pro rata basis according to the person's age.
Response

Overseas experience suggests that providing an earlier part pension can encourage early retirement. The Government considers that such encouragement is wasteful of resources and is not in the national interest.
It should also be noted that such arrangements are not compatible with Australian social security arrangements which are based on flat rate non-contributory pensions and benefits.

The Government is committed to providing opportunities for the continued employment and re-employment of older workers. This entails mechanisms to improve employment and labour force participation, to reduce unemployment and welfare dependence and to make adequate provision for the unemployed in the 55-64 age group.
In 1990, the Government will trial three different models of contact, interview, counselling and referral for 55-64 year old unemployed people.

During 1989-90 the Government will consult extensively with key community, employer and union organisations to develop a long term strategy for generating attitudinal change about the employment of older workers.
As part of a process to end age discrimination the Attorney-General will report in 1990 on the need for legislation to outlaw age discrimination in employment practices.
The Government will also monitor the impact of industry and award restructuring on older workers.
Changes to the administration of Reasonable Benefit Limits for superannuation benefits will provide an incentive for continued workforce participation by older workers.
Recommendation 11.

That the age of eligibility for the service pension for ex-servicewomen be increased from 55 to 60 years thereby establishing a common age of service pension entitlement for both ex-servicemen and ex-servicewomen, but that this adjustment be made so as not to affect the current population of female service pensioners aged 55-59 years or those women who have already met qualifying service requirements.
Response
The Government does not propose to alter the qualifying age for service pension.
Recommendation 12.
That all age and service pensioners be paid at the standard rate of pension currently payable to single pensioners, irrespective of their marital status.
Response
This matter is to be reviewed in the final issues paper to be produced by the Social Security Review.

Research into the income relativities required to provide the same standard of living for single and married income units where the household head is not in the workforce shows that the existing single pension of 60 per cent of the combined married rate is a reasonably accurate reflection of the different cost structures.

Any change to the current arrangements which directed additional expenditure to increasing the married rate of pension to a level equivalent to the standard rate of pension would decrease any additional assistance available for those groups shown to be in most need. These include those with little or no non-pension income, pensioners in private rental accommodation, those who have been in receipt of pension for a long period and those who live alone.
Recommendation 13.
That the Government retain the present 10-year residency eligibility requirement for the age pension, but:
(a) continue to conduct negotiations with overseas countries so that further reciprocal social security agreements may be concluded; and
(b) consult with the relevant ethnic communities in Australia both in the initial stages of developing agreement proposals and during the official negotiation process.
Response

Australia has current, operating social security agreements with the United Kingdom, New Zealand and Italy. The Agreement with Italy is the shared responsibility style of agreement which Australia now favours.
An agreement with Canada enters into force on 1 September 1989.
By the end of 1989 an Agreement with Spain and a revised Agreement with the United Kingdom should be signed-both could enter into force during 1990.
It is likely that Agreements with Malta, The Netherlands and Ireland and an Understanding with Quebec will be ready for signature during 1990.

Negotiations are continuing with Portugal and the Federal Republic of Germany. Information exchanges and discussions have begun with Austria, Greece, Yugoslavia, Turkey, Cyprus, Switzerland, the Scandinavian countries and the USA.

Formal negotiations do not commence until the relevant ethnic community has been consulted and indicates general support for an agreement. Community concerns are taken into account during formal negotiations. Community consultation during the negotiation phase is not appropriate given the confidentiality of government to government negotiations on an international treaty.
Recommendation 14.

That, to ensure the income support needs of the aged are met through a means testing process that is fair to all and allows government pensions to be directed to those genuinely in need of assistance, the Government amend the current assets test by requiring those owning houses of high market value to satisfy a separate and supplementary housing test similar to that advocated by the 1984 Gruen Panel of Review as part of its modified `tall poppies' assets test proposal.
Response
The Recommendation is rejected unequivocally. It is not Government policy to include the family home in the assets test.
Recommendation 15.
That the Government:

(a) widen access to the Pension Loans Scheme by allowing any age or service pensioner to borrow from it, irrespective of their income and ownership of assets, providing they have sufficient capital to repay the amount borrowed plus accrued interest, and
(b) publicise more widely both the availability and the advantages of the Scheme.
Response
The Pension Loans Scheme is designed to meet cases of genuine hardship where it is not practical for pensioners to organise their assets to provide for their own income support.
In view of the concessional interest rate available, an extension is likely to result in a poorly targeted increase in program expenditure and increased administrative costs.
Recommendation 16.

That, in giving effect to the Government's stated objective of addressing the need for further changes to the retirement incomes system, especially the need to develop a more integrated approach towards meeting the income needs of the aged through the social security system and the occupational superannuation system, the Government include in its consideration of the reform proposals put to it the option of introducing a two-tiered age pension system which:
(a) at one level, would provide a flat-rate, non-means-tested entitlement (set at 20 per cent of Average Weekly Earnings) to all people of eligible age, and

(b) at another level, would provide a means-tested income supplement (set at 10 per cent of Average Weekly Earnings) to those in particular need who are unable to supplement their income in retirement and old age by other means.
Response
The Government rejects this proposal.
Submissions to the Social Security Review generally agreed that the current system of a means-tested pension and occupational superannuation was the best system for Australia.
The means-tested nature of the age pension:
concentrates assistance on those in most need; and
provides supplementary assistance to those with moderate amounts of private income.
The payment of a flat-rate non-means tested entitlement would:
entail significant costs;
direct additional assistance to people who in most cases have already benefited from tax concessions for superannuation purposes throughout their working life;
reduce resources available to assist those with the least income and assets; and
on the basis of the Committee's costings, appear to entail a reduction in pension for some full rate pensioners.
Part Two-Income Support Provided through the Occupational Superannuation System
Recommendation 17

That the Department of the Treasury continues to calculate estimates of the cost of occupational superannuation taxation concessions and publish such estimates in each year's annual Budget Papers as well as in its annual Tax Expenditures Statement.
Response
This is existing policy to the extent it is possible:
figures are usually not available until about 18 months following the end of the financial year.
Recommendation 18

That the Government, noting that it may not always be appropriate that all employees belong to the same scheme, require through regulation, that employers sponsoring schemes for some of their employees, also offer superannuation scheme membership to all employees (including regular part-time employees) aged 18 years or more who have completed a maximum of 1 year's service or the equivalent of this period, with that employer.
Response to 18 & 19

The Government through its amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act intends to make it unlawful to discriminate against permanent part-time employees in the terms and conditions relating to superannuation schemes.
Recommendation 19
That a lead-in period of 1 year be allowed between the announcement of the new minimum membership eligibility standard and its date of first effect.
Recommendation 20.

That the Government amend the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act 1984 by repealing section 41 (1) to make it unlawful to discriminate against another person on the ground of the other person's sex or marital status in the terms and conditions relating to a superannuation scheme.
Recommendation 21.

That the Government repeal section 41 (4) of the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to make it unlawful to use gender-based actuarial or statistical data to determine contribution and benefit rates.
Recommendation 22.

That the Government encourage, through the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, complementary action by the Governments of the States and the Northern Territory to ensure that occupational superannuation schemes operated by them and their respective authorities do not discriminate against women on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy.
Response to 20, 21, & 22
Legislation to repeal section 41 (1) of the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and to replace it with more limited provisions is currently before Parliament.

Following enquiries by the Human Rights Commission (now the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission), the Government has taken steps to amend the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 to remove the general exemption in respect of superannuation. The effect of this will be to remove most forms of direct discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status in superannuation practice. At the same time, consistent with Human Rights Commission recommendations, the Bill allows for scope for more limited exemptions, for example, the inclusion in fund conditions of a provision based upon reasonable actuarial data.

The Government has written to all State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and has received assurances that State public service superannuation schemes either comply with the standards set in the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1989 or are in the process of being amended to comply.
Recommendation 23.

That, as a condition of eligibility for superannuation taxation concessions under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Government further regulate to require that, as a minimum, employer-financed benefits (except those covered by Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulation 8) be mandatorily vested in accordance with the following age and length-of-service criteria:
(a) full vesting to apply to all employees aged 30 years and over who have completed 1 year of service;

(b) graded vesting to apply to all employees aged 18 years and over but less than 30 years such that the proportion of employer-financed benefits vested equals 20 per cent after 1 year service, 40 per cent after 2 years of service and so on, so that 100 per cent vesting is achieved by an employee's fifth year of service;
(c) periods of service accrued with an employer before the age of 18 to be credited towards the graded vesting standard; and
(d) fund trustees be required to inform all members in writing of the vesting conditions applicable to their superannuation scheme.
Recommendation 24.
That the new compulsory vesting arrangements apply only to benefits accruing after the date of the introduction of the standards.
Recommendation 25.
That a lead-in period of 1 year be allowed between the announcement of the above recommended minimum vesting standards and the date of their first effect.
Recommendation 26.
That the new vesting standards be imposed only in conjunction with requirements for the compulsory preservation of vested employer-financed benefits.
Response to 23, 24, 25 & 26

The Occupational Superannuation Standards (OSS) Regulations made under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 impose the following vesting and preservation standards which superannuation funds must comply with in order to be eligible for taxation concessions.
The current vesting standards require a superannuation fund to vest in full in a member;
all member contributions and, from a specified date (generally 30 June 1986), all member financed benefits (that is contributions plus earnings); and
employer financed benefits standards arising from 3 per cent award based superannuation contributions.
The current vesting standards do not apply to other employer financed benefits flowing from company and industry based superannuation funds.

The Government recognises the need for a general minimum vesting standard. It also recognises the need to avoid onerous cost burdens on employers and proposes to phase in a minimum vesting standard over a 10 year period.

Employer financed benefits accruing from 1 July 1995 (other than those already required to be vested under existing standards) will vest in the employee at a rate of not less than 10 per cent per annum so that by the end of the tenth year with an employer there will be 100 per cent vesting of those benefits. This is a minimum standard. It does not prevent an employer, as many already do, from providing a faster vesting process.
Recommendation 27.
That, the Government regulate to require that, as a condition of eligibility for taxation concessions under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936:
(a) employer-financed benefits, which are compulsorily vested in accordance with the Committee's preceding recommendations relating to vesting, also be compulsorily preserved;
(b) member-financed benefits, which are compulsorily vested in accordance with Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations 6 and 7, also be compulsorily preserved; and

(c) benefits subject to these preservation requirements be preserved until a member's retirement from the workforce at an age of not less than 55 years or earlier in the case of certain contingencies (invalidity and other special circumstances) as otherwise prescribed in accordance with Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulation 11.
Response

Currently superannuation benefits in new schemes or 3 per cent award schemes are required to be preserved until retirement from the workforce at age 55 or later. Some other schemes also require preservation until this age. The Federal Government has decided to standardise the minimum preservation age.

From 1 July 1995 an amount equal to the minimum level of employer financed benefits required to be vested under the new vesting standard will be required to be preserved until retirement on or after age 55. This requirement applies only to employer financed benefits made after 1 July 1995 and does not apply to any benefits prior to this date. This does not replace the preservation requirement under the existing standards.

The Insurance and Superannuation Commission will be consulting the superannuation industry, employers and unions in the process of the detailed implementation of these improved vesting and preservation standards.

It is the Federal Government's intention that the vesting and preservation standards applying from 1995 will be monitored and reviewed with a view to determining the feasibility of further enhancement of vesting and preservation to age 60 and after 2005.
Recommendation 28
That, with regard to the form of occupational superannuation benefits:

(a) the Government regulate to make the eligibility of superannuation funds for taxation concessions under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 conditional on employer-financed benefits and tax-deductible `eligible persons'-finance benefits being paid in the form of superannuation pensions;
(b) the regulation not apply where an individual's entitlement commutes to a level of annual superannuation pension income which is unacceptably low;

(c) the introduction of the regulation be co-ordinated with the phasing-in provisions applying to the vesting and preservation of benefits recommended earlier so as to avoid this regulation having any retrospective effect in its design; and
(d) the lump sum option continue to be available for benefits funded from non-deductible employee contributions.
Response

The Government rejects this recommendation. The Treasurer announced in the 1988 Economic Statement that the Government would not restrict the present free choice between lump sum and pension superannuation benefits.

The Government is concerned that superannuation should be used for retirement purposes. The Government is committed to providing people with realistic opportunities and incentives to use lump sums to provide regular income.

The Federal Government has two elements in its strategy for meeting this objective. The first element consists of changes to superannuation Reasonable Benefit Limits to encourage annuities. The second element consists of removing the disadvantage to the purchase of annuities in pension and benefit income tests.

Superannuation Reasonable Benefit Limits (RBLs) set the maximum amount of tax assisted superannuation a person may receive. The RBL for superannuation pensions and annuities is considerably more generous than that applying to lump sums.

In May 1988 the Federal Government announced that superannuation funds could provide benefits up to those permitted under the higher pension RBL provided at least half of the benefit is taken as a pension or annuity. The remainder (up to half) may be taken as a lump sum.

The RBL administration arrangements are to be amended from 1 July 1990 to provide greater incentives for benefits to be taken as pensions and annuities. The new policy flows from a review by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) of the administration of the Reasonable Benefit Limit guidelines. This review took close account of retirement income policy concerns, particularly with respect to incentives for preservation, the taking of benefits as annuities and the promotion of longer workforce participation.
In conducting the review the ISC consulted widely with the superannuation industry, business and unions.

From April 1990 the social security (and veterans') income test will be amended to disregard the portion of an immediate annuity or funded superannuation pension which represents the notional return of the after tax purchase price. The timetable for implementing this change will allow time for consultation with the life insurance and financial advisory industries on the details for implementation. This measure is fundamental to increase incentives for retired people to use lump sum superannuation payments as a source of regular indexed income. It complements superannuation measures which are intended to encourage preservation of superannuation to retirement and the purchase of annuities.
There is already a significant tax advantage in preserving superannuation benefits in a rollover fund until retirement. This advantage will be maintained.

From February 1990, a concession will be provided to pensioners and beneficiaries, other than age and service pensioners, to encourage preservation of superannuation benefits to retirement. By disregarding from the income test on an ongoing basis the income accruing on compulsorily preserved superannuation, there will be a closer integration of the Federal Government's social security and superannuation policies. The compulsorily preserved amount will also be disregarded under the assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments made by honourable senators opposite after the tabling were nothing short of astonishing and certainly did not indicate a close understanding of the Committee's report. A large number of the Committee's recommendations dealt with the adequacy of the existing pension system. The Committee recommended that the pension be increased to guarantee adequacy for those without private income. By way of response, by April 1990, the Government's commitment to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings will be not only met but also exceeded. The Committee recommended that the Government increase rent assistance. In December 1989 rent assistance will rise by $5 a week, by a further $5 a week in June 1990, and by another $5 a week in September 1990, and will be indexed from March 1991. The Committee recommended that consumer price index adjustments to pension rates be speeded up. Indexation of pensions will be brought forward by 12 weeks, providing pensioners with the speediest CPI indexation in history. The Committee recommended that the Government look to the interaction between the social security and taxation systems. By July 1990, the income test free area for pensioners will be 100 per cent tax free. From July 1991 the income test free area will be indexed. By 1995 pensioners will be completely withdrawn from the tax system. That means that by 1995 no age or service pensioner will pay income tax-a commitment for which the Opposition has failed so far to give bipartisan support.

SPEECH.PARA: All these issues go to the heart of the issue of adequacy. There seemed to be no understanding of that from honourable senators opposite when speaking to the Government's response to this report. Senator Knowles said:
When the Government looks at the effect of the assets test and many other measures that it has taken, it will see that many more pensioners are in dire financial straits than some years ago. . .
For a government that claims to look after people on welfare, it has not been doing a particularly good job as far as pensioners are concerned.

There was also criticism of the special pension rate increase in April 1990 and constant criticism of the Government for not doing enough for pensioners. Yet just a breath or two later, Senator Knowles is criticising the Government for creating a `welfare mentality' where `there is no point in providing for one's retirement because the Government will look after one'. Senator Knowles's remarks clearly suggest a conflict in her understanding or a lack of understanding of the Committee's report. I will not take up any more time. I suggest to honourable senators who seem to have an insufficient understanding of the Government's response to the report that they read it as I have incorporated it by way of refutation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —For years under the Gray Government in Tasmania, the timber industry and the conservation groups were at loggerheads over the Tasmanian forests. The Gray Government, with its gung ho development policies, was prepared to allow the wholesale destruction of the beautiful pristine forests of Tasmania for short term gain, never giving a thought, or a cent, for the development of an alternative plantation based timber industry that would both conserve the valuable old forests and provide alternative employment in a sustainable industry. The decision of the Helsham Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry removed some, but not enough, of the National Estate areas from exploitation, while about 30,000 tonnes of old forest growth was surrendered to logging as a result. About one-third of the National Estate forests were incorporated into the World Heritage area while the conservation movement sought a moratorium on the rest. A new era in the relationship between the industry and the conservation movement was initiated in May this year with the formation of an historic Government in Tasmania-the Labor-Green Independent accord, the first of its kind in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: This year the industry said that it needed about 30,000 tonnes to replace the amount taken away by the Helsham inquiry. It seems that about 11,000 tonnes of this can be found outside the National Estate area. The remaining 18,000 tonnes have been provided by timber resources located in degraded coupes in National Estate areas-an area which amounts to about 300 hectares in all. In exchange for these areas, the industry has agreed to the addition of about 500,000 hectares of pristine wilderness to the World Heritage area to make up a total of about 20 per cent of Tasmania. Significantly, no jobs have been lost in this deal. It is necessary to stress that the logging that is occurring in the National Estate is taking part in heavily degraded areas. The conservation movement in Tasmania has in no way resiled from defending the National Estate. Recognising that the industry was in crisis, it was prepared to locate timber resources in areas which were already considerably degraded and trade those for a considerably larger area of pristine forest.

A four-person panel, consisting of a representative each from the Forest Industries Association of Tasmania, the Forestry Commission, the union movement and the conservation movement will have decided by next Sunday on the areas to be logged. The Tasmanian Minister for Forests, David Llewellyn, has been successful in helping to negotiate an agreement between the industry and the conservation movement and has delivered a compromise that seems to be more than satisfactory to all parties concerned. The Tasmanian Wilderness Society and the Australian Conservation Foundation held a joint press conference with the unions, the companies, the State Government and the Forestry Commission on 21 August this year. This group is to set up, over the next 12 months, a timber industry plan to move the industry entirely out of the National Estate areas. The two big pulp companies, Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd and Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd, which own two concessions covering the southern forests, have stated that they do not want to log in the National Estate; they just want to be assured of a secure resource base.

On another front, the big sawmillers also have just completed a six-month study on how they can get out of the National Estate. A broad integrated package for the entire industry in Tasmania is in the making. It will, if successful, be a model for the rest of Australia, particularly for the contentious south-east forests of New South Wales, where the Federal Government is still procrastinating on using the powers it has, and the State Government is continuing to be pig-headed about the issue. Tasmanian Premier Michael Field has already announced the boundaries of the World Heritage areas. Some on the western side have not been included because of their alleged mineral potential. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, has flagged the possibility that the Federal Government may expand the World Heritage area to include these latter areas. I join with the conservation movement to encourage the Federal Government to do so because of the low prospectivity of those areas and the fact that the area's conservation value far outstrips its economic value.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I was going to speak on a serious matter relating to the Australian Wheat Board. Unfortunately, I will have to deal with Senator Jenkins first because of her outburst. On 17 August she slandered me and my family and I objected to it. I will read to the Senate what Senator Jenkins said that I got annoyed about. On page 359 of the Hansard of 17 August 1989 it states:

SPEECH.PARA: It certainly would have been well known to Senator Panizza at the time, as boys-
b-o-y-s-
from Bindoon worked on the Panizza family property. He is not the only Western Australian senator on whose family property they worked . . .

I repeat: `he is not the only Western Australian senator on whose property they worked'. That is not past tense; it is present tense. So there are 12 of us in the Senate from Western Australia; take Senator Jean Jenkins out, and that leaves 11 senators from Western Australia who are under suspicion. Senator Jenkins continues:

. . . but I chose not to allude to that because I had no reason to address any personal remarks. But Senator Panizza has forced my hand in this case. I am surprised that he did not mention it himself . . .

Senator Jenkins by her own words knew, or she thought she knew, that she had something on me and my family. Then she has the hide to stand up here tonight and say that she did not slander my family. As I have said before in this place I do not mind defending myself. I have had plenty of experience at doing that. But there are people in my family who cannot defend themselves because they are no longer around to answer those accusations. That is why I have asked Senator Jenkins to remove that slander from this record.

The other night was the first time I challenged Senator Jenkins to repeat her comments outside the Parliament. I will tell her where I challenged her to repeat her comments outside-it was outside our Whip's office. Senator Jenkins stood up here tonight and denied that I had ever said that. That is not the only mistruth that Senator Jenkins has told us today. But I will come back to that later. She has gone on with a lot of other garbage about other Liberal Party members, or Labor Party members for that matter, being contacted. I was not contacted and a lot of my colleagues have said the same thing.

Let me get back to the reference to this other senator from Western Australia. When we told Senator Jenkins to put up or shut up she came in with that weak-kneed excuse-probably written by somebody else-that she did not want to embarrass that other senator; she would prefer not to mention his or her name. Senator Jenkins will not mention the name of any other senator because she did not have one in mind in the first place. So Senator Jenkins came in and made a totally untrue accusation. She should be judged for what she has said. I still invite Senator Jenkins to speak outside the Parliament so that we can settle this matter once and for all.

I will now come to the point about threatening people outside this Parliament. Senator Jenkins told us another untruth this evening. She said that I rang Sheila Pearce-if I have her name right-the President of the Child Migrant Friendship Society of Western Australia and that I abused her for half an hour. The biggest lie in this is that Mrs Pearce rang me. What is more, I did not abuse her. We only discussed what was in the Hansard that someone had sent her. All I can say is that I am working as hard as I can for the people who are ex-child migrants from Western Australia and from Australia to help them out if they are, indeed, in need.

For just a moment can I return specifically to the matter of the boys from Bindoon who worked on the Panizza family property. Senator Jenkins told us that she had two or three or four people tell her that I had said that I had ex-child migrants working on our property or that my parents had employed them on our property. That is a lie: it is a bare-faced lie. I will tell honourable senators why. I have explained to other people that I knew something about the child migrant situation and that I employed two ex-pupils of Clontarf, another Christian Brothers school. In this slanderous assertion, Senator Jenkins said that I employed boys from Bindoon. However, I said to those people that I had employed two ex-child migrants from Clontarf.

I am not generally in the habit of asking people where they went to school, whether they went to school, whether they belong to the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia or even the National Party of Australia before I employ them. I only want to know whether they are experienced at the job and what sort of a job they will do. I found out later that these two had been at Clontarf. One of them was 21 years old when I employed him-he was hardly a boy, even if Senator Jenkins was alluding to his having been at Clontarf-and the other one was 26 years old. The 26-year-old hung around for about four years and proved to be a very good and reliable employee and the other fellow hung around for 17 years. I will now cease my remarks on that subject. I hope that this will be the last time I will have to mention this subject in the Parliament.

I now turn to some other important matters. I know it is getting late in the evening but I would like to discuss briefly some aspects of the Australian Wheat Board as it looks at the delivery of wheat for this season. You are probably well aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Australian wheat industry is deregulated. I have a few concerns regarding the content of a circularised letter sent to wheat growers by the Australian Wheat Board relating to the payment for wheat delivered this season.

Contrary to the system before deregulation, two payments are made on the guaranteed minimum price. Initially, a harvest payment is made and a post-harvest payment is made in March. There are nine options for those payments. Option 8 is the one that concerns me. Under this option farmers can defer the after-harvest payment which is normally made in March until practically whenever they like, but it must be taken by the time the pool is closed which could be in two years time. Option 8 states:
Deferral of the total `Post Harvest Payment' until a later date nominated by the grower, payment subject to deductions.

There is also a footnote in the letter which I would like the person who is responsible for these matters to take up to ensure that the right information is provided to wheat growers. The footnote states:
It is our belief that `HARVEST PAYMENTS'-
that is, the first payment-

included in the Optional Payments Scheme would be assessed by the Taxation Department in the year of the wheat delivery. However `POST HARVEST PAYMENTS' included in the Optional Payments Scheme may not be assessable as income until the actual payment is made to the grower.
A ruling is currently being sought from the Taxation Department on the above and if our beliefs are confirmed it would mean that:

(a) There would be no tax advantage in including the `HARVEST PAYMENT' in the Optional Payment Scheme as these payments would be assessed as income in the year of wheat delivery. However growers may wish to include the `HARVEST PAYMENT' in the Optional Payment Scheme in order to minimise interest charges.

The information contained in the next point worries me and that has placed many farmers in a quandary in that it will have them make decisions concerning these payments which may cause them to fall foul of the Australian Taxation Office later. The footnote continues:

(b) There could be a tax advantage in including `POST HARVEST PAYMENT' in the Optional Payment Scheme were the grower to schedule this payment to be made after 1 July 1990. This payment could then be assessed as income in the year of payment to the grower.

I would just like to address that latter point and to point out the concerns I have about it. It is a pity that Senator Walsh is not here to hear this. The notion contained in the option is one that flies in the face of the principle that when a seller has control of the payment he receives, it is normally assessed in the year of sale. Where the seller has no control over receiving the payment, then it is assessed in the year in which it is received. In other words, the Wheat Board is floating the idea in an official letter to the growers. Some growers might not read past paragraph (b), and may take it that they can postpone the second payment to a subsequent financial year and be taxed in that year. For the reasons I have said, they could be quite wrong. I would like the responsible Minister to take that matter up and see whether he can give us a ruling some time in the future so that there will be no confusion in the minds of the growers before they start delivering their wheat later this year, which is not too far away. I did have a few other points, but I have held up the Senate for long enough this evening. I thank the Senate for its time.
