I said to Mrs Pearce that what Senator Jenkins had done and was continuing to do was all very sad and the only effective way of stopping her dead in her tracks was by asking her to make the apology or, as Senator Panizza put it, to either put up or shut up, and that would be the end of the story. Mrs Pearce said, `Well, if that is the case, that is fine and that is what I will ask her to do because she is damaging our cause. The whole system is damaging our cause'. Senator Jenkins comes in here tonight and says, `But I did not say that any senators in here had supposedly been contacted and not responded'. She went on to read from Hansard. She stated:
Mrs Pearce reiterated to me today-
that, is Senator Jenkins-
that she and other members of the society had previously approached Labor and Liberal members of parliament in Western Australia but these members were not willing to give them support.
I will let Senator Jenkins into a little secret.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not too loud now.

—Not too loud, no. Western Australian senators happen to be members of parliament. Is it not a shame that she has not yet realised that? Maybe it explains why she carries on in the way in which she does. The whole thing is outrageous.
—It is like telling fairy tales to kids.

—That is quite right. That is a very good summary of the whole thing-it is like telling fairy tales to kids, it really is. I have to confess that if Senator Jenkins's office would stop meddling in this and stop passing on little untruths to the Society, this would have died a long time ago. Unfortunately, we simply cannot get Senator Jenkins to control her staff sufficiently to stop this going on and unfortunately we in the Senate cannot even get her to come in here and tell the story as it is.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight she made the allegation-another allegation, where is it going to end?-that I had said that the Canadian delegation that had visited Perth had acted with uncouth behaviour. In the first instance, I did not name the Canadian delegation; in the second instance, when I spoke to her husband-cum-staff member-and he cannot deny that again because he has put it in a letter--

TALK.START.PARA: —He travels on the RAAF plane.
—That is right, he travels on the Royal Australian Air Force plane.
—As her husband.

—As her husband, but not as a staff member when he is being paid a salary and all the rest of it. He then pulls strings to beat people who are not only senior to Senator Jenkins, but who are officer holders in the Parliament whereas Senator Jenkins is not-and the list goes on. Her husband dodges the system. She went on to say that I had said this about the Canadian delegation. The Canadian delegation is not mentioned in my speech. When I took the point of order during Senator Jenkins's speech tonight and I said, `Where is the uncouth behaviour that I had allegedly referred to', she read what I had said in Hansard which in no way reflected on the Canadian delegation, that it had acted in an uncouth manner. I have to say that the Canadian delegation comprised very pleasant, intelligent, capable, competent people. I just wish I could say the same about Senator Jenkins. She summed it up by saying that I had alleged that they were gossiping. They were not gossiping. We simply were having a conversation in a very cool, calm and rational manner which, unfortunately, Senator Jenkins would not know about. The allegations just go on and on.

SPEECH.PARA: The members of the Canadian delegation-now that she has mentioned them-were just amazed. They were not being nasty, horrible or uncouth; they were just amazed that a member of the Federal Parliament did not seem to know too much. Her husband knew a bit more, but then again, who is the senator? Senator Jenkins still will not come clean. She will still not name the senators to whom she referred, alleging that other Western Australian senators had child labour on their properties. She still will not come clean. She is very brave to come in here and make the allegations, but when it comes to backing up her statements it is a different story. That is very sad, but it is what we have come to expect from Senator Jenkins.

As I said, I find it even sadder to think that she has dragged, from what I can gather from a telephone conversation, a very nice lady, Mrs Pearce, through all of this. It is a disgrace. Mrs Pearce is trying to do what I consider to be a very important job. I encourage Mrs Pearce to keep on going, to keep at it, even though Senator Jenkins has caused all of this trouble for her Society. It is very sad that a very nice lady, who is trying to do the best for people who have suffered, has had to go through all of this.

From the Senate's point of view, we have a senator here from Western Australia who, as I said before, with any degree of luck will not be here much longer. The honourable senator admitted a few weeks ago in one of her many articles that she gets into the papers, courtesy of a staff member who travels on a Royal Australian Air Force plane, that she should not have been elected in the first place. So with any degree of luck, within a short space of time-from what I gather, it might even be by 2 December-we will not have to put up with any of this rot any more and the Senate will be much better for it. I hope that this is the end of the story. It is sad that Senator Jenkins has made the allegations and that she will not back them up. But que sera, sera. I hope that before Senator Jenkins makes any other foolish, wild, scurrilous comments, she will think twice. I hope that her staff will think twice before providing her with information and before phoning around the country to provide inaccurate information because we will not stand for it. I will have great delight in repeating her antics around the electorate because it will show her in a very poor light. It will show that she is prepared to come in here, rant and rave and fiddle around the fringes in a true wimpish fashion but that, when challenged, she has not got the courage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for taking the time of the Senate at this late stage of the evening. I was unfortunate in drawing the short straw of being the last speaker. This is the first time that I have ever seen in either House of Parliament not one member of the Government in attendance-neither the Whip nor, more importantly, a duty Minister. I think that says something pretty considerable about the attention that particularly the ministry, if not my friend the Whip, are giving to this debate. I am not casting aspersions on Senator McKiernan or Senator Foreman who are just entering the chamber. Rather, the Government has been discourteous to the Senate by not having a Minister in attendance.
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. If the honourable senator wants to press the matter, we can attempt to bring the honourable senators in.
—There is no point of order.

—I do not want to do that. It is normal practice that there be a duty Minister. But I did not rise to speak about that. On 29 August I asked Senator Tate, in his capacity as Minister for Justice and as Minister representing the Attorney-General, whether he was aware of a recent series of articles and reports in the Australian newspaper concerning the activities of the Yugoslav secret police, the UDBA. In particular, I refer to an article of 29 July this year alleging that the UDBA `has formed close ties with a Federal member of Parliament'. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a source in the Yugoslav Department of Foreign Affairs in Belgrade . . . said information that may have originated from the MP, a Labor Party backbencher, has shown up in the dossiers of Croatian exiles in Australia, held at UDBA headquarters in the Yugoslav capital.
I asked Senator Tate:

Has the Australian Government investigated these allegations, particularly the allegation that the UDBA is operating in Australia? If not, why not? Will it now establish an official inquiry into the allegations? If the Government finds that there are UDBA or other agents provocateurs operating here, is it the Government's policy to expel them? Finally can the Minister assure the Senate that there is no known connection between any Australian Labor Party member of Federal Parliament and the Yugoslav secret police?
Senator Tate took that question on notice. Three days later, on Friday, 1 September, he responded:
I am aware of the articles and the various allegations made in them. I follow the practice of successive Commonwealth governments in not commenting on matters concerning national security.

In a statement I released later that day following receipt of that answer I said that in my view it was simply not permissible for the Government to be allowed this time to fall back on the excuse of national security. I pointed out that what is involved is, firstly, allegations that a foreign government-in this case Yugoslavia-is conducting clandestine secret police operations of a terrorist nature in Australia; secondly, that certain Australian citizens are the victims of these clandestine operations; and, thirdly, that a Labor member of Federal Parliament is alleged to be aiding and abetting these clandestine operations against Australian citizens.

I said in that statement that the Australian electorate has a basic right to information about these allegations and that, at the very least, the electorate has a basic right to know whether one of its own elected representatives is deliberately engaged in activities designed to damage Australian citizens. I also pointed out that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who was at that time in Belgrade, the Yugoslav capital, should be instructed to pursue these allegations with the Soviet Government while he was there. However, I understand that he did not raise the matter with the Yugoslav authorities nor were these matters raised with him.

I also understand that Senator Evans decided to go to Belgrade at very short notice. I wonder why that was the case. To my knowledge, Senator Evans has not reported to the Parliament on the reason for that visit to Belgrade at short notice, although he attended a conference of non-aligned countries. However, I understand that the suddenness of his decision to go threw the Yugoslav officialdom into something of a flap. It has not been explained why he decided to visit Belgrade at such short notice. It appears from press reports since his return that he may well have gone to negotiate the reopening of the Yugoslav Consulate in Sydney. I refer to a report in the Australian of 6 September by the foreign affairs correspondent, Roy Eccleston, which states:
Yugoslavia may be allowed to reopen its Sydney consulate-general later this year-about 12 months after the Federal Government ordered it shut after a shooting incident.

We well remember that shooting incident last year. It led to significant problems and a rupturing of relationships between Australia and Yugoslavia. The consulate was closed and its staff were expelled after the Yugoslav Government refused to hand over an official who had allegedly fired shots that seriously wounded a teenage boy, Josef Tokic, during a demonstration last November. The Opposition has said that it will oppose any reopening of the consulate until answers have been received to the allegations that have been made about the use of Yugoslav consulates as a cover for Yugoslavia's security service. Senator Evans is reported in the same article as having spoken in `glowing terms' about relations between the two countries whilst he was in Yugoslavia. He said:
relations . . . were already very much back on a sound footing with good economic and political co-operation.

I do not know where Senator Evans got that view but, in the light of recent allegations, I suggest that is a very false approach to have adopted. Why would he do this? Why would he allow the reopening of the consulate under these circumstances? In particular, why would he be prepared to have the Sydney consulate reopened at a time when it is reported also that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) is to reopen its files on Australians suspected of having links with Yugoslav secret service agents? It was reported in the Australian on 19 August that ASIO is to reopen its files and that an ASIO source had told the newspaper that an inquiry would soon be launched into the activities of a number of senior Australian public servants who were known to have had regular contact with identified agents of the Yugoslav secret security organisation-the UDBA-which, as I understand it, is now the Yugoslav Intelligence Service, the YIS.

Following my question in the Senate last week, to which I have already referred, my colleague Mr Aldred in the House of Representatives on Tuesday this week also raised the activities of the Yugoslav Intelligence Service in Australia. Amongst other things, Mr Aldred discussed the allegations in these reports that there are dossiers in Belgrade, the information in which has originated in Australia from the Yugoslav Intelligence Service. Mr Aldred said in his remarks in the House on Wednesday:

I am led to believe that several of these dossiers substantially originated from the Yugoslav Welfare Association based at Fitzroy in Melbourne. The Association ostensibly is a non-government community organisation catering for the welfare of Yugoslavs in Australia.
He went on:

Just exactly how these files containing details on Australian residents found their way from Fitzroy to Belgrade is a mystery but it is a mystery that needs to be investigated as a matter of some urgency. Quite obviously, somebody or bodies facilitated their transfer to the Yugoslavs.

It is worth noting, as I am advised, that the current Chairman of the Yugoslav Welfare Association and one of its co-founders is the Labor Federal member for Hotham, Mr Lewis Kent. Of course, Mr Kent has now been shoved aside as the member for Hotham for the next election to make way for Simon Crean. Instead, he will be contesting the new seat of Corinella for Labor. It is also worth noting that the Yugoslav Welfare Association has received substantial grants-in-aid funding from the Federal Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The evidence available to me indicates that that funding now exceeds $100,000. In the House of Representatives yesterday my colleague the honourable member for Mitchell, Mr Cadman, moved:
That this House expresses its concern that the Australian Government has not been unequivocal in denouncing attempts by the Yugoslav Government to manipulate Australian community groups.

Mr Cadman, a single speaker, spoke to that motion, as only one person is allowed to speak under the rules of the House of Representatives. The single speaker for the Government responding to the motion was the honourable member for Hotham, Mr Kent, the Chairman of the Yugoslav Welfare Association. Perhaps that is not surprising, as Mr Kent was born in Yugoslavia. As I understand it, he has been in Australia since the early 1950s. After his arrival he changed his name from his Yugoslav name, Lajco Kapolnai, to Lewis Kent. Nevertheless, I would have thought that the content of Mr Cadman's motion was of sufficient importance to require a member of the Government with more status and standing than Mr Kent to respond. It was an important, serious motion. I would have thought that it was the sort of motion that a Minister, probably a senior Minister, would normally respond to.

In the course of his speech, Mr Kent said in response to the allegations that dossiers on Australian citizens now with the Yugoslav Ministry of Foreign Affairs had originated in the Yugoslav Welfare Association in Fitzroy that the only information on individuals held by the Association was the name of the individual and the details of his or her welfare situation or problem. He said that this information was innocuous and that, even if it did get to Moscow, Belgrade or anywhere else, `it would be of no consequence'. Mr Kent also invited a Liberal member or senator to inspect the files of the Association.

Significantly, Mr Kent did not deny that information on personal files held by the Yugoslav Welfare Association may have found its way to Belgrade via the operations of the Yugoslav Intelligence Service in Australia or through any other route. That lack of denial is extraordinary in itself, particularly as Mr Kent is the Chairman of the Association. But equally extraordinary is his willingness to expose what I would regard as highly personal information on individuals, in effect, to public examination by members of parliament. I wonder what those persons who have placed their confidence and trust in the Yugoslav Welfare Association would think about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. The honourable member is reflecting overmuch on a member of parliament. I read the statement that the honourable member for Hotham made in the House of Representatives. He said that he would allow persons in, providing that no personal details were allowed to be distributed. Senator Short is going overboard.
—Order! I have just come into the chamber, so I missed what was said between the time I left my room and the time I took the chair. I will listen carefully from here on.

—What I said was that I found it extraordinary that Mr Kent in the House of Representatives yesterday invited a Liberal member or senator to inspect the files of the Yugoslav Welfare Association, as I understand it, to satisfy themselves that the contents were innocuous. I do not think it is possible for that invitation to have been extended without that information being available, as Senator McKiernan implied. So, with respect, I do not think I am going overboard on what Mr Kent said. I am giving a factual statement of what he said and what the obvious implication of that must be.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again: I wonder what those persons who have placed their confidence and trust in the Yugoslav Welfare Association would think about knowing that perhaps I or some other member of parliament had been invited to look at the files which contained their details. In any association, particularly of a welfare nature, the material in those files would be essentially of a personal nature. I was, therefore, amazed also at Mr Kent's assertion that the personal information on the files held by the Association is innocuous. On the contrary, such information must contain a great deal of information on highly personal matters concerning individuals or at least be of a nature that would lead to the obtaining of such personal data from other sources.

The allegations that have been made in the press and from other sources about the activities of the Yugoslav secret police in Australia and about the links between the secret police and a Labor member of the Federal Parliament are of the utmost gravity. On the weekend of 29 July the press actually named Mr Ivan Dronjic, the second ranking official in the Yugoslav consulate in Melbourne, as the particular parliamentarian's case minder and said that Mr Dronjic was one of the top ranking Yugoslav intelligence service agents now operating in Australia. A few weeks earlier, the Australian said this:

One of Europe's top terrorists, Yugoslav hit man Vinko Sindicic, now imprisoned in Scotland for attempted murder, has been revealed as the mastermind behind the biggest terrorist case in Australia's history-the alleged plot by Croatian exiles to launch a bombing campaign in Sydney 10 years ago.

They were convicted, and have been subsequently released. So these matters are very serious. They affect our national security. They affect the institution of Parliament. They go to the very core of our nationhood and our democratic freedoms. As I said in my statement last week and as my colleagues in the House of Representatives have repeated this week, I believe it is essential that there be a full inquiry into these allegations. I think that inquiry should be public. It could be a royal commission or a parliamentary inquiry. I am not advocating one particular form of inquiry over another. But what I am demanding on behalf of all our constituents is that there be a full inquiry into these very serious allegations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Long-winded conspiracy theories at 1 o'clock in the morning are not everyone's cup of tea, even in an institution as notoriously tolerant of ratbaggery and fanaticism as this one is. Nonetheless, I do not want to enter into the debate on the alleged activities of the Yugoslav intelligence agency in Australia or the question of the Australian response to any such alleged activities. I am not in a position to do so, nor is any other member of the Government; nor is any member of the Government likely to be in a position to do so, for the simple reason that, in accordance with the practice of successive governments in this country, none of us comment on operational matters affecting security and intelligence agencies. That is the reason why Senator Short's view of the world has not attracted a more substantial response from the Government than it has, and that is why it will not attract a more substantial response in the future. It is simply not a matter that is appropriate for public response by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I do make the point that the Australian Government does require all missions accredited to Australia to act in accordance with internationally agreed principles governing the conduct of diplomatic and consular staff, and Senator Short can be assured that those principles are very much present to our mind and very much govern the kind of response we make as a government to matters for which there is some element of substantiation. Beyond that, I can comment no further.

What brought me into the chamber at this ungodly hour was the fortuitous occurrence of my switching on the sound on a hitherto mercifully silent television screen to hear Senator Short making some gratuitous observations about my recent visit to Belgrade and some gratuitous assumptions about what I was doing there. Let me briefly set the record straight. The reason I was in Belgrade was to attend a meeting of the non-aligned summit, the preparatory meeting of the Foreign Ministers. It was not a visit I had originally planned to make, because Parliament was sitting and it was outside the program of overseas visits that I had originally contemplated. But when the timing of the second Paris ministerial meeting on Cambodia was established and it became apparent that one of the things governing the timing of that Paris meeting was its conjunction with the Belgrade meeting, to which many of the Paris Ministers were planning to go, I took advantage of the opportunity of being in Europe to pay a two-day visit to a conference which is probably second only to the United Nations General Assembly itself as a meeting ground and an important multilateral gathering. In particular, it is one to which Australia is invited, and has been for years, to attend as an observer and an occasion which offers a tremendous opportunity for a broad-ranging set of ministerial contacts.

In fact, in the course of my only two full days that I was present in Belgrade, I had 18 substantial bilateral meetings-11 with Commonwealth Foreign Ministers; four with either Foreign Ministers or senior officials from Saudi Arabia to talk about the live sheep issue; one with Mexico to talk about regional economic cooperation and a variety of related matters; one with Brazil to talk about the Antarctic initiative and some other related matters; and one with Mozambique to talk about southern Africa. In addition to those meetings, I had three meetings with Yugoslav Government Ministers. I would appreciate it if Senator Short would give me the courtesy of listening to the terms of this response, but he is incapable apparently of doing even that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise.

—It would be a great help if Senator Short listened and focused instead of going away and developing another set of conspiracy theories based on pig ignorance about what the real facts of the situation are. In addition to the 11 Foreign Ministers, I repeat, that I met, and in addition to the four other Ministers or senior officials from four other non-Commonwealth countries, I did pay three bilateral calls on the host country, Yugoslavia-Foreign Minister Loncar, who happened to be the chairman of the conference I was attending; the Prime Minister; and the Macedonian member of the Federal State Presidency, Dr Vasili Turpukovski. They were three courtesy calls that are part and parcel of the normal courtesy obligations of any Minister visiting another country, as I was.
—And did you raise the reopening of the consulate?

—I did not raise the opening of the consulate. The reopening of the consulate was raised with me, and I am about to tell Senator Short, if he will listen, what exactly transpired. The situation is that when the matter was raised with me-and it was put to me in forceful terms, in particular by Foreign Minister Loncar, that it was time for that consulate in Sydney to be reopened-I indicated to him, in the only conversation in which the issue arose substantively, although it was mentioned in passing in the other two, that the question of the reopening of the Sydney Consulate-General would not be considered by the Australian Government until at least towards the very end of this year. As with all decisions of this kind, the decision to close the Consulate-General will, of course, be reviewed in due course. No decision has been made to reopen the Consulate-General at this stage. Nothing I said to any of the Yugoslav Ministers to whom I spoke would give rise to any belief on their part that such a decision had been made. Nothing I said would give rise to any belief on their part other than that we would possibly be reconsidering the matter towards the end of this year. It should not be assumed that any such decision will be made at the end of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The general point I made to my interlocutors-I do not have the transcript with me-was that feelings in Australia had been very strong on that issue. We regarded what happened as intolerable. That strength of feeling was shared by the Government. We reacted accordingly at the time. We had wanted to take criminal proceedings against the consular officer concerned but that was made impossible by the particular reliance on the consular privileges that was used by the Yugoslav authorities at the time, in circumstances we all know and which I do not need to rehearse. I made the point that a very significant cooling-off period, as it were, or response period, would be necessary before any such reopening should be contemplated.

That is all I need to say to put the matter squarely on the record. In other respects, the bilateral relationship between our two countries is, as it always has been, in reasonably good shape. That was an essentially isolated incident. It was an unhappy and unfortunate incident with potentially tragic consequences. Mercifully, they were less than tragic so far as the injury to young Josef Tokic was concerned. Nonetheless, what happened was totally indefensible and the Government has made that clear on innumerable occasions. It is a decision that we will review in due course but the time for review of the decision has not yet come. That was made perfectly clear to the Yugoslav authorities in the course of a visit that was not a bilateral visit and not a visit made for the purpose of discussing or negotiating, as Senator Short intimated, anything to do with this particular question but a visit to attend a very important multilateral meeting. It was a meeting at which I took the opportunity to make a very large number of very important calls.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to my question without notice of 9 June 1989 concerning a former member of the Minister for Defence's staff, Mr Syd Hickman, and the answer given by Senator Button on 9 June 1989, and given Australian Public Service procedures requiring Commonwealth officers in sensitive positions to seek approval before taking up outside employment, did the Minister for Defence approve this move?
(2) When did Mr Hickman inform the Minister for Defence that he was to establish Arvin Consultancy P/L?
(3) When Arvin Consultancy P/L was registered as a lobbyist for the Transfield Group, was Mr Hickman's previous sensitive position taken into account?
(4) Does Arvin Consultancy now have contact or dealings with the Minister for Defence's office, or any other Minister's office; if so, what is the nature and scope of this contact?
(5) In what other areas of defence-related work, apart from the Anzac frigate project, is this consultancy involved?
(6) Was Mr Hickman formally advised of his obligations under Commonwealth law to avoid breaches of confidence and conflicts of interest; if so, by whom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Public Service procedures require some Commonwealth officers, whose work involves access to commercially sensitive information, to seek assent before taking up outside employment. These procedures do not have application to Ministerial staff.
(2) Mr Hickman informed the Minister of his decision to take up outside employment on 28 September 1988.
(3) I understand that an individual's previous employment is not relevant to the acceptance of their registration as a lobbyist in the General Register.

(4) Arvin Consultancy has had contact with the Defence Minister's Office, and other Minister's offices, on several occasions since it was established. Arvin Consultancy has no preferential access to the Minister's Office.
(5) This information, which is included in the registers of lobbyists, is provided by the lobbyist on a confidential basis.
(6) I am advised that Mr Hickman received a standard debriefing from officers of the Department concerning his obligation to protect Commonwealth information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 9 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: In the event of passage of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989, and specifically, in the event of passage of clause 226 in the form now before the Senate, can the Prime Minister say:
(a) which Minister does he intend should be the `Minister administering this section'-that is, proposed section 64B of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976; and
(b) which Minister does he intend should be `the Minister' for purposes of sections of the Act, other than proposed section 64B.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) The expression `Minister administering this section, has been used in subsections 64B (2), (3) and (4) to distinguish that Minister from the Minister for Finance who is mentioned in subsection 64B (1). The intention is that `the Minister administering this section' will be `the Minister' referred to throughout the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The current Administrative Arrangements Order identifies that Minister as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories: Recycled Paper

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 8 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the total amount of paper used annually by the Minister's Department and what is the value of this paper?
(2) What steps has the Minister taken to institute the use of recycled paper by the Department in his portfolio?
(3) If no such steps have been taken, why not?
(4) When does the Minister anticipate that this will occur?
(5) What steps has the Minister taken, or will the Minister take, to co-ordinate the use, collection and processing of recycled paper in his Department with other Departments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1989-90 my Department expects to use a total of 15,000 reams of paper at a cost of $68,000. This includes the cost of recycled paper which I have introduced into my office for media releases and general correspondence. The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories is adopting a similar program.
My Department's preliminary evaluation found that the increased use of recycled paper has no adverse effects upon office equipment.
My Department is investigating additional uses for recycled paper, and is increasing its use for general administrative purposes. In addition, my Department has implemented a paper management scheme.

(2) to (5) As was announced by the Prime Minister in his Statement on the Environment on 20 July 1989, the Minister for Administrative Services and I are investigating the use of recycled and unbleached paper in Commonwealth Government offices.
The Minister for Administrative Services has established an inquiry into the use of recycled paper with the following terms of reference:
In relation to Administrative Services' service-wide activities
1. List all contracts involving the use of paper products and document their paper content, scope of usage and approximate annual value. Contracts will include:
(a) those covering writing, copying and printing paper; and
(b) those covering all paper products other than writing, copying and printing paper.
2. For each category of paper use, identify the minimum performance specification to be met by the paper product.
3. Define what recycled paper is, its qualities, characteristics, and costs.

4. Following consultation with relevant agencies, assess the extent to which the above contracts can and should (or cannot and should not) be sourced from recycled (and/or less highly bleached) paper.

5. Recommend an implementation strategy covering the appropriate use of recycled paper by Commonwealth Government Agencies, including, as necessary, a strategy for gaining Government approval for relevant recommendations which extend beyond the authority of the Minister for Administrative Services.
6. Prepare a comprehensive report on the above matters for consideration by the Minister for Administrative Services not later than 30 September 1989.
In relation to Administrative Services' internal activities
1. Review existing recycling policies and practices and assess the scope for improvements.

2. Report to the Minister by 30 September 1989 in relation to internal recycling policies and other areas where there is scope within the portfolio (i.e. in addition to contracts) to increase the use of recycled and less highly bleached paper.

The Australia and New Zealand Environment Council has agreed to establish a working group to develop standards for recycled paper for government use and to examine further uses for low grade recycled paper. In addition, all portfolio ministers have been asked by the Prime Minister to report to me on their departments' wastepaper recycling strategies and ways to improve or extend those strategies.

The Prime Minister intends to report early next year on the implementation of the measures announced in his Statement, including the results of the investigations into departments' use of recycled paper and their wastepaper recycling strategies. My Department has implemented a major paper management and recycling program in its central office. This is working well and could be expanded across the public service. I shall continue to promote the expansion of this program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 16 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many drug detector dog teams are presently working within the Australian Customs Service, and at what locations and with which Customs unit.
(2) How many staff are located at the national detector dog training unit in Canberra.
(3) What is the annual ACS appropriation for the unit.
(4) What is the cost of training each dog team.
(5) What is the annual cost of maintaining each dog team.
(6) What is the useful work life span for each dog.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are 30 drug detector dog teams located as follows:
Sydney 6, Melbourne 7, Brisbane 6, Fremantle 6, Port Adelaide 2, Hobart 2 and Darwin 1.
The current training program is planned to raise the number in Sydney to 12 and in Melbourne to 8 by the end of 1989.
All dog teams are part of the Barrier Control Sub-Program.
(2) 12 officers are located at the training centre in Canberra; a manager, 4 instructors, 1 control officer, 2 support staff, and 4 kennel staff.
(3) During 1988/89 expenditure on the training centre was $500,000 and on Regional dog teams $1,692,000. Both figures include salaries.
(4) It costs approximately $30,000 to train a dog and handler.
(5) On average the annual cost to maintain a dog team is approximately $56,000.
(6) The average working life of a dog is 6-7 years.
